column2: The closing of Morrone & Sons, a bakery that had built an almost religious following, erased one of the last signs of Harlem’s Italian-American past.
Baghdad’s authority to bar Blackwater USA, a security company that was involved in the deaths of eight Iraqis, appeared to be in question.
Michael B. Mukasey is not a movement conservative, but he is likely to back the White House on security.
Mariano Rivera, it turned out, was involved in a bit of drama even before he took the mound during the Yankees’ 4-3 victory against the Boston Red Sox on Sunday night.
A boardwalk pavilion in Ocean Grove, N.J.,  has lost its tax-exempt status as the Methodist organization that owns it battles with state officials over gay civil union ceremonies.
BOSTON, Sept. 17 (AP) — Carl Yastrzemski said he did not know he had made history until he read about it in the newspaper the next day.
President Evo Morales of Bolivia knows a thing or two about unrest, having organized protests for years as the leader of the country’s coca cultivators.
Adobe Systems, the world’s largest maker of design software, reported quarterly results and targets ahead of Wall Street expectations on strong sales of its updated suite of products.

Michael Waltrip hired Dr. Eric Warren as technical director, the first of many moves he hopes will strengthen his three-car team. Warren, who has a Ph.D. in aerospace engineering from North Carolina State University, spent the last five years as technical director at Evernham Motorsports. He was replaced midway through this season as the team owner Ray Evernham refocused on building cars to help his slumping team.

The N.B.A. referee Joey Crawford was reinstated by Commissioner David Stern, five months after he was suspended indefinitely for improper on-court conduct. Tim Duncan, the San Antonio Spurs star, said that Crawford challenged him to a fight during a game against the Dallas on April 15. Crawford ejected Duncan while Duncan was laughing on the bench. Stern cited a pattern in suspending Crawford. But Stern met with Crawford and said he was satisfied that Crawford knew what “the N.B.A. expects from him.”.

N.H.L. Commissioner Gary Bettman formally added an outdoor game to the 2007-8 season. The New Year’s Day game between Buffalo and Pittsburgh is expected to break league attendance records by attracting 74,000 fans to Ralph Wilson Stadium, the Buffalo Bills’ home field in suburban Orchard Park. A normal Jan. 1 snowfall in Buffalo is about a tenth of an inch, according to National Weather Service records. Temperatures have varied from 0 degrees in 1970 to 63 in 1985.

Mike Tirico will take over part of Dan Patrick’s sports talk time slot on ESPN Radio.“The Mike Tirico Show” will start Thursday from 1 to 3 p.m. Eastern. Tirico serves as the play-by-play commentator for “Monday Night Football” and the N.B.A. finals on ESPN. He was one of the original hosts when ESPN Radio launched in 1992. Patrick announced in July that he was leaving ESPN after 18 years.

After making the playoffs the past two years and proclaiming themselves Stanley Cup contenders this season, the Rangers have had a rush on ticket sales. The team said all single-game tickets for the 2007-8 season at Madison Square Garden sold out less than an hour after they went on sale Saturday. Team officials said they believed it was the fastest sellout in franchise history. The Rangers may release some tickets, usually single ones, on game days to be purchased at the box office. All 41 home games sold out last season. The season opens October 4 with a home game against Florida. The first home exhibition game is Friday against the Devils.
The largest American project in Afghanistan is the repair and upgrade of the Kajaki Dam, which lies in the most problematic of all of Afghanistan’s provinces.
A police officer who molested women while on duty in uniform was convicted of sexual abuse and official misconduct in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn.
The police in Gary, Ind., came under fire after two teenagers who died in a car crash were not found until hours later, in a nearby ravine, by the father of one victim.

Investors assume that the central bank will reduce the overnight federal funds rate by at least a quarter of a percentage point, to 5 percent.

But many market analysts say that will not be enough to restore confidence.
Gete Wami of Ethiopia is running the Berlin Marathon on Sept. 30, then the New York City Marathon five weeks later. Such a turnaround is mostly unheard of in distance running.
Three senators who are considered potential swing votes on war policy said that a weekend visit to Iraq left them discouraged about prospects for political reconciliation.
The company said that its new product would establish a cellphone advertising network in which Google would match ads with the content of mobile Web pages.
The voluntary agreement will cut emissions for the university’s proposed science center 50 percent below the levels required by the national standard, according to a Massachusetts official.

Rescuers searched the waters off Staten Island yesterday for one of two Bangladeshi men believed to have jumped from a cargo ship at 5:55 a.m. as it left the Port of Newark for Virginia, the authorities said. One man was captured after he waved to a fisherman from Hoffman Island, just southwest of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, officials said. The captured man, Mohammad Nayem Uddin, 27, did not cooperate when detectives questioned him in his native language, the police said. The missing man was identified as Mohammad Bakhtier Uddin, 21. Both men were crew members of the 797-foot freighter Manhattan Bridge, whose home port is in Panama, the Coast Guard said. Their passports were found on the ship.

A section of 53rd Street in Midtown was named for the actor Jerry Orbach yesterday, six months after his widow started a campaign for the honor. The Transportation Department unveiled the street sign at the intersection of 53rd Street and Eighth Avenue, where Mr. Orbach lived in an apartment for more than 20 years. Mr. Orbach, above, best known for playing Detective Lennie Briscoe on television’s “Law & Order,” died in December 2004 at age 69.

The police were searching last night for a man who peppered the outside of an elementary school in southern New Jersey with gunshots, The Philadelphia Inquirer reported yesterday. The school, Garfield East Elementary, was locked down for two hours after the shooting. There were no injuries, the police told The Inquirer. Compiled by John Sullivan.

Senate Republicans said yesterday that they were planning to appoint a special counsel to further investigate the Democratic administration of Gov. Eliot Spitzer. In July, Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo issued a report finding that the governor’s staff had misused the state police in an effort to discredit the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno. The Senate Investigations and Government Operations Committee has been holding hearings into the matter since then. “We need professional advice,” said Senator George H. Winner Jr., an upstate Republican who is chairman of the committee. A selection would probably be made “in the next few days,” he said. The move to appoint a counsel was reported yesterday by The New York Post. The matter is also being investigated by the State Ethics Commission and the Albany County district attorney, P. David Soares.

Three people were killed in two collisions involving New Jersey Transit trains between midnight and 7 a.m. yesterday, causing delays of up to an hour during morning commuting, transit officials said. In the first crash, two South Carolina men — Arthur Connelly, 51, and his passenger, his brother Bill Connelly, 48 — were killed. Officials said Arthur Connelly had driven around the closed gates of a train crossing in Rutherford around midnight, when his car was struck by a southbound train. In the second collision, a man who was not identified was killed when he stepped directly into the path of a North Jersey coastline train at 7:04 a.m. in Red Bank. In both cases, the train operators told transit officials that they had blown their horns and slammed their emergency brakes but could not slow down quickly enough to avoid the collisions, said Dan Stessel, a New Jersey Transit spokesman.

The developer of a $168 million water park planned for Randalls Island has failed to meet the city’s deadline for arranging financing, Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr. said yesterday. In a letter to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, he said that the developer, Randalls Island Aquatic Leisure L.L.C., had not started construction even though work was supposed to have started seven months ago. The company could not be reached for comment last night. Warner Johnston, a spokesman for the Department of Parks and Recreation, said that the city had extended the financing deadline to tomorrow. “In the event that the concessionaire is unable to fulfill its financial commitments under the agreement, the city will take appropriate steps to ensure that development of this major community improvement continues,” Mr. Johnston said in a statement.

The president of a state employees’ union and a former companion of Gov. Jon S. Corzine’s had no right to discuss contract negotiations with the governor, the union’s national officials said yesterday. The union, the Communications Workers of America, said it filed court papers yesterday saying that the state president, Carla Katz, was not authorized to speak about the contract and that only the national union could conduct the negotiations. The papers will be filed as part of a lawsuit by state Republican officials seeking disclosure of e-mail messages between Ms. Katz and Mr. Corzine, a Democrat; Ms. Katz has said that they should remain confidential because they involved contract talks. The union said yesterday that it was taking no position on whether the messages should be released, but wanted to clarify its procedures. Ms. Katz could not be reached for comment.

The Civilian Complaint Review Board, the agency responsible for monitoring police conduct, named Joan Thompson, an executive with experience in equal-opportunity employment, its executive director yesterday. Ms. Thompson, currently director of equal opportunity for the Department of Education, succeeds Florence L. Finkle, who resigned in May to head a medical fraud unit in the office of Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo. The board has come under harsh criticism from the New York Civil Liberties Union, which charged in a Sept. 5 report that it had bowed to pressure from the police and failed to aggressively pursue cases of misconduct. Ms. Thompson, who previously held senior positions with the police departments in New York and Baltimore, said that the recent criticism provided “something for me to work on.”.

New Jersey will ask New York for 600 decommissioned subway cars to be sunk off the coast to create artificial reefs to attract fish, lobsters and other marine life, New Jersey environmental officials said yesterday. New Jersey, which has the East Coast’s largest artificial reef complex, stopped accepting subway cars in 2003 after environmentalists raised concerns that the cars might leach high levels of asbestos as they disintegrated. But New Jersey’s environmental protection commissioner, Lisa P. Jackson, wrote in a staff memo yesterday that studies conducted by federal agencies and by other states that have sunk subway cars satisfied her that asbestos did not pose a serious threat. Cindy Zipf, the executive director of Clean Ocean Action, a critic of the subway plan, said yesterday that she hoped New Jersey officials would ask for the subway cars with the least amount of asbestos.

A wrongful death case involving a passenger on the United Airlines plane that crashed into a field in Pennsylvania on Sept. 11, 2001, has been settled, lawyers for the passenger’s widow said yesterday. The case was scheduled to go to trial in Federal District Court next Monday, and it would have been the first death or injury case stemming from the terrorist attacks to go to trial. The suit on behalf of the passenger, Patrick Driscoll, was brought by his widow, Adelaide, against the airline; Argenbright Security, an airport security company; and others. Mr. Driscoll, 70, was a retired research director at Bell Communications. The amount of the settlement was not released.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 17 (AP) — David Wells knows his baseball career is almost over. In fact, Wells said he thought he was finished last month when the San Diego Padres let him go.
The Supreme Court started hearing a set of petitions against the plans of Pakistan’s president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, to be re-elected while still in military uniform.
Being able to test for human growth hormone in urine is preferred by professional baseball and football leagues but detecting the hormone in urine is a difficult task.
France’s foreign minister, Bernard Kouchner, sought to tone down remarks he made the day before that the world had to prepare for possible war against Iran.
A military hearing will convene at Fort Bragg on Tuesday in a rare public examination of the rules that govern the actions of Special Operations troops in Afghanistan.
The Bloomberg administration’s decision to hire a criminal defense lawyer to defend city agencies involved in a deadly fire is unusual, though not unprecedented.
The social network site says it can tailor ads to the personal information that its users leave on their pages.
A season-ticket holder testified that he heard Isiah Thomas speak of Anucha Browne Sanders in terms she said were quite familiar to her and that made her increasingly uncomfortable.
Paetec Holding said it would buy the privately held McLeodUSA, which manages high-capacity fiber networks, for $492 million in stock.
Liberia’s Truth and Reconciliation Commission will collect testimony on Staten Island, home to many civil war survivors.
The company plans to announce the creation of I.B.M. Lotus Symphony, free programs for word processing, spreadsheets and presentations.
An attack by Israeli warplanes inside Syria struck what Israeli intelligence believes was a nuclear-related facility that North Korea was helping to equip, officials said.
The issues that plagued the Giants’ defense late in 2006 haunt this year’s version: a high completion percentage for quarterbacks, few sacks, and difficulty making a stop on third down.

Frank Thomas hit three home runs last night to lead the host Toronto Blue Jays past the Boston Red Sox, 6-1, raising his total to 512 and tying Ernie Banks and Eddie Mathews for 18th on the career list.
Mr. Swearingen was the most powerful oil executive of his generation and a highly visible defender of the industry during the energy crisis of the 1970s.
A melodramatic turn in the trial of four men accused of killing a gay man because of his sexual orientation temporarily obscured the darker nature of the case.
Receiver Justin McCareins let two touchdown passes slip out of his hands in the penultimate minute of the Jets’ game against the Ravens on Sunday.
Negotiations between General Motors and the United Automobile Workers resumed today, and union leaders told members they faced tough decisions.
A federal judge ruled that the courts do not have the authority or the expertise to decide injury lawsuits concerning global warming.
The Senate needs to make sure that Michael Mukasey, President Bush’s nominee to be attorney general, is willing to take the tough steps necessary to repair a very damaged Justice Department.
AOL will move its headquarters from Dulles, Va., next spring as it tries to retool itself as an advertising company that competes with the likes of Google, Yahoo and Microsoft.

The troubled subprime mortgage lender said that it was giving up its status as a real estate investment trust because it could not afford the $157 million dividend it would have to pay to maintain the status.
James Oliver Rigney Jr. was a prolific author who under the pseudonym Robert Jordan wrote the “Wheel of Time” series, a best-selling multivolume fantasy saga.
Eritrean officials, responding to American accusations that they have abetted terrorists in the volatile Horn of Africa, defended their actions on Monday.
Federal prosecutors reaffirmed their charge that the largest Muslim charity in the United States was an arm of the radical Palestinian group Hamas.
With the American toy industry reeling from recalls of millions of Chinese-made toys, some of Europe’s best-known toy makers find themselves in a fortuitous position.
A coalition of environmental activists and investors is asking the Securities and Exchange Commission to require companies to disclose the risks that climate change may pose to their bottom lines.
Panicky customers of Northern Rock have withdrawn $4 billion since the bank acknowledged Friday that it could no longer raise money because of the credit squeeze.
The deal, for $350 million in cash and stock, is the second sizable acquisition Yahoo has announced this month.
Revenues from the resort-style casinos would help pay for road and bridge repair, and provide property tax relief for homeowners.
Senator Barack Obama chastised Wall Street executives on Monday as failing to protect middle-class interests and called for increased federal oversight of credit rating agencies.
A metal band from Taiwan is timing its New York concerts to advocate for its country’s quest for recognition before the world.
A profanity-filled audio recording, apparently of O. J. Simpson and others during the incident that led to his arrest on charges of armed robbery, has surfaced online.
The Treasury secretary said that turmoil in the world’s financial markets could continue for some time, but he cautioned against hasty introduction of new regulations.
A federal study shows that per capita spending in the lowest-spending state, Utah, was only 59 percent of that in Massachusetts, the highest-spending state.
Nickelodeon is introducing a line of consumer electronics branded with personalities from some of its most popular shows.
The case of Madeleine McCann, who went missing in Portugal earlier this year, finds echoes in the 1982 case of a child who disappeared in the Australian desert.
The smuggling and sale of illicit Chinese cigarettes, long a challenge for law enforcement agencies in New York, appears to be growing.
A plan to open a group home for troubled male teenagers does not sit well with some of those who would become their neighbors.
With the recalls of toys by Mattel and others, the European Union is taking a second look at whether its safety regulations are adequate.
The charges against two former New York Racing Association employees, the retired jockey Braulio Baeza and Mario Sclafani, were dismissed Monday by a Saratoga County judge.

A division of the Dole Food Company issued an international recall of bagged salad after a sample taken from a store in Canada tested positive for E. coli, the company said. There have been no reports of illness, company officials said. The voluntary recall affects all packages of Dole’s Hearts Delight salad mix sold in the United States and Canada with a “best if used by” date of Sept. 19 and a production code of A24924A or A24924B, Dole said. The romaine, green leaf and butter lettuce hearts that went into the blend were grown in California, Colorado and Ohio, and processed at a Dole plant in Springfield, Ohio. The company acted came a day after the Canadian Food Inspection Agency warned consumers not to eat Hearts Delight. The Food and Drug Administration discussed the problem with Dole, a spokesman for the agency said.
José Reyes has experienced a ragged past two months complete with struggles at the plate, base-running blunders and a potential gap in maturity.

NASA has decided to replace leaky hydraulic seals aboard the space shuttle Discovery, which might cause a delay in a launching planned for Oct. 23. The leak was traced to the right main landing gear strut, which cushions the impact when the shuttle lands. Early efforts to correct the problem by cycling the hydraulic system did not work as well as officials had hoped, and so “the decision was, ‘Let’s just go ahead and bite the bullet and change the seals,’ ” said Kyle Herring, a NASA spokesman. NASA has five extra days built into the launching schedule, and officials said the work, which requires removing the wheels and brakes, might be completed without causing a slip of the launching date.

Two convicted murderers escaped from prison by climbing ladders and hoisting themselves over two fences, the authorities said. One was quickly captured, and the other remained at large. The inmates were working on a cleaning crew at the prison in Florence when they attacked a guard and tied him down, according to a release from the Corrections Corporation of America, which operates the prison. Detective Walt Hunter of the Florence police said one of the men, Kollin Folsom, was found in a building about a mile south of Florence. The authorities searched for the other inmate, identified as Roy Townsend.

A voter registration law wrongly barred thousands of Florida residents from taking part in the 2006 election and should be thrown out, the N.A.A.C.P. and others said in a federal lawsuit. The law prevents voters from registering if their driver’s licenses or Social Security information does not match what is on the registration form. Opponents of the law say it, and similar requirements in a number of states, have caused myriad problems. Legitimate voters have been thwarted for having a maiden name on a driver’s license instead of a married name, or because of database input errors that make one digit wrong in a birth date, opponents said. Plaintiffs in the suit filed in United States District Court include the Florida State Conference of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and the Haitian-American Grassroots Coalition.

A former prison nurse pleaded guilty to killing a corrections officer while helping her inmate husband escape and was sentenced to life in prison without parole. The woman, Jennifer Hyatte, 33, appeared in white prison overalls with handcuffs and ankle shackles at the same Roane County courthouse where she was accused of killing Correction Officer Wayne Morgan. Ms. Hyatte shot Officer Morgan and another guard on Aug. 9, 2005, as they escorted her husband, George Hyatte, from a court appearance back to a van waiting to return him to prison. The couple fled the state, but were captured 36 hours later at a motel in Columbus, Ohio. As part of the plea deal to avoid the death penalty, Ms. Hyatte must testify in her husband’s murder trial.

The authorities are significantly scaling back search efforts to find the adventurer Steve Fossett after an intensive two-week effort failed to find his plane, officials said. “It arrives at the point when the mission has to evolve,” said Maj. Cynthia Ryan of the Nevada Wing of the Civil Air Patrol. Major Ryan said her agency, which had more than 20 planes in the air last week, had just two looking for Mr. Fossett yesterday. Chuck Allen, a spokesman for the Nevada Department of Public Safety, said state and federal officials would meet again tomorrow to discuss ending the huge effort, which has included dives into a lake, air patrols and volunteers poring over Internet data for clues to Mr. Fossett’s whereabouts.

Jurors in the Los Angeles murder trial of the music producer Phil Spector completed their sixth day of deliberations without a verdict. Mr. Spector, 67, has been charged with second-degree murder in the shooting death of Lana Clarkson, 40, a struggling actress whom he had met hours before her death. She was found dead in his Alhambra home in February 2003 slumped in a chair in the foyer with a gunshot wound to the mouth. Prosecutors say he killed her when she rejected his overtures; Mr. Spector’s lawyers have argued that forensic evidence suggests the wound was self-inflicted. Jurors, who listened to testimony for five months, asked last week to see the gun recovered from the scene.
These are our choices for today’s judicial contests in Brooklyn.

Stocks fell yesterday as heavy withdrawals from the British bank Northern Rock reignited concern over the cost of credit and sent the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index down for the first time in five days.
Buffalo Bills tight end Kevin Everett is showing some movement in his hands and greater strength in his leg muscles, further positive signs after he sustained a life-threatening spinal cord injury.
The players took their marks for that most somber New York City courtroom ritual on Monday, a murder trial in the slaying of a police officer.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 17 (AP) — The fate of Barry Bonds’s record-breaking home run ball is now in the public’s hands after its buyer announced Monday that he was taking votes on whether to give the ball to the Hall of Fame, brand it with an asterisk or blast it into space.

After being criticized for allowing politics to interfere with academic freedom, the University of California, Irvine, announced it will hire Erwin Chemerinsky to be dean of its new law school after all.

If the death of a 36-year-old woman is eventually tied to an experimental gene therapy treatment for rheumatoid arthritis, it could set back a field that has already had its share of failures and black eyes.
All Venezuelan schools, public and private, must submit to state inspectors enforcing the new educational system and will be closed and nationalized if they refuse.
A new system will help developing nations recover assets stolen and sent abroad by corrupt leaders, assets that amount to an estimated $40 billion a year.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 17 (AP) — Two fired executives of the Penn Traffic Company, a regional grocer, have been charged with fraud, federal regulators said Monday.
The White House is threatening to veto a bill that would extend a program ensuring that terrorism insurance is available and affordable for major projects and buildings.
Oil soared to another record yesterday on worries that global energy supplies could shrink to critical levels during this winter heating season because of strong growth in demand.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,775 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:.
Gov. Jon S. Corzine was in stable condition after undergoing surgery on Monday to remove excess bone growth on the left leg he broke in a car crash in April.
In New England, the Patriots’ videotape scandal has yielded an unlikely outcome: Coach Bill Belichick as victim.
Not yet predicting an economic downturn but seeing continued fallout from the national mortgage crisis, city officials are looking to rein in costs.
Replacing paper tickets with electronic ticketing will save airlines $3 billion annually on the roughly 400 million tickets sold outside of the United States alone.
Representative Jim Ramstad said Monday that he would not seek a 10th term, saying he is “burned out.”
Detroit Lions quarterback Jon Kitna left Sunday’s game in the second quarter with a concussion, returned in the fourth and led the Lions to a 20-17 victory in overtime.
In recent interviews to plug his new memoir, Alan Greenspan has obscured more than he has clarified.
The sharp increases provide more evidence that the troubles in the housing and mortgage markets may prove long-lived.
SHANGHAI, Sept. 17 (AP) — The United States needs only a tie against Nigeria to reach the quarterfinals of the Women’s World Cup.

NEWARK, Sept. 17 (AP) — The home builder Hovnanian Enterprises claimed “huge success” on Monday with its weekend sales blitz, which included six-figure discounts on homes being built or completed in 19 states.
Aldemaro Romero was a Venezuelan pianist and composer whose music was interpreted by artists from Tito Puente to Dean Martin.
It’s time to end the embarrassing servitude of Washington, D.C., which is denied true democratic representation.
Many of the monks who live on the Solovetsky Islands, among the holiest sites in Russian Orthodox Christianity, are alarmed by recent efforts to open the islands to tourists.
Brett Somers was an actress and comedian who amused game show fans with her quips on “Match Game,” one of the most popular quiz shows of the 1970s.
The trouble with factory farms is that they are raising more than pigs. They are raising drug-resistant bugs as well.
A lawsuit filed Monday attempts to recoup tens of millions  spent by government-financed health programs to purchase the painkiller and to treat patients for its side effects.
Percy Rodrigues was an actor who broke ground when he was cast as a neurosurgeon in the series “Peyton Place” in 1968.
Experts said a European antitrust ruling might signal problems for companies like Apple, Intel and Qualcomm.
An airline official said wind shear may have doomed the flight that crashed Sunday on Thailand’s resort island of Phuket.

You know how people’s lives are often referred to as journeys? Well, I’ve always thought that comparison was extremely apt. A well-spent life, like an outstanding trip, is made up of unexpected turns, strange encounters and priority-changing experiences.
Complaints from foreign business and leisure travelers have led the United States government to take steps to improve the treatment of travelers upon arrival.
Shinzo Abe may have stepped down as prime minister of Japan last week, but the country’s antiquated economy remains.
“The Age of Turbulence” is really two books, one of which Alan Greenspan probably preferred writing and one of which he understood his audience would prefer reading.

The home of the jazz great John Coltrane in Dix Hills, N.Y., has been added to the New York State and National Registers of Historic Places. Coltrane, the saxophonist and composer, who was born in 1926 and died in 1967, would have observed his 81st birthday on Sunday.

A lock of hair and wool leggings belonging to Sitting Bull, below, leader of the Hunkpapa Lakota Sioux, are to be returned by the Smithsonian’s National Museum of Natural History to his closest living relatives.
A complete set of Harry Potter novels autographed by their author, J. K. Rowling, and believed to be the only such set in the world, will be auctioned for charity.

Alisher Usmanov, a Russian steel magnate, bought the entire collection of Russian art and objects once owned by the cellist Mstislav Rostropovich and his wife, the soprano Galina Vishnevskaya, Sotheby’s announced yesterday.
The Primetime Emmy Awards broadcast on Sunday attracted its smallest audience in 17 years as NBC’s “Sunday Night Football” proved to be a bigger draw in the ratings.
Cameron Mackintosh, the British producer of a host of Broadway and West End hits, said that China could look forward to Chinese versions of “Les Misérables,” “Mamma Mia!” and other shows.
Russian buys Rostropovich art, De Montebello, with an asterisk, Smithsonian returns Sitting Bull relics and more culture news.
To the Editor:.

PASSPORT BOTTLENECK EASES The processing time for passport service is back to the normal six to eight weeks, according to the State Department, which has issued more than 16 million passports so far this fiscal year (which ends Sept. 30) compared with 12.1 million in the 2006 fiscal year. Processing time for those who pay for expedited service is under three weeks, the department said. Long delays in passport service developed early this year after new regulations went into effect requiring United States citizens to present passports when returning by air from Canada, Mexico, Bermuda and most of the Caribbean.

After more than 50 years as a New York institution of cabaret and jazz for the caviar and pearls set, the Café Carlyle, inside the Carlyle Hotel on the Upper East Side, has undergone its first face-lift.

At a low-key ceremony  on Monday, President Nicolas Sarkozy of France inaugurated La Cité de l’Architecture et du Patrimoine, (the City of Architecture and Heritage) in Paris, which reopened after a $114 million, decade-long makeover.
For its season opening, the Royal Liverpool Philharmonic went to the unusual extreme of building a new hall: a virtual environment in the online world Second Life.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.

Hitler’s globe is missing. Wolfram Pobanz, a 68-year-old retired cartographer, is positive that it’s not the one in the Deutsches Historisches Museum, with the Russian bullet hole through Germany, and he can prove it.
A botanist by training, Phung Tuu Boi is fighting the effects of Agent Orange, an invisible poison that has affected Vietnam for decades.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
The origin of our own genus Homo is one of the most intriguing and intractable mysteries in human evolution.
Twenty years after a treaty was signed to end the use of chemicals that destroy the ozone layer, experts meet to discuss the next steps in preventing ozone threats.

When some performers and award winners blurted out expletives on Sunday night on Fox’s broadcast of the 59th Primetime Emmys,  Fox censors hit the delete button, leaving viewers with confusing seconds of dead air and wondering whether the censorship was of language or of political views.
Researchers studying handedness found data in a group of early 20th-century films of everyday English life.
There are many ways to try to save endangered species, including freezing sperm and eggs for breeding programs. With fish, though, that approach is limited.
Now in its fourth year, the Conflux festival, centered mostly on the intersection of Havemeyer Street and Metropolitan Avenue, offered everything from audio graffiti to surveillance technology.
Readers respond to articles in Science Times with thoughts on climate change.
The uneven distribution of the burdens of the Iraq war among Americans is the worthy subject of “Flags,” a sadly clumsy new play by Jane Martin.
The Parker Quartet, formed in 2002, when its members were students, is intent on reaching new audiences as it builds its career.
Martha Graham, a tiny, raven-haired woman with the passion and fury of several armies, put modern dance on the map. And like any choreographer, she didn’t do it alone.
Buoyant, colorful acting enlivens this moderately contrived but engaging comedy from Marie Jones, the author of “Stones in His Pockets.”
Where do moral rules come from? From reason? From God? Some suggest morality can be found buried deep in evolution.
The enduring theme of William Friedkin’s 1980 film “Cruising” is the reality of evil and its uncomfortable proximity to sex.
At this time of year, the world seems built for birds on the wing.
For some patients, it can be difficult to determine how much treatment is just too much.
At what decibel level does noise start to do irreparable hearing damage?

9 P.M. (ABC) ELVIS: VIVA LAS VEGAS Thirty years after Elvis Presley’s death, ABC News examines how the King, left, reinvented Las Vegas — and vice versa — in this two-hour special. It includes interviews with intimates like Presley’s former wife, Priscilla, who describes how having to sing the same songs night after night left him feeling like “a stallion caged in a tiny stall,” and appearances by contemporary musicians who perform his hits and discuss his influence. They include Miranda Lambert, Joe Perry, Toby Keith, Chris Isaak, Brandi Carlile, 50 Cent, Beyoncé, Daughtry, Celine Dion, Faith Hill, Norah Jones, Paul McCartney, Willie Nelson, the Rock, Patti Scialfa and the Three 6 Mafia. Elizabeth Vargas is host.
Advocates for the use of stun guns by police departments point to evidence that they are generally safe. But a recent demonstration shows otherwise.
Women who have more than two alcoholic drinks a day double their risk of endometrial cancer compared with those who drink less, a new study finds.
When patients with heart disease are brought to a hospital, why not suggest a screening for their family as well?
Of all medical specialties, psychiatrists are the least religious, a survey has found, and the most religious doctors are the least likely to refer their patients to psychiatrists.
Daniela Iacoboni, a genetic counselor, seeks to balance information about risk with caution about passing on serious diseases.
A leading brand in the market for outdoor apparel is listening to the call of the wild by enlisting a menagerie’s worth of beasts to burnish its image.
A “poisonous cocktail” of many drugs can interact in dangerous ways and cause side effects that can be far worse than the diseases they are treating.

BARRON--Abraham Theodore . Entrepreneur, Philanthropist. Ted Barron was the former chairman of the Board of Assured Environments Inc., one of the largest pest management companies in the New York area. The company was built and prospered under his strong leadership. Known also as a leading authority on waste management, Ted headed up a survey team that restructured the public waste system in Nigeria, Africa. Throughout his long career, Ted was successful in many fields of endeavor. A distinguished veteran of World War II, he served four years in the Navy with the Mediterranean fleet. Upon his return to Boston, he established, owned, and operated a family scrap iron waste company. While in Boston he was appointed Director of Physical Fitness for the state of Massachusetts and also served on the President's council at Brandeis University. His business acumen took him to New Orleans where for fourteen years he was associated with the Abroms Corporation, a prominent mergers and acquisitions firm. He then formed his own merger and acquisition company, Barron Associates. Barron Associates continued to be one of his major interests in both New York and Florida until his death on Friday, September 14th. He was 85. Ted was an active supporter and generous contributor to many charities including Covenant House and Beth Israel Medical Center in New York and the Association for Retarded Children in Boston. He was a founder of the Mount Sinai Hospital in Miami and was honored with the Covenant House Humanitarian award in 2002. In addition to his loving wife Jean, he leaves two daughters, Cheryl Levy and Leslie Reicher of Boston and his son, Scott of Seattle, Washington, three grandchildren and six greatgrandchildren. Private services will be held in Miami and Boston.
BAER--Art , Sept. 17, 1925Sept. 17, 2006. Artie darling, Happy Birthday, ''Not a day goes by'' we'll miss you and love you forever. Paul, Ceil, Jill, Ellie, & Missy

A survey released yesterday by The Chronicle of Philanthropy found that Philippe de Montebello, below, the director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, was the highest-paid executive last year at an American nonprofit institution, earning slightly more than $4.7 million. But that number comes with a kind of asterisk because Mr. de Montebello was given a $3 million payment last year on the occasion of his 30-year anniversary as the Met's leader. A one-time pension payment, other benefits and his regular salary brought the figure to $4.7 million, said Harold Holzer, a spokesman for the Met. By contrast, Glenn D. Lowry, director of the Museum of Modern Art, earned $1.3 million last year, said The Chronicle's 15th annual survey, which examined 298 nonprofit institutions. William Brody, president of Johns Hopkins University, had the highest pay among university leaders, with $1.6 million in salary and other benefits.

As the third-quarter fund-raising period draws to a close, the candidates are stepping up their efforts to pull in money, and today Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is inviting people to a Washington lunch to discuss domestic security, for $1,000 a head. SCHAPER--Ethel A. , died suddenly on September 16 at Greenwich Hospital, with her children at her side. Widow of Armin Schaper, the love of her life for 59 years, she was born in 1923 in New York City, the daughter of Charles R. Adelson and Jane Levinson. A graduate of Mount Holyoke College in 1944, Ethel was a highly respected artist, interior decorator, antique dealer and Cordon Bleu chef from Dione Lucas' cooking school. A dedicated volunteer, she served as President of the Board of the Mount Holyoke College Club of Westchester and worked tirelessly for the Sarah Neuman Center and Planned Parenthood. She is survived by a brother, Richard Adelson, of Woodstock, VT, and her children, who adored her, Douglas B. Schaper of Harrison, NY and Elizabeth Schaper of New York City, and her devoted canine companion, Duffy. Visitation will be on September 19 from 7-9pm at the William Graham Funeral Home in Rye, NY; graveside burial on September 20 at 11:00am at Greenwood Union Cemetery in Rye, NY. A memorial service to be held at a later date. SCHAUFFLER--Frederick. A brief report from Bloomberg News in Business Day on Saturday, about Apple Inc.'s $100 credit offer to early iPhone buyers, misstated a restriction on the offer. Customers may use the credit to buy gift cards redeemable on Apple's iTunes music site; iTunes is not excluded from the offer.

Despite their history with Ronald Reagan's presidency, Republican voters are much more likely than their Democratic counterparts to say celebrities should stay out of politics, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll. The poll found that 71 percent of Republican voters said celebrities should not be involved in politics, while just 31 percent of Democratic voters and 43 percent of independent voters agreed. Oprah Winfrey may be backing Senator Barack Obama, Democrat of Illinois, but the poll suggests that such endorsements could have limited pull, since most voters say a celebrity's backing would not matter to their vote. And 78 percent of voters say most people they know would not be influenced by a celebrity's endorsement of a candidate.

INTRO This is the third in MoveOn.org's series of ''betrayal'' ads, which began last week with a print ad that called Gen. David H. Petraeus, commander of American forces in Iraq, ''General Betray Us.'' The second was a 30-second spot that started yesterday on CNN criticizing President Bush for not reducing the number of troops to pre-escalation levels. The ''Betray Us'' ad elicited a ferocious response from Republicans, including Rudolph W. Giuliani, a presidential candidate. TITLE ''Giuliani AWOL''

The New York Times will stop charging for access to parts of its Web site, effective at midnight Tuesday night, reflecting a growing view in the industry that subscription fees cannot outweigh the potential ad revenue from increased traffic on a free site. The move comes two years to the day after The Times began the subscription program, TimesSelect, which has charged $49.95 a year, or $7.95 a month, for online access to its columnists' work and to the newspaper's archives. TimesSelect has been free to print subscribers to The Times, and to some students and educators.

Pain and Morphine To the Editor:

A pair of gilded horns, above -- reproductions of the fifth-century originals stolen 205 years ago and melted down by a debt-ridden watchmaker and goldsmith -- were taken yesterday from a Danish museum, Reuters reported. The police were looking for two cars seen near the Kongernes Jelling Museum in South Jutland, where they were on loan, the Danish National Museum said. The original Golden Horns of Gallehus, covered with soldered figures and carvings of beasts believed to be from Celtic mythology, were unearthed in Jutland in the 17th and 18th centuries. They were stolen in 1802 by Niels Heidenreich, who melted them to make shoe buckles and trinkets. He admitted the crime and spent nearly 40 years in prison.

The Civilian Complaint Review Board, the agency responsible for monitoring police conduct, named Joan Thompson, an executive with experience in equal-opportunity employment, its executive director yesterday. Ms. Thompson, currently director of equal opportunity for the Department of Education, succeeds Florence L. Finkle, who resigned in May to head a medical fraud unit in the office of Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo. The board has come under harsh criticism from the New York Civil Liberties Union, which charged in a Sept. 5 report that it had bowed to pressure from the police and failed to aggressively pursue cases of misconduct. Ms. Thompson, who previously held senior positions with the police departments in New York and Baltimore, said that the recent criticism provided ''something for me to work on.''

When Mitt Romney took off on Senator Hillary Clinton's health care plan yesterday, he chose to do so in front of an unlikely place: St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan, home of the Rudolph W. Giuliani Trauma Center. Mr. Romney, the former Massachusetts governor, was in his Republican opponent's home city for fund-raising, and, asked about the locale of the press event, he said he was unaware that the former mayor had been honored with the naming of the hospital's trauma center. (Mr. Giuliani's wife, Judith, had taken a central role in raising money for the center.) MICHAEL LUO

Throughout the inaugural weeks of his presidential campaign, Fred D. Thompson, the newest Republican candidate, has compared the debates to a circus show, with seals lining up to catch fish. And while he has said that he is ''not above acting like a seal every once in a while,'' his coyness about exactly when he will participate in debates has left some Republicans wondering what was behind his hesitation. The campaign, however, disclosed Mr. Thompson's October debate schedule yesterday, and despite speculation about his supposed reluctance to debate, his commitments match the list of established Republican debates that month. The campaign announced that Mr. Thompson would appear at an Oct. 9 debate sponsored by CNBC on economic issues in Dearborn, Mich.; an Oct. 14 forum in Manchester, N.H.; and, a week later, at a debate in Orlando, Fla.

He lacks money and viability, but at least former Senator Mike Gravel is collecting lovely parting gifts. Mr. Gravel, a long-shot presidential candidate, was seen ambling alone on Capitol Hill carrying a blue goody bag. ''I got this from Charlie Rose,'' he said, referring to a TV interview he had just finished. The bag's contents: ''Micro-roasted'' Peruvian coffee, a Newman's Own chocolate bar and a sugar cookie. Mr. Gravel, Democrat of Alaska, was walking to his car, set to devour his sugar cookie lunch, when a reporter asked if he was having fun? ''Oh, heck no,'' he said.

GITTIS--Howard . The University of Pennsylvania mourns the death of Howard Gittis, an esteemed alumnus of both Penn's Wharton School and its Law School. As a longtime Overseer of the Law School, Howard was recognized with its Distinguished Service Award, a fitting tribute to his deep affection for the school and volunteer leadership. His friends also honored him with the establishment of an endowed undergraduate scholarship in his name for exceptional graduates of Central High School in Philadelphia. His generosity to Penn included the establishment of the Law School's Gittis Center for Clinical Legal Studies. The School's Gittis Hall is also named in recognition of his outstanding philanthropy. We have all lost a great friend and we extend heartfelt condolences from the entire Penn community to Howard's family. James Riepe, Chair, Board of Trustees Amy Gutmann, President Michael A. We will always remember him as a loving grandfather and brilliant advocate whose wisdom, guidance, and passionate belief in our mission contributed profoundly to FAI's growth and led to groundbreaking legislative achievements. THOMPSON--Harry . Of New York City and Southampton, L.I., died on Saturday, September 8, at his home in Southampton. Survived by his wife, the sculptor Immi Storrs, and his daughter, Maya Casagrande. Born October 4, 1929, in Englewood, NJ. Graduated from Knox College, in Illinois, where he was captain of the football team. Served with the Army in Korea, where he was lent to the Korean Military Advisor Group as a cryptographer. Graduated from Harvard Business School in 1955. Named Senior Creative Director in charge of new product development at Marschalk advertising agency, a subsidiary of Interpublic Companies. Named president of Tinker Campbell Ewald, another Interpublic subsidiary. Accompanied Terence Cardinal Cooke to Africa to visit the Sahel Desert in Africa during a severe famine. Appointed Commissioner of Youth for New York City by Mayor Abe Beame. Served as chairman of several telecommunications companies of the Galesi Group, managing director of Swiss Army Brands, and director of the Madison Fund, Schwinn/GT Corp, and BriteSmile, Inc. Also survived by stepchildren Cecil and Maya Auchincloss of NYC and Newport, RI, sister Peggy Studney of Chicago, five nephews, and a niece. A memorial service will be held on Thursday September 27th at 4 p.m., St. Jean Baptiste Church, 184 E. 76th Street, NYC. The family requests that, in lieu of flowers, contributions be made to Tanda (169 E. 78th Street, 2D, NYC 10075), an organization that helps South African AIDS orphans, of which Harry's daughter is managing director. Harry was more than a proud father and loving husband. He was an athlete (an avid swimmer and a skier who frequented the slopes of Sugarbush and Aspen in their spacious early days); a storyteller; a roving spirit. ''Irresistible as Rabelais, but most tender for/The lame dogs and hurt birds that surrounded him/He was a procession no one could follow after/But be like a little dog following a brass band.''

Following is a first set of answers from James Sanders, an architect, author and filmmaker based in New York City who is taking questions from City Room readers this week. Readers are invited to submit additional questions here. Questions should touch upon the planning, architecture and design of the city and their depictions in films.

In his About New York column, Jim Dwyer examines the puzzling suicide of Sgt. Denise A. Lannaman of Queens, who killed herself in Kuwait last October. Sergeant Lannaman was part of an Army logistics group. Two officers in that unit, a lieutenant colonel and a major, who had power over contract awards and had been accused of taking bribes, committed suicide. Questions remain about why Sergeant Lannaman — a Navy veteran who held a variety of jobs and often struggled with mental illness — took her life.

Ten advocacy groups that normally support greater investments in public transportation released a two-page letter [pdf] today to Elliot G. Sander, executive director of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, urging that the authority put off any final action on a fare and toll increase until March 31, 2008 “at the earliest.”The authority has called for its board to vote by December on a plan to increase by 6 percent the total revenue from fares and tolls. It is not clear whether or how the base subway and bus fare and the cost of unlimited-ride MetroCards would be affected. The fare increase would take effect in early 2008.

The “I Love New York” jingle hit the airwaves in May 1977, and many New Yorkers over 30 cannot hear the melody without bursting into song or at least feeling nostalgia for Bernadette Peters, the Milford Plaza or those dancing chorus girls from “42nd Street.”Now state tourism officials are hoping a revitalized jingle campaign will inspire city-dwellers to pack their bags and head to upstate locales like the Central-Leatherstocking District, named for the novels of James Fenimore Cooper (the “Leatherstocking Tales,” including “Last of the Mohicans” and “The Deerslayer”) and home to attractions like the Baseball Hall of Fame in Cooperstown (“a truly fascinating place” founded by the novelist’s father.)
New Yorkers have seen the future, and apparently it’s a lot like an Irwin Allen movie.

Government watchdog groups are calling on the State Board of Elections to abandon a proposal floated last month to start using some touch-screen voting machines in polling places next year, for use primarily by the disabled. Under the proposal, the vote counting function of the machines would not be used and a paper record would be counted instead.

When Steven J. Mandel said he wanted to make an announcement today “from the ruins of his office,” he was not kidding. His fifth-floor corner suite on Lexington Avenue, directly overlooking the spot where an underground steam pipe exploded on July 18, is a gutted shell.

When New York State releases its list of “persistently dangerous” schools each year, as required under the No Child Left Behind law, it relies on data provided by schools and school districts. Jen O'Neill is the editor of Fair Game, a magazine devoted solely to women's soccer. She is based in Newcastle, but she's currently in China for the Women's World Cup and will be filing posts for the Times soccer blog.

Boris Gelfand of Israel took advantage of some loose play by his opponent, Alexander Morozevich of Russia, to win his sixth round game and tie Viswanathan Anand of India for the lead of the world championship tournament in Mexico City. Vladimir Kramnik of Russia, the defending champion, and Alexander Grischuk of Russia were tied just a half point behind the leaders. More information about the tournament and the standings can be found at the official Web site of the championship.

The Bank of Beijing almost doubled on its first day of trading in Shanghai after investors ordered 127 times the stock on offer in the largest initial public offering by a Chinese city bank. An oversight board of the Teamsters union announced that it had filed charges against Don Hahs, the president of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers and Trainmen, accusing him of embezzling $58,000 in union money. The Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, a 59,000-member union based in Cleveland, merged with the Teamsters in 2004. The oversight board accused Mr. Hahs of using nearly $50,000 in union money to buy regular season and playoff tickets for the Cleveland Cavaliers, “for which there was no union purpose.” The board also said Mr. Hahs had the union pay $7,751.97 in personal travel expenses for his wife. Mr. Hahs did not return a telephone message.

A Mexican drug lord pleaded guilty in San Diego to federal crimes that carry a mandatory life term, a deal that spares him execution. The man, Francisco Javier Arellano Félix, was captured last year when the Coast Guard found him deep-sea fishing off Mexico. He pleaded guilty on Monday to running a continuing criminal enterprise and conspiracy to launder money.

University of Florida officers used a Taser on a persistent questioner at a forum on Monday with Senator John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts. Video of the incident involving the student, Andrew Meyer, 21, was played extensively on television reports and the Web. The university asked state investigators to review the case, and the university president, Bernie Machen, called the confrontation regretful and said two officers had been placed on administrative leave. Mr. Meyer spent a night in jail before being released on his recognizance.

Thirteen House members have been subpoenaed to testify in the trial of a military contractor charged with bribing Randy Cunningham, a former California congressman who is now in prison. The 13 include former Speaker J. Dennis Hastert, Republican of Illinois, and Representative Roy Blunt of Missouri, the Republican whip. All said they would not comply, on the advice of House lawyers. The House general counsel’s office is preparing to move to quash the subpoenas after failing to obtain a clear explanation of why the lawmakers’ testimony is needed, said an aide to Representative Darrell Issa, a California Republican who was subpoenaed.

In ''Knife Skills Illustrated: A User's Manual'' by Peter Hertzmann (W. W. Norton, $29.95), lefties are not ignored. In fact, every step-by-step cutting procedure, whether it's trimming an artichoke, boning a fish or peeling ginger, is shown with right-handed and left-handed methods. The line drawings are clear and easy to follow. The book begins with general information on knives, how they are made, the various models available and which constitute a basic wardrobe. The book tells how to keep knives sharp and what kinds of cutting boards are best. The only shortcomings I found were the dismissive remarks about Japanese knives, like the santoku models that are now widely sold.

Russia said in talks with France that it would oppose tougher sanctions on Iran, and accused the United States and European Union of undermining efforts to resolve the crisis over Tehran's nuclear program diplomatically. The tense talks between Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov and his French counterpart, Bernard Kouchner, took place just days before a United Nations Security Council meeting to discuss how to get Tehran to suspend its uranium-enrichment efforts. Separately, Viktor A. Zubkov, Russia's new prime minister, announced the resignation of Acting Defense Minister Anatoly E. Serdyukov, on the grounds of wanting to avoid the appearance of nepotism. Mr. Serdyukov is married to the prime minister's daughter.

For serious coffee drinkers who want no hazelnut flavorings or caramel toppings there are more places than ever to enjoy a well-made espresso. Among them are Ninth Street Espresso, which started in the East Village and has now opened a spacious 27-foot coffee bar in the Chelsea Market, 75 Ninth Avenue (15th Street). It's a no-nonsense affair, which the owner, Kenneth Nye, said will be the model for future expansion. (He just sold his counter at the Classic Stage Company near Union Square to one of his baristas and it is now called Everyman Espresso.) The menu is limited to typical Italian-style and French-press coffees ($1 to $4). Customers can select single origin coffees or a blend. Coffees are also sold by the pound, $11 to $14; (212) 228-2930.

Having long been a legend in his own mind, Bengals receiver Chad Johnson, above, may finally be as good as he thinks he is. Johnson has never been as productive as his speeches and commercials have implied. His career high in touchdowns in a season is a pedestrian 10, and having played six full seasons entering 2007, Johnson had 41 receiving touchdowns, or 38 fewer than Jerry Rice had in his first six.

Unlike most other sandwich and salad shops with food to go in Midtown, Certé, 20 West 55th Street, offers a sleek, pleasant dining area and some first-rate food. Notable, in a neighborhood that is short on good bake shops, are sweet temptations, including linzer cookies ($1.25), Valrhona chocolate brownies ($2.25), and for a chocolate indulgence, cream-filled chocolate ''brownwich'' pastries, above, ($1.75). The breakfast and lunch menus go on for pages. Nothing is more than $11.95 and most of the food is less than $10; (212) 397-2020, certenyc.com.

In the army they're called M.R.E.'s -- meals ready to eat. That phrase could apply to a new line of meals in containers designed for civilians and made in France by St. Dalfour, a company best known for its fruit conserves. Called Gourmet on the Go, its vacuum containers, with lids that peel off, hold 6.2 ounces. They come with a tiny fork and packets of salt and pepper. Though they can be heated in a microwave oven with the lid off, the meals are fine as is. They can go in lunchboxes, backpacks and emergency kits. (United Airlines has started selling them in on-board meal packs.) Of the six varieties, the wild salmon and vegetables, couscous, three beans and corn, and the whole grains and beans were surprisingly good and well seasoned. Pasta with tuna and pasta with vegetables both had an off-putting, somewhat slimy texture. All are made without preservatives. It should be noted that the nutrition information is based on a half-container serving, which is somewhat unrealistic; an adult can easily finish one.

A MOVE TO RESTORE CONFIDENCE In an effort to stop the turmoil in the housing and financial markets from bringing down the overall economy, the Federal Reserve cut its benchmark interest rate by an unusually large one-half percentage point, to 4.75 percent from 5.25 percent. While the news that the Federal Reserve cut its benchmark interest rate by half a point was welcomed by many, the reaction was not universally upbeat. Economists and market specialists cautioned that the cut would take time to work through the system, and it may do little to help families confronted with rising mortgage payments and falling home prices. All 277 underground subway stations will be wired for cellphone service within six years under a deal announced by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. The company that won the work, Transit Wireless, will pay New York City Transit a minimum of $46.8 million over 10 years, and will also cover the full cost of building the wireless network in the underground stations, estimated at $150 million to $200 million. Cellphone carriers would pay the company a fee to carry their signals on the network. The cellphone network will start in six downtown Manhattan stations in two years. Once it is shown to be working properly, Transit Wireless will have four more years to outfit the rest of the underground stations.

Today's Q&A subject on The Quad is the writer John Ed Bradley. A novelist and a longtime contributor to Sports Illustrated, as well as publications such as Esquire and GQ, Bradley is also a former center for the Louisiana State football team. When his playing days ended in 1979, Bradley moved on, so much so that he lost contact with most of his former teammates and coaches. The thought of no longer being able to play football, and perhaps having the best years of his life already behind him at such a young age, was haunting. Bradley first publicly addressed those feelings in a widely praised 2002 Sports Illustrated essay. He has just released a memoir called "It Never Rains In Tiger Stadium," which expands on the essay. Bradley, who lives on the same street that he grew up on in Opelousas, La., spoke to us about how football is like a great love affair, appreciating his former teammates and coaches, and realizing that Hemingway didn't know anything about the SEC.

This is the third time I've had the privilege of writing for The New York Times. The first time I was an active duty Marine deployed to Camp Falluja, Iraq. The second, writing in June for this blog, I was transitioning out of the Marine Corps and starting a new life as a civilian in my hometown. Now I finally feel that I'm fully integrated into the civilian world and I'm getting increasingly comfortable with my new surroundings. That being the case, I think it's finally time to get off the fence and discuss something I was unable to publicly discuss as an active duty Marine: some of my opinions on the war in Iraq.

More so than when I reviewed it in early 2005, the deceptive expensiveness of BLT Fish struck me during a recent visit, my first in a good long while. BLT Fish is one of those Craft-y restaurants where the bill has a way of climbing higher than you expect it to, in part because there are all those tempting sides --- two distinct categories of them, one for "vegetables" and the other for "potatoes/rice" --- and servers make a point of directing your attention that way. What's more, the wine list doesn't do the budget-conscious diner too many favors.

When they list baseball nightmares, the 1964 Phillies are always near the top of the list. They led by six and a half games in the National League (no divisions in those days) and managed to blow it in the final 12 games of the season. Last Friday, the Mets began the day with a six-and-a-half-game lead, too -- over the Phillies, no less. Six games later, that lead is down to two and a half as the Mets, who have never had an epic collapse, possibly try one on for size.
