Setting aside, if you can, the war in Iraq, the issues on the campaign trail some days follow the same chords as they did in the 1990s. Guns and Social Security, for example, and religion.

Reports on a small Peruvian town's plight over the past few days include more than a few elements to boggle the mind -- and then to make you wonder whether an episode of "The X-Files" is playing out in real time. (To set the spooky mood, just watch this short video.)

It seems as if the Championship Subdivision is all the rage this year. You can't really blame people. Appalachian State was quite an eye-opener, even if Michigan went out the next week and got spanked by Oregon. Anyway, Eric Lacy of the Detroit News lists the five programs that he thinks could handle a move to the Bowl Subdivision.
Two of Wall Street's biggest investment banks posted earnings on Thursday -- and the differences could hardly be starker.
The Carlyle Group has agreed to sell a minority stake to the Abu Dhabi government in a transaction that values the Washington-based private equity giant at nearly $20 billion.
Yet another major buyout deal may be on the rocks.

Melvyn I. Weiss, a leading class-action securities lawyer, is expected to be indicted as early as Thursday in connection with the kickback scheme that has ensnared his firm, Milberg Weiss, and several former lawyers there, the firm said Thursday in a statement.
A new Cormac McCarthy paperback landed with a thunk on my desk yesterday - a new edition of his hell-bent 2005 novel "No Country for Old Men."

The government-controlled stock exchange in Dubai, the fast-growing Middle East business center, announced Thursday in Stockholm that it plans to take significant ownership in the Nasdaq Stock Market in New York and the London Stock Exchange, The New York Times reported.

Deutsche Bank, Germany's biggest bank, will write down the value of leveraged loans and scale back hiring plans after making "mistakes" during the credit boom that ground to a halt in the past two months, the bank's chief executive, Josef Ackermann, said.
Goldman Sachs will not bail out its embattled flagship Global Alpha hedge fund, nor will it close the fund, according to press reports.

Bear Stearns may have lost market share in the lucrative prime brokerage business because of problems with internal hedge funds and recent management changes at the investment bank, Deutsche Bank analyst Mike Mayo told MarketWatch.

Canada's federal broadcast regulator is preparing to hold public hearings early next year into the proposed 35 billion Canadian dollar ($34.9 billion) takeover of BCE, a move that could extend the closing of the deal until April, according to The Globe and Mail.
France will seek to control the gas and electricity utility created by the merger of state-owned Gaz de France and Suez by creating a "golden share," the finance minister said Wednesday.

Shareholders of Topps, the basebal -card and bubble gum producer brought an end to a long-running fight Wednesday, by approving a $9.75-a-share, $384 million buyout bid from Michael Eisner's Tornante and the private equity firm Madison Dearborn Partners.

The Bank of England abruptly reversed its policy on Wednesday of refusing to ease lending standards, offering to inject cash into British money markets amid criticism that it had not done enough to stem a credit squeeze that has undercut its economy.
The China Construction Bank, the country's biggest property lender, raised 58.05 billion yuan ($7.7 billion) in mainland China's biggest initial public offering ever, state media reported Wednesday.

A real estate information start-up, Zillow, said late Wednesday it closed a $30 million round of financing. Legg Mason Capital Management, a Baltimore-based global asset management group known for its mutual funds, led the round.
A group of hedge fund firms is suing over what they say was a conspiracy to hide massive debt of the beverage maker LeNature from shareholders.
J Sainsbury, the British supermarket chain, softened its opposition to Qatar's 10.5 billion pound ($21 billion) takeover bid after Qatar said it would borrow less to fund the deal.

Venture capital investments in the renewable energy sector are on course to reap annualized returns of more than 50 percent, as commitments to the climate change sector to date this year hit $6 billion, outstripping the total for the whole of last year.

A women's apparel group, Kellwood, said late Tuesday that the Sun Capital Securities Group had offered to acquire all outstanding shares of the retailer in a deal that would value the company at more than $1 billion including debt.
Amyris Biotechnologies, a developer of a process to make biofuels using engineered microbes, said Wednesday it had closed part of its $70 million second round of funding.

Diageo's chief executive, Paul Walsh, said his company, which owns the Smirnoff vodka brand, is "very interested" in buying Sweden's Absolut vodka, valued at about $6 billion. Any possible antitrust problems are probably surmountable, he added.

Lehman Brothers announced Wednesday that it had capped its fifth venture capital fund at $365 million, after setting a goal of $300 million, to focus on mid- to late-stage investments in technology companies over the next four years.

Kelso & Company has generated about $5 billion in commitments for its latest private equity fund, the New York firm's eighth leveraged buyout investment pool, and is said to be targeting a final close at between $5 billion and $6 billion, The Deal.com reported.
Sullivan & Cromwell, the New York law firm, has unveiled a plan to pay senior associates and counsels supplemental bonuses tied to the firm's financial performance.
A Securities and Exchange Commission lawsuit against the deposed media baron Conrad Black is going ahead after begin interrupted by his criminal fraud trial.

A San Francisco biotechnology company, Renovis, which slashed its workforce in January after one of its drug candidates flopped a major test, said Wednesday it had agreed to be purchased for $151.8 million in stock by a German drug firm, Evotec.
Mortgage insurers MGIC Investment and Radian Group, who failed in their efforts to strike a merger agreement, said Wednesday that they had sold investments in the Sherman Financial Group.
Evergreen Investment Management and its affiliates have agreed to pay $32.5 million to settle charges of improper market timing, the Securities and Exchange Commission said Wednesday.

Allergan, which is testing its blockbuster antiwrinkle drug Botox as a treatment for overactive bladder, said Wednesday that it would buy Esprit Pharma for $370 million to expand its role in treating bladder disorders.
Technical difficulties halted electronic trading on the Chicago Board of Trade for nearly two hours on Wednesday afternoon, exchange officials said.
More than 10,000 demonstrators rallied in a small Louisiana town to protest the treatment of six black teenagers who were arrested in the beating of a white schoolmate.
When Eva Birath began bodybuilding at age 47, she aimed to change her physique, her psyche and maybe even some perceptions.
Boxing greats gathered at Madison Square Garden to celebrate the life of the historic boxing ring, which is being retired.

Time was when overtime was extra money for extra work, which in its simplest form it still is, but there is nothing simple about it anymore. In today's perpetual workplace, where downtime has merged with work time, where you can carry your office in your pocket, where collars are no longer distinctly blue or white, how does one measure overtime?

It was a tense moment in Wednesday's game. Aubrey Huff was facing Mariano Rivera in the ninth inning with the tying run on second and two outs. Catcher Jorge Posada went to the mound, and the crowd exploded with noise.
Already common on the Web, mashups are popping up in mobile phone browsers as well.

I often set my iTunes program to shuffle all the songs, but find it jarring when Christmas music pops into the mix. Is there a way to make iTunes skip these holiday albums when it randomly shuffles my music?
When I am making lists in Microsoft Word, the program automatically capitalizes the first letter of each word when I press the return key. How can I make it stop doing this?
The computing power inside even the cheapest digital cameras allows a photographer to get even better pictures — if they can decipher the myriad shooting modes built into the devices.
Firefly Mobile’s $125 flyPhone has a completely black face that lights up in different ways depending on what the child is doing.
Within that trimmer shell, Sony has doubled the built-in memory to 64 megabytes, which results in noticeably faster-loading games displayed on its bright 4.3-inch screen.
Tapeless camcorders have arrived, but be aware of price, capacity and picture quality.
Auric Goldfinger, the James Bond villain, would love the LaCie Golden Disk, a 500-gigabyte external hard drive.
KoogaPet can store an animal’s personal information and medical records on a U.S.B. drive that measures less than 1 by 1 ½ inches.
Steve Mills, who recruited Anucha Browne Sanders to the Knicks, testified Wednesday that she came to his office in tears in late 2005 to tell him she was resigning.
Good lighting and good design go hand in hand for reading and working.
Five of the top Democratic presidential candidates tried to win over older voters at an AARP-sponsored forum in Davenport, Iowa.
A proposal to cut off money for military operations in Iraq fell far short in the Senate today, a day after Democrats lost their best chance of changing the course of the war.
A team of scientists says it has found evidence in three wrist bones that an extinct group of people were members of a distinct species.
Norman Hsu, the Democratic fund-raiser who was a fugitive from the law, was charged today with bilking investors of at least $60 million in a nationwide Ponzi scheme.
President Bush warned again that he would veto the bill if it emerged from Congress in its present form.
The euro traded above $1.40 for the first time since the common European currency was introduced.
Iraqi health officials confirmed the first cases of cholera in Baghdad today, in a sign that an epidemic that has infected approximately 7,000 people in northern Iraq is spreading south.
Ben S. Bernanke’s call for consideration of stricter regulation of mortgage lending practices signals a shift from regulatory policy over the past several years.

The Books of The Times review yesterday, about “The Lion and the Unicorn” by Richard Aldous, an account of the rivalry between William Gladstone and Benjamin Disraeli, referred incorrectly in some copies to their difference in age. Disraeli was five years older than Gladstone, not five years younger.

The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, pressed Israel and the United States today to make sure that an upcoming Middle East peace conference this fall tackles the big, politically sensitive “final status” issues.
Under the deal, Borse Dubai becomes the first government-controlled stock exchange of the Middle East to hold a significant stake in an American rival.
The election has become the focus of the deepest political crisis General Musharraf has faced.
The involvement of the Buddhist clergy, which is revered in this country, presents a serious challenge to the junta.
Dubai would become the first Middle Eastern government with a large stake in an American stock exchange.

The Sports of The Times column on Friday, about the National Football League’s punishment of the New England Patriots for videotaping an opponent’s signals, misidentified a player whom Commissioner Roger Goodell suspended for conduct off the field while the player was with the Chicago Bears. He is Tank Johnson — not Tank Williams, who plays for the Minnesota Vikings. (Tank Johnson signed a two-year contract on Tuesday with the Dallas Cowboys, but will not play until he completes his eight-game suspension.).
Settlement talks in the dispute over the estate of the philanthropist Brooke Astor appear to have come to a halt, two people who have been briefed on the situation said yesterday.
“Kid Nation,” CBS’s much-disputed reality show, is not about watching children build a new society in a ghost town in the New Mexico wilderness.
Two teenagers were shot, one fatally, in a Brooklyn housing development last night, the police said.
By holding the Orioles to a run and seven hits, Andy Pettitte helped the Yankees gain ground in two races.
A career and life riddled with contrasts added another Wednesday night when Sonny Vaccaro, who at 67 still describes himself as a renegade, gave a 90-minute speech at the Harvard Law School.
If the Mets were not on the verge of an historic collapse, Moises Alou would have rested his ailing left quadriceps. But Alou does not have time to get better.
The Giants have not announced whether first-round pick Aaron Ross would supplant either Sam Madison or Corey Webster at corner back when the Giants play at Washington on Sunday.
The leader of an insurgent group in Dagestan, an internal Russian republic bordering Chechnya, was trapped in a house and killed in a battle with Russian forces.
A General Assembly committee rejected Taiwan’s application to become a member of the United Nations, the 15th straight year that the bid has failed.
NATO said it would give Serbia information on the cluster bombs that were part of the alliance’s 1999 airstrikes to eject Serbian forces from the breakaway province of Kosovo.
The Millennium Challenge Corporation, an international antipoverty agency, approved a five-year, $698 million program of foreign aid to Tanzania.
The Alliance for a Green Revolution in Africa said it would develop a center to train African scientists to develop hardier, higher-yielding varieties of crops.
A candidate supported by Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez for a Surrogate’s Court judgeship in Brooklyn was handily defeated by one endorsed by reform-oriented groups and a wide array of politicians.

José Mourinho, who led Chelsea to consecutive English Premier League titles in 2005 and 2006, quit as manager yesterday, one day after the team was held to a 1-1 tie by Rosenborg in its Champions League opener.

Notre Dame will not release quarterback Demetrius Jones from his scholarship this season. Jones, who started in the season opener against Georgia Tech but lost his job, can play for Northern Illinois next season, but he will need to pay his own way there this year.
HAUPPAUGE, N.Y., Sept. 19 — The property tax increases were going to be draconian. Cuts in services and mass layoffs loomed.

Four people have been charged with beating a man who was found dead last October in Riverhead, the Suffolk police said yesterday. The man, Jaime Figueroa, 35, of Flanders, was found in the woods near Union Avenue on Oct. 4, the police said. The police said he was beaten during a drug deal the night before. The suspects — Kenneth Hughes, 19, Jared Hysell, 21, and Eric Montez, 28, all of Riverhead; and Kristan Miles, 19, of Mastic Beach — are charged with first-degree gang assault, the police said. Detective Lt. Jack Fitzpatrick said Mr. Figueroa was trying to buy crack cocaine when the suspects, believing that he was a police informant, beat him before dragging him into the woods.

The city’s public advocate, Betsy Gotbaum, announced yesterday that she had appointed a panel to examine the effectiveness of mayoral control over the city’s public schools. The panel, called the Commission on School Governance, includes several prominent public figures, like Stephen Berger, who recently headed a commission on closing and consolidating hospitals throughout the state. Other members are Frank J. Macchiarola, a former city schools chancellor, and Herman Badillo, the former congressman. The commission is expected to hold several hearings and make recommendations sometime next year. Ms. Gotbaum, a critic of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Chancellor Joel I. Klein, said the commission would “independently evaluate” the school management law and “present a balanced and impartial report.” The City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, also announced yesterday that the Council had formed its own working group to look at the effectiveness of mayoral control.

An administrator at one of the nation’s largest prescription drug management companies admitted yesterday in Federal District Court that he planted an electronic “bomb” in the company’s computer system. Yung-Hsun Lin, 51, of Montvale, pleaded guilty to a computer crime and faces up to 10 years in prison. Sentencing is set for January. Prosecutors said Mr. Lin was angry at the possibility of losing his job at Medco Health Solutions after it was spun off from Merck & Company in 2003.

A man on trial in the killing of a police officer in Flatbush in 2005 had access to the parking garage where the police had chased the suspect, a witness testified yesterday in State Supreme Court. The defendant, Allan Cameron, 29, has been charged with first-degree murder. The officer, Dillon Stewart, 35, above, was shot and killed during a car chase in the early hours of Nov. 28, 2005. Prosecutors are trying to prove that Mr. Cameron fired on Officer Stewart from his car, then sped into the garage on East 21st Street and closed the door as the police gave chase. Lacking an eyewitness to identify the gunman, they are using forensic and scientific evidence in an effort to connect Mr. Cameron, the gun and the car. The witness, Walter Ross, who is a neighbor, said he had seen Mr. Cameron driving the car regularly.

The New York Taxi Workers Alliance, which represents more than 10,000 taxi drivers in the city, filed a lawsuit yesterday seeking to block the New York Taxi and Limousine Commission from installing global positioning system software on all city taxi meters. The suit, filed in Federal District Court, said the software was an invasion of privacy and denied the drivers their constitutionally protected right to their own property. City officials said they could not comment on the suit until they had seen it.

A homeless man accused of raping and torturing a Columbia University graduate student has been found mentally fit to stand trial by a court-appointed psychiatrist, the man’s lawyer said yesterday at a hearing in State Supreme Court. But the lawyer, Arnold J. Levine, contested the finding and said he wanted his client, Robert A. Williams, examined by a second expert. Mr. Levine said after the hearing that he was considering raising a psychiatric defense, although he would not elaborate. Justice Carol Berkman scheduled a hearing for Oct. 24 to determine Mr. Williams’s mental competency. Mr. Williams, 30, is accused of forcing his way into the woman’s apartment in Hamilton Heights in April, where the police say he raped her, burned her with hot water and bleach and slit her eyelids.

A Manhattan lawyer has sued Con Edison over damage to his office caused by the July 18 steam pipe explosion on Lexington Avenue. The lawyer, Steven J. Mandel, claims that the utility has not made good on its promise to pay for damaged property and cleanup expenses at his fifth-floor offices at 370 Lexington Avenue. Mr. Mandel, who estimates the final cost at $400,000, also says that someone stole computer equipment and sports memorabilia after the explosion. Joseph P. Petta, a Con Edison spokesman, said the company had offered to pay Mr. Mandel but wanted to receive a full claim rather than make a partial payment. Mr. Petta said the company would respond to Mr. Mandel in court.

Jurors in the trial of two men charged with murder as a hate crime saw transcripts yesterday of computer instant messages between the suspects and the victim. Prosecutors in State Supreme Court are trying to prove that the defendants, John Fox, 20, and Anthony Fortunato, 21, lured a gay man, Michael J. Sandy, 29, of Williamsburg, to a remote spot in Sheepshead Bay by pretending that the meeting was for a sexual encounter. Once there, prosecutors claim, Mr. Sandy fled and was hit by a car. Mr. Fortunato’s lawyer, Gerald J. Di Chiara, has said that his client is also gay and that the encounter was planned not as a robbery but as a misguided attempt to reveal Mr. Fortunato’s homosexuality to his friends.
Mount Vernon’s political future hung in the balance Wednesday as Mayor Ernest D. Davis, a three-term incumbent seeking re-election, did not concede victory to his challenger, Clinton I. Young.
NBC Universal announced plans for a service to make popular NBC programs available free for computers and other devices.
A proposal that Senate Democrats had put forward as their best chance of changing strategy in Iraq died as Republicans stood behind President Bush.
A hearing on charges that Special Forces soldiers murdered an Afghan man last October made evident that the Army is also examining itself and how it is fighting the war in Afghanistan.

Senate Republicans hired a high-profile former federal prosecutor to assist their investigation of the Spitzer administration, escalating the months-long political battle between Gov. Eliot Spitzer and the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno.
The consortium that had agreed to buy Sallie Mae for $25 billion may scuttle the deal if it is unable to negotiate a lower price.

The owners of a dry-cleaning business here are shutting down the store that was involved in a $67 million lawsuit over a pair of pants. A lawyer for the owners of Custom Cleaners, Jin Nam Chung and Ki Chung, said they were closing the store because of a loss of revenue and the emotional strain of defending the suit. They will continue to operate another cleaning business. A customer, Roy Pearson Jr., sued after accusing them of losing a pair of his pants. He originally sued for $67 million, later lowering his claim to $54 million. A judge denied Mr. Pearson’s claim in June, but he is appealing.

An Iowa machinist accused of sending threats and unarmed bombs to investment firms has been indicted on securities fraud and other charges, federal prosecutors said. The man, John Tomkins, above, is linked to more than 12 threatening letters dating from early 2005, said Patrick J. Fitzgerald, the United States attorney in Chicago. Two cases involved partly connected pipe bombs sent to investment firms in Denver and Kansas City, Mo., as part of an effort to manipulate the prices of stock in which Mr. Tomkins, 42, had holdings, Mr. Fitzgerald said.
Recent incidents in Iraq have revealed large gaps in the laws applying to armed contractors.
G.M. and the U.A.W. have shifted negotiations to other issues after being unable to agree on how much G.M. would invest in a health-care trust.

Charges were dropped against a woman accused of killing one of her newborn twins in 2004 and keeping other fetal remains around her home in Ocean City. A prosecutor, Joel Todd, asked a grand jury to dismiss the murder charges against Christy Freeman, 37. Barry Neeb, an Ocean City police spokesman, said the dismissal was issued because of insufficient evidence after a medical examiner’s report.

The state said a team of construction companies from Colorado and Washington State had been selected to build a replacement for a collapsed Interstate bridge, with a bid of $233.8 million. The contract could be worth millions more if the Interstate 35W bridge is finished ahead of schedule. The winning bid was the most expensive and tied for the longest construction timetable — 437 days — among the four bids. Officials chose the winner based on a formula that balanced speed and construction cost with other factors, including quality and aesthetics. Drawings and other details were not released.
For freedom of the press to be more than a promise and for the public to be kept informed, reporters must be able to pursue the news wherever it takes them.
John Edwards’s presidential campaign is asking for a criminal investigation after an aide’s internal e-mail messages were copied and mailed to some people he disparaged.

Important computerized information about veterans remains at risk of being stolen from the Veterans Affairs Department, government investigators say. The report by the Government Accountability Office was issued more than a year after a computer hard drive containing personal information for 26.5 million veterans and active-duty personnel was stolen from the home of a V.A. employee.

The House Ethics Committee announced an investigation of Representative Bob Filner’s run-in last month with a baggage worker at Dulles International Airport. The incident resulted in charges of misdemeanor assault and battery against the congressman, a California Democrat. The committee said a bipartisan group would defer taking action until the criminal proceedings were resolved. Mr. Filner has said the charges are a result of a “misunderstanding” after his bags had been delayed.

A judge rejected a Harvard student’s request for extra break time during her nine-hour medical licensing examination so she could pump breast milk. The student, Sophie Currier, 33, sued after the National Board of Medical Examiners turned down her request to take more than the standard 45 minutes in breaks during the exam. She said if she did not nurse her 4-month-old daughter or pump breast milk every two to three hours she risked medical complications. Judge Patrick Brady of Norfolk Superior Court said Ms. Currier had other options.
Dale Earnhardt Jr. announced Wednesday that his car for Hendrick Motorsports would carry No. 88 and would be sponsored by Amp Energy Drink and the National Guard.
Two senior officials were appointed to clear bureaucratic roadblocks blamed by Washington for the painfully slow pace of admitting Iraqi refugees to the United States.
Some in the N.F.L. community believe Jets Coach Eric Mangini breached an unspoken code of honor among coaches by allowing his team to turn in his former mentor.
Making an unusual campaign swing outside his own country, Rudolph W. Giuliani said that he would like to see a broad expansion of the NATO alliance, including an invitation to Israel.
There is a food chain extending from Washington to the poverty precincts across the nation, and it is ever subject to legislative whim and crimping in nutrition aid.
Dan Rather asserts that CBS violated his contract by giving him insufficient airtime on “60 Minutes.”
Corrections
Next week’s Morgan State debate on minority issues would be just the platform for Republican presidential candidates to lay out their vision to Americans.
Melvyn I. Weiss was indicted today in connection with a scheme in which his firm is said to have paid kickbacks to people to serve as named plaintiffs in class-action lawsuits.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 19 (AP) — Tony La Russa had little to say Wednesday about speculation he would leave the St. Louis Cardinals after a dozen seasons to manage the Seattle Mariners next season.
A domestic violence case involving a television evangelist  has left some questioning her credibility.

Schools in at least a dozen districts in northern New Jersey will be closed today as a precaution after an anonymous bomb threat was received by the mayor of Emerson, in Bergen County, police officials said yesterday. The closings affect nearly 12,000 students.
The judge in the murder trial of the music producer Phil Spector decided to give the jury members new instructions and rejected the idea of allowing them to consider a lesser charge.
Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki said that his government had registered seven cases in which Blackwater USA’s guards had killed Iraqis.
While many expected Ben S. Bernanke to bring a different style to the Federal Reserve, in practice Mr. Bernanke is remarkably similar to his predecessor, Alan Greenspan.
All 277 underground stations in the New York subway system are to be wired for cellphone use.

A remark by Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly that the Police Department was considering a request by Iran that its president visit ground zero set off complaints before the department corrected itself.
Mets catcher Paul Lo Duca decided that he needed to do something drastic after another depressing loss Tuesday night. So he shaved his head.
Saffron-robed monks have become the spearhead of a movement that began on Aug. 19, when a few hundred citizens marched to protest a government increase in fuel prices.
Compensation for ghetto workers, who generally received a small but often negligible wage, was one of the last outstanding claims dating from the Third Reich.
The city comptroller said an audit showed that the city had not ensured that all principals accurately report violence in their schools.
Passing the Dream Act would show that America has not lost its ability to recognize, with grace and gratitude, the great potential in the immigrants among us.
The bill is expected to give federal drug regulators significantly more money and power to ensure the safety of the nation’s drug supply.
The U.S. will back the nomination of Dominique Strauss-Kahn to become managing director of the International Monetary Fund.
A government regulator on Wednesday said Fannie Mae could slightly increase the amount of mortgages it can buy for its investment portfolio.
Facing increasing competition in the smartphone market, Palm Inc. said Wednesday that it might see a small loss in its fiscal first quarter.
Foreign Minister Bernard Kouchner of France said that his remarks that the world had to prepare for a possible war with Iran had been misinterpreted and that he was a man of peace.
The calendar for the primary elections remains in the air, producing an interstate rivalry creating unintended consequences.
Barrick Gold is offering a $10 million prize to anyone who can increase the amount of silver it recovers from a mine in Argentina.
The revival of the bill is the first effort to advance a piece of broad immigration legislation that failed in June.
The lessons learned from a complex terrorism trial in 1996 are still echoing with Michael B. Mukasey.
A powerful car bomb that killed a Christian lawmaker was the latest in a deadly string of bombings that have rocked Lebanon as the country prepares to select a new president.
In Mexico City, the fight over what would be Latin America’s tallest skyscraper — at 984 feet — takes on a tinge of high drama.

Several weeks ago, according to the owner of an upstate New York auction company, he and his staff were combing through the belongings of an elderly man about to enter a nursing home. The house was just outside Palmyra, the birthplace of the Mormon religion, and amid the attic clutter, at the bottom of a box of books, was the treasure: a 177-year-old first-edition copy of the Book of Mormon.
In a news conference, quarterback Donovan McNabb repeated his statement from HBO’s “Real Sports” that black quarterbacks face greater scrutiny than their white counterparts.
A New Jersey mother has been frustrated in trying to send cans of Silly String to soldiers in Iraq who say the goo is useful for finding trip wires in buildings.
In a ceremony Wednesday that attracted a who’s who of boxing greats and world champions, Madison Square Garden retired its 82-year-old boxing ring.
Skepticism of N.B.A. officiating has almost certainly never been higher, which Ronnie Nunn, N.B.A.’s director of officiating, acknowledged Wednesday.
Evergreen Investment Management and its affiliates have agreed to pay $32.5 million to settle charges of improper market timing.
A panel ruled that the judge, Noel A. Ferris, had mischaracterized the evidence and the demeanor of the asylum seeker when she ruled his testimony not credible.
A federal judge ruled that the state’s newly revised lethal injection procedures were unconstitutional.
The food maker General Mills reported on Wednesday that its first-quarter profit rose 8 percent as rising revenue offset higher ingredient costs and increased spending on marketing.
The final defense witness in the case against the polygamist leader Warren S. Jeffs testified that there had been no rape in the consummation of the marriage of a 14-year-old girl.
Delays in the Small Business Administration’s disbursal of grant money caused layoffs and cutbacks at women’s business centers.
A senior military official warned on Wednesday that Iran had prepared a plan to attack Israel if Israel bombed Iran, saying that Iran’s “missiles can reach all parts of Israel.”
Few politicians will be sorry over the departure of David M. Grandeau, Albany’s top ethics enforcer.
Agriculture Secretary Mike Johanns will resign his cabinet post to begin preparing to run for a Senate seat from Nebraska.

The Red Sox saw their lead over the Yankees in the American League East cut to a game and a half when the host Toronto Blue Jays finished a sweep last night with a 6-1 victory against Boston. The Red Sox have lost four in a row and five of six.
Kellen Clemens’s creditable performance at Baltimore in his first N.F.L. start did not stoke the embers of debate in the hot zone that is the Jets’ practice facility.
Senate Republicans rejected complaints that a new law that denies terrorism detainees the right to appeal their detention to federal courts ran against the nation’s principles.
Allergan said yesterday that it would buy Esprit Pharma for $370 million to expand its role in treating bladder disorders.
The University of Memphis signed an agreement with the Chinese Basketball Association that will include Coach John Calipari running a series of coaching clinics and camps throughout China.
The report says the state housing agency’s failure to properly oversee subsidized middle-income housing has led to a deterioration of  the buildings, among other problems.

Manchester United, Arsenal, Barcelona and A.S. Roma opened with victories yesterday in the European Champions League. Cristiano Ronaldo scored against his former club in Manchester United’s 1-0 victory at Sporting Lisbon. Wayne Rooney returned for United after missing five weeks with a broken foot. Arsenal beat visiting Sevilla, last season’s UEFA Cup champion, 3-0; Barcelona, the 2006 Champions League titlist, defeated visiting Lyon, 3-0; and A.S. Roma beat visiting Dynamo Kiev, 2-0.Inter, the Italian champion, lost at the Turkish champion Fenerbahce, 1-0.

With the Breeders’ Cup at Monmouth Park next month, the New Jersey Racing Commission passed new regulations that will allow prerace testing on thoroughbreds for performance-enhancing agents.The commission approved out-of-competition testing for EPO and TCO2 testing on thoroughbreds competing at the four state tracks.The regulations were part of several measures enacted by the commission for the Breeders’ Cup World Championships on Oct. 26-27.EPO is a blood-doping agent that enhances the red blood cells, and has the potential to improve performance. TCO2 testing measures the total carbon dioxide level in a racehorse. Excessive TCO2 indicates that an alkalizing agent, commonly referred to as a milkshake, was administered to improve performance.

Daniele Bennati of Italy won his second stage of the Vuelta a España, outracing his countrymen Paolo Bettini and Alessandro Petacchi in the final yards in Talavera de la Reina. Denis Menchov of Russia kept his overall lead by 2 minutes 1 second.

Jörg Jaksche of Germany, the first rider to admit using blood doping prepared by a Spanish doctor in the Operation Puerto scandal, was barred for a year by the Austrian cycling federation. Just before the start of this year’s Tour de France, Jaksche, 30, who lives in Austria, admitted he had used performance enhancers since 1997, and blood doping prepared by the Spanish doctor Eufemiano Fuentes since 2005.

The two Women’s World Cup matches scheduled for yesterday were postponed for a day because of a typhoon. The Canada-Australia Group C match in Chengdu, China, and the China-New Zealand Group D match in Tianjin will both be played today. That will allow them to be played simultaneously with the other final group matches set for today — Norway vs. Ghana in Group C and Brazil vs. Denmark in Group D.All four games are critical and will determine which four teams advance to the quarterfinals. Of the eight teams, only Ghana has no chance to advance.
The man who lighted the pyrotechnics that caused a fire that killed 100 people in a Rhode Island nightclub in 2003 was granted parole on Wednesday.
A defense lawyer asked a federal jury to look beyond what she described as fear-mongering against a Muslim charity the government has accused of financing the terrorist group Hamas.
The legislation, opposed by the White House, would significantly expand the federal program that assists the insurance industry in the event of a major terrorist attack.

The recent uproar over stealing signals reminded us that more pitchers seem to be holding their glove in front of their face when they talk to their catcher or manager -- presumably to prevent adept lip-readers on opposing teams from gathering information. The glove-as-mask tactic has made the mound resemble Halloween at Rawlings. The Yankees’ Andy Pettitte becomes almost completely faceless -- except for a pair of peering eyes -- when he lifts his glove up toward his pulled-down cap. But using the glove as a shield apparently has other purposes, too. The Times’s Tyler Kepner tells us that former Yankee Scott Proctor performed this action more than anyone he can remember -- because the lip-reader he feared the most was his wife. It seems Proctor’s wife didn’t like seeing him spew expletives on the mound when he pitched poorly. So he reflexively put his glove in front of his mouth to hide his expletives, and then just kept doing it. And remembering Proctor’s early struggles with New York, it’s easy to understand why his words weren’t family friendly.

In “Outlaw DNA” (PLAY, June 2007), Gretchen Reynolds wrote perhaps the first in-depth article in the United States about the allure and the perils of illegal gene therapy in sports, including the possibility that athletes might use genetic modifications to create “super-knees.” The perils, at least, were underscored this week, during hearings in Illinois into the death of a 36-year-old woman who’d received experimental gene therapy to treat her arthritic knee. Doctors don’t yet know whether the treatment contributed to her death, and the genetic approach was different from the one Reynolds examined. Still, given the mindset of cheating athletes, Reynolds doesn’t expect them to be deterred by the news.

(CBS) SURVIVOR: CHINA In this, the 15th installment of the reality series, 16 Americans get jostled around in downtown Shanghai before moving to a mountaintop temple for a Buddhist ceremony in which they are told to leave all their possessions behind. The castaways are then divided into two teams — Fei Long, or Flying Dragon, above, and Zhan Hu, or Fighting Tiger — and marooned on separate islands in the Zhelin Reservoir in the south-central province of Jiang Xi with nothing but their clothes. The rest of the season is devoted to finding “hidden immunity idols” that are located in plain sight, kidnapping members of the opposing tribe and, of course, trying to capture the $1 million prize. Contestants include Ashley Massaro, a professional wrestler; Jean-Robert Bellande, a poker player; and Amanda Kimmel, a beauty queen.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) — Following is the 56-to-44 roll call vote by which the Senate refused to consider an amendment that would have required troops spend as much time at home training with their units as they spend deployed in Iraq or Afghanistan. On this vote, a “yes” vote was a vote in favor of an amendment and a “no” vote was a vote against it. Supporters fell four votes shy of the 60 they needed to bring the amendment up as part of a defense bill. Voting “yes” were 49 Democrats, 6 Republicans and 1 independent. Voting “no” were 0 Democrats, 43 Republicans and 1 independent.

HEILBRUNN--Harriet. Members of the Board and Staff of Dorot extend their deepest sympathies to Helaine Lerner and the entire Heilbrunn family. Harriet, together with her late husband, Robert, embraced Dorot's poor, isolated and hungry elderly through their generous support of Dorot's Home - Delivered Meal Program. We will forever cherish Harriet's love for people of all ages, her own creativity and devotion to the arts, her kindness of spirit, and her resilience. May her family be comforted in their time of loss. Paula Resnick and Phil Silverman, Co-President's Vivian Fenster Ehrlich, Executive Director Dorot Inc.

NESSELSON--Gertrude S., died in Dallas, TX on Sunday September 16, age 85, from the consequences of a stroke. Wife of the late Morton R. Nesselson, Trudy is survived by her children: Barratull and Paul Bronstein. Also surviving are her beloved cousin, Ruth Waldman, and Mrs. Waldman's children: Diane Waldman and Laurel Salend. A Memorial service will be held on Monday October 8, at the Sparkman Hillcrest Funeral Home (Dallas) at 10am. Contributions may be made to any institution or charity serving medical needs.

TENNIS players who want to increase their speed or agility on the court choose lighter sneakers. Speed shoes, as they are sometimes called, weigh about quarter-pound less than most high-performance footwear and can minimize fatigue during a long match. ''Every ounce at the foot, is like a pound at the hip,'' said David Sharnoff, a podiatrist in Shelton, Conn., who has advised players on the Women's Tennis Association Tour. Lightweight shoes, he said, lessen stress on ''lower extremity joints.''

WARREN--June Peel Willock, actress and wife of the late William C. Warren, Dean of Columbia Law School, died September 5. The Columbia Law School community mourns her passing. Born in England, she came to the U.S. in 1945 after marrying William Warren. She worked in radio at CBS and in early live TV including ''The Jackie Gleason Show.'' With Dean Warren, she spurred development and raised money for scholarships and a new Columbia Law School building, William and June Warren Hall, dedicated to them in 1998. A Columbia Law School scholarship is also given in her name. She is survived by her sons Robert P. Warren and William L. Warren; a daughter, Larissa W. Gibson and her husband, W. David; and four grandchildren, Robin P.P. Warren, Linneen C. Warren, Leslie C. Gibson and Kathleen J. Gibson. Dean Warren died in 2000. A memorial service will be held September 30, 2007, 3:00pm, at the West Side Presbyterian Church, Monroe Ave., Ridgewood, NJ. Dean David M. Schizer, Lucy G. Moses, Professor of Law Columbia Law School

GITTIS--Howard. The partners, counsel, associates and staff of the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison LLP express profound sorrow at the death of Howard Gittis, Vice Chairman of MacAndrews & Forbes Holdings Inc. Howard was our client and beloved friend. His joyful personality and sincere interest in all of those who worked with him will be greatly missed. We express our deepest sympathy to all members of his family. GITTIS--Howard. From the Schaffel family to all of the Gittis children and grandchildren. We couldn't have a better second family if we tried. Hope to spend the rest of the summers with you. Sorry for the great loss. Love Bill, Nancy and Alex GITTIS--Howard. The Board of Directors and management of Jones Apparel Group, Inc. express our deepest regrets at the passing of Howard Gittis, our Presiding Director and a member of our Board of Directors for 15 years. Howard's contributions to our Company were immensely valued, and his advice and guidance will be very much missed by those of us who had the privilege to work with him. We offer our heartfelt condolences to his family and associates. Wesley R. Card, President and Chief Executive Officer Jones Apparel Group, Inc. GITTIS--Howard. The family and friends of Howard Gittis mourn his passing on September 17th in New York City. Born in 1934 in Philadelphia, Howard Gittis is a graduate of the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania and Penn's Law School. He spent 25 years at Wolf, Block, Schorr and Solis-Cohen where he had served as the Chairman of the Executive Committee. Howard joined MacAndrews & Forbes in 1985, where he was Vice Chairman and Chief Administrative Officer until his death on September 17th. He was a loving father to Caroline Werther, Hope Sheft, Marjorie Katz and Emily Lambert Gittis, loving brother to Lenore Gittis, and loving grandfather to Samuel, Maxwell, Miles, Elijah, Sophie, Joshua and Henry. He is also survived by Sondra Gittis and Lynette King Gittis. Contributions in his honor can be made to the Howard Gittis Endowed Scholarship For Achievement and Excellence at Central High School, Philadelphia, The University of Pennsylvania, and Temple University. GITTIS--Howard. Dear Howard, summer camp is over and it's time to hang up our tennis rackets, store the golf clubs and put away the swim suits. I have loved every summer for 20 years, unfortunately for us camp will never open again. I will miss you and the great times we had. Your doubles tennis partner, Bill Schaffel

ROMANOFF--Theodore. Beloved son of Janet Romanoff, died as a result of a terrible accident, age 32, in Florida at the end of August. He joins his father Prince Nikita for whom he cared tenderly after his massive stroke and who died May 3, 2007. May the angels watch over them both. Theo was gentle, kind and a loving soul. He cherished everything in nature and took great care not to inflict harm on any living thing. Theo dreamed of becoming a teacher and studied Classics and Egyptian and ancient languages at Columbia University and at Brown University, where he earned a M.A. with honors. He was also close to his Russian heritage, his father being a Russian author and historian. 40-days memorial service is planned for October 3rd at Frank Campbell's in NY.

David Rockwell, the designer behind the dramatic interiors of the Manhattan restaurants Nobu 57 and Country, has created a dramatic line of wallcoverings for Maya Romanoff, a manufacturer of surfacing materials. His Stitched patterns are made of hand-dyed paper with lines and organic curves sewn into it; the vinyl Double Take appears to change texture as you move about the room; and the Blanket wallcoverings (about $130 to $200 a yard), above, are a feltlike wool blend with ''the warmth and calming quality of a favorite blanket,'' Mr. Rockwell said. ''It's a surprising combination of comfort and glamour, and wraps a room and its inhabitants in a soothing embrace.'' Information: (773) 465-6909 or mayaromanoff.com. TIM McKEOUGH

On Sept. 28 and 29, the Museum of Modern Art will hold a symposium in conjunction with the exhibition ''Lost Vanguard: Soviet Modernist Architecture, 1922-32'' to discuss efforts to preserve Russia's long-neglected 20th-century masterpieces, like Vladimir Shukhov's 1922 Shabolovka Radio Tower, below left, and Konstantin Melnikov and V. I. Kurochkin's 1936 Gosplan Garage, below right. Barry Bergdoll, the chief curator of architecture and design at MoMA, will lead the symposium, and panelists include Clementine Cecil, co-founder of the Moscow Architecture Preservation Society, and Sergey Gordeev, a Russian lawmaker who is president of the Russian Avantgarde Foundation. Information: moma.org/thinkmodern. CHRISTOPHER MASON

HARRISON--Pauline Louise duPont, died September 11 in New York City. Mrs. Harrison was a long-time trustee of the Winterthur Museum and Planned Parenthood of New York City and was a Silver Life Master of the American Contract Bridge League. A memorial service will be held September 29, at 2pm, at St. James Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Ave. Instead of flowers, the family requests that contributions be sent to Planned Parenthood of New York City or Winterthur Museum.

BRENNAN--John Joseph, Sr., a longtime resident of Manhasset, NY, died suddenly September 18. He was 83. Eileen, his loving wife of 59 years, his sister, 10 children, their spouses, 24 grandchildren, two great-grandsons, a brother-in-law and numerous nieces, nephews and cousins survive him. He was born October 11, 1923, in New York City, third of William R. and Margaret Healy Brennans six children. Raised in Neponsit, he went to St. Francis de Sales, Brooklyn Prep, Holy Cross College and Fordham Law School. He joined the family business Brennan and Sloan, Inc., a concrete contracting firm. In his long career he worked on many New York City landmarks, including the UN, the Citicorp and McGraw Hill buildings, CBS headquarters and the Jacob Javits Convention Center. He was past-president of the Building Trades Employers Association. He married Eileen Fitzgerald on July 10, 1948. They moved to Manhasset in 1957, where they raised their 10 children. A parishioner of the Church of St. Mary in Manhasset, he was a member of the Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick of the City of New York. He is survived by his wife, Eileen, of Manhasset; sister, Sr. Beatrice Brennan RSCJ, of Albany; daughters Eileen Ann Brennan of Kent, NY; Beatrice Wall (Robert) of Lloyd Harbor, NY and Virginia Waechter (Jim) of Nashville; and sons John Jr. (Joan) of Ardmore, PA; Edward (Julia) of Sea Cliff, NY, Michael (Lisa) of Manhasset, Stephen (Patricia) of Irvington, NY, Peter (Bernadette) of Bronxville NY, Thomas of Philadelphia and William (Margaret) of Waterloo, Belgium and Yorktown Heights, NY; brother-in-law Michael F. Armstrong, of New York; grandchildren, Nell (Ted) Timmer, Mary and Kate Ogorzaly; Claire, John, Nora, Ned, Billy, Michael, Lauren, Carrie, Jack, Fiona, Anna Rose, Eliza, Molly, Elizabeth, Kevin, Catherine and James Brennan, and Robert, Kevin, Patrick and Jack Wall, and great-grandsons Henry and Jasper Timmer. Visiting at Fairchild Sons Inc. of Manhasset Thursday and Friday 2-4pm and 7-9pm Funeral Mass Saturday 10am at St. Marys Church in Manhasset.

An exhibition of recent work by the Italian architect and designer Ettore Sottsass opened last night at the new Friedman Benda gallery in Chelsea. Mr. Sottsass, now 90 years old, is perhaps best known as the founder of Memphis, the Milanese design group that produced brightly colored postmodern furniture, lighting and ceramics in the 1980s. This collection, completed since 2005, includes colorful glassworks, glued and wired together, and large sculptural cabinets made of acrylic, aluminum and tropical wood. Cabinet No. 78, above, is painted ash; No. 79, top, is sycamore and zebra wood. Through Oct. 27, 515 West 26th Street (10th Avenue), (212) 239-8700 or friedmanbenda.com. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

GERRY--Martha Farish. The Board and Staff of United Hospital Fund are deeply saddened by the loss of an extraordinary woman, wise and generous leader, and dear friend. Her relationship with the Fund began during WWII when she joined the ranks of women volunteering to help alleviate the unprecedented shortage of medical personnel, raise the image of hospitals, and provide financial support. During her almost 30 years as a member of the Fund's board, she served as Vice Chairman and then Honorary Director. She cofounded the Fund's Tribute to Hospital Trustees in 1991, which continues as one of New York's premier health care events. Her wisdom, candor, and unassuming ways set her apart as one of the Fund's most caring, committed, and effective leaders. We extend our deepest condolences to her children and to the Farish and Gerry families. J. Barclay Collins II, Chairman James R. Tallon, Jr. President GERRY--Martha Farish. The Trustees, Physicians and Staff of New York-Presbyterian Hospital are deeply saddened by the passing of our dear friend Martha Farish Gerry. A NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital Life Trustee, Mrs. Gerry was an enthusiastic and generous supporter of the Hospital for more than forty years. She was elected Trustee of the Presbyterian Hospital in 1965. As Honorary Chairman of the Steering Committee for the building campaign for Morgan Stanley Children's Hospital, her leadership and generosity helped open the doors to this world-class facility in 2003. Her important contributions impacted numerous areas, including neonatal care, medical ethics and Hospital modernization. Mrs. Gerry leaves an outstanding legacy of stewardship and benevolence. We join with all those who knew her in mourning her loss. Our deepest condolences are extended to Mrs. Gerry's family and friends. John Mack Chairman Board of Trustees Herbert Pardes, M.D. President & CEO NY-Presbyterian Hospital GERRY--Martha Farish/d. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory's Board of Trustees, faculty, and administration are saddened at the passing of Martha Farish Gerry. Mrs. Gerry was a generous supporter of the research, educational initiatives, infrastructure, and programs of Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory for nearly two decades. As a member of the Board of Trustees of the Laboratory from 1991, Mrs. Gerry served as Secretary of the Board from 1997 to 2000, and thereafter as an Honorary Trustee. Her outstanding service and enthusiasm were valued by everyone at Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory. To her family and her many friends, we express our deepest sympathy. Eduardo G. Mestre, Board Chairman Bruce Stillman, President James D. Watson, Chancellor W. Dillaway Ayres, Chief Operating Officer GERRY--Martha F., of Monticello, FL on September 17, 2007 in her 89th year. Beloved wife of the late Edward H. Mother of Libbie F., Cornelia Corbett, Martha Townley, and William F. Grandmother of Jennie Merovick, Laura Suski, Heather Corbett, Cornelia Corbett, Alyda Corbett, Richard Corbett, Edward, and Serena. Great-grandmother of five. Service St. John's of Lattingtown, Monday, September 24, 2007 at 11am. Private interment for family and close friends at Pinckney Hill, FL. In lieu of flowers, donations to: Family & Children's Association: 100 East Old Country Rd., Mineola, NY 11501 or National Museum of Racing & Hall of Fame: 191 Union Ave., Saratoga Springs, NY 12866 or Tall Timbers Research Station: 13093 Henry Beadel Dr., Tallahassee, FL 32312.

In a city of millions, where many live in small apartments, well-priced, scaled-down home furnishings are always in demand. CB2, a store that carries Crate & Barrel's less expensive furniture and accessories, is scheduled to open its first New York location, in lower SoHo, in late October. At 8,000 square feet, the store will have merchandise for every room in the house, including tableware that looks much like Crate & Barrel's and hand-tufted wool rugs like the 5-by-8-foot Dots Rug ($299), above. Some items may look familiar to shoppers, since CB2 has had a Web site for several years, but until now there have been only two stores, both in Chicago. CB2, 451 Broadway (Grand Street), cb2.com. MARIANNE ROHRLICH Good deals and secret sources may be reported to rohrlich@nytimes.com.

For details, see www.parsippanyfuneral.com. Memorial donations in Carolee's memory may be made to the Carol G. Simon Cancer Center at Morristown Memorial Hospital or Susan G. Komen for the Cure North Jersey.

The Philadelphia Phillies could not make it two extra-inning victories in a row. Shigeru Ban, the Paris-based Japanese architect, seems to favor architecture that provides a raw experience. Two years ago, New Yorkers lined up to hike through shipping containers he stacked on a Hudson River pier as a mobile art cathedral for Gregory Colbert's majestic animal photography. And who can forget his Tokyo apartment with its exterior walls made of flapping white curtains? Now Mr. Ban, right, has returned to Manhattan's West Side with a design for a condominium on 19th Street near 11th Avenue that can be thrown open entirely to the elements. The Metal Shutter Houses are nine duplex apartments (ranging in size from a 1,950-square-foot three-bedroom to a 3,180-square-foot four-bedroom penthouse with three terraces, above right) encased in perforated metal shutters that operate exactly like the rolling grates of the Chelsea galleries and Korean delis that inspired them. Duplex owners will be able to mechanically adjust their own shutters, and inside each apartment, a 20-foot window wall will pivot open, above left, getting these few Manhattanites as close to California living as they might possibly dream of being. That feeling will no doubt be reinforced by Frank Gehry's IAC headquarters just feet away on the lot next door.

MITCHELL--Timothy A., Ph.D., February 17, 1927-September 18, 2007. Beloved husband of the late Julie Zuback Mitchell, beloved brother of Catherine Krein, Theresa Crider, and the late John Mitchell, beloved uncle and beloved friend. A veteran of World War II, poet and author of several philosophical books; he earned a B.A. from St. Francis College in Brooklyn, an M.A. and a Master and Doctorate of Philosophy from St. John's University in Brooklyn. Dr. Mitchell was President of the ''Pro Ecclesia Foundation'' and Editor and Publisher of ''Pro Ecclesia Magazine.'' He received numerous awards for his work as a Catholic professor, theologian and philosopher. For funeral information call Redden's Funeral Home, 325 West 14th Street, NYC, 212242-1456. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the St. Veronica's Restoration Fund, 149 Christopher Street, NYC 10014.

Rudolph W. Giuliani’s leadership on 9/11 has become the central thrust of his campaign for the presidency. In a detailed front-page examination of the former mayor’s performance during and after the World Trade Center attack, Michael Powell describes Mr. Giuliani’s memorable words and presence of mind that day, but also the lingering questions over the adequacy of the city’s emergency preparations, the advice the mayor received from a psychologist on how to counsel a city in shock, and Mr. Giuliani’s ill-fated bid to extend his term for three months, convinced that he had become irreplaceable. A video about Mr. Giuliani’s performance on 9/11 accompanies the article.

On Long Island beaches, the typical identifiable flying objects are gulls and flies, but this time of year beachgoers are beset with flutters of orange and black that drift southward in swarms.For the next couple of weeks the shoreline is awash with monarch butterflies traveling the thousands of miles south to warmer climates in Mexico and other places for the winter. Boaters and fishermen report seeing swarms flying over the waterways, and beach users watch them flit over the sand and cavort in the dune brush.

Fulfilling a campaign promise, Gov. Eliot Spitzer announced today that residents will be able to apply for state driver’s licenses without regard to immigration status. Applicants for driver’s licenses will no longer be required to provide a Social Security number or show that they are eligible for one. Instead, they will be allowed to provide foreign passports, previous state driver’s licenses and “other valid and verifiable documents” to prove their identity.

Walking around Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge has a way of taking you by surprise, rising up improbably tall in the corner of your eye when you’re looking for something else. The 690-foot-high structure is visible in the distance from miles away, of course (I’ve noticed it from Downtown Brooklyn as well as the top of the Empire State Building recently), so seeing it looming so close can be jarring if you’re not used to it.Bay Ridge residents, though, are used to it: The bridge has been a fixture in the consciousness of the neighborhood since even before it was built from 1959 to 1964. Brooklynites’ problems this summer with construction on the bridge backing up traffic for blocks around are just the latest episode in a long love-hate relationship between the span and its neighbors.

AIRPORTS: The Washington area is served by three airports: Washington Dulles International, which is about 30 miles (50 kilometers) to the west, Baltimore/Washington International Thurgood Marshall Airport, or BWI, 30 miles to the northeast, and by far the most convenient (but without international service) Ronald Reagan National Airport, just across the Potomac River from downtown Washington (flying in to National at night, with a clear and splendid view of the Washington Monument, White House and Capitol, can be a thrill).

AIRPORTS: Most visitors' first glimpse of Turkey will take place as they fly over the sprawl of Istanbul's seemingly endless apartment blocks and neighborhoods dotted with mosques before landing at Istanbul Ataturk Airport. Named for the founder of the modern Turkish republic, this modern facility is pretty easy to negotiate upon arrival. Many Westerners needing a visa can buy one at the airport, just prior to going through passport control. (Be sure to check in your home country first!) It's a short walk to the baggage carousels and the duty free shops. If you have friends who live in town, ask them before hand if you can pick something up here for them: alcohol, perfumes and, yes, the ever popular cigarettes, are much cheaper here. One annoyance is that the luggage carts are not free of charge as they are in many European airports. Who has Turkish lira coins at this point? Once you have your bags and your duty free treats, proceed to the exit. Yes, there is a customs desk, but controls are few and far between. Once in the main concourse, you will find ATMs for getting local currency and even a Starbucks and a Gloria Jeans in case you just simply cannot wait for a dose of caffeine. Please note that departing passengers really do need to get here 2 hours before their flights. The lines can be mind-bogglingly long, there are several checkpoints before reaching your plane and the shopping opportunities get better on your way to the gate.
