The Board, residents and staff of 30 East 72nd Street mourn the passing of Andre Emmerich, our dear friend and neighbor. We'll miss his wise counsel, elegance, grace and love of life. We send our condolences to his wife, Susanne, and the rest of his family. EMMERICH--Andre, in his 83rd year, died peacefully at home in New York City on September 25, having suffered a stroke after a fiveyear battle with Lewy Body Disease. He is survived by his beloved wife Susanne, his loving sons, Adam (Pamela), Toby (Julie) and Noah, their mother Constance, by four grandchildren, Sarah, Rebecca, Benjamin and Cosy, by his sister Nicole (L. William) Teweles of Milwaukee, and his extended family. Born in Germany, and raised in Holland, Andre Emmerich came to New York City with his family in 1940 at the age of 15. He graduated from Oberlin College at 19. In 1954 he founded the Andre Emmerich Gallery in New York City. The gallery represented leading colorfield artists including Helen Frankenthaler, Hans Hofmann, Morris Louis and Jules Olitski, and sculptors such as Anthony Caro. Emmerich also pioneered connoisseurship and exhibition of Pre-Columbian art in the United States, and exhibited Greek and Roman art. He established Top Gallant sculpture park in Quaker Hill, a showcase for large-scale outdoor sculpture. Emmerich twice served as president of the Art Dealers Association of America, and was a founding member of the American Association of Dealers in American, Oriental and Primitive Art, and a member of the IRS Art Advisory Panel. Emmerich was a scholar and frequent lecturer and prolific author, including his books ''Art Before Columbus'' and ''Sweat of the Sun and Tears of the Moon --Gold and Silver in Pre-Columbian Art'', and many articles in Art News, The Wall Street Journal, and The New Criterion, among others. The funeral and internment will be private. A memorial will take place at a later date. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to Incontinentia Pigmenti International Foundation (IPIF), 30 East 72nd Street, NYC 10021, or Weill Cornell Department of Neurology, In honor of Andre Emmerich, Memory Disorders Program, 1300 York Avenue, NYC 10021, attn: Tom Horton. EMMERICH--Andre, was one of the original Board members and benefactors of The Fields Sculpture Park and Art Omi. His relentless passion for art was an inspiration not only to our organization but to countless others who benefited from his knowledge and wisdom. He will be deeply missed. Francis Greenburger and the entire Board and Staff of Omi International Arts Center

The photo below not only shows who was happier after the qualifying session on Saturday - Lewis Hamilton who scored the pole or Fernando Alonso who finished second - but it also tells us in a subtle way which driver fits in better at the McLaren Mercedes team. Hamilton's short McLaren hair fits in perfectly with the company image and work ethic. While Alonso instantly became cleaner cut with his very first appearance testing the McLaren last December - after years worth of the grunge image cultivated at Renault - his hair by comparison to Hamilton's is infinitely less the McLaren look. We should have seen from the beginning the significance of this sign, as Alonso's rebel tendencies were clearly there to be read from the outset: My hair will be cut thus far, but no further.

Alexander Grischuk of Russia outplayed Viswanathan Anand of India in the 13th round of the world championship tournament in Mexico City but then missed a probable win in a rook and pawn ending, allowing Anand to escape with a draw. Anand's two main rivals, Boris Gelfand of Israel and Vladimir Kramnik of Russia drew, so Anand preserved his one point lead going into the 14th and final round. Anand is now assured of at least a tie for first place. Only Gelfand can catch him and only if he wins and Anand loses tomorrow's final game. More information about the tournament and the standings can be found at the official Web site of the championship.

Senator John McCain said in an interview that his Christian faith is probably of better spiritual guidance than that of a Muslim candidate for president.
Greg Winter and Jim Yardley discuss China’s pollution problems.
A bomber wearing an Afghan military uniform approached a bus full of Afghan soldiers on their way to work and detonated a belt of explosives.
A Taliban bomber killed 27 Afghan troops and an unknown number of civilians in an attack on an army bus in the capital, Kabul, government officials said.
Linebacker Ben Moffitt and defensive end George Selvie led the defensive charge that rattled West Virgina’s offense, which committed six turnovers.
If confirmed as attorney general, Judge Michael B. Mukasey will recuse himself from any matters involving  Rudolph W. Giuliani, the White House said.
Hillary Rodham Clinton said Friday that every child born in the United States should receive a $5,000 “baby bond” from the government to help pay for college or buying a house.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28 (AP) — Now that the Philadelphia Phillies have reached first place, they look as if they like it there.
Brendan Shanahan scored twice to lift the Rangers over the Islanders in a preseason game that lacked the star power and brawling of their previous matchup.

Constitutional amendments that would limit negative campaigns and profoundly change the rules for Mexican elections were assured of passage late Thursday when a majority of state legislatures ratified them.
Britain’s large academic union said that it would be illegal for its members to boycott Israeli academic institutions.
Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Wednesday about digital music sales at Amazon.com misidentified the name of its online store. It is Amazon MP3, not MP3.

An article on Wednesday about an accusation that a 1906 landscape painting by Gustav Klimt owned by the cosmetics magnate Leonard A. Lauder was looted during World War II misidentified the subject of an unfinished Klimt portrait. It portrays Amalie Zuckerkandl, a great-aunt of Georges Jorisch, the man who contends that the 1906 work was looted from his grandmother’s property; it is not of Amalie Redlich, Mr. Jorisch’s grandmother.

A picture caption with the continuation of a front-page article on Thursday about the coming documentary “Expelled: No Intelligence Allowed” misidentified the scientist shown. He is Peter Atkins, a chemistry professor at Oxford University — not Richard Dawkins, an evolutionary biologist at Oxford. (Both men were interviewed for the film.).
Alfonso Soriano’s leadoff home run snapped Chicago out of its doldrums as the Cubs clinched the National League Central title.

Because of an editing error, a report by The Associated Press in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Thursday about the winner of the 2007 Rea Award for the Short Story misstated his surname in one reference. He is Stuart Dybek, not Rea.

Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about Jin Lei, a Chinese pharmaceutical executive who has been charged with felony smuggling and drug trafficking, referred incorrectly to a government affidavit that was filed in the case. It was filed in a Federal District Court electronic filing system, not an online Food and Drug Administration database. (The affidavit was by a special agent of the F.D.A.) Also because of an editing error, the article misstated the date Mr. Jin was charged. It was on Sept. 19 — not on Monday, which was the day the affidavit was unsealed.
Serbs and Kosovo Albanians held their first direct talks at the United Nations on the future of the province.
The High & Low Finance column in Business Day yesterday misstated the size of the stock loan market. It is more than $700 billion, not million.
A plan by developers for a 70-story office tower at the edge of Mexico City’s historic Chapultepec Park was shelved in the face of neighborhood opposition and threatened lawsuits.

An art review on Sept. 18 about “The Age of Rembrandt: Dutch Painting in the Metropolitan Museum of Art” misstated the ranking of the museum’s inventory of Rembrandt paintings. The Met, the National Gallery in London and the Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg, Russia, say they each own 20 Rembrandt paintings; the Met does not exclusively have the largest number outside Amsterdam.

A school janitor who attacked offices in London and other parts of Britain with a letter bomb campaign in January and February in which eight people were wounded was sentenced to a prison term of at least five years.
BOSTON, Sept. 28 (AP) — The 12-year wait for the Boston Red Sox is over. They’re the American League East champions.
Up to 15,000 opponents of President Mikheil Saakashvili jammed the center of Tbilisi, the capital, to protest the arrest of the former defense minister.

A picture caption with the continuation of a front-page article on Thursday about the coming documentary “Expelled: No Intelligence Allowed” misidentified the scientist shown. He is Peter Atkins, a chemistry professor at Oxford University — not Richard Dawkins, an evolutionary biologist at Oxford. (Both men were interviewed for the film.).

Because of an editing error, a sports article in some editions on Tuesday about the fight-filled preseason hockey game between the Rangers and the Islanders misstated the significance of the game. It was the first game in which the Islanders’ Chris Simon and the Rangers’ Ryan Hollweg both played since Simon received a 25-game suspension for hitting Hollweg with his stick on March 8. It was not the teams’ first meeting since the incident. (The teams played twice last season after the incident, but Simon was suspended for those games.).
Alan Webb, America’s best young middle-distance runner, has one more race this year: Saturday’s Fifth Avenue Mile.

An engine on an American Airlines jet caught fire during a flight to Chicago, forcing the pilots to return to St. Louis and evacuate the aircraft on the runway. There were no reports of injuries aboard the MD-80 jet, said Jeff Lea, a spokesman for Lambert-St. Louis International Airport. The National Transportation Safety Board is investigating.
A court in Stuttgart, Germany, cleared the defending champion Paolo Bettini to compete in tomorrow’s world championship road race despite Bettini’s refusal to sign an anti-doping pledge.

A new settlement restricts the use of pepper spray on young offenders in the custody of the Texas Youth Commission, officials said. The deal rescinds a commission order that allowed pepper spray to be used to subdue juveniles before other forms of restraint are applied. The settlement comes in a suit originally filed on behalf of three youths.

The trainer Larry Jones was not giving away any secrets when he said Hard Spun would try to lead all the way in today’s Kentucky Cup Classic at Turfway Park. But this time he hopes Hard Spun will be able to hold off Street Sense and reverse the order of finish in the Kentucky Derby.

The Oklahoma Court of Criminal Appeals upheld the conviction of a former judge who was convicted of exposing himself by using a sexual device while presiding over trials. The former District Court judge, Donald D. Thompson, was sentenced in 2006 to four years in prison on four counts of indecent exposure, and his conviction was upheld Thursday. He spent almost 23 years on the bench and served as a state legislator before retiring from the court in 2004.

A student fired shots inside a high school and held three students hostage for more than an hour before being taken into custody, the authorities said. No one was injured. The 17-year-old student, whose name was not released because of his age, initially took about 30 students hostage at Las Plumas High School in Oroville. He quickly released most of them, but held three girls for about an hour, said Capt. Jerry Smith of the Butte County Sheriff’s Department.
George Hincapie has signed a two-year contract with T-Mobile. Hincapie, a 34-year-old American, helped Lance Armstrong win all of his record seven Tour de France victories between 1999 and 2005.

A neighbor of a 6-year-old girl who was found hanged in her family’s garage in Corsicana has been charged with sexual assault and capital murder, officials said. The body of Hanna Mack was found on Sept. 10 by her mother. The neighbor, Shaun E. Arender, 19, left, was linked to the scene by DNA evidence, said Chief Deputy Mike Cox of the Navarro County Sheriff’s Department. Mr. Arender was already in jail on unrelated burglary and drug charges.

Tina Thompson scored 14 points to help the United States defeat Canada, 85-37, yesterday and secure the top seed in Group B at the FIBA Americas women’s tournament in Valdivia, Chile. The Americans will play the second-place finisher in Group A in the semifinals tonight.

Jimmie Johnson won his second consecutive pole and the 12th of his career when he took his No. 48 Chevrolet around the 1.5-mile tri-oval at Kansas Speedway at a top speed of 175.063 m.p.h. Ryan Newman’s Dodge qualified second for tomorrow’s Lifelock 400 at 174.893 m.p.h., but the car failed inspection because the roof was too low.
Shane Mosley voiced his frustration with a report that accused him of using designer steroids as part of a doping regimen before a 2003 fight against Oscar De La Hoya.

Protecting Michael B. Mukasey, a retired federal judge, cost taxpayers an estimated $28 million over more than seven years — or $10,000 a day — even as Justice Department agencies argued about how much of a threat he faced. Now nominated to become the nation’s 81st attorney general, Mr. Mukasey was given United States Marshals as bodyguards while presiding over a high-profile terror trial as a Federal District Court judge in Manhattan. Mr. Mukasey kept the protections until 2005, nine years after the trial ended.

England, the defending champion, defeated Tonga, 36-20, to advance to the quarterfinals of the World Cup in Paris. England faced the prospect of becoming the first defending champion to fail to reach the quarterfinals. But after a dominating performance, the English will play Australia in Marseille on Oct. 6 in a rematch of the 2003 final.

The authorities identified a man they want to question in connection with a homemade videotape showing a young girl, believed to be 4 or 5, being sexually assaulted. The girl, believed to be 4 or 5, has been located by sheriff’s officials and is safe with relatives, an investigator said. The man, Chester A. Stiles, 37, whose last known address was Las Vegas, remains at large, said Sheriff Tony DeMeo of Nye County.
A North Jersey mayor and his wife have been indicted of extorting gifts and cash that paid for gambling, plastic surgery and a dog.
Unlike other states, Texas is risking a confrontation with the Supreme Court by choosing to proceed with lethal injections after the court stayed one execution.
Experts urged the Food and Drug Administration to ban over-the-counter, multisymptom cough and cold medicines for children under 6.
Rhetorically, President Bush has moved forward on global warming. In terms of substance, he remains as isolated as ever.
Omesh Hiraman was ordered by a judge on Friday to submit to a psychiatric examination to assess his fitness to stand trial.
The State Department’s director of management policy is leaving for Iraq this weekend to lead a team to conduct a broad review of the use of private security contractors.
China’s rulers need to know that the world is watching to see whether they will use their influence to stop the killing in Myanmar.
President Bush would rather sacrifice the health of uninsured children than yield an inch of ideological ground.
Iraqis said seven men who were killed in an airstrike in Baghdad on Thursday were civilians, but the American military had a different version of events.
General Motors is hoping the new Chevrolet Malibu will help lure back buyers of family sedans from Japanese rivals.
The former president said that Senator Barack Obama has about as much experience as Mr. Clinton himself did in 1988, the year he decided not to run for the White House.
New York State driver’s licenses should go to residents who have proved their identity — and their ability to drive safely.
The franchiser had been accused by the Justice Department of overseeing the preparation of fraudulent tax returns.
A software update to Apple’s iPhone on Friday disabled third-party applications and rendered iPhones that had been unlocked completely unusable.
Mr. Wirtz was the longtime owner of the Chicago Blackhawks, the National Hockey League franchise controlled by his family for more than half a century.
After it took over 410 department stores, Macy’s tried to wean people off of coupons. Now the chain is backtracking.
Since Sunday, Ned Yost has been ejected from three games and suspended for another while his floundering team has all but played itself out of the National League Central race.
Mr. Noble was a former director of the Museum of the City of New York who earlier exposed three famous works at the Metropolitan Museum of Art as fakes.
Rabbi Shapira, a chief rabbi in Israel for 10 years, was best known for urging soldiers to disobey orders to evacuate the Gaza Strip.
Higher prices, partly due to demand for ethanol made from corn, have helped slash American food aid to its lowest level in a decade.
To a growing chorus of fellow Democrats and others who share many of the New Jersey governor’s goals, he has taken too long to do too little.
Despite their differences, Oregon quarterback Dennis Dixon and New Hampshire quarterback Ricky Santos  have one undeniable link: both have been tutored by Chip Kelly.
President Bush said Friday that major carbon-emitting nations should all set goals for reducing greenhouse-gas emissions, but did not specify what those goals should be.
With time running out for Michigan lawmakers to solve a $1.75 billion gap in the state’s next budget, residents are bracing for a shutdown of some services as early as Monday.
Democrats and their allies mapped out a strategy to override an expected veto of a bipartisan bill providing health insurance for 10 million children, most of them in low-income families.

An important test of the system to defend against long-range ballistic missiles was rated a success on Friday when an interceptor collided with a mock warhead high over the Pacific, Pentagon officials said.
Dr. Rieveschl, a chemical engineer, invented the antihistamine Benadryl.
Marsh & McLennan, the world’s largest insurance broker, won dismissal Friday of almost all of a customer lawsuit that accused the company of colluding with insurers to fix prices.
A day after John Edwards said he had decided to participate in public campaign financing as a matter of principle, his campaign manager appeared to scale back the candidate’s initial commitment.
Dividers intended to make soliciting sex much more difficult will be added to stalls in two men’s rooms at the Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport.
I’m hardly naïve about the existence of police abuse, but there has been a definite move in big cities away from thuggishness toward more effective strategies.
Federal officials said that one crackdown after another had shown how difficult it was to break up the sprawling market for illegal performance-enhancing drugs.
Houston Texans defensive tackle Cedric Killings had been discharged from the hospital about an hour before the emotional reunion.

The institutions that are to close or be merged under an effort to shrink New York’s hospital industry will receive public funds to cover legal costs associated with closing and to pay off debts, state health officials said.
A lawsuit accusing the company founded by Mayor Michael Bloomberg of discriminating against pregnant women could prove embarrassing.
Satellite photographs of rural Myanmar show what seems to be evidence of human rights abuses gathered from space.
Jenna Bush’s first book, “Ana’s Story,” will get a first run of 500,000 copies and a cross-country publicity swing.
An American refugee aid worker accompanying Haitians seeking asylum in Canada was charged by Canadian authorities this week with immigrant trafficking.
The jury in Anucha Browne Sanders’s lawsuit against Madison Square Garden and Isiah Thomas deliberated for seven and a half hours, but did not reach a verdict.
A rare blown save by Mariano Rivera and a Boston victory officially ended New York’s run of nine straight division titles.
As the Mets have lost 10 of their last 14 games and watched a comfortable seven-game bulge vanish, David Wright has been one of their most productive hitters.
Officials said they were seeking ways to persuade nations to cut off lending.
Myanmar’s armed forces appeared to have sealed tens of thousands of protesting monks inside their monasteries, but attacks against bands of demonstrators continued.
Frank Messina’s poetry captures, in its own way, feelings of anguish and fear deep in fellow fans’ hearts.
Jeffrey B. Swartz, the chief executive of Timberland, discusses the challenges to making environmental progress in the shoe industry.
Dr. Nils Stormby sold off his collection of about 4,500 rare and expensive bottles of wine at an auction in Manhattan on Friday.
NetBank Inc., an online bank with $2.5 billion in assets, was shut down by the government on Friday because of an unsustainable level of mortgage defaults.
Describing golden trout — California’s official fresh-water fish — requires reference to the colors on a painter’s palette.

Rudolph W. Giuliani, who has been facing questions about immigration on the campaign trail, said a plan to allow illegal immigrants to obtain driver’s licenses would lead to chaos.
Woody Austin fell face first into the lake along the 14th fairway, but nonetheless helped the International team win four matches to cut the Americans’ lead to 7-5 after two days at Royal Montreal.
An increasingly outgunned Taiwan is quietly pushing ahead with plans to develop missiles that could strike the mainland, defense and security experts say.

A front-page article on Thursday reported on the implications of the newly negotiated contract between General Motors and the United Automobile Workers union, including the impact of its terms on both the company and its unionized employees. Among the provisions was a voluntary employee benefit association, or VEBA, which will hold in trust the money to provide health care benefits to union members. The article said that under previous contracts, the medical benefits were so generous that union members had little incentive to take better care of their health. This unattributed assertion, unsupported by any evidence that personal health habits are influenced by the level of health care coverage, should not have been made.
An August rise in consumer spending and the cooling of a key inflation indicator raised hopes that the economy is still somewhat protected from turmoil in the housing market.
Supporters of the former speaker of the House are planning to begin a “feasibility assessment” of his chances.
Maybe it takes someone whose sense of home has been intensified by distance to understand the logic in leaving Pittsburgh to watch a Steeler game.
The novelist John Grisham has been named in a libel lawsuit filed over a nonfiction best seller he wrote about the 1982 murder of a cocktail waitress.
Nominees for 2008 induction in the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in Cleveland were announced yesterday.
Only two students have been enrolled at the Academy of St. Joseph, which hoped to compete for students this year with some of New York City’s pricier secular schools.
Experts say that the risk of children suffering lead poisoning from playing with a tainted toy isn’t as high as from other possible sources.
A man known as June Bug operates what may well be the only pedicab in Brooklyn.
The deterioration of buildings at the Smithsonian Institution threatens their collections and restricts access to exhibits.
CBS edged past ABC in the ratings Thursday, thanks to an impressive start for the eighth season of “CSI.”
Angela Gheorghiu, the Romanian soprano, was fired by Chicago’s Lyric Opera from her role as Mimi in a production of “La Bohême” that is to open on Monday.
“Musical,” a video project by Dara Friedman, features various people singing show tunes in public parts of Manhattan while a crew discreetly shoots them.
A campaign to change the way electoral votes are apportioned in California in order to benefit the Republicans in 2008 was in turmoil after the resignation of its leader.

A Pennsylvania judge, Stanley R. Ott of the Montgomery County Orphans’ Court, will hear arguments on Oct. 19 by two groups who want him to rescind permission for the financially troubled Barnes Foundation to move its art collection to downtown Philadelphia from its longtime home in Merion, Pa.
The facts are that divorce is down, and today’s marriages are more stable than they have been in decades.

The writer Douglas Brinkley says he will return the advance he received from Penguin Group USA for a biography of Jack Kerouac.

Tanya Rider, who had been missing for more than a week, was found 20 feet down a roadside ravine in a Seattle suburb after the signal from her cellphone led investigators to her.
An American Army sniper was acquitted of murder charges in connection with the deaths of two Iraqi men during the spring.
As Hollywood’s studios rush to shoot movies before contracts with actors and directors expire, strategists for the industry’s writers are considering whether to force a stop to the action.
The team recently signed a lease for a showroom of luxury suites for the new 51,000-seat stadium under construction in the Bronx.

Now in its fourth year, New York Musical Theater Festival addresses the difficulties of mounting a new musical by providing a forum where audiences and producers can view a cross-section of the current crop.
After a tumultuous and brutal August, the stock market is within striking distance of the records it set in July.
The NY Art Book Fair has the slightly unreal feeling of an artists’ project, the artists in this case being its founding directors, Kasia Korczak and Payam Sharifi.
One of the leading lawyers for the inmates at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, is being investigated for allegedly bringing contraband swimsuits and underwear to his clients.
A 30-year-old officer is seeking unspecified monetary damages from the New York Police Department, claiming that he has been ostracized because he is gay.
Daniel Cooperman of Oracle will join Apple to replace Donald J. Rosenberg. Mr. Cooperman is the company’s second general counsel appointment in the past year.
The United States, Britain and France chose unity over speed and agreed to delay until November a United Nations Security Council vote on a third sanctions resolution against Iran.

Naomi Klein essentially accuses Milton Friedman of being the godfather of a Mafia-like gang who have exploited the public disorientation associated with catastrophes and political crises to impose an unwanted free-market ideology on much of the world.
3Com, the computer networking company, said Friday that it had agreed to be acquired by Bain Capital Partners  in an arrangement that also gives a Chinese company a minority stake in the company.
“The Unbecoming Solo,” by Alexandre Roccoli, is the first in a larger project of international residencies at Chez Bushwick called “Force Majeure.”
A ruling removes the last major obstacle for Pakistan’s president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, before the Oct. 6 vote, which he is expected to win.
September’s stock market rally may have made bargains harder to come by, but fund managers say they are still finding some solid prospects at decent values.
There is an elephant in the room at the Brooklyn headquarters of Daptone Records — a skinny, British elephant with an enormous beehive hairdo and a knack for getting her picture in the tabloids.
Despite the hassles of air travel, there are ways to make your trip easier, pay a visit to Dracula’s castle and more.
A federal prosecutor from Gulf Breeze, Fla., was arrested last week after authorities said he arranged with an undercover agent to have sex with a 5-year-old girl.

DANBY--Ken. Renowned Canadian realist artist, passed away September 23, 2007. He is survived by his wife Gillian, brother Marvin and wife Susan, sons Sean and wife Suzanne, Ryan and wife Anne, and Noah and his fiancee Kristanna, his stepdaughter Julie Reid and husband Don Reid, stepson Stefen Elmitt and wife Gillian Elmitt, grandchildren Jocelynand Owen Danby, Cheyne and Perry Reid and Shannon and Stephanie Elmitt. Also survived by sister-in-law Anne McNutt and husband Fred; nephews and nieces Keith Danby, Mark Danby, Sabrina Danby, Jennifer McNutt-Bywater, John McNutt, Kathleen Daniels, Joanna Quarry. Celebration of the Life of Ken Danby, Wednesday, October 10, 2007, 7:00-9:00 pm River Run Centre, Guelph, ON. www.riverrun.ca or www.kendanby.com for more information. MacDonald Stewart Art Centre, Guelph, Ontario will be proudly presenting a collection of Ken Danby's work September 25-December 16, 2007. www.uoguelph.ca/msac/ An endowment fund has been established to honour Ken's memory that will support arts education and charities important to him. Memorial donations can be directed to the Ken Danby Legacy Fund c/o The Guelph Community Foundation, P.O. Box 1311, Guelph, ON N1H 6N6 or online at www.guelphcf.ca. Additional information can be obtained from Wall-Custance Funeral Home and Chapel, 206 Norfolk St., Guelph (www.wallcustance .com or 519-822-0051).

NOON (Nickelodeon) WORLDWIDE DAY OF PLAY In its annual effort to get children off the couch and into motion, Nickelodeon (as well as its sister networks Nicktoons and Nick Games and Sports) will go dark from noon to 3 p.m. The theme continues at 6 p.m. on Nickelodeon with the season finale of ''Let's Just Play Go Healthy Challenge,'' which has followed two 13-year-olds in their efforts to become more fit. We'll see Kenderick, above, compete in a triathlon and April play in her first match with the volleyball team. 8 P.M. (Fox) COPS The granddaddy of reality shows celebrates its longevity with a one-hour 20th-anniversary special, featuring the best high-speed pursuits, domestic disturbances, D.U.I. arrests and, you hope, fat guys running while their pants fall down from the past two decades.

YALOF--Philip. Beloved husband and companion; father of Jed (Barbara), and Clay (Kathy); grandfather; and brother (Herbert, Harvey -deceased). His warmth and generosity touched many. Funeral Services Sunday September 30 at 12:45pm at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

FRIEMAN--Rebecca . The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn with profound sadness the passing of Rebecca Frieman, beloved mother of Adam, whose commitment has strengthened our ability to serve those in need and enriched the Jewish community. Rebecca's dedication to tikkun olam, repairing the world, will continue impacting the lives of millions in New York, in Israel, and around the world as Adam carries on the torch of philanthropy. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Adam; to his wife, Janie; to their children, Jonathan and Eric; and to the entire family. John M. Shapiro, President Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

NOBLE--Joseph. The Museum of the City of New York mourns the passing of Joseph Veach Noble, Director of the Museum 1970-1985. Asserting that the ideal history museum has ''one foot in the present and one foot in the past,'' he produced exhibitions on contemporary issues and introduced multi-media exhibitions to make the institution relevant to all New Yorkers. Susan Henshaw Jones President and Director

SAFFADY--Kathryn Anne , died suddenly and unexpectedly on September 24, 2007. Beloved wife of William Saffady; mother of Stephen Saffady (d. 1972), Michael Saffady, Carolyn Saffady, and Katherine Peters; mother-inlaw of John Peters; grandmother of Austin Coleman, Samantha Saffady, Ione Saffady-Fishman, Beatrix Saffady-Fishman, Vaughan Peters; daughter of Beulah Van Coevering; daughter-in-law of Josephine Saffady; sister of Nicholas Van Coevering and Martin Van Coevering. Much loved and much missed. Funeral services are private.

FLINN--Robert H. , of New York and Vero Beach, FL, formerly of Rye, NY, passed away September 28th, 2007 after a long illness. Husband to Charlotte; father to Leslie Flinn, Colin Flinn, Evan Saucedo and Douglas Flinn; father-in-law to Susan Flinn and Eric Saucedo; grandfather to Jackson Saucedo and Robert G. Flinn. Son of the late Irene and Harry Flinn and friend to many. A life long athlete, Bob Flinn was a basketball star in his youth for Mamaroneck High, Colgate University and in the Navy during the Korean War. He was also a successful entrepreneur and financier. With his father, he owned Flinn Motor Corp. He was founder and president of Eco Leasing Corp. and Flinn Capital Corp. and a developer of Audubon at Naples, Frenchmen's Creek and other successful ventures. A funeral mass will be held at 11am at Resurrection Church in Rye, NY on Wednesday, October 3rd with a reception to follow at Apawamis Club in Rye. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Colgate University in Hamilton, NY or to Catholic Charities.

MITCHELL--Mayer ''Bubba'' . The Board of Directors and staff of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee (AIPAC) are deeply saddened by the passing of our dear friend Mayer ''Bubba'' Mitchell who served as AIPAC President, Chairman of the Board and a member of the organizations national Board of Directors. He will be remembered for his impeccable good judgment, wise counsel, courage and conviction. Bubba Mitchell defined modern American pro-Israel activism, reaching beyond his own state's borders and across party lines to ensure that strong U.S.-Israel ties had bipartisan support throughout the United States. We extend our deepest sympathies and continued friendship to his dear wife Arlene, to their children Richard (Susan) Mitchell, Melinda (Steven) Wertheim, Joy (James) Grodnick, Lisa (Barry) Bukstein, and their eight grandchildren. May his example continue to inspire our community and his memory forever be a guiding light and comfort to those who were blessed to know him.

SPENCE--Donald Pond , Died September 25, 2007, after a short illness in Princeton, NJ. Born February 8, 1926, son to Professor and Mrs. Ralph B. Spence of Teachers College, Columbia University. He is survived by his wife of 56 years, Mary (nee Cross), and four children: Keith and his wife Bonnie of Jacksonville, FL, Sarah and her husband James McGregor of Athens, GA, Laura and her husband Adam Ash of Princeton and Katherine, also of Princeton. Also survived by three grandchildren: Ned McGregor, Nate Ash and Hannah Ash and three stepgrandchildren. He also leaves his sister Carol Spence Muntz and her husband Donald Muntz of Charlottesville, VA. Dr. Spence graduated from the Lincoln School in 1943 and had one semester at Harvard University before joining the military. He served in Europe with the 14th Armored Division from 1944 to 1946. He received his BA from Harvard in 1949 (Class of 1947) and his Ph.D. in Clinical Psychology from Columbia in 1955. From 1954 to 1974 he conducted research and taught at the Research Center for Mental Health of New York University. He graduated from the New York Psychoanalytical Institute as a certified psychoanalyst in 1966. In 1974 he became a Professor of Psychiatry at the Robert Wood Johnson Medical School of the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey (UMDNJ). He retired December 31, 1996. Dr. Spence served on review committees for NIMH and the New York Psychoanalytic Institute, was a Fellow and Division President of the American Psychological Association, and was a member of AAAS, Sigma Xi and Who's Who. He wrote well over 100 articles and book reviews. In 1982, Dr. Spence authored Narrative Truth and Historical Truth, which is now considered a classic text in the field. Two other books followed as well as several translations to other languages. He received many honors and awards, most recently the Lifetime Achievement Award for the Theoretical and Philosophical Division of the American Psychological Association in 2004. In his retirement, he had time in indulge in other pleasures: music, especially the singing voice; woodworking; and the outdoors in every season. Many of his happiest times as an adult had been instilled in him as a child at Camp Treetops in Lake Placid, NY, and the Adirondack Mountains were always his favorite place. In Princeton, he was active with the Senior Resource Center, Habitat for Humanity, Musical Amateurs, Pro Musica, Old Guard, and House II, Communities Without Walls. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to your favorite charity in his name. A Memorial Service will be held in the spring.

DeREGIS--John Joseph , 58, of New York, died August 13, 2007. He is survived by Robert I. Padyjasek, his life partner of 21 years, sister Karin DeRegis, brother/sister-inlaw Richard and Ginger DeRegis, sister-in-law Jeannie DeRegis, sister-in-law Annie DeRegis, all of Syracuse, NY, brother Mark of Los Angeles, and sister/brother-in-law Janis and Craig Woodard of Belle Mead, NJ. He was the son of the late John Morris and Joan Garden DeRegis of Syracuse, NY. He was a coowner of Studio@5 E19 Street, a salon in the Flatiron District of Manhattan. He began his career as a hairstylist upstate in Syracuse and Rochester and was a graduate of the Continental School. He moved to New York in 1970 for Glemby International, teaching styling techniques at their salons around the country. Having worked at Bergdorf Goodman, Saks, and other salons in the city, he opened his own salon 25 years ago in SoHo, where he lived for the last 30 years. His clientele reflected the city that he deeply loved. Interment at Trinity Church Cemetery in Manhattan will be private. Memorial donations in his memory may be made to friendsindeed.org. John was a warm, loving, trusting, sweet and gentle soul, born on Christmas Day; a simple, wonderful man who loved his Italian heritage and his family, good movies and friends, dancing, the sun, the beach, a sparkling swimming pool, baking oatmeal cookies and apple pies, and especially making his clients look their best. He made the world a better place, was loved by all, and will be always in our hearts. Aeternum Vale. Requiescat In Pace.

FINKELMAN--Claire , of Brooklyn Heights, at 82. Civil Rights and Anti-War Activist, Fighter for peace and Justice, Social Worker at St. Francis School for the Deaf. Service, Monday 11:30am at ''Riverside'' 76th and Amsterdam.

An article in The Arts on Wednesday about claims by the heirs of a Dutch Jewish art dealer for restitution of works recovered in Germany after World War II included an incorrect name provided by a lawyer representing the heirs for the dealer's mother, and misstated the year that the dealer, Nathan Katz, left the Netherlands. His mother was Eva Franken Katz, not Lena Pelz Katz, and Nathan Katz left the Netherlands in 1942, not 1941.

RENNERT--Fred , of Boynton Beach, FL, passed away on Monday, September 24th, 2007 after a courageous battle with Gastric Cancer at the age of 82. He was born in Mannheim, Germany on April 2nd, 1925. Fred was a shining light to all who knew him. During World War II he was a prisoner of war in Germany and saved his company from certain death since he spoke fluent German. He was a recipient of the Purple Heart and Bronze Star Medals for his heroic service. He most certainly exemplified the men in the book. ''The Greatest Generation''. Fred was always thankful he could return from the war and live a full and productive life, and that he did. He lived life to the fullest in every sense of the word and to all those he met he brought the brightest smile. Fred Rennert, beloved husband of Corinne, his wife of 57 wonderful years, loving father to his daughter Debra of Delray Beach, FL and son Richard of Tarrytown, NY. Devoted grandfather to Scott, Amanda, Sara and Julia, and brother to Esther. He will be missed ALWAYS.

KULESZA--Dr. Edward S . With great sadness we mourn the sudden and tragic death of our esteemed colleague and friend Edward Kulesza, M.D. Loving husband, father, brother, son, friend, mentor and so much more. As a physician at Coler Goldwater Memorial Hospital since 1988, he was never too busy to help. Dedicated to his wife Beth, son Eddie and daughter Christina, taking care of his parents, working, coaching and volunteering, one could not believe one man could do it all. A battle with cancer was hard fought and our Ed was the victor. Life went on. NOTHING could stop him. For those of us who knew Eddie, we were extremely blessed to have had him in our lives. We will remember times spent with our friend with bittersweet memories. With sincerest condolences to the Kulesza family, His Colleagues KULESZA--Dr. Edward S. Died September 25, 2007. Born in 1952, graduate of Holy Cross, Worcester, MA and Universidad Autonoma de Guadalajara, he has been part of the Coler Goldwater family since 1988. A dedicated physician with a warm heart, he was a 'straight shooter', always itching to help others. In addition to his passion for patients, he loved football and coached in the Bi County Junior Scholastic League. His pool parties, where he routinely invited all staff were legendary. After a battle with cancer which he won, he returned to a full work and social life. We have lost our dear friend to a senseless accident and will miss him always. Funeral mass on Monday, October 1, 2007 at Sacred Heart Church, North Bergen, NJ. With sympathies to the Kulesza family, Coler Goldwater Medical Staff

PERALTA--Grave de , Marcia McKim Huston Cartaya Grave de Peralta, died Monday September 17, 2007, in La Jolla, California. She was born off the coast of Georgia on a piece of land known as Sea Island on September 21, 1921. Her son Armando Rene Grave de Peralta, Jr. predeceased her three years ago in a boating accident. She leaves her former husband Armando Rene Grave de Peralta of New York City and La Jolla, California, and two stepsons Frederic de Peralta of New York City and William Adams de Peralta of Oceanside, CA. One of a kind, she lived many years in Greenwich Village, NY and was very active on the board of her Homeowners Association. She was an avid sports fan whose interest had been initiated via her grandfather Colonel Rupert Huston who owned the NY Yankees, built Yankee Stadium and brought Babe Ruth to the Yankees. In her younger years she was a good swimmer, tennis player and skier. Bridge was also an important part of her life. She was a constant student of politics, history, and anything that was happening in the world. Her feistiness, irreverent sense of humor, and clever repartee made her a great addition to all occasions, large or small. She knew the art of conversation from the old days. When she first became acquainted with her husband Armando in 1944, he said she was one of the most beautiful ladies he had ever met. But to reflect on her actual charm, she was a superbly excellent dancer particularly when dancing the Argentine tango ''Arraballero'' in which she excelled quite spectacularly; swinging and swaying delightfully holding tight to her partners hand responding to its direction, creating a spectacle elegant and grand that invariably called everybody's attention without any fear of anyone's intervention, as the audience usually arose and applauded. A Celebration of her Life will be held on Thursday November 8, 2007 at 2:30pm at Greenwood Memorial Park & Mortuary, 4300 Imperial Ave., San Diego, CA 92113. The service will be held at the Grave de Peralta Private Estate. She is deeply mourned by everyone who knew her. We extend our sympathies to her family and friends.

POSSNER--Merrilee J. , 64, died September 21, 2007 in Bethesda, MD after a courageous battle with cancer. Daughter of the late Julia and Sidney Possner, she was born in Brooklyn and lived in Washington, D.C., NYC, and, most recently, in Portsmouth, NH. She is survived by her sister and brother-in-law, Karen Possner and Stan Wiggins of Bethesda, MD. Following graduation from Brooklyn College, she moved to Washington, D.C., where she worked for the Library of Congress. Returning to NYC, she earned an MSW and was a social worker for two decades. A love of American folk art led to a second Masters at NYU in Folk Art Studies and an internship at the American Folk Art Museum. She subsequently joined Christie's auction house, where she became head of Americana at Christie's East. Relocating to New Hampshire in 1992, she joined Northeast Auctions where she was chief researcher and appraiser of American Folk Art. She was a board member of the Portsmouth Historical Society and a Proprietor of the Portsmouth Athenaeum. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Strawbery Banke Museum, PO Box 300, Portsmouth, NH 03802, the Portsmouth Historical Society, PO Box 728, Portsmouth, NH 03802 or Community Hospice of MD-South, 8200 Professional Place-Suite 104, Landover, MD 20785.

NEW I.M.F. LEADER The former French finance minister, Dominique Strauss-Kahn, will lead the International Monetary Fund, inheriting an organization suffering from the weakest loan demand in almost three decades. The nomination of Mr. Strauss-Kahn, 58, was approved by the lender's executive board yesterday and he will start Nov. 1, the I.M.F. said. He succeeds Rodrigo de Rato, whose three years in the job made him the shortest-serving managing director in the fund's 60-year history. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

EMMERICH--Andre, in his 83rd year, died peacefully at home in New York City on September 25, having suffered a stroke after a fiveyear battle with Lewy Body Disease. He is survived by his beloved wife Susanne, his loving sons, Adam (Pamela), Toby (Julie) and Noah, their mother Constance, by four grandchildren, Sarah, Rebecca, Benjamin and Cosy, by his sister Nicole (L. William) Teweles of Milwaukee, and his extended family. Born in Germany, and raised in Holland, Andre Emmerich came to New York City with his family in 1940 at the age of 15. He graduated from Oberlin College at 19. In 1954 he founded the Andre Emmerich Gallery in New York City. The gallery represented leading colorfield artists including Helen Frankenthaler, Hans Hofmann, Morris Louis and Jules Olitski, and sculptors such as Anthony Caro. Emmerich also pioneered connoisseurship and exhibition of Pre-Columbian art in the United States, and exhibited Greek and Roman art. He established Top Gallant sculpture park in Quaker Hill, a showcase for large-scale outdoor sculpture. Emmerich twice served as president of the Art Dealers Association of America, and was a founding member of the American Association of Dealers in American, Oriental and Primitive Art, and a member of the IRS Art Advisory Panel. Emmerich was a scholar and frequent lecturer and prolific author, including his books ''Art Before Columbus'' and ''Sweat of the Sun and Tears of the Moon --Gold and Silver in Pre-Columbian Art'', and many articles in Art News, The Wall Street Journal, and The New Criterion, among others. The funeral and internment will be private. A memorial will take place at a later date. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to Incontinentia Pigmenti International Foundation (IPIF), 30 East 72nd Street, NYC 10021, or Weill Cornell Department of Neurology, In honor of Andre Emmerich, Memory Disorders Program, 1300 York Avenue, NYC 10021, attn: Tom Horton.

ERLANGER--Dr. Herbert L. M.D., May 1, 1925-September 27, 2007. Dr. Erlanger became a member of the Department of Anesthesiology at New York Hospital in 1957, after completing his undergraduate degree at Columbia College and his medical education at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons. He was on the faculty for clinical anesthesiology and related sciences at Weill Medical College of Cornell University for almost half a century. From 1990 to 2005 he was the coordinator of the Weill Cornell preanesthesia testing center, where he charted more than 100,000 patients. More recently, he was an associate professor at John Jay College and Borough of Manhattan Community College, both of the City University of New York. Dr. Erlanger was an avid fitness enthusiast and a devoted member of the bass section of several New York City choruses. He leaves his loving wife, Dr. Jane Katz, son, Robert K. Erlanger, daughter, Holly Knight, and five grandchildren. Service Sunday 11:45am at the ''Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations may be made to John Jay College Foundation for Wellness in memory of Dr. Herbert L. Erlanger at 555 West 57th Street, NY 10019.

LEDBETTER--William Joe Born in Memphis, Tennessee on January 24, 1927, passed away at his home in Montecito, California. He went peacefully in his sleep September 21, 2007 after several months of challenged health. His daughter was with him. Family and friends were nearby. He was the son of Andrew and Jessie Ledbetter. After serving in the Naval Reserve during World War II, William attended the University of Memphis, the University of Nebraska, and received his law degree at Washington & Lee University, where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa and the Order of the Coif. Following graduation, he practiced law as an associate of Cravath, Swaine & Moore in New York City until he was hired by General Electric Company where he reached the position of Associate Corporate Attorney. From there he moved to Honeywell Inc. where he served as General Counsel. So much of his legal work involved raising money to support the company's venture into the computer business that in the early seventies he changed his emphasis from law to finance and was subsequently employed by Addressograph - Multi graph first as Vice PresidentFinance and then as Vice President of International Operations with subsidiaries in 23 and dealers in 110 countries. In 1978, William became Vice President-Finance of Textron Inc., a pioneer conglomerate with divisions involved in more than thirty unrelated businesses. There he became involved in almost all aspects of the Company's business, especially the purchase and sale of discrete business units. He retired from Textron in 1989 as Senior Executive Vice President. In addition to his business activities William was involved in many charitable and civic activities such as Vice Chairman of the Board of Roger Williams Hospital, Member of the Rhode Island Board of Accountancy, Member of Board of Rhode Island Mental Health Association, Vice President of V. P. Finance Association of Cleveland, President of Minnesota Corporate Counsel Association, and many fund raising activities for United Way, Red Cross and similar organizations. In 1956, William met and married Shirley Ann Good of Santa Paula, California. As a result of changes in his career the couple lived in several locations including New York City, Minneapolis, Cleveland and Providence, and, thus, developed a wide circle of friends across the country. Upon retirement, they moved to Shirley's birthplace, a lemon ranch in Santa Paula, where they lived until Shirley died in an auto accident in 2005. William is survived by a son, Gleghn Andrew Ledbetter of Cornville, AZ and a daughter, Sally Ann Ledbetter of Westport, MA. Because William's friends are so scattered across the country, there will not be any single memorial service and those who wish to do so are requested to remember him and celebrate his life in their private way. Gifts in remembrance of him are requested to be made to the Museum of Ventura County or the GoodLedbetter Scholarship Fund at the School of Law at Washington & Lee University.

EMMERICH--Andre , in his 83rd year, died peacefully at home in New York City on September 25, having suffered a stroke after a fiveyear battle with Lewy Body Disease. He is survived by his beloved wife Susanne, his loving sons, Adam (Pamela), Toby (Julie) and Noah, their mother Constance, by four grandchildren, Sarah, Rebecca, Benjamin and Cosy, by his sister Nicole (L. William) Teweles of Milwaukee, and his extended family. Born in Germany, and raised in Holland, Andre Emmerich came to New York City with his family in 1940 at the age of 15. He graduated from Oberlin College at 19. In 1954 he founded the Andre Emmerich Gallery in New York City. The gallery represented leading colorfield artists including Helen Frankenthaler, Hans Hofmann, Morris Louis and Jules Olitski, and sculptors such as Anthony Caro. Emmerich also pioneered connoisseurship and exhibition of Pre-Columbian art in the United States, and exhibited Greek and Roman art. He established Top Gallant sculpture park in Quaker Hill, a showcase for large-scale outdoor sculpture. Emmerich twice served as president of the Art Dealers Association of America, and was a founding member of the American Association of Dealers in American, Oriental and Primitive Art, and a member of the IRS Art Advisory Panel. Emmerich was a scholar and frequent lecturer and prolific author, including his books ''Art Before Columbus'' and ''Sweat of the Sun and Tears of the Moon --Gold and Silver in Pre-Columbian Art'', and many articles in Art News, The Wall Street Journal, and The New Criterion, among others. The funeral and internment will be private. A memorial will take place at a later date. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to Incontinentia Pigmenti International Foundation (IPIF), 30 East 72nd Street, NYC 10021, or Weill Cornell Department of Neurology, In honor of Andre Emmerich, Memory Disorders Program, 1300 York Avenue, NYC 10021, attn: Tom Horton.

ALBRECHT--Walter E., age 78, died September 28, 2007 at his home in Manhattan. A graduate of both Harvard College and Harvard Business School. He also studied at the London School of Economics. During the Korean conflict, he was awarded a Direct Commission in the USAF. He completed pilot training and served many years in active Reserves, retiring as a Lt. Colonel. During a civilian career at CitiBank, he was a Vice President with global responsibilities. He is survived by his wife, Eleanor Muezen Geraghty Albrecht, his daughter Bronwyn Fannan, granddaughter Madeline Fannan, three stepchildren, Kevin Geraghty, Brian Geraghty, Kathleen Geraghty Simons and four step-grandchildren, Andrew Geraghty, Kathryn Geraghty, Morgan Simons and Alexander Simons. In lieu of flowers, donations are requested to Mary Manning Walsh Home and Calvary Hospice.

GOODMAN--Cora . Beloved wife of the late Irving. Cherished mother of Alane Seidner and Alyce Zinn. Treasured grandmother of Robin, Syndee, Ricky, Ithan and Barry and great-grandmother of Ryan, Jesse and Taylor. You are our whole world, best friend, our everything. You have touched everyone who has ever known you with your beauty, love, generosity, brilliance and talent. Your accomplishments are immeasurable; a gifted musician, composer, artist, writer, poet and devoted educator. A commitment to countless charitable organizations including The B'nai Brith AntiDefamation League, The League of Women Voters and The Senior Citizen Advisory Board have showcased your passion for dedicating yourself to what you believe in. Your achievements in business as the Floor Superintendent at Gimbels and the Regional Manager of Field Enterprises Corporation had you recognized by Fortune Magazine as an Outstanding Businesswoman of the Year. But most of all you are recognized by your family as their greatest gift. You are the heart of our family and will continue to beat in each one of us. We are so proud of everything you are and everything you've done. We will love you and treasure you forever. Your Loving Family To Eternity

REYNOLDS--Jack . Died in Dallas, TX on September 26, 2007. He was born on September 27, 1922, in Houston, TX, to Frank Reynolds and Gertrude MacMurray. He graduated from high school in Englewood, NJ in 1941; from Wesleyan University (CT) in 1948; and from Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons in 1952. He had a residency in radiology at St. Lukes Hospital in NYC. He was a member of Sigma Xi and Alpha Omega Alpha. He served in the U.S. Army from 1943 to 1946. He married Mary Jane Schermerhorn on November 2, 1952 in Englewood, NJ. After his residency he joined the Radiology faculty of the University of Texas, Health Science Center at Dallas in 1957, and also the staff at Parkland Memorial Hospital. He was on duty in 1963 when President Kennedy was shot. During his 48 year teaching career, he was a favorite teacher of many classes and he earned many honors for his excellence in teaching. He loved Texas, especially Big Bend. He was an amateur artist, and his work was admired by high school classmate Ellsworth Kelley. He is survived by his wife of 54 years, Mary Jane Reynolds, his son, David Reynolds and wife Susan of Houston, two grandsons, and many cousins, nieces and nephews. Memorial services will be Monday, October 1, at 10:00am at Lovers Lane Methodist Church in Dallas, TX. Please make donations to the Jack Reynolds fund of the Dallas Foundation for the Southwestern Medical Foundation, 900 Jackson St., Suite 150, Dallas, Texas 75202.

McROBERTS--Jeanne L. , of Boynton Beach, FL on September 25, 2007 age 80. Beloved wife of the late Franklin C. Mother of Mary Louise, Lansdell C., and the late Franklin C. Dear sister of Nancy Pirtle. Grandmother of Franklin, Eric, Alexander, and James. Service at St. John's of Lattingtown, Lattingtown, NY Tuesday 10:15am.

SAUL--Stephen Henry , Ph.D. Scholar, Teacher, Humanist, died peacefully at home in Honolulu of AUL on August 29, 2007. He was recently retired as Associate Entomologist/Professor with special expertise in genetics from PEPS (Department of Plant and Environmental Protection Services) in the College of Tropical Agriculture and Human Resources at the University of Hawai'i at Manoa. Born in Brooklyn in 1941, Stephen was a graduate of Stuyvesant High School as a National Merit Finalist with achievement awards in Chemistry, Mathematics and Physics; Brooklyn College; and the University of Rochester. He was awarded New York State Regents Scholarships for College and for the study of Medicine. He was a member and living example of the ideals of Alpha Phi Omega, the national service fraternity, and Sigma Xi, the Scientific Research Society. Prior to moving to Honolulu, he was a Ford Foundation Fellow in Population Biology at the University of Chicago, and Visiting Assistant Professor and Post-Doctoral Researcher in the Vector Biology Laboratory at the University of Notre Dame. Stephen read extensively in cosmology and had deep respect and reverence for the nature of both the physical and biological world. As a biologist he fully understood the natural cycle of life, including the role of death in perpetuating the cycle. His message to family and friends is that he was fortunate to have had a very good life; he was grateful for being able to experience so much that was professionally and personally rewarding. For him, everyone mattered and every being was important. His keen intellect and inherent idealism propelled him to pursue a life of continuous learning on a wide range of subjects outside of science including history, literature, philosophy and the arts; he was always ready to share the resulting knowledge and understanding, doing so most often with disarming wit and humor. He found the engaging response of his students most gratifying. Stephen served as President of the Pacific Orchid Society of Hawai'i, and led discussions with other devotees of classical music as the FEMLS; he particularly treasured the friendships forged through such shared interests. A kind, appreciative and loving person, Stephen gave freely of himself. He will be deeply missed and remembered by many as a bright light in their lives. The insights and sensibilities for which Stephen was so admired, were considered by him a continual gift since his early years to the present from the family he loved: grandparents David (deceased) and Irene Saul (deceased); parents Jerome (deceased) and Lottie Saul; aunts and uncles Gertrude (deceased) and Sydney Peimer, Bernard (deceased) and Helene (deceased) Saul, Marian and David (deceased) Lubin, and Robert (deceased) and Elaine Saul. He is survived also by wife Alice Saul of Honolulu, HI; brothers David N. Saul and wife Susan of Wayland, MA and Arthur D. Saul and wife Mary Ann of Dix Hills, NY. Memorial Service Thursday October 4, 2007 10:30am Oahu Cemetery Chapel, 2162 Nuuanu Avenue, Honolulu, HI 96817 Telephone: 808-528-3441

LAPIDUS--Alexander . Loving husband of Florence and father of Karen, beloved son of Mary and Leon and brother of Marvin and Henry, passed away on September 16, 2007. The family owned Lapidus Bungalow Colony, in White Lake, NY, the summer home of generations of Jewish families since 1933. Involved in many businesses throughout his life, he entered the Antiques field late in life and was very successful. A juvenile diabetic for 79 years, he was loved and respected by all who knew him. A unique person who loved his family and was always there to help a friend. He will be greatly missed.

Last Sunday's column about the MoveOn.org advertisement prompted more than 350 messages from readers. Here is a much larger collection of letters than could fit in the print edition.Re "Betraying Its Own Best Interests" (Sept. 23):I've supported and donated to MoveOn.org in the past, and I've opposed the Iraq war since before Day 1, but when I saw the ad, I was appalled.I grew up during the McCarthy years and remember what it was like to hear people like George Marshall routinely being accused of betrayal. Funny thing about mud, it smells exactly the same whether it's being hurled from the left or the right.That said, I do wonder whether you're right in suggesting that the Times should have forced MoveOn.org to lose the "Betray Us" line as a condition of publication.It's my impression that the First Amendment protects, among other things, our right to make perfect fools of ourselves, and I'm not sure The Times should be in the business of shielding political groups (or anyone else) from exposing themselves to richly justified ridicule.It would have been far better to publish the ad as submitted, while running an editorial, on the same day if possible, properly taking MoveOn.org to task for its savage characterization of an honorable soldier trying to make the best of an impossible mission. THOMAS N. BETHELLDeer Isle, Me., Sept. 24, 2007 •

Two golfers playing together made holes in one on the same hole. The landmark morning for Bill Maslowski and Carl Workinger came Thursday while they were playing in a threesome at Grandview Golf Course near Pittsburgh, The York Dispatch reported. Maslowski got his ace first, using a 5-iron on the 152-yard fourth hole. Steve Fahs, the other player in the group, hit second but missed the green. Workinger then used a 6-iron to hit his ball into the cup. According to a Golf Digest study, the odds of two players in the same foursome acing the same hole are 17 million to 1.

The N.H.L. opened its season yesterday afternoon on the banks of the River Thames, where the Los Angeles Kings felt right at home. The teams play the second game of their series today.The N.H.L. has opened its season outside North America three other times — in Japan in 1997, 1998 and 2000 — but this was the first league game played in Europe.

Marcus Williams, a backup point guard for the Nets, broke his right foot and will have surgery tomorrow. Rod Thorn, the Nets’ president, said he did not know how Williams was injured. Michael Hill was named general manager of the Florida Marlins yesterday, replacing Larry Beinfest, who became president of baseball operations.The Marlins also named Dan Jennings and Jim Fleming as assistant general managers, adding to their roles in the team’s player personnel and development departments. Hill, Beinfest, Jennings and Fleming all accepted extensions, keeping them under contract for at least the next eight seasons.Beinfest was named the Marlins’ general manager before the 2002 season and helped Florida put together the team that won the World Series in 2003. Hill becomes the third general manager in Marlins history. He had been an assistant general manager under Beinfest since 2002.

Fiji upset Wales, 38-34, to reach the Rugby World Cup quarterfinals for the first time in 20 years. The Fijians stunned Wales with 25 consecutive points in nine first-half minutes in Nantes, France. The “Living In” article last Sunday, about Poughkeepsie, N.Y., reversed information about student enrollment and test scores in two high schools. Arlington High School had 719 in its graduating class last year; its average SAT scores were 524 for verbal and 534 for math. Poughkeepsie High School had a senior class enrollment of 211 and average SAT scores of 468 for verbal and 495 for math.

Gary Taubes (Sept. 16) urges caution in accepting premature epidemiologic results. We agree: scientists are generally skeptics. As cautious pragmatists, our work has improved life expectancy and quality. Epidemiology demonstrated the hazards of smoking, the benefits of lowering blood pressure and cholesterol, that infant sleeping position reduces SIDS, sun exposure causes melanoma and folate supplementation helps prevent birth defects. Some were “bolts from the blue,” and since no one knows what bolts remain undetected, we keep looking. Uncertainty along the way is the hallmark of science and the price of progress. Premature media pronouncements erode public trust. Good epidemiologists eschew these. Clinical trials, also in our toolbox, are useful but no panacea because we cannot randomly expose people to risks and because participants are self-selected and often unrepresentative. Granted, epidemiology is time consuming, expensive and requires public will. But don’t lose the forest for the trees: epidemiology has hugely improved health.

FLINN--Robert H. , of New York and Vero Beach, FL, formerly of Rye, NY, passed away September 28th, 2007 after a long illness. Husband to Charlotte; father to Leslie Flinn, Colin Flinn, Evan Saucedo and Douglas Flinn; father-in-law to Susan Flinn and Eric Saucedo; grandfather to Jackson Saucedo and Robert G. Flinn. Son of the late Irene and Harry Flinn and friend to many. A life long athlete, Bob Flinn was a basketball star in his youth for Mamaroneck High, Colgate University and in the Navy during the Korean War. He was also a successful entrepreneur and financier. With his father, he owned Flinn Motor Corp. He was founder and president of Eco Leasing Corp. and Flinn Capital Corp. and a developer of Audubon at Naples, Frenchmen's Creek and other successful ventures. A funeral mass will be held at 11am at Resurrection Church in Rye, NY on Wednesday, October 3rd with a reception to follow at Apawamis Club in Rye. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Colgate University in Hamilton, NY or to Catholic Charities.

Survivors include Patricia of Chatham, MA, children Edward, Janice and Andrew, five grandchildren and a great-grandson.

RENNERT--Fred , of Boynton Beach, FL, passed away on Monday, September 24th, 2007 after a courageous battle with Gastric Cancer at the age of 82. He was born in Mannheim, Germany on April 2nd, 1925. Fred was a shining light to all who knew him. During World War II he was a prisoner of war in Germany and saved his company from certain death since he spoke fluent German. He was a recipient of the Purple Heart and Bronze Star Medals for his heroic service. He most certainly exemplified the men in the book. ''The Greatest Generation''. Fred was always thankful he could return from the war and live a full and productive life, and that he did. He lived life to the fullest in every sense of the word and to all those he met he brought the brightest smile. Fred Rennert, beloved husband of Corinne, his wife of 57 wonderful years, loving father to his daughter Debra of Delray Beach, FL and son Richard of Tarrytown, NY. Devoted grandfather to Scott, Amanda, Sara and Julia, and brother to Esther. He will be missed ALWAYS.

EAST VILLAGE OFFERINGS To the Editor: Regarding ''Weekend in New York: The East Village: An 80-Block Slice of City Life'' (Sept. 16): I was delighted to see the East Village feature until I realized that the column was all about food, bars, shopping and pricey new hotels. It's bad enough that my beloved neighborhood, which I call ''the N.Y.U. Food Court,'' has almost become all about food, bars, shopping and pricey new hotels. But couldn't you have mentioned a few of the longstanding cultural institutions -- La MaMa, P.S. 122, Danspace Project at St. Mark's Church and others -- still playing a role in New York's innovation and pre-eminence in the arts?

WHOSE NOSTALGIA? To the Editor: The writer of the letter ''Mourning a Lost Rural Life'' (Sept. 16), who regrets that ''technology and progress'' have brought an end to what he calls ''a wonderful way of life'' in Galicia, invites a question. Did the people living that life find it so wonderful? Or did they abandon it because they preferred technology and progress to a life spent tilling the fields? Why are Americans so nostalgic about other people's pasts?

The problem with waiting for a randomized trial to make decisions about health is that the ''gold standard'' randomized trial actually has its share of tarnish. Conversely, although some observational studies are done poorly, well-designed nonrandomized research often withstands the test of time. The take-home message for readers should be not to expect certainty from any individual study, observational or randomized. Progress in science is iterative and incremental -- in the long run, we get closer to ''truth'' as overall evidence accumulates on a given topic. Putting what we know into practice would prevent more disease than worshiping at the altar of randomized trials. John Concato, M.D.

MITCHELL--Mayer ''Bubba'' . The Board of Directors and staff of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee (AIPAC) are deeply saddened by the passing of our dear friend Mayer ''Bubba'' Mitchell who served as AIPAC President, Chairman of the Board and a member of the organizations national Board of Directors. He will be remembered for his impeccable good judgment, wise counsel, courage and conviction. Bubba Mitchell defined modern American pro-Israel activism, reaching beyond his own state's borders and across party lines to ensure that strong U.S.-Israel ties had bipartisan support throughout the United States. We extend our deepest sympathies and continued friendship to his dear wife Arlene, to their children Richard (Susan) Mitchell, Melinda (Steven) Wertheim, Joy (James) Grodnick, Lisa (Barry) Bukstein, and their eight grandchildren. May his example continue to inspire our community and his memory forever be a guiding light and comfort to those who were blessed to know him.

AMAZON LUXURY To the Editor: Regarding ''Into the Amazon'' (Sept. 16): I was struck by the level of luxury and comfort offered by the resorts that have sprung up in the Amazon region. They are a far cry from the simple accommodations we had when, as a young boy, I lived with my parents at the edge of the Amazon jungle in Ecuador. But, as Larry Rohter mentions, ''luxury, of course, is a relative concept.'' Relative, in the sense that no amount of luxury will ever help me relive the amazing memories I have from those days, long before the new breed of lodges. But, to those who don't have such memories, go for it.

NOBEL'S STOCKHOLM To the Editor: ''36 Hours in Stockholm'' (Sept. 9) points out many of the pleasures of the Swedish capital. In addition to suggestions of where to get a glass of rosé or shop for vintage clothing, any visit to Stockholm should include the Nobel Museum. Complementing this would be a tour of the Stadshuset (City Hall), in whose Blue Hall the Nobel banquet is held each Dec. 10.

I never expected to gain any new insight into the nature of my generation, or the changing landscape of American colleges, in lit theory. Lit theory is supposed to be the class where you sit at the back of the room with every other jaded sophomore wearing skinny jeans, thick-framed glasses, an ironic T-shirt and oversize retro headphones, just waiting for the lecture to be over so you can light up a Turkish Gold and walk to lunch while listening to Wilco. That's pretty much the way I spent the course, too; through structuralism, formalism, gender theory and postcolonialism, I was far too busy shuffling through my iPod to see what the patriarchal world order of capitalist oppression had to do with ''Ethan Frome.'' But when we began to study postmodernism, something struck a chord with me and made me sit up and look anew at the seemingly blasé college-age literati of which I was so self-consciously one. According to my textbook, the problem with defining postmodernism is that it's impossible to. The difficulty is that it is so . . . post. It defines itself so negatively against what came before it -- naturalism, romanticism and the wild revolution of modernism -- that it's sometimes hard to see what it actually is. It denies that anything can be explained neatly or even at all. It is parodic, detached, strange and sometimes menacing to traditionalists who do not understand it. Although it arose in the postwar West, the generation that has witnessed its rise has yet to come up with an explanation of what postmodern attitudes mean for the future of culture or society. The subject intrigued me because, in a class otherwise consumed by dead-letter theories, postmodernism remained an open book, tempting to the young and curious. But it also intrigued me because the question of what postmodernism -- what a movement so posteverything, so reticent to define itself -- is spoke to a larger question about the political and popular culture of today, of the other jaded sophomores sitting around me who grew up in a postmodern world.
Bret Anthony Johnston Texas A&M-Corpus Christi, Class of 1996

DeREGIS--John Joseph , 58, of New York, died August 13, 2007. He is survived by Robert I. Padyjasek, his life partner of 21 years, sister Karin DeRegis, brother/sister-inlaw Richard and Ginger DeRegis, sister-in-law Jeannie DeRegis, sister-in-law Annie DeRegis, all of Syracuse, NY, brother Mark of Los Angeles, and sister/brother-in-law Janis and Craig Woodard of Belle Mead, NJ. He was the son of the late John Morris and Joan Garden DeRegis of Syracuse, NY. He was a coowner of Studio@5 E19 Street, a salon in the Flatiron District of Manhattan. He began his career as a hairstylist upstate in Syracuse and Rochester and was a graduate of the Continental School. He moved to New York in 1970 for Glemby International, teaching styling techniques at their salons around the country. Having worked at Bergdorf Goodman, Saks, and other salons in the city, he opened his own salon 25 years ago in SoHo, where he lived for the last 30 years. His clientele reflected the city that he deeply loved. Interment at Trinity Church Cemetery in Manhattan will be private. Memorial donations in his memory may be made to friendsindeed.org. John was a warm, loving, trusting, sweet and gentle soul, born on Christmas Day; a simple, wonderful man who loved his Italian heritage and his family, good movies and friends, dancing, the sun, the beach, a sparkling swimming pool, baking oatmeal cookies and apple pies, and especially making his clients look their best. He made the world a better place, was loved by all, and will be always in our hearts. Aeternum Vale. Requiescat In Pace.
Pop Kelefa Sanneh

SAUL--Stephen Henry , Ph.D. Scholar, Teacher, Humanist, died peacefully at home in Honolulu of AUL on August 29, 2007. He was recently retired as Associate Entomologist/Professor with special expertise in genetics from PEPS (Department of Plant and Environmental Protection Services) in the College of Tropical Agriculture and Human Resources at the University of Hawai'i at Manoa. Born in Brooklyn in 1941, Stephen was a graduate of Stuyvesant High School as a National Merit Finalist with achievement awards in Chemistry, Mathematics and Physics; Brooklyn College; and the University of Rochester. He was awarded New York State Regents Scholarships for College and for the study of Medicine. He was a member and living example of the ideals of Alpha Phi Omega, the national service fraternity, and Sigma Xi, the Scientific Research Society. Prior to moving to Honolulu, he was a Ford Foundation Fellow in Population Biology at the University of Chicago, and Visiting Assistant Professor and Post-Doctoral Researcher in the Vector Biology Laboratory at the University of Notre Dame. Stephen read extensively in cosmology and had deep respect and reverence for the nature of both the physical and biological world. As a biologist he fully understood the natural cycle of life, including the role of death in perpetuating the cycle. His message to family and friends is that he was fortunate to have had a very good life; he was grateful for being able to experience so much that was professionally and personally rewarding. For him, everyone mattered and every being was important. His keen intellect and inherent idealism propelled him to pursue a life of continuous learning on a wide range of subjects outside of science including history, literature, philosophy and the arts; he was always ready to share the resulting knowledge and understanding, doing so most often with disarming wit and humor. He found the engaging response of his students most gratifying. Stephen served as President of the Pacific Orchid Society of Hawai'i, and led discussions with other devotees of classical music as the FEMLS; he particularly treasured the friendships forged through such shared interests. A kind, appreciative and loving person, Stephen gave freely of himself. He will be deeply missed and remembered by many as a bright light in their lives. The insights and sensibilities for which Stephen was so admired, were considered by him a continual gift since his early years to the present from the family he loved: grandparents David (deceased) and Irene Saul (deceased); parents Jerome (deceased) and Lottie Saul; aunts and uncles Gertrude (deceased) and Sydney Peimer, Bernard (deceased) and Helene (deceased) Saul, Marian and David (deceased) Lubin, and Robert (deceased) and Elaine Saul. He is survived also by wife Alice Saul of Honolulu, HI; brothers David N. Saul and wife Susan of Wayland, MA and Arthur D. Saul and wife Mary Ann of Dix Hills, NY. Memorial Service Thursday October 4, 2007 10:30am Oahu Cemetery Chapel, 2162 Nuuanu Avenue, Honolulu, HI 96817 Telephone: 808-528-3441
