ALL TOO REAL Perhaps more than any other program on television now, ''Intervention,'' A&E's documentary series about addiction, highlights the sticky situations reality show producers can find themselves in as they document unpredictable and unstable subjects or situations. [C1.] ''Kid Nation,'' the CBS reality program that had trouble attracting advertisers because of early criticism of its premise, has nearly tripled its number of advertisers since the premiere, though the audience has continued to shrink. [C3.]

What does the debut of a new television series say about its eventual success? Last year, only one new program, ''Brothers and Sisters,'' above, with Rob Lowe and Calista Flockhart, broke into the top 10. Ratings during the first week of the fall TV season last year, and this year, at right, were driven by fans revisiting their favorite programs. Among the new series in 2006, ''Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip'' premiered at No. 21 and ''Smith'' came in at No. 33. Both have been canceled. ''Cane,'' a new show starring Jimmy Smits, had its series premiere this week at No. 25. SHELLY FREIERMAN
McCARTHY--Jack . Best friend for 30 years. I will miss you terribly. In my heart you are ''on the bag'' forever. Martin Winkelman

There is no hardier theme in musical theater than the story of the ingénue trying to break into the cold, cruel world of showbiz. The latest entry in the lists, ''Greetings From Yorkville,'' by Anya Turner and Robert Grusecki, at the SoHo Playhouse, puts a reality-show spin upon this familiar subject. This time it's the autobiographical story of a struggling team of songwriters trying to get a foothold on the big time, performed by the people who wrote and lived it. Such self-referentiality could be squirm-inducing; here it's not -- or not very often. The story is slender enough: Boy meets girl, girl finds cheap walk-up on the Upper East Side (the Yorkville of the title), boy and girl work various jobs and try to get their songs heard.

What I want to write is the final book on Columbus, and I will not be able to do it without science to settle this. FRANCESC ALBARDANER, who hopes that DNA tests will clear up the dispute over where Christopher Columbus came from. [A16]
A Two-Sport Town With Kansas off to its best start since 1995, Jayhawks fans finally have something to talk about in October besides the start of basketball practice.

The Union Square Theater is carving out a niche as a home for a kind of barely verbal foreign import that has become a standard feature of the Off Broadway menu. These high-energy spectacles -- the offspring of hits like ''Stomp'' and ''Blue Man Group'' -- are sometimes called events or experiences, and audiences are usually told that the shows are a sensation somewhere very far away. This year it was ''Be,'' a rather loud headache from Israel featuring half-dressed actors leaping in the air, clowning around and banging on things. The new tenant is the lowbrow South Korean entertainment ''Jump,'' offering another band of half-dressed actors leaping and banging and clowning. There are differences, of course, but they aren't much greater than those between the menus at McDonalds in Seoul and Tel Aviv.

CANARICK--Dr. Sidney . North Shore Country Club records with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Sidney Canarick. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. N. Barry Ross, President Jeffrey Levy, Secretary

October being an auspicious month in the history of Moominland, the Manitoba Theater for Young People, from Winnipeg, Canada, has pitched its tent at the Duke on 42nd Street to perform ''Comet in Moominland,'' Graham Whitehead's adaptation of the 1946 novel of the same title by the Finnish writer and artist Tove Jansson. Playing through Sunday as a presentation of the New Victory Theater, this absorbing and imaginative intermissionless 55-minute show, created by William Chesney, Leslee Silverman and Mr. Whitehead, brings to faithful, slightly truncated life Ms. Jansson's tale of young Moomintroll and his friends and family as a fiery comet hurtles toward an October rendezvous with Earth.

DICKER--Norman . Devoted husband of Irene, loving father to Rena and Jerry Gombo and Mordy and Wendy Dicker, adored grandfather of Josh, Eric, Corey, and Zachary. Shiva at Dicker residence through Wednesday night.

MICHAELS--James . Jim appreciated dynamic reporting and demanded excellence. Along with Jean Briggs, he inspired Paul Klebnikov to pursue his journalistic career. Jim was Chairman of the Paul Klebnikov Fund, and friend to the family. We will never forget this.

O'SHEA--Thomas W. , 73, of Keene, NH, died on Friday, October 5th with his son Matthew at his side. Mr. O'Shea was born in New York City and remained a resident until 1998, when he moved to New Hampshire. He is survived by his loving son, Matthew, former wife and best friend, Erna O'Shea, grandchildren Conor, Kate and Tommy and his daughter-in-law, Katie. Wake at Riverdale Funeral Home, 214th St. and Broadway in Manhattan, Monday, October 8, 2-5pm, 7-9pm. Funeral Mass Tuesday, October 9, 10:45am at St. John's Church, Kingsbridge Avenue in the West Bronx.

KARTEN--Solomon , age 86, passed away on Sunday October 7 at Winthrop Hospital, Mineola, NY. He is predeceased by his wife of 40 years, Sarah Karten, and is survived by their loving children, Susan Karten, Leslie Karten and Stuart Karten, and granddaughters Sophie, Ruby, Rachel, Bess and Liza. He is also survived by his current wife Ruth Karten, her children and grandchildren. Formerly an entrepreneur owning a 50's luncheonette, he returned to college and earned a doctorate in education K-12 and also became a professor of reading disabilities at Hofstra University. He had an insatiable appetite for information and knowledge and started everyday reading the New York Times cover to cover. He inspired his family and students and will be missed by all who loved him.

SULLIVAN--Rev. Patrick Joseph, S.J. Beloved brother of Eileen R. Mudryk and brother-in-law of Louis Lanaro. Survived by several loving nieces and nephews. Reposing at the Jesuit Community Chapel at Loyola Hall, Fordham University, Bronx, NY, on Tuesday from 3-5 and 7-9 pm, and Wednesday from 3-5 pm. Mass of Christian Burial at Fordham University Church on Wednesday at 7:30 pm. For information contact Farenga Bros. Inc., Directors, 718-654-0500.

Does the Webcam Make Me Look Fat? Either great minds think alike or single people are getting really desperate these days. Several start-up companies have suddenly sprouted to bring the 21st-century phenomenon known as speed dating to the Web.

SHAPIRO--Rita L . Dear and loyal friend, unique spirit. To Karen and Richard we send our love and condolences. Ruth Ritterband and Oren Ritterband SHAPIRO--Rita L., peacefully at home on October 6 at age 88. Treasured wife of the late George M. Shapiro, cherished mother of Karen (Richard) Spector, of Beachwood, Ohio, and the late Sanford N. Shapiro. Devoted sister of Dr. Martin (Dorothy) Lubin. A welleducated woman of great intelligence and insight she was her husband's invaluable partner in building his outstanding legal career. She was a very active and involved member of Park Avenue Synagogue where the new building was dedicated in the early 1990's in her and her husband's honor. In her fifties she contracted multiple sclerosis, and for more than 30 years she endured her increasing limitations with courage and humor. She became a passionate Yankee's fan in her later years. Services on Monday, October 8, at 10am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street. Shiva at 1160 Park Avenue, 3 to 9pm, October 8 and thereafter in Beachwood, Ohio. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Park Avenue Synagogue or the National MS Society. SHAPIRO--Rita L. Park Avenue Synagogue mourns the passing of our longtime and devoted congregant Rita Shapiro, wife of our late Chairman of the Board George M. Shapiro. We extend to the entire family our heartfelt sympathy. May her memory remain for a blessing. David H. Lincoln, Senior Rabbi Amy A.B. Bressman, Chairman of the Board Menachem Z. Rosensaft, President

KLAUSNER--Sheldon (Shel) on October 5, 2007. Real estate investor and developer. Beloved husband of the late Rahel, father of Arthur and David. Father-in-law of Robin and Denise. Friend to Gloria, Tom and Indra. Private memorial service.

HARRIS--Cecily . The Board of Governors and members of Montammy Golf Club express their deepest sorrow at the passing of their beloved member and extend their heartfelt sympathy to Robert, Peter and Jane, James and Molly, and the entire family. Mark J. Shirvan, President HARRIS--Cecily, born April 24, 1928 in New York City, died peacefully at home on October 6, 2007 in the loving care of her family. Cherished wife of Robert, adored mother of Peter, Susan and James, beloved grandmother of Zoe, Benjamin, Elizabeth, Siena and Elijah. Co-founder of Nutrition Industries and Smart Balance Foods, she worked tirelessly by the side of Robert to manage, develop and expand them into substantial national entities. Gracious, considerate, thoughtful, honest, she lived her life with dignity and modesty. Her loyal devotion to family, her selfless concern and interest for people she worked and interacted with touched all who knew her. Her passing leaves a void in the hearts of her family and friends, who are yet comforted by the knowledge that her spirit will continue to live with us.
FREEDMAN--Aaron . Happy 97th Birthday Daddy. It's been 2 yrs and Mom and I miss you everyday. Love, Annie

The United Automobile Workers union has set a Wednesday deadline in talks with Chrysler on a new four-year contract, people close to the negotiations said late Sunday. The two sides talked throughout the weekend after the union pushed to intensify discussions late last week, choosing Chrysler to go second in national contract talks after G.M.

TALMADGE--Arthur , 84, beloved and best friend for 58 years to Phyllis. Loving and totally devoted father to Jonathan and Micki. The best zayde to Sophie and Hannah. Labor arbitrator and Rabbi, he died after a long struggle with Alzheimer's. Graveside services were held. Shiva at home.

Updated, 1:37 p.m. | Opponents of the Atlantic Yards project that is set to rise near Downtown Brooklyn gathered at the federal courthouse in Lower Manhattan as the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit heard arguments in a case challenging the use of eminent domain to acquire land for the 22-acre, $4 billion project.The lawsuit, known as Goldstein v. Pataki, was filed in October 2006. It is one of the most significant eminent domain cases to be brought since the United States Supreme Court, in the Kelo v. City of New London decision in June 2005, held that public officials may transfer condemned property to another private interest if doing so would create a superior benefit to the public.

The case of the missing Pulitzers – three gold medals awarded to Newsday in 1954, 1970 and 1974 that were discovered missing last week from a safe in the newspaper’s headquarters in Melville, N.Y. – is still officially a whodunit, but it seems that the paper is on their way to getting the medals back.The Suffolk County Police announced today that the medals, which were awarded to Newsday in the public service category, were recovered by F.B.I. agents and would be authenticated with the company that makes the Pulitzer medals and then returned to the paper.

While commuting to work, City Room has been noticing advertisements by the New York Transit Museum Store for wooden subway cars. (They run along standard-width train tracks used by Thomas the tank engine and other train sets, except these subway cars haven’t been recalled).But clicking though to the subway store site revealed the wooden train page with only five subway lines for sale — the A and F and Nos. 1, 4 and 7 — in comparison to rich selection of subway lines offered on the mouse pads, T-shirts, Beanie Bears and watches and other paraphernalia, sold on the site.

What was interesting about this debate was how the Republican candidates continued to gingerly step away from the Bush administration. If you recall the first one of these, back in May, most of the candidates were quite supportive. But as the campaign has rolled along, the would-be standard bearers have felt an increasing need to distance themselves from the status quo. As Senator McCain said at one point: "The American people no longer have trust or confidence in our government -- our failure -- Katrina, our failures in Iraq, our failures to get spending under control -- and we've got to restore that trust and confidence." Even first-timer Fred Thompson offered some criticism, saying "I don't think anybody believes anything coming out of Washington anymore."
Mark Bittman uses a braise-and-glaze technique to dress up carrots.

Video game maker EA Sports shipped it's latest version of FIFA Soccer to stores in North America today. The 08 version of the game, which is designed for Xbox, Nintendo Wii, Sony Playstation and computer systems, aims to provide couch footballers "a soccer videogame experience that matches the complexity, finesse and beauty of the real-world game," only without the actual running, kicking and -- one would hope -- fewer bruises. As Jack Bell reported on Goal this summer, the Red Bulls striker (and NYT blogger) Jozy Altidore will be featured on the game's cover, left, along with Ronaldinho and Guillermo Ochoa, the Mexican goalkeeper for Club America.

I see the blog is racing along, so I will keep this brief and hope it will all end here. Some of you probably noticed that Marc Jacobs posted, explaining his side of what happened at the end of the Vuitton show, and I also contacted him by phone. I'm convinced after talking to him that the tongue-wagging, face-pulling on the runway was misunderstood and not directed at Suzy Menkes, though it upset her, and I offered him my apologies for the fuss. After the dust-up in New York, Jacobs said he had put a T-shirt on her seat at the LV show as an olive branch. It showed a cartoon of the fashion critic wringing the designer's neck and it was embroidered by Lesage. He thought it was a sweet way of making up.

Self-mutilation is still mutilation: Matthew Yglesias, who blogs for The Atlantic, objects to a passage in an article by Bret Stephens, a columnist for The Wall Street Journal. In the column, Stephens writes:

A number of readers seemed to enjoy the Talking Heads reference at the end of yesterday's column. Here's how it happened: I knew the piece would be about various ways in which Bush is just like previous conservative standard-bearers; writing it, I found myself using a repeated phrase -- "People claim to be shocked" -- and realized that it had a preacher-like tone to it; and that led me to David Byrne's preacherish lyrics.

So, I was teaching one of my classes (WWS593), and somehow the subject veered off into monetary policy and the lessons of Japanese experience -- so I decided to drop the prepared lesson plan and talk about Japan in the 90s.

I suspect a few readers -- and diet researchers -- will take issue with my Findings column about Gary Taubes' new book, "Good Calories, Bad Calories," and his debunking of the myth that low-fat diets will prolong your life. I'll be happy in subsequent posts to debate the low-fat diet as well as other issues raised in his book, like the causes of obesity and the case for low-carb diets. But before we start the food fight, I'd like to delve into the question of why scientists and other groups fall prey to the fads called "informational cascades."

The Cowboys' 25-24 victory over the Bills last night is already being called an instant classic. The Dallas Morning News called it "miraculous." If you missed it, highlights of the Cowboys' comeback can be seen here on NFL.com. The comparisons between Tony Romo and Brett Favre are already rampant, and Romo solidified the bond last night, according to Buck Harvey of the San Antonio News-Express. In full gunslinger mode, Romo was dreadful for all but the last four minutes, but he still managed to lead a game-winning drive when it mattered. The real star was kicker Nick Folk, who had to make a 53-yard field goal (his longest ever) twice to win the game because Bills Coach Dick Jauron called timeout right before the snap. The folks at AOL Fan House are calling for an end to that strategy, which has been used at the end of at least two other games this season. For the Bills, though, it was another demoralizing moment in a demoralizing season.

Say whatever you want about Yankees fans -- Lord knows, they'd say whatever they want about you - but you cannot deny that they are driven by their collective bond. Their reputation might be colored by negativity, as anyone who has ever foolishly worn an opposing team's jersey at Yankee Stadium can tell you, and they certainly have never been afraid to inform their own players of their shortcomings, when they deem them deserving. But one cannot doubt their passion and, surprisingly, at the end, their grace.
A group of infrastructure funds led by JPMorgan Chase agreed to buy a British water company Southern Water from the Royal Bank of Scotland for about 1.3 billion pounds ($2.7 billion).
Kohlberg Kravis Roberts agreed to buy a Turkish freight company U.N. Ro-Ro Isletmeleri in a transaction worth 910 million euros ($1.3 billion), Turkey's biggest private-equity acquisition.
Winton Capital Management, a $10 billion London hedge fund manager, has sold a 10 percent stake to a new Goldman Sachs-backed private equity fund reportedly targeting hedge funds.
Sonepar, a French distributor of electrical sockets and switches, bid 2.51 billion euros ($3.5 billion) to acquire a Dutch rival, Hagemeyer, and become the biggest distributor in the industry.

Textron said Monday that it would purchase United Industrial for about $1.1 billion in a deal that company officials said underscored the importance of unmanned aircraft to the United States military.
Members of the Sainsbury family will move to block the Qatari bid for the Sainsbury supermarket chain unless a deal is struck with the group's pension fund trustees, The Telegraph reported.
ConSentry, a Silicon Valley startup that says its Internet network switches are more efficient than those of giant incumbent Cisco, has raised a $21 million round of funding.
Morgan Stanley is unleashing a major drive to tap India's domestic wealth next year, hiring 100 private bankers in a bid to manage $1 billion in assets by the end of 2010.

Vonage, the Internet phone-calling pioneer, has settled its patent dispute with Sprint Nextel for $80 million and agreed to license Sprint's Internet-calling technology, the two companies said Monday.

In a bid to strengthen its position in the fast-growing data-loss prevention market, the computer security company McAfee said it has agreed to buy a privately owned enterprise security software company SafeBoot for $350 million in cash.

In the latest reminder of the immense wealth created since Google went public in August 2004, shares in Internet giant surpassed $600 in Nasdaq trading on Monday, joining Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway among the six stocks that top that mark.
The Royal Bank of Scotland Group, Banco Santander and Fortis won control of ABN Amro, the biggest Dutch bank, after its shareholders backed a buyout bid valued at 71.9 billion euros ($101 billion).

Warren E. Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway sold a block of listed shares in PetroChina for the fifth time in three months, dropping its stake in the company's share capital to 6.97 percent, according to a filing to the Hong Kong stock exchange Monday.

Infinity World Investments, a subsidiary of Dubai World, said Monday that its cash tender offer for the casino operator MGM Mirage had expired short of its goal but it would still buy $1.2 billion in shares.
The state of Connecticut accused a unit of Marsh & McLennan of illegally inflating insurance costs for consumers nationwide in an antitrust suit filed on Monday.
Shares of SOHO China, a Beijing property developer, soared 15 percent on their first day of trading Monday in Hong Kong in the latest hot public stock offering.

Yahoo will subscribe for 10 percent of the shares to be sold by Alibaba.com, China's largest e-commerce company, in an initial public offering that is expected to raise about $1 billion, according to a term sheet.

Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
Aired Monday night on NBC: Well, the number one movie again this weekend was a football film called, "The Game Plan." Obviously not about UCS or UCLA.
Brian Cashman said he saw George Steinbrenner after the game. He told him he was sorry. Steinbrenner did not respond.
Seemingly seeking a quid pro quo, Georgia now has the second-largest troop presence among American allies in Iraq.
Scott Boras, Alex Rodriguez’s agent, strongly suggested that becoming a free agent again would be the savviest and most lucrative choice for Rodriguez.

Two physicists, one French and one German, who discovered how to manipulate the magnetic and electrical properties of thin layers of atoms in order to store vast amounts of data on the tiny disks in iPods and other wonders of modern life, were named as winners of the Nobel Prize in Physics.
The markets took newly released Fed board minutes as a positive sign, and the Dow gained nearly 121 points.
The senator would spend up to $25 billion a year to create 401(k)-style retirement accounts for all Americans.
A German citizen who said he was kidnapped by the C.I.A. and tortured in a prison in Afghanistan lost his last chance to seek redress in court today.
NBC said it would pay $925 million for Oxygen,  a cable television network that focuses on women viewers and is led by Geraldine Laybourne.
The joint venture places several of the nation’s most recognizable beer brands under a single concern.
Rescue workers found the wreckage in the Cascade Range on Monday night.
Two people were found shot to death last night in a parked automobile in Newark, the police said.

The police charged a Bronx teenager with murder yesterday in the death of his 3-month-old daughter. The police said that because the baby had been crying on Sunday, her father, Steven Morales, 17, covered her with a blanket, which blocked her breathing. She apparently suffocated, investigators said. Officers answering an emergency call found the baby, Sophia Monteguado, unconscious and unresponsive at the family’s apartment. She was taken to Jacobi Medical Center, where she died. The police arrested Mr. Morales and charged him with murder, manslaughter and criminally negligent homicide. The baby’s mother, who lived with Mr. Morales, was not identified and was not charged.

Police arrested the grandmother of a 2-year-old girl who died yesterday after apparently overdosing on medication. Alma Williams, 61, the child’s legal guardian, told the police she awoke at 4 a.m. and found the girl in the bathroom with medicine strewn across the floor. The police said Ms. Williams collected the pills and returned to bed after the child told her that she had not swallowed any. Several hours later, Ms. Williams was unable to wake the girl, the police said. Emergency workers took her to Beth Israel Hospital, where she was pronounced dead a short time later. The authorities did not release her name. Later, the police arrested Ms. Williams and charged her with endangering the welfare of a child. The girl’s 4-year-old sister, who was not harmed, was removed from the home by the State Division of Youth and Family Services.
American Electric Power, one of the nation’s largest utilities, is expected to announced an agreement to settle a long-running lawsuit over emissions from its coal-fired power plants.
Zach Randolph made his first six shots in a Knicks uniform Monday night, in a 101-92 preseason victory against the Philadelphia 76ers

The Vodafone Group has agreed to buy the Italian and Spanish businesses of a Swedish telecommunications group, Tele2, for 775 million euros ($1.1 billion), it said. The deal will allow Vodafone, which is based in London, to supply fixed-line broadband Internet service to customers in Italy and Spain, adding to its broadband assets in Britain, Germany and France. Tele2 Italy had more than 2.6 million customers as of June 30, including 400,000 broadband customers. Tele2 Spain had 550,000 customers at the same date, including more than 240,000 broadband customers.

The China Minsheng Banking Corporation said it would acquire a 9.9 percent stake in the United Commercial Bank, a California bank that focuses on Chinese-dominated communities, for $317 million. China Minsheng, based in Beijing, said it would acquire the stake in UCBH Holdings, the parent company of United Commercial. China Minsheng has said its strategy was to expand outside China; UCBH, which acquired a bank in Shanghai this year, has said it wants to expand in China.

Rosneft, the Russian state oil company, raised its 2007 production estimate by 24.5 percent, to 2 million barrels a day, or 100.6 million tons, as a result of recent acquisitions. The company, based in Moscow, acquired major assets of Yukos, the oil company that was controlled by Mikhail Khodorkovsky, this year. A statement on Rosneft’s Web site said the increased output was a result of several acquisitions and increased production rates at several oil fields.

Symbion Health, the biggest health care company in Australia, agreed to be broken up and sold to Healthscope and two buyout companies for as much as 3.1 billion Australian dollars ($2.8 billion), reviving a plan blocked by its biggest shareholder a month ago. Healthscope will pay as much as 1.7 billion Australian dollars for Symbion’s 270 medical and diagnostic centers, while Archer Capital and Ironbridge Capital will buy the company’s drug distribution and vitamin business for 1.4 billion Australian dollars, Healthscope said. The deal was blocked this year by Primary Health Care, which had made an earlier bid that was rejected and held a 20 percent stake in Symbion.

Bang & Olufsen, a maker of luxury consumer electronics, said first-quarter profit rose 59 percent on a 6 percent increase in sales. The company said it earned 57.6 million kroner ($11 million) in the three months through August from 36.2 million kroner a year earlier. Sales rose to 926.4 million kroner. Bang & Olufsen, based in Denmark, said a lower tax rate and an increase in the number of Bang & Olufsen stores it operates contributed to the improved results. Wholesale revenue in the United States rose 25 percent, partly as a result of sales of a new television, the BeoVision 7, a 40-inch TV with DVD with a suggested retail price of $13,250.
Members of the military and their families are among the Americans who are at risk of being undercounted in the next census.
Elderly gay people in assisted-living centers and nursing homes increasingly report being mistreated.
Democrats remain nervous that they will be called soft on terrorism if they insist on strict curbs on gathering intelligence.
Olie Kolzig did what he usually does to the Islanders. For the Washington Capitals, that was simply perfect.
Gen. Pervez Musharraf’s “election” as Pakistan’s president was a perversion of democracy.
An incident involving the apparent poisoning of a 20-year-old woman has led to the arrest of her mother, who investigators believe also killed her two husbands.
The giant student lender is suing the firms that agreed to buy it, but are now trying to renegotiate the deal.
Trying to run as a primary and general-election candidate carries risks, particularly for Senator Clinton.

An article yesterday about the first year on the job for Pittsburgh’s 27-year-old mayor, Luke Ravenstahl, misstated the city’s fiscal history. Pittsburgh filed for “distressed city status” in 2003, which led to its finances being placed under the oversight of a state panel; it was not declared bankrupt. Also, the article referred incorrectly to John McIntire, a blogger who commented on the mayor’s handling of several controversies. Mr. McIntire is a former — not current — talk-show host for KDKA news radio.
There will be no Cubs-Yankees World Series this year, luckily for Hillary Rodham Clinton.
Efforts to enact a federal shield law for journalists have passed a critical milestone in the Senate.
The Dolphins announced Monday that quarterback Trent Green would miss at least this Sunday’s game against Cleveland and would not commit to when he might return.
Thank-you notes have become the new frontier for students courting college admissions offices.
It’s time to rein in the test zealots who have gotten such a stranglehold on the public schools in the U.S.
The Internet phone-calling pioneer came under fire from traditional phone companies that sought to shut it down, saying Vonage had infringed on their patents.
Altria’s move out of New York gives the art world a chance to shake its addiction to what has, in fact, always been tobacco money.
Marion Jones, the former track and field star who admitted Friday that she used performance-enhancing drugs, relinquished the five medals she won at 2000 Sydney Olympics.
Residents of a tiny town in the Northwoods of Wisconsin were reeling after, police say, an off-duty sheriff’s deputy went on a shooting rampage.
America’s largest truck-leasing company said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings would be less than it forecast as demand fell for freight-hauling trucks.
As global demand soars and prices rise, energy companies are going to the ends of the earth to find new supplies.
Florida’s largest private landowner plans to eliminate more than 75 percent of its work force, sell about 100,000 acres of land and scrap its dividend.

The thoroughbred great John Henry, a two-time horse of the year who earned more than $6.5 million before retiring to the Kentucky Horse Park, was euthanized yesterday, the park said. He was 32. A park spokeswoman said John Henry’s health had declined over the weekend. John Henry, a gelding, had lost considerable body mass and was in kidney failure, she said. John Henry, a Hall of Famer, was retired 22 years ago to the park, where officials were making plans for a public memorial service.
Despite an impressive résumé, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. is struggling to draw crowds and coverage on the trail.

Edwyn Owen, who played on the 1960 team that won the first Olympic gold medal in hockey for the United States, was found dead in a burning car in Topeka, Kan. He was 71. Investigators have not determined the cause of the fire but said part of the engine probably made accidental contact with dry grass, leading to flames that spread to the car.Autopsy results released said that Owen, who was known as Bob, died of smoke inhalation, thermal burns and heart disease. His car was found engulfed in flames Friday near a Topeka park.Owen played on the team that won the gold in Squaw Valley, Calif. He did not play professional hockey after the Olympics.

Bernard Robinson, a reserve with the Nets, tore the medial collateral ligament in his left knee in practice last week. Rod Thorn, the Nets’ president, said there was no timetable for his return. After being acquired from Charlotte in exchange for Jeff McInnis and cash considerations in January, Robinson, a three-year veteran swingman, played 10 games for the Nets. He has averaged 4.6 points, 2.6 rebounds and 1 assist in 128 career games.
The unusual heat and humidity that plagued major road races Sunday has event organizers reviewing their preparations for those conditions — and their plans for future races.

The jurors in the British inquest into the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, 10 years ago traveled to Paris to retrace her final moments. They went by bus to the traffic tunnel where the car Diana and her companion, Emad Mohamed al-Fayed, known as Dodi, were riding in crashed into a pillar. The police stopped traffic there for about 20 minutes to allow the group to inspect the tunnel on foot.

The police said they had arrested a man on suspicion of behaving indecently toward three teenage girls at Aiglon College in Chesières, one of the most exclusive preparatory schools in the world. Shortly after the episode, Prince Andrew of Britain announced that his eldest daughter, Princess Beatrice, fifth in line to the throne, would not attend Aiglon as planned.

Voters in Costa Rica, Central America’s second biggest economy, backed a free trade agreement with the United States in a referendum Sunday. With 96.3 percent of the vote counted, 51.6 percent of voters backed the agreement, the independent Supreme Electoral Tribunal said on its Web site. President Óscar Arias, above, the winner of the 1987 Nobel Peace Prize, has staked much of his political agenda on passage of the agreement. A rejection would have been the first time a free trade deal with the United States was refused by any country. Before the voting began, the White House warned that the United States would not renegotiate the accord if it was voted down.

The health minister announced plans to limit the right of young doctors to work abroad as a survey showed that almost 50 percent of them were ready to seek better-paid jobs elsewhere. The new legislation would include a requirement for young doctors to practice at home for twice as many years as they spent in training before they could obtain a certificate allowing them to work abroad. A medical intern earns about $210 a month, while a specialist working in a hospital earns about $700, according to official figures.

The International Court of Justice in the Hague, the United Nations’ highest court, granted Honduras sovereignty over four Caribbean islands in its decades-old dispute with Nicaragua, and carved up rich fishing grounds and offshore exploration concessions for oil and gas. The decision by the court is binding and without appeal. Both countries found elements to like in the judgment: Honduras got the islands, while Nicaragua could argue that the court gave it more than it had sought.

The police in Europe have unscrambled digitally manipulated images found on the Internet to reveal the face of a man shown abusing boys in Vietnam and Cambodia. Interpol released four reconstructed photos in a public appeal for help, hoping that someone will recognize the man whose identity and nationality remain a mystery and who, it said, apparently travels the world sexually abusing boys. The pictures had been manipulated to disguise the face with a twirling pattern. Computer specialists in Germany’s federal police force worked with Interpol to reverse the blurring effect. The resulting photos show a man with slightly receding dark hair, 35 to 40 years old. Interpol asked people who recognize him or who have other information to contact the police or the Interpol bureau in their country.

Ending a three-year moratorium on the death penalty, Afghanistan executed 15 prisoners in Kabul by gunfire for crimes including murder, kidnapping and armed robbery. Officials said no fighters for the Taliban or Al Qaeda were among them. The deaths could complicate relationships between the government and some NATO countries with military forces that hand captured militants over to the Afghan government, raising the question of whether countries that do not use the death penalty might stop surrendering prisoners. The Dutch Foreign Ministry expressed distress, saying, “Abolition of the death penalty is one of our priorities in terms of international human rights policy.”.

Yang Chunlin, a land rights activist who was detained in July after obtaining more than 10,000 signatures on a petition that proclaimed human rights more important than playing host to the Olympics, has been chained for days in fixed position and forced to clean the wastes of other inmates, according to the group China Human Rights Defenders. Mr. Yang is awaiting trial in Heilongjiang Province on charges of subverting state power. According to relatives, he has been denied access to a lawyer.
The next generation of cancer drugs may come from organisms pulled from a 40-billion-gallon pit with corrosive water the color of a scab.
Detroit is facing the possibility of two strikes within just three weeks if talks between the United Automobile Workers and Chrysler fail to produce a deal by Wednesday.
Some terrorism and security experts are supporting a plan to grant driver’s licenses to illegal immigrants, saying it will bring a hidden population into the open.
The Starch service, which measures print advertising effectiveness, is undergoing a major makeover in a sign of the growing importance of accountability to advertisers.
The ice was cold but everything else was hot on the first official day of ice skating at Rockefeller Center.
Condo developers must begin repaying construction loans taken out before the market turned sour, but if buyers do not close, some lenders may be left holding the bag.
A former pizza parlor manager was sentenced to life in prison Monday for kidnapping one of two boys whom the authorities said he held captive and sexually abused in his apartment.
Gary D. Forsee’s resignation came on the heels of news reports last week that the company’s board was seeking to replace him as early as December.
The environmental impact report’s approval is vital to the $20 billion project because it allows a series of multibillion-dollar loans to be exercised.
The Harlem Honeys and Bears are Manhattan’s only synchronized swimming group for adults ages 50 and older.
Repairs to the  apartment building damaged in last October’s plane crash are in the “home stretch”, according to a co-president of its condominium board.
The European Union said the Thomson Corporation’s plan to buy the Reuters Group raised competition concerns for the supply of financial information.
Underscoring the importance of unmanned aircraft to the United States military, Textron Inc. said it would buy the United Industrial Corporation for about $1.1 billion.
As another retailer, Stop & Shop, moved to discontinue film processing at its 300 stores last month, the nation’s new emphasis on digital processing is pronounced.
A news helicopter pilot stepped out of a Midtown oyster bar only to be struck by an out-of-control yellow taxicab that jumped the curb, the police and witnesses said.
Mr. Golden was an investment banker, a philanthropist and a main architect of American science policy in the 20th century.
Senator Barack Obama presented a plan on Monday to decrease the nation’s dependence on foreign oil and fight global warming.
The Service Employees International Union board gave the go-ahead to locals to endorse a candidate, an unusual move.
Eager to expand the holiday shopping season, retailers are trying a novel approach: early advertising that deliberately plays down the tinsel and holly.
The Diamondbacks’ staff had a 3.73 earned run average when Chris Snyder was behind the plate, the fourth lowest by a catcher in the majors this season.
Television images of about a dozen masked men were broadcast by Kosovo’s main public television channel last Wednesday.
A photographer for the New York Post could face six years in prison after being arrested on the job.

An 81-year-old man entering his parked car in Middle Village was killed yesterday morning when another driver smashed into the vehicle, the police said. The man, Franz Fuerch of 75th Street, was struck by a car driven by Diana Toro, 29, of Queens about 11 a.m., the police said. Mr. Fuerch was the father of Richard Fuerch, a deputy fire chief who was one of three officers relieved of their commands after the fatal Deutsche Bank fire in August. The police said Ms. Toro crashed into another parked car before hitting Mr. Fuerch’s vehicle near the intersection of Metropolitan Avenue and 74th Street. Ms. Toro tried to drive away, but was restrained by witnesses, the police said. She was charged with driving while intoxicated and vehicular manslaughter, the police said.
Shelley Duncan attended the World Series last season to cheer for his brother, Chris, a St. Louis Cardinals outfielder, and support his father, Dave, the Cardinals’ pitching coach.

The police have charged a mother with second-degree murder after the remains of a newborn girl were found in a garbage bag inside a truck in the Orange County town of Deerpark. A woman reported finding the remains on Friday. On Sunday evening, the police charged Christine Maher, 37, who lives in a rental trailer on the property but was in the county jail at the time because of another arrest. She is accused of causing the child’s death after giving birth around Sept. 24.

A man has been charged with kidnapping after the police said he bound his former companion and her 78-year-old grandmother and assaulted them during a home invasion in Berlin. The man, Samuel Harrington, 33, of Naugatuck, is being held on a $1 million bond and is scheduled to be arraigned in State Superior Court today. The police said the women were hospitalized with serious injuries. The police have accused Mr. Harrington of breaking into his former companion’s house on Sunday morning, binding them with tape and beating them. Compiled by John Sullivan.

A man was arrested yesterday after the police said he chased another man through Bellport, rammed his car and shot it with a handgun. The dispute began at 8 a.m. on Bellport Avenue when the men, Terry Poyner, 34, of Bellport, and Eric Tischler, 32, of East Patchogue, argued and Mr. Tischler left in his 1992 Honda Prelude, the Suffolk County police said. Detective Sgt. Bryan McMenemy said there had been bad blood between them for a few years. The police said Mr. Poyner chased Mr. Tischler and repeatedly rammed his car. Mr. Tischler ran from the car and called the police, while Mr. Poyner fired two rounds from a .40-caliber handgun into the vehicle, the police said. Mr. Poyner was charged with criminal possession of a weapon, criminal mischief and reckless endangerment, the police said.

A mother and two of her children have died of injuries suffered in a fire last week, while a third child remained in critical condition yesterday, the authorities said. The fire devastated the family of Ernesto Sanford, who was at work when the blaze started Oct. 1 about 6 a.m. in their rented home in East Orange. On Friday, a boy, 2-year-old Jasani, died. The next day, Mr. Sanford’s wife, Angela Mickens-Sanford, 28, and their daughter LeShanti, 5, died. A 3-year-old girl named Shamaya is in critical condition at St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston, with burns over 90 percent of her body. The Essex County prosecutor’s office has called the blaze an accident, but it has yet to determine a cause.

A man was being held yesterday after the police said he falsely reported a shooting at the College of New Jersey, the Mercer County prosecutor’s office said. Michael Larkin, 19, of Trenton, was arrested Sunday afternoon after a 6 a.m. call reported a shooting at the school’s freshman dormitory in Ewing. The campus police and officers from the Ewing Township Police Department found no evidence of a shooting, college officials said. Mr. Larkin, who was not a student there, was being held at the Mercer County jail on a charge of making a false public alarm, with bail set at $25,000, the authorities said.
Ms. Rothman was a leader of the feminist health movement in the 1970s who suggested that women could  end very early pregnancies without medical supervision.
The Dallas Cowboys scored 9 points in the final 20 seconds last night, with Nick Folk’s 53-yard field goal as time expired giving them an improbable 25-24 victory against the Buffalo Bills.
Rescue workers found the wreckage of a private plane in the Cascade Range and began searching for survivors.
The fast-food giant said its third-quarter profit had risen 17 percent on the strength of surging sales in the international and China divisions.
Prosecutors plan to dismiss the case against a federal prosecutor who had been accused of arranging to have sex with a 5-year-old girl after he committed suicide in prison.
A plan to turn a Victorian house into a historic Connecticut town’s first synagogue has met with stiff opposition.
The Communist Party of  India has seized on the country’s deepening friendship with the United States to emerge as an oppositional force against the coalition government.
Seeking more pay and pension and job security, Royal Mail carriers and sorters began their second strike in less than a week on Monday.
Plaxico Burress has become an unexpected role model and leader on the Giants. Surprisingly shy and thoughtful, he speaks in a whisper but never avoids a question.
The Jets can reel themselves back onto firmer ground by stringing together a winning streak, but they cannot afford any more false steps or their character may spring a few leaks.
In the deadliest of a series of blasts Monday, a suicide bomber drove his truck into a police station north of Baghdad.
The new service represents Google’s first steps toward turning its powerful ad network, which places ads on Internet sites, into a system for distributing content.
Signs of epizootic hemorrhagic disease, a virus carried by tiny biting insects, have been found in the carcasses of nearly 200 deer in New Jersey, stat officials said.
The Royal Bank of Scotland, Banco Santander and Fortis won control of ABN Amro, the biggest Dutch bank, after shareholders backed a buyout bid valued at $101 billion.
Investors cashed in some gains from last week’s rally and awaited quarterly corporate earnings reports as Wall Street finished a quiet session mostly lower.
Andrew Witty was named GlaxoSmithKline’s new chief executive, ending a yearlong internal competition to succeed Jean-Pierre Garnier, who retires next year.
Three men were charged with murder on Monday in the shooting of a football player on the University of Memphis campus during an attempted robbery, the authorities said.
The basket of a hot-air balloon in Albequerque tipped after the craft became stuck Monday, sending a woman on a 60-to-70-foot fall to her death, the state police said.
Thanks to the balloon man, also known as Tom Durnin, it is hard to be a stranger in Hazlet, N.J.
An aid worker arrested last month was in possession of  information that could jeopardize national security, a prosecutor at a Nigerian High Court said Monday.
While many school systems are banning iPods, some are also trying to co-opt the devices to help students learn subjects from French to chemistry.

YOU CAN LOOK IT UP And probably will, because you are not going to believe some of the first-class round-trip fares for flights between New York and Hong Kong. One example: Cathay Pacific’s nonstop published walk-up fare for first class was listed at $23,537 round trip yesterday, according to Terry Trippler, an air fare analyst. “That’s the highest published fare I’ve ever seen, and I’ve been doing this for 38 years,” he said. On the booking site Orbitz.com, round-trip walk-up fares on New York-Hong Kong routes with one stop ranged from about $10,000 on several airlines to about $22,000 on United. Surging demand for premium seats on the North Atlantic and Asian routes is a major reason for the sky-high walk-up fares. Another reason is airlines know that some travelers booking on short notice have little flexibility.
Seeking to ease soaring insurance premiums, New York regulators are proposing that insurance companies set aside extra money to pay for major hurricane damage.
The economic far right, not social conservatives, calls the shots in the Republican nominating process.
Thanks to new information technologies and various hotel programs, traveling sports fans can more easily track scores and close deals while on the road.
Reviews of the Lanvin, Louis Vuitton, Miu Miu and Ralph Rucci shows in Paris.
The Detroit Symphony Orchestra named Leonard Slatkin as its next music director.

Lending video games a fresh gloss of professional respectability, the Writers Guild of America intends to present its first Videogame Writing Award at its 2008 Writers Guild prize ceremony in February in Los Angeles.

One week after “Desperate Housewives” returned for its fourth season on ABC, the network’s Sunday night lineup remained down but still solid in the ratings, finishing second only to NBC’s live football coverage.
To some eyes the words “Portslade Massif” scrawled in white emulsion paint across the window and wall of the Ink-d Gallery in Brighton, England, appeared to be the work of vandals.
Celine Dion plans a yearlong, worldwide tour beginning on Feb. 14 to promote “Taking Chances,” her first English-language album in three years.
To the Editor:.
In a small university town in Sweden, vandals destroyed seven large photographs, part of an exhibition titled “The History of Sex,”  by the New York artist Andres Serrano.
Leonard Slatkin is named Detroit Symphony director, cracked floor is sculptor’s statement, cleaning crew erases an artist’s words and more culture news.
To some eyes the 548-foot crack running the length of the Turbine Hall at the Tate Modern museum in London may be nothing more than a hole in the floor.
To the Editor:.
Amanda Congdon, who made news last year when she graduated from the webcast news show “Rocketboom” to ABCNews.com, is making news now because ABC News declined to renew her video-blogging contract
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
When an actor walked offstage during a performance of “Is.Man,” he carried any hope of a dazzling American debut for the Dutch writer Adelheid Roosen.
When I travel, I am reminded of the anonymous voices sharing their latent animosities, soulful confessions and hidden acts of kindness that happened while traveling.
To the Editor:.
Two Americans and a Briton won the 2007 Nobel Prize in medicine for their work in gene targeting.
The LeFrak housing company, known for its sturdy brick buildings from Queens to Manhattan, is now developing upscale properties under a new generation of ownership.
On Sunday night at Madison Square Garden, Marc Anthony’s electrifying salsa set was merely the prelude for  Jennifer Lopez’s pop extravaganza.
A large part of “Xover’s” witty spell lies in the paths the dancers trace across the stage.
This production, insightfully and urgently conducted by Donald Runnicles and featuring the impressive German tenor Peter Seiffert in the title role, bodes well for David Gockley’s tenure.
When a group of people agree on something, that doesn’t always mean they are right.
The Gotham Early Music Scene hopes to expand the audience for early music in New York, and high on its list of strategies are sampler concerts.
Reading a baboon’s mind affords an excellent grasp of the dynamics of baboon society.
It seems that the antidepressant has emerged as the drug of choice among women searching for new ways to cool the hot flash.
Although this novel shares some themes with Alice Sebold’s acclaimed best seller, “The Lovely Bones,” it demonstrates none of the psychological acuity or emotional chiaroscuro of that earlier book.
President Nursultan A. Nazarbayev indicated a cooling in the dispute with the Italian-led consortium developing the Kashagan project.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.

Terry Dean Bartlett and Katie Workum took an imaginary trip to Paris for their latest installment of DanceOff! — rechristened, for the night, FranceOff! — as part of the French Institute Alliance Française’s Crossing the Line festival.
Shares of SoHo China, a Beijing property developer, soared 15 percent on their first day of trading in Hong Kong, valuing the company at $6 billion.
The Orchestra of St. Luke’s successfully harnessed the moviegoing idea on Saturday night in an intermittently successful program of new music in a new format called “In the Grace of the World.”
The mezzo-soprano Beth Clayton took the stage of the New York State Theater on Sunday afternoon as a Carmen prepared to eat the whole wimpy garrison of soldiers for breakfast.
One of the sobering lessons of “Treasures III: Social Issues in American Film 1900-1934” is that the pictures of this period were in many ways more open to the social and political world.
Researchers have discovered a plant for which pollination is only partly about smelling nice.
More than 100 pro-democracy students clashed with supporters of the president Monday at Tehran University.
Forty years after his death, Che Guevara is as much a marketing tool as he is an icon of socialist revolution.
A town in Darfur near the African Union peacekeeper base that was attacked last month has been razed to the ground and 7,000 residents have fled.
Esa-Pekka  Salonen has been a composer all along, as Friday’s Composer Portrait at the Miller Theater conclusively demonstrated.
“Secrets of the Samurai Sword,” an installment of the “Nova” series, could have used a few more bits of dazzle to enliven what is essentially a metallurgy clinic.
Recent entries from Tara Parker-Pope’s blog, at nytimes.com/health.
Mosquito nets have the potential to save lives in malaria-plagued countries. But what is the best way to get them to those who need them most?
The so-called sterile clean rooms where NASA assembles its spacecraft and prepares them for launching houses an interesting array of bacteria.
The move suggests that the alliance on Iraq forged between former Prime Minister Tony Blair and Washington is unraveling.
The military junta in Myanmar said that it had named its deputy labor minister to act as a liaison with the opposition leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi.
For the first time, scientists have successfully implanted blood vessels grown from a patient’s own cells.
Science Times readers respond to articles about global warming, cats and marital spats.
Cushy bumpers placed around your baby’s crib may do more harm than good, a new study finds.
Postmenopausal women who suffer from full-blow panic attacks may be at a higher risk for heart disease and death.
In time of economic crisis, rates of obesity, diabetes, stroke and coronary heart disease drop, a new study finds.
A spokesman ruled out an assassination attempt in the crash, which killed four people on Monday.
Turns out timing may matter when it comes to children’s television habits.
Coronary CT scans may offer valuable insight for those looking to find the cause of their high cholesterol. But are there risks?
Is too much chlorine bad for your hair and skin?
Understanding how satellites work.
Researchers are trying to discover the cause of declining fish populations.
A tiny camera records the activities of crows.
Registered Traveler programs are moving ahead slower than anticipated as the T.S.A. lags in approving technology that would speed up airport security checks.
Joe Torre has been a fixture for 12 years, never missing the postseason. Torre always seemed to be the right man for the job across the long, hot Steinbrenner summer.
On TBS, Chip Caray’s play-by-play of the Yankees’ 8-4 win in Game 3 on Sunday night was packed with errors and silly strategy, enough to give me agita.
Paul Byrd pitched into the sixth inning, allowed two runs and struck out Alex Rodriguez twice as the Indians won, 6-4, and sent the Yankees home.
Although Torre has won four titles with the Yankees, Derek Jeter said this might have been his best year of managing because he rallied a team that seemed out of the playoffs at midseason.
The Cleveland Indians eliminated the Yankees in their American League division series in what may have been  Manager Joe Torre’ s final game.
Alex Rodriguez, who may be the finest baseball player in the world, was the first Yankee on the field Monday and the first player working. But it wasn’t enough to help the Yankees win.

Irakli Okruashvili, a prominent former government official, recanted on national television his claims that President Mikheil Saakashvili was corrupt and had committed grave crimes and cover-ups, including ordering the assassination of an Georgian oligarch. Mr. Okruashvili had held top posts in Mr. Saakashvili’s government, including defense minister, before declaring his opposition to the president. After making allegations against Mr. Saakashvili last month, Mr. Okruashvili was promptly arrested and charged with corruption. His turnabout on television was not immediately explained. His lawyer later said that she had not been allowed to attend the videotaped confession, raising questions about the confession’s credibility. Politicians loyal to Mr. Saakashvili suggested that Mr. Okruashvili had been plotting a coup, and that more arrests would be made.

MASSARSKY--Steven , Entertainment attorney and business entrepreneur, dies at 59. Steven Massarsky, an attorney and businessman who was a mentor to many and always generous when it came to sharing knowledge and guiding others to follow their dreams, died October 5, 2007 at 12:26pm EDT, in Manhattan. He was 59 and lived in Manhattan. The cause was complications related to cancer, said his mother Yetta Massarsky. Steven Massarsky was most recently founder and CEO of the Business Incubation Group Inc. The Business Incubation Group primarily focused on incubating companies that market and sell consumer products and services. His responsibilities included management of the company and its personnel. The Business Incubation Group provided business, strategic and marketing direction to the incubatees and liaising with advisors and consultants. In 1989, backed by venture capital, Massarsky co-founded Voyager Communications Inc. (Valiant Comics), which grew into the third largest comic book publisher in the U.S. In 1993, Voyager was voted ''publisher of the year'' by the comic book retail industry. The following year, the company was sold to Acclaim Entertainment, Inc. (NASDAQ) where Massarsky remained as President and Publisher of the Acclaim Comics division. As President and Publisher of Acclaim Comics and its predecessor Voyager Communications, Massarsky was responsible for the vision, operation and all development and strategic planning worldwide. Earlier in his career, Massarsky operated an entertainment law practice; his clientele included Nintendo, The Wailers, Cabbage Patch Dolls, the Psychedelic Furs, Collins Management, Aerosmith, Tom Chapin, Muse America and Willie Mays. Prior to his law practice, Massarsky owned and operated an artist management company and managed the careers of artists such as The Allman Brothers Band and The Wailers, and was responsible for launching the career of Cyndi Lauper. Massarsky began his career working in the management of political campaigns such as George McGovern, John Kerry, Alan Cranston and Allard Lowenstein. Massarsky held an A.B. in political science from Brown University and a J.D. from Rutgers University School of Law. He is a founding board member of The Brown University Entrepreneurship Program, served on the boards of Shop Well With You (not-for-profit) and BAM Entertainment (NASDAQ). He was a frequent guest lecturer at universities and graduate schools. Massarsky was a member of the California and New York Bar Associations and the Brown University Sports Foundation. He was a member of the Weehawken, NJ Hall of Fame. Mr. Massarsky, son of the late Asher Massarsky, D.D.S., is survived by his mother, Yetta Massarsky, of Fort Lee, New Jersey; sisters and brothers-in-law Ellen Gertler and Richard Gertler, D.D.S. and Marilyn and David Judovin; five nieces, a nephew and seven great-nieces and nephews; and his loving fiancee Pui King Hui. Funeral Services were on Sunday, October 7 at 1pm at the Gutterman-Musicant, 402 Park Avenue in Hackensack, NJ. He was buried at the Riverside Cemetery in Rochelle Park, New Jersey. Donations can be made to the James F. Holland Research Fund, c/o Dr. James Holland, Mount Sinai Hospital, One Gustav L. Levy Place, Box 1129, New York, NY 10029.

(Cinemax) DEAR TALULA ''One minute I'm in that bubble of new motherhood, and the next I'm told I have breast cancer,'' the filmmaker Lori Benson says in this short documentary chronicling her experiences with the disease at 38, a little over a year after the birth of her daughter, Talula. After receiving her diagnosis, Ms. Benson, above with Talula, began filming her life -- from her decision to have a mastectomy to her fear of her mortality. Mostly, ''Dear Talula'' is a love letter to her daughter. 8 P.M. Where does a candidate go to find ''wise counsel and invaluable experience'' for his campaign? Fred D. Thompson has turned to his mentor, to a daughter of the vice president and to a former Virginia senator whose defeat last fall contributed to the Democratic takeover of the Senate. Yesterday, Mr. Thompson appointed to his leadership team former Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., who is regarded as Tennessee's political dean; Elizabeth Cheney, the vice president's daughter who has worked for the State Department on Middle East policy; and George Allen, the former Virginia senator.

Fred D. Thompson, a Republican candidate for president, spoke to a few hundred people the other night in one of the ballrooms in the Marriott convention center in Coralville, Iowa. The crowd, not unusually for a political event in Iowa, was decidedly older, for the most part north of 50. A few hours later, Senator Barack Obama, the Illinois Democrat, addressed an audience of more than 1,000 just up the hallway. His crowd contained a striking number of people under 30. Mr. Obama has clearly struck a chord among younger voters. And his campaign has made what seems to be the most sophisticated effort of any of the Democrats to reach out to them, sending recruiting teams to Iowa high schools and trying to ensure that New Hampshire college students who might be out of state on Primary Day get absentee ballots.

MORGAN--J.Ronald, Jr . Finacial Services Executive, dies at 69. J. Ronald Morgan Jr., retired CEO of Pershing Limited in London and former CEO of Thomson McKinnon Securities in New York, died on October 6th at his home in East Hampton. He was surrounded by his beloved wife Carol, daughters Kelly and Kim, sons Ron, Ted, Chris and Scott, sister Joan, and sister-in-law Marilyn. The cause was cancer. Mr. Morgan had been battling melanoma for ten months. Born on April 25, 1938 in Brooklyn, New York, he was the son of the late J. Ronald and Irene Morgan, He received a Bachelor's Degree in Business Administration from Manhattan College in 1960. J. Ronald began his career in 1966 as a Certified Public Accountant with Coopers & Lybrand in New York. From 1966 to 1989 he worked for the retail brokerage firm, Thomson McKinnon Securities, becoming Chief Operating Officer in 1984 and then Chairman and CEO in 1987. During the same time, he was Trustee for the Financial Accounting Standards Board, Chairman of the National Securities Clearing Corporation. Chairman of the New York Stock Exchange Regulatory Committee, and Director of the Securities Industry Association. In 1990, Mr. Morgan moved to London as CEO of Pershing's UK operation, a post he held until 2004 when he retired. During his 15 years in London, he was Director of Pershing Limited, CREST Co., DLJ Direct UK, DLJ International, CSFB Europe and London Clearing House. In April of 2006, he was named a non-executive Director for iimia Investment Group plc. In his spare time, J. Ronald was Treasurer and Board member of the Huntington Crescent Club, Board Member of the Canterbury School in New Milford, Connecticut, and most recently Treasurer of the East Hampton Rotary Club. Mr. Morgan is survived by his loving wife Carol, his two daughters Kelly Morgan and Kim Wieland, his four sons J. Ronald III, Edward, Christopher, and Scott; and his 15 grandchildren. He is also survived by sister Joan Flatley and brother Thomas Morgan. A wake will be held from 5-8pm on Wednesday, October 10, 2007 at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, on Madison Avenue in New York. Funeral Services will be held at the Church of St. Patrick on Thursday, October 11, 2007 in Huntington, New York.

When the major Republican candidates debate tonight in Dearborn, Mich., political observers will be focused on Fred D. Thompson, the former Tennessee senator and onetime ''Law & Order'' actor whose early performance on the stump has been panned. The thinking among pundits is that his presidential fortunes could pivot on how well he does at the debate. But how many people watch these debates anyway? Ratings show that the total is more than usually watch a cable television program and considerably more than the number tuned in around this point in the 2004 race.

GOTBAUM--Carol Anne Stiger , 1961 -2007. Funeral services were held Sunday for Carol Anne Stiger Gotbaum, who died tragically on September 28, beloved wife of Noah Gotbaum, and cherished mother of Ella, Nathaniel and Tobias Gotbaum. She is also survived by two sisters, Heidi Serra of London, England, and Patricia Muller of Pretoria, South Africa, and a step-mother Dassie Stiger. Her parents, Commander Brian and Catherine Vorster Stiger and a sister, Geraldine Merle, prede ceased her. Carol was the daughter-in-law of Victor and Betsy Gotbaum of New York and Sarah Gotbaum of Chevy Chase, Maryland. Her insight, warmth, compassion and loving nature will be sorely missed by her family and all who knew her. She gave selflessly and touched so many lives all over the world. The family asks those wishing to honor Carol to donate to any of the following charities: Phoenix House www.phoenix house.org which operates drug and alcohol treatment and prevention programs; Mothers2Mothers, www. m2m.org, an AIDS prevention charity in her beloved South Africa; New York Cares, http://nycares.org, which connects caring volunteers to people in need; or to the Carol Anne Gotbaum Memorial Fund at Congregation Rodeph Sholom www. rodephsholom.org.

GOLDEN--William T., on October 7th, just short of his 98th birthday. Adored Husband of Catherine Morrison Golden and of the late Sibyl Levy Golden. Beloved Father of Sibyl R. Golden and Pamela P. Golden. Loving Son of the late S. Herbert and Rebecca H. Golden. Devoted Brother of the late Barry Golden. Dear friend to many. Funeral private. Memorial Service at a later date. GOLDEN--William T. It is with profound sadness and deep affection that the Trustees and Staff of the American Museum of Natural History mourn the death of William T. Golden, our superb Chairman from 1989 to 1994, distinguished Chairman Emeritus thereafter, and an esteemed Trustee for nearly 40 years. Bill was one of the Museum's guiding stars whose wise counsel, incisive intelligence, passionate involvement, and commitment to science were unsurpassed. In his distinguished and highly influential career, Bill dedicated himself tirelessly to increasing the understanding of science among both the public and policymakers, championing public support of the scientific endeavor as an investment in our country's future, and fostering a scientifically literate citizenry. The Museum was enormously privileged to have his outstanding leadership and able hand during a time of important institutional growth and transformation. His leadership and longstanding generosity are captured in his role in helping the Museum advance the frontiers of science, including building vanguard research programs in such areas as microbial biology, and, perhaps most tangibly, in the beautiful Golden Corridor of Science, which extends through the Museum's research areas and bridges scientists and disciplines. It stands as a symbol of Bill's devotion to the scientific pursuit as a catalyst for the advancement of society and humanity, which was a hallmark of his remarkable life. He found unending joy and fascination in science and in the wonders of nature. In this and so many other ways, he will always be a touchstone for all of us at the Museum. He was a renaissance man, a great New Yorker, a great American, and a great citizen of the world. Most of all, Bill was the dearest of friends, forever young in spirit and intellect and we shall miss him terribly. Our deepest condolences go to his beloved wife Catherine, his daughter Sibyl, Chairman of the Museum's Center for Biodiversity and Conservation, his daughter Pamela, and the many whose lives he touched. Lewis W. Bernard, Chairman Ellen V. Futter, President GOLDEN--William T. The entire Barnard College community is deeply saddened by the death of our long-serving trustee William T. Golden. Bill was a generous, active, and steadfast supporter of Barnard for over 30 years. For his many contributions to the College, as well as his lifelong dedication to advancing public support for the sciences and the humanities, he was presented with the Barnard Medal of Distinction in 1999. Sincere condolences are offered to his wife Catherine, daughters Sibyl and Pamela, and his entire family. Anna Quindlen, Chair of the Board Judith Shapiro, President GOLDEN--William T. The Trustees, Faculty, and Staff of The Mount Sinai Medical Center mourn the passing of William T. Golden, a dedicated member of our Boards of Trustees were he served with distinction for more than 52 years. Bill Golden's personal commitment to science at Mount Sinai was outstanding. In addition to being one of the founders of The Mount Sinai School of Medicine, he generously supported research endowment programs and other trustee initiative. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Catherine, his daughters, Dr. Pamela P. Golden and Sibyl R. Golden, and the entire family. Peter W. May, Chairman The Board of Trustees, Kenneth L. Davis, M.D., President and CEO, The Mount Sinai Medical Center GOLDEN--William T. The Board of Trustees and staff of The New York Hall of Science mourns the passing of William T. Golden. His vision and leadership launched the position of Science Advisor to the President during the Truman administration. His lifelong commitment to education in the sciences and substantive international and domestic science policy discussions have enriched the nation and will benefit generations to come. Nicholas Donofrio, Co-Chair Ivan Seidenberg, Co-Chair Marilyn Hoyt, Pres & CEO Alan Friedman, Consulting Senior Scientist

The Union Square Theater is carving out a niche as a home for a kind of barely verbal foreign import that has become a standard feature of the Off Broadway menu. These high-energy spectacles -- the offspring of hits like ''Stomp'' and ''Blue Man Group'' -- are sometimes called events or experiences, and audiences are usually told that the shows are a sensation somewhere very far away. This year it was ''Be,'' a rather loud headache from Israel featuring half-dressed actors leaping in the air, clowning around and banging on things. The new tenant is the lowbrow South Korean entertainment ''Jump,'' offering another band of half-dressed actors leaping and banging and clowning. There are differences, of course, but they aren't much greater than those between the menus at McDonalds in Seoul and Tel Aviv.

October being an auspicious month in the history of Moominland, the Manitoba Theater for Young People, from Winnipeg, Canada, has pitched its tent at the Duke on 42nd Street to perform ''Comet in Moominland,'' Graham Whitehead's adaptation of the 1946 novel of the same title by the Finnish writer and artist Tove Jansson. Playing through Sunday as a presentation of the New Victory Theater, this absorbing and imaginative intermissionless 55-minute show, created by William Chesney, Leslee Silverman and Mr. Whitehead, brings to faithful, slightly truncated life Ms. Jansson's tale of young Moomintroll and his friends and family as a fiery comet hurtles toward an October rendezvous with Earth.

Perhaps the most famous exchange from Rudolph W. Giuliani's radio call-in show during his years as mayor of New York was when he told one caller angered by the city's ban on pet ferrets that he was ''somewhat deranged,'' adding, ''This excessive concern with little weasels is a sickness.'' So with Mr. Giuliani now running for president, The Caucus reached out to that caller, David J. Guthartz, who said, ''I'm so well-grounded it's not even funny.'' Mr. Guthartz is now the executive president of New York Ferrets Rights Advocacy/ The Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Ferrets.

Doctors are writing a new prescription for menopause: the antidepressant. It's not that all menopausal women are depressed. Instead, the antidepressant has emerged as the drug of choice among women searching for new ways to cool the hot flash.

Upsetting a heavily favored South Korean squad, a group of video gamers from the United States won the overall team title over the weekend at the World Cyber Games Grand Final in Seattle. The World Cyber Games is one of the world's biggest video game tournaments, and the finals drew more than 700 players from 74 countries. Competing in 12 PC and Xbox 360 games, the United States team won three gold medals, in Dead or Alive 4, Gears of War and Tony Hawk Project 8. South Korea and Brazil each took two gold medals, and Germany won one. In his first professional tournament Dustin Valcalda of Reno, Nev., went undefeated in Tony Hawk. Over all, the tournament awarded more than $500,000 in cash and prizes. ''With so many quality video game players representing 74 countries this weekend, e-sports continues to gain popularity and worldwide acceptance,'' Hyoung-Seok Kim, chief executive of International Cyber Marketing, the tournament's organizer, said in a statement.

There is no hardier theme in musical theater than the story of the ingénue trying to break into the cold, cruel world of showbiz. The latest entry in the lists, ''Greetings From Yorkville,'' by Anya Turner and Robert Grusecki, at the SoHo Playhouse, puts a reality-show spin upon this familiar subject. This time it's the autobiographical story of a struggling team of songwriters trying to get a foothold on the big time, performed by the people who wrote and lived it. Such self-referentiality could be squirm-inducing; here it's not -- or not very often. The story is slender enough: Boy meets girl, girl finds cheap walk-up on the Upper East Side (the Yorkville of the title), boy and girl work various jobs and try to get their songs heard.

I find it very interesting how McLaren Mercedes today sent out a press release stating that there would be, and always has been, absolutely fair and equal treatment of the two drivers on the team, Fernando Alonso and Lewis Hamilton. It is a sign of how important that concept is to the McLaren team. Take a look at Michael Schumacher's treatment at Ferrari and it is easy to see that the same concept of equality was never something that Ferrari particularly worried about. (Whether they were right or wrong is irrelevant, as is whether Schumacher deserved this or not. It could be argued that Schumacher was just so much better than most of his teammates that the team felt obliged to help him on a down day, knowing he would deliver in the end.) My point is that it is simply clear that Ferrari supported Schumacher over his teammates and did not worry about the concept of equality, whereas McLaren - which is being accused here and there of not treating both teammates equally - DOES value equality.

During the 2007 Major League Baseball season, the 30 franchises brought in 79.5 million fans, an all-time high. Of those 79.5 million people, 71.9 million of them attended games at stadiums other than Fenway Park, Coors Field, Jacobs Field and Chase Field, the home parks of the four remaining playoff teams. That adds up to a heckuva lot of people left with no rabid rooting interest from here on out.
