WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 - The way Representative John Yarmuth of Kentucky sees it, lawmakers on Capitol Hill and Americans everywhere have forgotten who the Founding Fathers really intended to run the country -- not the President who was more of a Constitutional after-thought but the Congress, the people's elected representatives.

In the third week of its fourth season, Fox's medical drama "House," with Hugh Laurie, continued to soar in the ratings, leading Tuesday night with 17.7 million viewers, according to Nielsen's estimates. Among adults 18 to 49, the 9 p.m. show easily surpassed its closest competitors on the night, NBC's "Law & Order: Special Victims Unit," which won the 10 p.m. hour with 12.2 million total viewers, and ABC's "Dancing With the Stars" results episode at 9 p.m. (16 million), which finished third overall in the 18 to 49 set.For the night, Fox ranked No. 1, despite its drama "Bones" (8.3 million) finishing runner up at 8 p.m. to CBS's "NCIS" (16.1 million). CBS earned second place overall in total viewers but finished fourth among adults 18 to 49.
You will still have to wait until Friday for my Gems & Gimps start/bench ramblings, but I just had to chime in on a few items of fantasy relevance that have unfolded in recent days.
The first review of Conscience of a Liberal I've seen, by Tyler Cowen:

Critics of "An Inconvenient Truth" include Al Gore's political opponents, global warming skeptics and even rank-and-file scientists. But the former vice president waited until today for a detailed review from a high court in Britain.

All that and a bag of S-chip: Conservative bloggers are in an introspective mood after the blogburst of outrage, much of it now retracted, over the economic status of the family of 12-year-old Graeme Frost, who gave the Democratic response to President Bush's radio address on Sept. 29. (See this story in The Times for details.)

London is rapidly developing as the favorite haven for the world's billionaires, according to a new report in the Wall Street Journal. Recent studies show that the U.K. is now home to 17 percent of Europe's high net-worth individuals and the number grew by more than 8 percent last year. Only three of the U.K.'s 10 richest people are originally from the U.K., the article notes.
Individual awards for players in team sports like soccer are always problematic.

OK, I did an interview via sportscam with talkingpointsmemo.com, one of my favorite sites. I haven't watched it myself yet, but here it is. I gather I did a masterful job of hiding the heaps of paper that cover every flat surface in my office.

How big is the problem?

When do you tell the parents?

What can and should universities do when a student seems to be in trouble?
From The Associated Press today:
When Anne Jarmain wrote and produced her first pilot for a television episode earlier this year, she wasn't certain whether the New York Television Festival would even accept it.
Many hedge funds wilted in the dog days of August, burned by the subprime mortgage market's implosion. But Morgan Stanley's quantitative-strategies traders had one heck of an awful day.
Promotional commercial for House & Garden "Design Happening" week.
DERRY, N.H. -- Hillary Rodham Clinton left her "Middle Class Express" bus behind in Iowa.

From the moment we first traveled to Beaufort, S.C., to meet Greg Huddy of Allison Ramsey Architects, we knew it was a going to be geographically challenging for two people from the Northeast to hire a South Carolina firm to design a house to be built in Florida.
Something was missing a few weeks ago when we examined Bill O'Reilly's remarks about his visit to a famous Harlem restaurant: Stephen Colbert's reaction.
From a barbershop in Northwest Washington, D.C., provided by a supporter of John Edwards with a sense of humor.
In last night's debate, both Rudolph W. Giuliani and Mitt Romney mentioned Hillary Clinton a dozen times, and not in a flattering way.

Zephyr Teachout, who was Howard Dean's director of online organizing during the 2004 presidential campaign, says the content on the Web sites for the current crop of Democratic presidential candidates is so vapid that it is "irreponsible and slightly offensive." She writes at techPresident, a group blog that follows the 2008 campaign online:
The Blackstone Group has the dubious distinction of having a Congressional bill named in its honor. But it's the Carlyle Group that seems to be activists' bete noir du jour.

When the Broncos' Mike Shanahan beat the Raiders with the help of a last-second timeout to ice kicker Sebastian Janikowski, it started a trend among coaches. Wade Phillips, the Cowboys' coach, complained about the tactic to Calvin Watkins of The Dallas Morning News, but even he admits he would try it.

Aired Tuesday night on NBC: Last night, the New York Yankees were eliminated from the playoffs by the Cleveland Indians. The Yankees are upset because their season is over -- and the Indians are upset because now they have to go back to Cleveland.
Aired Tuesday night on CBS: Beautiful day here in New York City, very warm again today - it was so warm that Pamela Anderson married Al Roker.
On Wednesdays, this blog is the delivery vehicle for "Living With Music," a playlist of songs from a writer or some other kind of book-world personage.

Shane M. Wallace, an investment banker who played a leading role on a number of the largest telecommunications mergers of the last 15 years, died Tuesday at his home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 38. The cause was brain cancer, his wife, Dana, said.
So Joe Klein didn't much like yesterday's Republican debate on the economy. Among his post-debate thoughts at Swampland, Time's political blog:
In the world of mergers and acquisitions, three letters still seem to be on the tip of everyone's tongue: M.A.C.

Honda has revealed two of the vehicles it will show at the Tokyo Motor Show at the end of the month. One, the Puyo, is a funky little thing that we've come to expect from the biannual Tokyo show. It's a bubble of a car that would fit in nicely with Corbin Bernsen's collection of snow globes. The other is a compact, glass-roof hatchback called the CR-Z.
After reading our "Celebrating Japanese Classics" post, Benjamin Hsu at Japanese Nostalgic Car directed me to this JC Penney commercial, featuring a first-generation Honda Accord.
Mariano Rivera said just now that if the Yankees dismiss Joe Torre as their manager, it will play a role in his decision to return to the team.
The last post generated some excellent nominations for cascades, and I welcome more, as well as suggestions for stopping mistaken cascades.
David Pogue offers a closer look at the Centro cellphone by Palm.

The Jena Six case resonated widely enough in the United States to spark the largest civil rights protest in years and a fierce national conversation, but the emotionally fraught object at its center appears to be ascendant as well.
A regime worth changing: Laura Bush takes to the op-ed page of The Wall Street Journal to tell the military junta in Myanmar to "step aside" in a "peaceful transition process." She writes:
Quick: Name the top five most-watched shows on basic cable so far this year.

In NBC Universal's $925 million purchase of Oxygen Media, the company is paying $12 a subscriber, Bill Carter reports in today's Times. "It paid $22 a subscriber for Bravo in 2002, when that channel had 54 million subscribers."

If you want to know the kind of high regard people have for Joe Torre, read this comment from Don Mattingly: "The two regrets I had as a player are that I wish I would have had a chance to play with Thurman, and I wish I would have had a chance to play for Joe."
My colleague David Leonhardt suggests that people don't feel that bad about the economy:

New Mexico Gov. Bill Richardson, a former pitcher for Tufts University who once wanted to play pro ball, has "2008 All Star" baseball cards printed up that feature him poised to pitch as part of his campaign literature.

Analysts and investors seem to be waving aside the possibility that the proposed merger of SABMiller and Molson Coors in the United States could run into trouble with regulators. But not that long ago, a similar deal seeking to combine the No. 2 and No. 3 players in a consolidated industry -- sometimes called a 3-to-2 deal, because it reduces the industry leaders from three to two -- was blocked on antitrust grounds.

There is always some sort of club vs. country rowe when national teams are trying to cobble together a squad for qualifying tournaments during the height of the European league and cup season. It's usually between the club managers and national team coaches who all want their best players healthy and on the field.

The United States Chess Federation, the governing body of chess in the United States, finds itself in a difficult position following the filing of a federal lawsuit accusing Susan Polgar and Paul Truong, who are married and are members of its executive board, of posting inflammatory remarks on the Internet under false names in order to get elected. The lawsuit by Samuel H. Sloan, who ran unsuccessfully for re-election to the board, was brought a week after an administrator of the federation's Web site published a report showing that Mr. Truong was most likely the author of the posts.

Aired Tuesday night on NBC: Well, the Republicans had another big presidential debate earlier today on CNBC. It's like NBC, but with even less viewers. Did you see them lined up? It looked like a pack of vanilla wafers. Attack of the white guys. I was waiting for a hockey game to break out.
The National Book Award finalist list is out this morning ... it looks interesting and not miserably strange at first glance. And, whew, Farrar, Straus & Giroux all but owns the fiction list.
Things seem to be getting back to normal in Myanmar, the kind of normal that prompted the huge protests in the first place.

At the new restaurant Tailor in SoHo, the servers wear pinstriped uniforms so form-fitting they look like riding outfits. The foie gras is paired with peanut butter and cocoa, the pork belly with butterscotch, and a vodka-based drink that looks like a martini tastes like pink bubblegum.
Truth squadding the most contentious point of the debate last night, Michael Cooper, the Times's City Hall budget reporter during the end of the Giuliani administration, notes:

News flash: Political debates still boring, even with Fred Thompson. "I thought that in his first debate Fred Thompson would come across as either bright or dumb," writes Roger Simon at The Politico. "I forgot about dull. He wasn't terrible. He wasn't great. He was just 'eh.'" Simon later adds:

Today's links have a distinctly off-the-field vibe. Whether it's possible violations by former players, alleged road-rage incidents involving legendary coaches or menacing phone calls to Heisman Trophy candidates, we've tried to collect it in a nice, neat package for you.
While commuting from Manhattan to an upstate New York teaching job, I got to experience the vigor of morning rush hour in Grand Central Terminal. I found the flow of people hypnotic.
The firms that have been pursuing Sallie Mae fired back on Tuesday, after the nation's largest student lender filed suit against them.
Many investors are wondering how Edward Lampert, the billionaire hedge-fund manager who controls Sears Holdings, plans to wring profits from the shopworn department-store chain.
Shareholders looking for deep pockets to sue in securities fraud cases faced an uphill battle at the Supreme Court on Tuesday.
Some hedge funds may intentionally inflate returns to avoid reporting losses and keep investors on board, according to a new study.

In his first public remarks since quitting last week as chief executive of the Internet phone company Skype, Niklas Zennstrom said Tuesday that he had no regrets about his handling of the company but conceded that he might have tried to squeeze money out of it too quickly.

With no deep-pocketed private equity investors on the horizon, Cadbury Schweppes has decided to go ahead with a plan to spin off its 7 billion-pound ($14.2 billion) North American soft drinks business.

Pzena Investment Management, which oversees more than $30 billion in assets for institutions, wealthy individuals and mutual funds, set a price range of $16 to $18 per share for its upcoming initial public offering. In an amended prospectus filed Wednesday with regulators, the firm said it planned to sell about 6.1 million shares in the offering, slightly below the 6.4 million shares it forecast in the previous prospectus.
The Royal Bank of Scotland is the investment bank that is most heavily exposed to a potential downturn in the private equity industry, according to an analysis by Financial News.

The buyout firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and the electric equipment distributor Sonepar of France were among companies that announced takeovers on Tuesday, indicating that the buyout market is still alive despite dire warnings by some analysts that merger activity would cool after this summer's turmoil in the credit markets.

Royal Philips Electronics, Europe's largest consumer electronics maker, plans to sell LG.Philips LCD shares for as much as $2.2 billion, according to sale documents e-mailed to investors and cited by Bloomberg News.

One of the Deutsche Bank's top United States consumer advisory bankers who quit the German bank earlier this year has emerged at the center of a merger to create a beer-brewing giant with combined revenues of $6.6 billion, Financial News reports.

Two blocks from the Capitol, a 20-something man lectured a full room at the Hyatt Regency Hotel filled with what appeared to recent college graduates, ranging in dress from jeans to suits. The focus of discussion was how to get candidates into office using the Web. And while it may sound like a typical Washington strategy session, the lecturers weren't the insiders you'd expect.

As proposals in the United States Congress to raise taxes on private equity firms and hedge funds appear to have stalled, lawmakers across the pond are moving forward with their own, albeit somewhat less onerous, plans.
Steven G. Schulman, a former partner at the law firm now known as Milberg Weiss, pleaded guilty on Tuesday to a racketeering conspiracy charge.

China has more billionaires than any country except the United States, as soaring stock and property prices helped to increase wealth among the country's super-rich, researcher Rupert Hoogewerf said on Wednesday.
Google said Tuesday that it had bought a Finnish start-up Jaiku, which makes a mobile phone application people can use to send short messages about where they are and what they are doing.

The Calyon trader fired last month for alleged unauthorized trading that led to 250 million euros ($353 million) of losses said his bosses knew what he was doing and considered him a "golden child" of the New York office.
Bank of America's $21 billion deal for LaSalle Bank may have some consequences for Chicago's private club scene.
AT&T agreed to pay $2.5 billion for licenses that will allow it to expand wireless services or provide video broadcasts in much of its coverage area, the company announced Tuesday.
Software maker Cognos has apparently not ruled out a sale of the company, after SAP's deal to buy a rival left it as the only large, independent vendor of business-intelligence software.

Despite the summer's woes at buyout firms and hedge funds, private investment vehicles -- large institutional investors with long-term plans to diversify away from simple stocks and bonds -- are likely to continue pouring billions into alternative investments, The New York Times reports. And at least for now, the effort to crimp the industry's tax advantages has faltered.
Motorola rejected the notion of buying Chicago-based digital mapmaker Navteq because such a deal would run counter to its strategy, Motorola's chief executive, Edward Zander, said Monday.

When Acxiom, the information services company, announced last week that its proposed buyers had backed out of their $2.25 billion deal to take it private, the company said that the two firms -- ValueAct Capital Partners and Silver Lake Partners -- had paid it $65 million, or half of the original $130 million breakup fee.
NBC Universal, it seems, got itself a bargain with its $925 million deal for Oxygen, a cable television channel aimed at women.
Venture capitalists who feared getting caught up in a proposal to raise taxes on "carried interest" breathed a sigh of relief as the bill appeared to stall in Congress.

Corporations are falling short in explaining executive compensation to investors, Securities and Exchange Commission officials said Tuesday in their first review of corporate filings since new pay disclosure rules were put in place.

Stock in China's biggest coal miner, Shenhua Energy, rose 87 percent in its Shanghai opening Tuesday after an initial public offering that raised 6.6 billion Chinese yuan ($8.9 billion), -- a record for a mainland stock exchange.

Newmont Mining agreed Tuesday to buy Miramar Mining of Vancouver, British Columbia, for about 1.5 billion Canadian dollars ($1.52 billion) in cash to gain access to the target's reserves in the Canadian Arctic.

The chairman of Alitalia told union officials Tuesday that he expected to reach a deal on the sale of the Italian government's 49.9 percent interest in the ailing airline within a month, prompting speculation that the government had abandoned most of the conditions that led to the collapse of an auction of the stake in June.
Golub Capital Partners, a middle-market lender, has pulled its $150 million initial public offering but plans to go public sometime in the future, an official said Tuesday.

Academics face many common career issues: the often interminable Ph.D., jobs that require relocation, battles for tenure. Then, even if they settle into positions, they struggle with how to spread their ideas beyond the ivory tower.

Internet advertising start-up ReachLocal has closed a $55.2 million Series D venture financing to offer small local businesses the same services that aQuantive and ValueClick provide to Fortune 500 companies.

A small-molecule drug developer Metastatix raised $35 million in a second round of venture financing led by Seattle's Frazier Healthcare Ventures to move its first compound for treatment of a variety of cancers into clinical development and to support additional drug programs in H.I.V. and inflammation.
Compiled by Andrew Das, Benjamin Hoffman, Naila-Jean Meyers, John Woods and Toni Monkovic
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

For parents who worry that their children will never eat anything but chocolate milk, Gummi vitamins and the occasional grape, a new study offers some relief. Researchers examined the eating habits of 5,390 pairs of twins between 8 and 11 years old and found children's aversions to trying new foods are mostly inherited.
What happens when idealism becomes power? That question is the driving force of Jeremy Kagan’s inert yet strangely compelling film “Golda’s Balcony.”
Where “Control” might have been literal-minded and sentimental, it is instead enigmatic and moving, much in the manner of Joy Division’s best songs.
Here are some widely repeated assertions about wine, and some explanations suggesting that nothing is that simple.
House Democrats squared off against the Bush administration over measures to help homeowners trapped by unaffordable subprime mortgages and falling home prices.
If the F.D.A. follows the advisory panel’s recommendation, Medtronic may be able to enter the lucrative American market for drug-coated stents by the end of this year.
Both Mitt Romney and Rudolph W. Giuliani made misleading claims in their back-and-forth over their conservative fiscal credentials.
A pension fund in Michigan filed a shareholder suit against Mattel and its board, asserting that a mishandling of product safety procedures was responsible for three recent toy recalls.
The MGM announcement comes amid an otherwise dismal year for the Atlantic City casino industry, which faces competition from new slot parlors in the region.
A student shot himself after he wounded several people today at the SuccessTech Academy, according to reports.
The news is a serious setback to Boeing and to the Dreamliner, which has so far lined up 710 orders from nearly 50 airlines.
The vote was nonbinding and so largely symbolic, but its consequences could reach far beyond bilateral relations with Turkey.
Rejecting a request from President Bush, two Congressional panels adopted a measure that gives federal judges more oversight on foreign electronic surveillance.
A noose was hung on the door of a black professor’s office at Columbia University Teachers College yesterday.
After disclosing yesterday why Mayor Robert W. Levy had been missing, his lawyer said today that he would resign.
Gerhard Ertl’s work in surface chemistry has applications across an array of fields, including the environment.
The United Automobile Workers union reached a tentative agreement this afternoon with Chrysler LLC, about six hours after the union struck the auto company.

Freddy Adu is back on the United States national team roster for next Wednesday’s exhibition game at Switzerland. Adu, who played his only game for the national team last year, was among 21 players picked for the initial roster by Coach Bob Bradley.

Spencer Hawes, the Sacramento Kings’ rookie center, will have arthroscopic surgery on his left knee today. No timetable was given for his return. Hawes, a 7-foot center out of Washington and the 10th pick over all in the draft, had surgery on the same knee when he was 14.

The IndyCar Series champion Dario Franchitti will make his Nascar debut in the Truck Series race at Martinsville Speedway Oct. 20. Franchitti, who also won the Indianapolis 500 this season, is moving to Nascar next season. He made his stock-car debut in the ARCA race at Talladega Superspeedway last weekend and finished 17th.

The Ansonia has been home to Babe Ruth, Igor Stravinsky and Angelina Jolie, but now an Upper West Side couple say that a substantial part of the 14th floor in the historic building has become home to “a horrific plague of roaches.”.
The deal will allow AT&T to expand wireless services or provide video broadcasts in much of its coverage area.

An obituary on Sept. 28 about Wolfgang K. H. Panofsky, a physicist and arms control adviser, omitted an original signatory of a 1963 treaty to ban atmospheric testing and included another country erroneously. In addition to the United States and the Soviet Union, Britain — but not China — signed the treaty. (A correction in this space yesterday addressed the error on China but, like the article, did not include Britain.).

An article on Monday about an attack by vandals on a Monet painting in the Musée d’Orsay in Paris misidentified the art movement with which “Fountain,” a work by Marcel Duchamp that was vandalized in Paris last year, is most closely associated. It is Dada, not Surrealism.

An article on Sept. 28 about the Food and Drug Administration’s oversight of clinical trials misstated the amount of time that the Oklahoma Board of Medical Licensure and Supervision suspended the license of Dr. David Linden, a psychiatrist, who was given a warning letter by the F.D.A. for his handling of clinical trials. It was for 45 days, not three months.

A front-page article on Thursday about secret Justice Department legal opinions on interrogation misstated the period during which Paul C. Kelbaugh, a former Central Intelligence Agency lawyer, served as deputy chief of the legal group at the agency’s Counterterrorist Center. It was from September to December 2003 — not from 2001 to 2003.

A picture caption on Monday with an article in Business Day about efforts by U.S. News & World Report to build a business in information and ratings misstated the other journalism interests of its owner and editor in chief, Mortimer B. Zuckerman. Although he is indeed the publisher of The Daily News, he no longer owns The Atlantic Monthly. (He sold it to David G. Bradley, a Washington businessman, in 1999.).
A front-page article yesterday about the presidential campaign of Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. misstated the year he ended a previous campaign for president. It was 1987, not 1988.

A front-page article on Thursday about a movement in California to apportion the state’s electoral votes by Congressional districts gave an outdated title for Bruce E. Cain, who commented on opposing strategies by Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and Rudolph W. Giuliani. Mr. Cain is the former director of the Institute of Governmental Studies at the University of California, Berkeley — not the current director. (That post is now held by Jack Citrin; Mr. Cain is a professor of political science at Berkeley.).
Reality TV impresario Mark Burnett formed a joint venture with the gambling group Genting to develop, produce and distribute game shows and reality series in Asia.
A former Milberg Weiss partner pleaded guilty to being part of a scheme to pay kickbacks to individuals who remained on call to act as lead plaintiffs.
Refining margins are expected to be a drag on third-quarter earnings of oil and gas producers as refining margins dropped by more than half from second-quarter levels.
By combining social networking and online video, Blinkx hopes to better compete with YouTube, the market-leading video-sharing service owned by Google.
A New Jersey hospital suspended 27 employees after they pried into the medical records of George Clooney and his companion, who were hurt in a motorcycle accident.

Yahoo will buy 10 percent of the shares in the Hong Kong initial public offering of Alibaba.com, the business-to-business unit of China’s biggest online retailer, according to a preliminary document. Alibaba.com and its parent, the Alibaba.com Corporation, will offer 858.9 million shares, or a 17 percent stake in the unit, which helps businesses buy and sell products to each other, according to the document. The stock’s listing is scheduled for Nov. 6. Yahoo already owns a 40 percent stake in the Alibaba.com Corporation.

Berkshire Hathaway, controlled by Warren E. Buffett, sold shares of the PetroChina Company, the biggest oil producer in China, valued at 2.8 billion Hong Kong dollars ($364 million). Berkshire sold 220.5 million shares at an average of 12.80 Hong Kong dollars a share on Sept. 25, cutting its stake to 5.44 percent of the stock not controlled by the Chinese government, according to a filing with the Hong Kong stock exchange. Mr. Buffett has sold almost half of his holding this year, according to calculations based on filings and Berkshire’s annual report. The stock has jumped sevenfold since Berkshire bought its stake in April 2003.

The Newmont Mining Corporation said it would buy a Canadian exploration company, the Miramar Mining Corporation, for 1.5 billion Canadian dollars ($1.52 billion). The deal, approved unanimously by Miramar’s board, will give Newmont control of the undeveloped Hope Bay project in the territory of Nunavut, in far northern Canada. Newmont, based in Denver, agreed to pay $6.25 a share for Miramar, which is based in North Vancouver, British Columbia. The price is a 20 percent premium to Miramar’s closing price Friday, the last day it traded before the acquisition was announced.
At Yankee Stadium Tuesday, Chien-Ming Wang said he would dwell on his postseason starts for a month or two and next season, he would have to refine his changeup and slider.
Eddy Curry’s shoulder injury Tuesday was found to be relatively mild, a report that qualifies as the best news the Knicks have had in weeks, if not months.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 9 (AP) — Ray Chapman’s spirit could be floating the Cleveland Indians through a season unlike any other in their history.
The automaker’s strategy appears to be to save money by curtailing operations in North America while expanding in growth markets in Asia and elsewhere abroad.
For millions of New Yorkers, Joe Torre has long felt like a beloved family member.

The older sister of a 4-year-old Bronx boy who died of internal injuries last year described in court yesterday the series of beatings that she said her brother endured in the three days before his death.

China signaled its “resolute opposition” to United Nations sanctions against the government of Myanmar after the violent suppression of pro-democracy demonstrations there this month. “Any action adopted at the Security Council should be extremely prudent and responsible and helpful to the mediation efforts of the secretary general,” said a spokesman for the Foreign Ministry, Liu Jianchao.

Having spent his life as a stalwart in the famously corrupt political party known as the PRI, Roberto Madrazo has never suffered from a reputation for honesty. So it brought laughter here when the former presidential candidate was disqualified this week for cheating in the Berlin Marathon. Mr. Madrazo, who came in third in last year’s presidential race, crossed the finish line in Berlin on Sept. 30 with a startling time of 2:41:12, a full hour ahead of his personal best, easily winning the category for men 55 and older. But a photographer wondered why Mr. Madrazo was wearing a windbreaker and tights when most of the runners finished in sweat-soaked T-shirts and shorts. Race officials checked and on Monday said that Mr. Madrazo had taken a shortcut. An electronic tracking chip carried by all runners showed he had skipped two checkpoints, reappearing to win the race. He could not be reached for comment yesterday.
China opened a new attack on the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader, accusing him of supporting the banned movement Falun Gong.

Chasing China in resource-rich Africa, Prime Minister Manmohan Singh is to fly to Nigeria on Sunday in the first state visit there by an Indian prime minister in 45 years. Energy-starved India has been courting oil-rich African countries in recent years. Nigeria already provides for 11 percent of India’s crude oil supply, and Nalin Surie, a foreign ministry official, told reporters that India would seek deeper energy ties.

The police arrested dozens of people suspected of being members of the Sicilian Mafia in an operation they said was linked to the killing of a member of the Santapaola crime family. They said they had issued 32 warrants and carried out most of them, in Sicily, Naples and Genoa.

A bomb exploded in the Basque city of Bilbao, under a car the newspaper El País said was used by a bodyguard for a Socialist member of the Basque Parliament. An unidentified man was wounded. There was no claim of responsibility, but the regional government blamed the Basque separatist group ETA. The blast took place days after 23 members of Batasuna, ETA’s outlawed political wing, were arrested.
China and India have indefinitely postponed their first joint military exercise, which was to have been held in China next month.
Despite dire warnings by some analysts that merger activity would cool after this summer’s turmoil in the credit markets, the buyout market is still alive.

The Black Coaches and Administrators released its fourth hiring report card yesterday, and it came with a warning: Add more diversity to the head-coaching ranks or risk facing a future civil-rights lawsuit. The report showed that of 197 head-coaching vacancies since 1996, only 12 went to black coaches, and only 26 blacks had been hired at Football Bowl Subdivision colleges. This season began with 12 coaches who are members of minority groups at the 220 universities in the F.B.S. and Football Championship Subdivision that play football and are not historically black colleges or universities.

Alex Zanardi, the Italian racecar driver who lost both legs in a 200-mile-an-hour crash in 2001, said he would compete in the wheelchair division of the New York City Marathon on Nov. 4. Zanardi, then 34, was leading the American Memorial 500 in Germany when his Honda Reynard was hit by the car of Alex Tagliani of Canada. Zanardi’s car was split in half and flew into the air. Zanardi’s legs were amputated at the knees, but 20 months later he returned to the track, drove 13 laps and reached 195 m.p.h. during a race. He used a hand control for the clutch and throttle. An artificial right leg, fitted to a special pedal, operated the brake.

Ricky Rudd will be behind the wheel of the Robert Yates Racing No. 88 Ford this week at Lowe’s Motor Speedway in Charlotte, N.C., after missing five weeks with a separated left shoulder. Rudd was injured Sept. 2 in a wreck at California Speedway. The 50-year-old Rudd, who recently started his 900th race, had never missed a race because of injury.
With the chances of a presidential run by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg appearing to dwindle, a small band of enthusiasts is trying to keep interest in a candidacy alive.
Growing disagreements over how to carry forward arms control treaties threaten to bog down meetings in Moscow between top-level Americans and their Russian counterparts.

Texas Tech has banned the sale of a T-shirt bearing the likeness of Michael Vick hanging the dog mascot of rival Texas A&M. The red-and-black shirts that say “Vick ’em” on the front in an apparent reference to the Aggies’ slogan “Gig ’em,” was created by a Tech student who was trying to sell them before Saturday’s game in Lubbock. The back of the shirt shows a football player wearing a No. 7 Vick jersey, with an image of the A&M mascot Reveille at the end of a noose.
The House voted 375 to 3 on Tuesday to make it easier to convict private contractors of defrauding the federal government during wartime.
At issue is whether Israeli intelligence showing nuclear ties between Syria and North Korea was conclusive enough to justify military action.
A fight over health insurance illustrates what can happen when politicians showcase real people to make a point.
The student was accused of punching a safety officer and the principal, who tried to intervene, was accused of obstructing government activity and resisting arrest.
A Democrat’s campaign to unseat Gov.  Haley Barbour shows the difficulties Democrats face in the Deep South.
The big discount chain has sought to reduce the property taxes it pays on 35 percent of its stores, according to a report by Good Jobs First, a group critical of Wal-Mart.
Regulators called on companies to give investors more insight into how compensation decisions were made and to ensure that proxies were “clear, concise and understandable.”

A fourth man was charged with murder in the shooting of a football player on the University of Memphis campus during a botched robbery, the authorities said. Arrested was Devin Jefferson, a 20-year-old student at the university. The authorities said the victim, Taylor Bradford, 21, was singled out for money. Mr. Bradford was rumored to have won more than $3,000 at a nearby casino the night before the police found him Sept. 30 in his car, which had crashed into a tree a few blocks from his campus apartment.

Searchers combing through wreckage found the bodies of the 10 people killed when their plane crashed in the rugged central Cascade Range on their way home from a sky-diving event. The debris at the remote crash site indicated that the Cessna Caravan 208 went down in a steep nose dive, said Sheriff Ken Irwin of Yakima County. The plane left Star, Idaho, near Boise, on Sunday evening en route to Shelton, Wash., northwest of Olympia. It had been returning from a sky-diving meet in Idaho when it disappeared. It was not immediately clear what caused the plane to crash. The authorities did not immediately release the names of the victims, who ranged in age from 18 to 40, because not all family members had been notified.

The horror faced by two abducted boys was revealed in court, where their captor pleaded guilty and prosecutors said a video showing him torture one boy underlined why he should die in prison. The kidnapper, Michael Devlin, left, offered no apologies but shed light on why one of his victims stayed with him more than four years: The terrorized boy, Shawn Hornbeck, cut a deal just as Mr. Devlin was beginning to strangle him, telling Mr. Devlin he would do whatever was asked of him to stay alive. “I attempted to kill him, and he talked me out of it,” Mr. Devlin said. Mr. Devlin abducted a second boy early this year, days before both victims were discovered alive in his apartment in the St. Louis suburb of Kirkwood. Mr. Devlin received dozens of life sentences after his pleas to more than 80 counts, including sexual assault, kidnapping and attempted murder.

A former cook pleaded guilty to killing four people last year during a four-day rampage in southern Maine’s ski country. The plea from Christian Nielsen, 32, came a day before jury selection was to begin in his trial. He faces up to life in prison when he is sentenced Oct. 18.
The first giant fast ferry carrying cars and passengers among the Hawaiian Islands may not resume service until the state fully gauges its environmental effects, a judge ruled.

The state’s attorney general has closed an investigation into whether an aide to the Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney illegally ran a license check on a reporter last spring. No charges were filed. Attorney General Kelly Ayotte said her office found no evidence that anyone, during the time in question, had requested registration records for the car that a New York Times reporter, Mark Leibovich, was most likely driving and concluded that no crime was committed.

The Sankaty Head Lighthouse on Nantucket completed its journey 405 feet across a bluff, and now sits in a new spot just off the fifth hole of a golf course. Crews started moving the lighthouse, which was threatened by erosion, further inland on Oct. 1. It must still be lowered onto a new concrete foundation, which should be completed by Friday, said Bob Felch, president of the ’Sconset Trust, a land preservation group that is raising $4 million to move and preserve the lighthouse. The structure’s light will be turned on in the next two or three weeks, Mr. Felch said.
As Washington officials react with almost contented silence to a weak dollar, European officials are grumbling because it makes American exports cheaper in world markets.
A report said that poor training and a variety of errors by police commanders led officers to turn on demonstrators and journalists at a pro-immigration rally in Los Angeles in May.
If George Steinbrenner lets Manager Joe Torre go, as expected, most people around the team believe the front-runner to succeed him is the bench coach, Don Mattingly.

Two physicists who discovered how to manipulate the magnetic and electrical properties of thin layers of atoms to store vast amounts of data on tiny disks were named winners of the Nobel Prize in Physics.
Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates has approved a plan to ease the strain of two wars on the military by increasing the size of the active-duty Army to 547,000 by 2010.
Eli Manning and Eric Mangini are participating in “NFL Play 60: The NFL Movement for an Active Generation,” a program that will focus on the health of young fans.
An Argentine tribunal sentenced the Rev. Christian von Wernich for conspiring with the military in murders and kidnapping against leftist opponents.
The critique was an unusually blunt one coming from Dan Bartlett, who was one of President Bush’s closest aides until he resigned in July.

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority will hold meetings next month to allow the public to sound off on proposals for an increase in bus, subway and commuter rail fares and in bridge and tunnel tolls. Meetings will be held in the five boroughs and in Westchester, Rockland and Nassau Counties beginning Nov. 5. A schedule of the meetings is available at the authority’s Web site, www.mta.info. The authority has made two proposals for possible increases, including one that would establish a lower fare for riding subways and buses during off-peak periods. Both proposals would raise the base subway and bus fare to $2.25 from $2.

Newsday has come a step closer to regaining three Pulitzer Prize medals that vanished from the newspaper’s safe and were sold in a Sept. 28 auction, the police said yesterday. The three gold medals, awarded to the paper in the public service category in 1954, 1970 and 1974, were recovered by F.B.I. agents and will be returned to the paper once they are authenticated, said Detective Sgt. Robert Doyle of the Suffolk County police. Sergeant Doyle said investigators were still trying to find who took the medals, whose disappearance was discovered last week. The sergeant said that the police had learned the identity of the Long Island man who sold the medals through an auction house and that he said he had bought them at an estate sale on Long Island.

A college student from Westchester County died on Monday of bacterial meningitis at Westchester Medical Center in Valhalla, college officials said yesterday. The college, Bentley College in Waltham, Mass., said the student, Erin Ortiz, 18, was visiting her family in New Hampton when she was taken to the hospital. The college has been notifying students who had close contact with Ms. Ortiz, and is providing antibiotics.

A teenager was shot in the face about 5 a.m. yesterday as he looked out a third-story window from his family’s apartment in Bushwick, the police said. They said the teenager, Tavin Alves Clarke, 16, was in critical condition at Kings County Hospital Center. It was unclear whether he was the intended target or was hit by random gunfire. The police said there had been a scuffle outside the apartment on Cooper Street in which shots were fired. Tavin’s 5-year-old brother found him unconscious, bleeding and lying against a windowsill, said their sister, Mekela Clarke, 18. No arrests have been made.

Prosecutors in State Supreme Court rested their case yesterday against a man accused of killing a police officer in Flatbush. The officer, Dillon Stewart, 35, left, was shot dead in November 2005 while chasing a car that had run a red light. The defendant, Allan Cameron, 29, was charged with murder. Lacking an eyewitness to the shooting, prosecutors presented scientific and circumstantial evidence in the trial to connect Mr. Cameron to the car and the handgun that were used. They closed their case with testimony from a DNA expert. In the course of the trial, which lasted more than three weeks, defense lawyers elicited some testimony to suggest that Officer Stewart had been hit by police gunfire aimed at the fleeing car. Closing arguments are expected today.
Chrysler workers could walk off the job as early as today, even as the company has already moved to shut half its American assembly plants to let its inventories thin out.

New Jersey Transit will begin running late-evening express trains to accommodate crowds at the new Prudential Center in Newark, which will open this month. Four new westbound express trains will travel on the Northeast Corridor after 9:20 p.m. and stop in Newark on runs between New York and Trenton. Three express trains will be added on the North Jersey Coast Line. New Jersey Transit will also extend the hours of its ticket windows, information booth and waiting room at Newark Penn Station until 11 p.m. nightly and later on nights when there are events at the arena. The Prudential Center, the new home of the New Jersey Devils, is two blocks west of Newark Penn Station.
A hangman’s noose was found attached to the office door of a black member of the faculty at Teachers College at Columbia University.

Saying that New Jersey needed to do more policing by relying on data and intelligence, Gov. Jon S. Corzine unveiled the first of a three-part statewide crime strategy yesterday. Mr. Corzine, flanked by the attorney general, Anne Milgram, and other top law enforcement officials on the State House steps, said the strategy would help with the burgeoning problems of gangs and gang-related violence. “We’re building infrastructure to allow our police departments to do Compstat,” said Ms. Milgram, referring to the New York Police Department’s crime statistic tracking program.

An 88-year-old Middlesex County man is the first person infected by West Nile virus in New Jersey this year, state health officials said yesterday. The man, who was not named, has been hospitalized with the potentially fatal disease since Sept. 3, the health department said. Human cases of West Nile virus in New Jersey have declined since 2003, when there were 34. Five cases were reported in Bergen, Essex, Union and Middlesex Counties last year. Compiled by John Sullivan.
Germany’s focus on the 2008 European Championship has been deflected by a growing controversy over the decision of one of its youth players to withdraw from a match in Israel.
There is no quarterback controversy in Dallas, but Tony Romo did something Monday night that Chicago’s Rex Grossman has never done: throw five interceptions in a game and still manage to win.
The joint venture, to be known as MillerCoors, will become a more formidable No. 2 challenger to Anheuser-Busch, which has long dominated the American market.

President Álvaro Uribe said he called a Supreme Court justice to ask about an investigation of  a jailed paramilitary leader who connected Mr. Uribe to an unsuccessful plot to assassinate another militia chief.
Stocks rallied after minutes from the Fed’s Sept. 18 meeting showed concern by policy makers about a credit squeeze and uncertainty about the economy’s direction.

Unions representing city firefighters and officers charged yesterday that Fire Department officials ordered a halt to internal e-mail messages about the Deutsche Bank building fire that killed two firefighters in August.

The aluminum giant reported a 3 percent rise in third-quarter earnings as gains from the sale of its stake in a Chinese aluminum company helped offset weaker aluminum prices.

An article on Sept. 15 reported on a planned auction of a piece of the Willamette meteorite that was removed by a curator at the American Museum of Natural History in New York City a decade ago and traded for a fragment of another rare meteorite. The article and headline said Darryl Pitt, the man who had acquired the piece to be auctioned, needed the money. The article also described Mr. Pitt as being nervous about being photographed. And it said that he was upset that the Confederated Tribes of Grand Ronde, an American Indian group in western Oregon where the meteorite was found in 1902, had denounced the auction of the object, which they considered sacred.
The NASA spacecraft on the way to Pluto has discovered lightning in the polar regions of Jupiter, scientists said Tuesday.
A New York woman filed suit against a West Village restaurant for being thrown out of a women’s room there by a bouncer who, she said, did not care she was really female.
An already difficult second N.F.L. season ended for Arizona’s Matt Leinart Tuesday when he was placed on injured reserve with a broken collarbone.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 9 — The mystery of the missing mayor is solved. The city now has an explanation of why and where Mayor Robert W. Levy took an indefinite medical leave, putting this resort city in municipal limbo for nearly two weeks. What has not been resolved is how much longer he will remain mayor.

PLAYER In the Netherlands, the Brazilian striker Afonso Alves scored an Eredivisie-record seven goals in Heerenveen’s 9-0 victory over Heracles Almelo on Sunday. Alves, 26, has played five times internationally for Brazil and was the Dutch league’s top scorer last season with 34 goals in 31 games.
For the past month, Denise Sandy has been watching the trial of two men accused of killing her only son, Michael J. Sandy, 29. When she has spoken, she has spoken of forgiveness.

President Bush tried Tuesday to prod Congress into reauthorizing his biggest domestic achievement, the 2001 No Child Left Behind education law.
Teachers facing various complaints can be ordered to a reassignment center, more commonly known among New York teachers as a “rubber room.”
The Department of Defense has identified 3,807 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:.

The net number of people leaving New Jersey for other states has more than tripled since 2002, and if the trend continues, the state’s total population could dip next year for the first time in decades, researchers at Rutgers University are reporting today.

Health officials said Tuesday that Banquet pot pies might be linked to 139 cases of salmonella in 30 states, and ConAgra Foods Inc. voluntarily stopped production at the Missouri plant that makes the pot pies.
Roberto Madrazo, a veteran politician for the Institutional Revolutionary Party, was disqualified this week for cheating in the Berlin Marathon.
Abetted by a revenue bond program, several Washington nonprofit groups have agreed to buy space in new and renovated office buildings in prime downtown locations.

With the major television networks facing tough competition Monday from baseball playoffs on TBS, the science fiction hit “Heroes” fell to an all-time low in the ratings.
Yoko Ono urged the world to give peace a chance yesterday at the unveiling of the Imagine Peace Tower on Videy island, Iceland.

FALLON--Joseph P., of Wainscott passed away on October 7, 2007. He was an attorney in Easthampton and a navy veteran from WWII. Beloved dad of Patrick Fallon, Monica Kortmann and Cecilia Pinto; daughter-in-law Barbara Fallon, and sons-in-law Roy Kortmann and Mark Pinto; loved grandchildren Alexa and Katie Fallon; Fallon, Conor, Kerrie and Shannon Kortmann; Alex and Gregory Pinto; and former wife and long-time friend Lorelle Fallon. Visiting Thursday and Friday, 2-4 and 7-9, Yardley & Pino Funeral Home, 94 Pantigo Road, Easthampton. Funeral Mass Saturday, 10:00am, at Most Holy Trinity Church, Easthampton. Interment at Most Holy Trinity cemetery, Easthampton. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Disabled American Veterans, P.O. Box 14301, Cincinnati, OH 45250-0301.

MILLER--Miriam B. Born on October 23, 1919 and died October 8, 2007. She is survived by her loving daughters, Laura Miller and Sarah Miller; sons-in-law James Schacher and Robert Taglin; beloved grandchildren Lee Miller Taglin and Dana Miller Taglin and adoptive daughter Laura Osinoff.

MORGAN--J.Ronald, Jr. Financial Services Executive, dies at 69. J. Ronald Morgan Jr., retired CEO of Pershing Limited in London and former CEO of Thomson McKinnon Securities in New York, died on October 6th at his home in East Hampton. He was surrounded by his beloved wife Carol, daughters Kelly and Kim, sons Ron, Ted, Chris and Scott, sister Joan, and sister-in-law Marilyn. The cause was cancer. Mr. Morgan had been battling melanoma for ten months. Born on April 25, 1938 in Brooklyn, New York, he was the son of the late J. Ronald and Irene Morgan, He received a Bachelor's Degree in Business Administration from Manhattan College in 1960. J. Ronald began his career in 1966 as a Certified Public Accountant with Coopers & Lybrand in New York. From 1966 to 1989 he worked for the retail brokerage firm, Thomson McKinnon Securities, becoming Chief Operating Officer in 1984 and then Chairman and CEO in 1987. During the same time, he was Trustee for the Financial Accounting Standards Board, Chairman of the National Securities Clearing Corporation. Chairman of the New York Stock Exchange Regulatory Committee, and Director of the Securities Industry Association. In 1990, Mr. Morgan moved to London as CEO of Pershing's UK operation, a post he held until 2004 when he retired. During his 15 years in London, he was Director of Pershing Limited, CREST Co., DLJ Direct UK, DLJ International, CSFB Europe and London Clearing House. In April of 2006, he was named a non-executive Director for iimia Investment Group plc. In his spare time, J. Ronald was Treasurer and Board member of the Huntington Crescent Club, Board Member of the Canterbury School in New Milford, Connecticut, and most recently Treasurer of the East Hampton Rotary Club. Mr. Morgan is survived by his loving wife Carol, his two daughters Kelly Morgan and Kim Wieland, his four sons J. Ronald III, Edward, Christopher, and Scott; and his 15 grandchildren. He is also survived by sister Joan Flatley and brother Thomas Morgan. A wake will be held from 5-8pm on Wednesday, October 10, 2007 at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, on Madison Avenue in New York. Funeral Services will be held at the Church of St. Patrick on Thursday, October 11, 2007 at 11am in Huntington, New York.

DOWD--Joseph J., 80, of Brooklyn, Remsenburg, and Hutchinson Island, died peacefully after a lengthy illness on Saturday, October 6, at his home in Remsenburg, New York. Beloved husband of the late Margaret E. Dowd. Loving grandfather of Michael, Patrick, and Daniel McConnell. Revered friend and mentor of John and Susan McConnell, Patrick and Helen McConnell. Former United States Marine, graduate of New York University and St. John's Law School; teacher, Assistant Corporation Counsel, Member of the New York State Assembly (1960-1970), Civil Court Judge (1971-1980), and New York State Supreme Court Justice (1981-2004). Rising from humble beginnings, by virtue of outstanding character and unimpeachable integrity, he served as a leading member of the political and legal community of Kings County for more than four decades. Wise, compassionate, possessed of gentle humor and quiet strength, his life was an honor and a blessing generously shared. Repose at Follet and Werner Funeral Home, Westhampton Beach, New York on Wednesday from 2-4 and 7-9pm. Mass at Immaculate Conception Church, Westhampton Beach, on Thursday at 10am. In lieu of flowers donations in his memory may be made to St. Vincent's Services, 66 Boerum Place, Brooklyn, NY 11201. A celebration of the lives of Joseph and Margaret Dowd will be held in Brooklyn shortly, at a time and place to be announced.

VON TISCHLER--Ida. Died at home on October 6, 2007 at 100. Beloved wife of the late Joseph. Devoted mother of Karen Genovese and Barry von Tischler (Ellen). Loving sister of Julius Gantman. Cherished grandmother of Letitia (Chris), Frank, Kim, Bradley, Dana and Brittany. Loving great-grandmother of Kayla, Emerson and Matthew. Services were Tuesday, 1pm, at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

DONOVAN--Richard P., Essex, CT, Richard Cushman Priddie Donovan, 86, died Sunday, October 7th in Essex, CT, after a brief illness. He moved to Essex in 2003 from Pelham, NY, his home for 50 years. He was an attorney practicing municipal bond law in New York City. In 1953 Dick Donovan joined the law firm of Sullivan, Donovan, Henehan, and Hanrahan, which his father Gerald Donovan co-founded in 1928. Dick practiced there his entire career, retiring as the senior partner in 2003, when he closed the firm. For many years the firm was known simply as Sullivan Donovan. In 1948 he graduated first in his class from Cornell University Law School, where he was a member of the Law Review. Before entering private practice, he served as a staff attorney to the SEC in Washington, DC, and as an Assistant US Attorney in the Southern District of NY. From 1969 to 2003 Dick served on the Board of Directors of NY Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Children and as its Secretary from 1971 to 1991. He served on the Board of Trustees of New Rochelle Hospital Medical Center (now the Sound Shore Medical Center of Westchester) from 1974 to 2003. Dick was born in New York City on August 14, 1921 to Gerald Donovan and the former Louise Wiess Priddie of Beaumont, TX. He grew up in New Rochelle, NY, and graduated from Iona Preparatory Academy. A 1942, Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Brown University, he was also a member of Delta Kappa Epsilon. In WWII he served on the battleships USS Alabama and USS South Dakota in both the Atlantic and Pacific theaters. A Navy Lieutenant at war's end, Dick taught flying at the Naval Air Station in Jacksonville, FL. His great-uncle, Harry Wiess of Beaumont, Texas, was a founder of the Humble Oil Company, later part of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, now ExxonMobil. A new book's subtitle, ''The Connoisseur's Guide to Oyster Eating in North America,'' tells its tale. Rowan Jacobsen, the author of the book, ''A Geography of Oysters'' (Bloomsbury, $24.95), sorts out the oysters by species, by flavor and by region. There are details of oyster biology and oyster culture; these days, almost all oysters that are sold or served have been cultivated. Mr. Jacobsen has sound arguments for observing the ''R'' rule of eating oysters only in months with that letter because oysters from warmer water do not taste as good and can be a health risk when not cooked. And for the squeamish who resist the notion of eating a living creature, he offers this: ''Left in their natural environment, most oysters would be eaten by something: why shouldn't it be you?''

A clubhouse attendant packed the belongings from Alex Rodriguez's locker into cardboard boxes yesterday, in what may have been a sign that Rodriguez did not plan to visit Yankee Stadium anytime soon. He may never return as a member of the Yankees because he seems sure to exercise the opt-out clause in his contract. While the agent Scott Boras did not specifically say that Rodriguez would opt out with three years left on his 10-year, $252 million contract, he suggested that becoming a free agent again would be his client's savviest choice.

The Board of Directors of the Black Rock Forest Consortium, along with the Forest's administration and em ployees, mourn the passing of William T. Golden, visionary founder of the Consortium and its first chairman. Mr. Golden purchased the 3,800 acre Black Rock Forest from Harvard University in 1989 and established the original consortium of 15 member scientific and educational institutions. Since the Consortium's founding, more than 25 masters and Ph.D. theses and more than 400 total publications have been produced from scientific research at the forest. Consortium membership has grown to 20 organizations, including the American Museum of Natural History and Columbia University. The Forest currently serves more than 10,000 visitors each year through environmental education programs. All of this work flourishes today as the result of one of Mr. Golden's many extraordinary ideas for the advancement of the sciences. His warmth, humor and compassion will be deeply missed by all involved with the forest. The Black Rock Forest Consortium extends its deepest sympathy to Mr. Golden's daughter and Consortium Board Chairman, Sibyl R. Golden, to his wife, Catherine Morrison, and to the entire family. The Trustees and Staff of the Carnegie Institution of Washington mourn the loss of senior trustee William T. Golden. Bill Golden was an icon of American science policy, and the Carnegie Institution was privileged to have his support and guidance for more than 35 years. Dedicated, passionate, and always involved, Bill served as secretary of the Carnegie board of trustees from 1971 to 1999 and chaired or participated in numerous committees. He was particularly instrumental in the planning and construction of the Las Campanas Observatory in the Chilean Andes, now home to some of the largest and most scientifically productive telescopes in the Southern Hemisphere. The Carnegie Observatories auditorium in Pasadena, California, bears his name in appreciation of his efforts. Bill embodied the Carnegie principle that exceptional people can produce extraordinary results when given the freedom to pursue their passions. We were truly fortunate that this legendary man chose to join the Carnegie family. On behalf of the board and the scientists of the Carnegie Institution, we offer our deepest condolences to his wife Catherine, his daughters Sibyl and Pamela, and others dear to him. Michael E. Smith, Chairman Douglas Blonsky, President GOLDEN--William T. The American Academy of Arts and Sciences mourns the loss of William T. Golden--visionary statesman, presidential adviser, and generous patron of science, culture, and civic life. A Fellow of the Academy for nearly 25 years and the recipient of the Academy's Scholar-Patriot Award, he was the exemplar of what the Academy's founders--America's founding fathers-termed an engaged citizen. Bill was a catalyst for the ideas and institutions that forged a new bond between science and government. For research institutes, federal agencies, hospitals, museums, foundations, and environmental organiza tions--nearly 100 in numberhe provided those most precious qualities: the willingness to listen and the courage to act. The Academy was honored to be the beneficiary of his wisdom and guidance throughout his years as a Fellow. A charter member of the Academy Trust, he valued and upheld our historic mission to serve the nation and the world. His time and support have been critical in shaping our plans and in developing a vision for the future. We are all indebted to him for his tireless service. Friend, colleague, and mentor to generations of men and women, he will be deeply missed. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Catherine; his daughters Sibyl and Pamela, and to all those touched by his grace, gentle humor, wisdom, and generosity. Emilio Bizzi, President Louis Cabot, Vice President and Chair of the Academy Trust Leslie C. Berlowitz, Chief Executive Officer

Blue Marble Ice Cream in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, has an airy, whitewashed look that suggests the seashore, which somehow enhances a scoop of refreshing mint chip, deeply flavorful strawberry, creamy vanilla or lightly sweetened green tea, above right. Alexis Miesen and Jennie Dundas, the owners, have created a child-friendly place serving mini-portions as well as full ones ($1.50 to $5.50). There is a garden and a children's play area. The store's name comes from the Earth's nickname, the ''big blue marble,'' Ms. Dundas said. Table tops are made partly from sorghum and benches partly from wheat board.

Glittering edible jellied jewels in stained-glass colors usually depend on fruit for their flavors. Some of these Sweet Vellies do indeed involve strawberries, blueberries and passion fruit. But all also have a savory component, like sage or rosemary, and some, like tomato-basil, corn-thyme and roasted red pepper, are entirely vegetable based, offering an intriguingly tasty new take on an old favorite. They pair nicely with cheese for nibbling. They are made by Great Performances, a catering company with a farm in the Hudson Valley. A package of 12 is $12, one of 25 is $18 at the Sweet Life, 63 Hester Street (Ludlow Street), and at the cafes at Sotheby's and Wave Hill.

VICENTE--Harriet. The Board of Directors, the Scientific Council members and the staff of NARSAD/The Mental Health Research Association (the world's largest philanthropic organization funding research on the causes, treatments and prevention of mental illnesses) mourn the death of our extraordinary, dedicated board member emeritus. Harriet joined the NARSAD board in 1992 at an early stage of our organization's program of providing research grants for the most promising research in our field. She was an active board member until taking an emeritus role in 2007. She was always a generous donor, providing support for outstanding young scientists engaged in breakthrough research, especially those with important new studies in genetics focused on the causes of severe mental disorders. She became a Research Partner supporting specific young scientists at pivotal moments in their research careers. Promising faculty members of Columbia and Rockefeller Universities were beneficiaries of her directed grant support. She particularly supported outstanding research progress in Spain, the homeland of her late husband, the distinguished artist Esteban Vicente. Beyond her financial support to scientists she gave them wise counsel and new opportunities. While serving as a director and an active donor, she also organized and led events to bring information about NARSAD's sponsored new research to her wide circle of acquaintances. She spoke to all enthusiastically against stigma and for possibilities of better treatments and cures for mental illnesses. Harriet Vicente's deep concern for those suffering for mental illness and her ever constructive efforts to help them were admired by all in our organization. We join all who knew her in deep sorrow at her passing. Geoffrey Birkett, President Constance E. Lieber, President Emeritus Herbert Pardes M.D., President of NARSAD Scientific Council Thomas Rabaut, Chairman VICENTE--Harriet, in her 87th year, died peacefully on October 4 from a cerebral hemorrhage. Harriet was born on April 6, 1921, in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, the elder daughter of Philip and Eva (Goell) Godfrey. She is survived by her sister, Ellen Marquis of San Francisco, her niece Tessa (Michael Brown), her nephew David (Beth), her great-nieces and nephews Nathaniel and Michael Leeds (Kiren) and Sophia Lee, the children of her deceased niece Lisa Lee (Arthur), and Mina Ebtehadj Marquis. An insatiable traveler since early childhood trips to Europe with her parents, with deep engagement during her adult years in a broad range of activities in, among other places, Spain, Israel and Turkey as well as in the United States, Harriet remained throughout her life an unabashedly enthusiastic New Yorker. Harriet's involvement in the art world began in the late 1940s when she and her then husband, Donald Peters (deceased 1960) became investors in the Samuel M. Kootz Gallery and assembled a notable collection of the then emerging New York school of abstract expressionist artists and European masters represented by Kootz. In 1958, while working as a volunteer in the Leo Castelli Gallery, she was introduced to Esteban Vicente who was having a show of his drawings at the gallery. In 1961, a year after her husband's death, she and Esteban were married. A committed Zionist since youth, Harriet, under the auspices of the Jerusalem Foundation, sponsored two projects with the aim of promoting peace between the Jewish and Arab communities. In 1980, she sponsored a playground in memory of her late daughter, Alison Peters, on the boundary between the two communities to provide a safe place for Arab and Jewish children to come together to play. A month before her death, Harriet provided additional funding to restore and enhance the park and provide for its future upkeep. Since 2003, Harriet has also sponsored the Independent Skills Program for young Arab women at the Beit David Community Center, located in the Arab Wadi Joz neighborhood of Jerusalem. Harriet was a founding member and on the Executive Board of the Women's Division of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine which celebrated its 50th anniversary in 2004. From 1992 until her retirement to Emeritus status in 2006, Harriet served as a board member of NARSAD, The Mental Health Research Association, which is the world's largest nongovernmental agency funding research on the causes, treatment and prevention of mental illness, including schizophrenia, depression and a range of other serious neuropsychiatric disorders. Long interested in developing ties with Spain, in 1997 Harriet supported a NARSAD Young Investigators Award to Dr. Enrique Baca - Garcia, a young Spanish researcher who went on to become one of the most influential persons in introducing advanced psychiatric knowledge and treatment to the Iberian Peninsula. Last year, she provided support for Dr. Garcia's sabbatical year spent at the Columbia University Department of Psychiatry in New York updating his knowledge of cutting-edge methodologies to take back to his university in Madrid. In 1998, Harriet was instrumental in the founding by the Province of Segovia of the Esteban Vicente Museum of Contemporary Art in Segovia, Spain, Esteban's birthplace. The museum and community center was made possible by the joint gift of Harriet and Esteban of 150 of Vicente's works. Harriet was Honorary President of the museum whose governing board is a consortium of public officials from the national, regional, provincial and city governments, as well as corporate and private members. The regional government of Castile-Leon has recently funded a major expansion of the museum in connection with which Harriet undertook to provide the annual operating budget of the new addition. In 1999, the King of Spain awarded Harriet, together with Esteban, the Gran Cruz de la Orden de Alfonso X el Sabio (Grand Cross of Alfonso the Wise), a decoration established in 1902 to honor extraordinary contributions by Spaniards or foreigners to Spanish education, science, culture and research. In 2000, Harriet endowed an annual Vicente fellowship to enable mid-career Spanish artists to live and work at Yaddo, the artists' community in Saratoga Springs, New York. In 2002, Harriet joined The Rockefeller University Council, the University's most distinguished group of benefactors and friends, where she established the Esteban Vicente Postdoctoral Fellowship for young investigators in the field of mental illness. She has also been a generous supporter of the University's Women & Science initiative. In 2006 Harriet was instrumental in the creation in P.S. 170 of an in-school and after-school program of music and art. P.S. 170 is an early childhood public school in the South Bronx with a predominantly Hispanic population. By a vote of the parents, the name of the school has been changed to the Esteban Vicente School, with the purpose of encouraging identification of the students with a highly successful and distinguished Hispanic artist. In accordance with Harriet's wishes, her ashes will be buried, beside those of Esteban, in the garden of the Vicente museum in Segovia on a date to be determined. The interment will be open to any who may wish to attend. A memorial will be held in New York also at a later date. Contributions in Harriet's honor may be made to NARSAD at 60 Cutter Mill Road, Great Neck, NY 11021 or to the Harriet and Esteban Vicente Foundation at 501 Fifth Avenue, Suite 1803, New York, NY 10017. VICENTE--Harriet. To the students, staff and parents of The Esteban Vicente School, Harriet was an inspiring presence and a true believer in the power of art to inspire and motivate children. When PS 170, an Early Childhood School in the South Bronx, voted in 2006 to change its name to The Esteban Vicente School, Mrs. Vicente responded. She was instrumental in helping us further her husband's legacy and support our mission to educate children both academically and creatively. Mrs. Vicente shared her energy and belief in art's transformative power with our children and inspired them to think of art as an essential part of their lives. Thanks to her generous support, The Esteban Vicente School now offers yearlong dance, visual arts, songwriting and music programs for all children. Our community will always fondly remember our abuela, Harriet Vicente. The Students, Staff and Parents of The Esteban Vicente School VICENTE--Harriet. The Board of Directors of the Esteban Vicente Museum of Contemporary Art deeply regrets the loss of its Honorary President, Harriet Vicente. Her kindness, enthusiasm and experience in the art world were as valuable as her economic support. We, who had the pleasure and honor of meeting her either in business meetings or informal situations want to emphasize her genius in identifying priorities and challenges. Especially interested in education, she often expressed her desire to strengthen that area in our institution. Her constant aim was to insure that the youngest children could gain access to the art world and, on the other hand that the artists could work with both passion and means. Regarding the latter, we must remember her biannual sponsorship of a Yaddo fellowship, which allowed a Spanish artist to spend a month in an extraordinary residency for creators. We are indebted to her for her joint donation, with Esteban Vicente, of 152 works for the permanent collection of the museum, as well as the subsequent donations she made of other works by Esteban plus his personal library. Above all, we are indebted to her for her generous sponsorship of the museum, undoubtedly the most important cultural institution in Castile Leon. For these contributions, among others, in 1999 she was awarded the Gran Cruz de la Orden de Alfonso X. Her indefatigable dedication to the arts, her personal charm and her loyalty to the museum, in addition to an innate intelligence that had not decreased with the passage of years, make her departure especially sad. Therefore, we want to join in their sorrow all those who enjoyed her friendship, love and generosity. Javier Santamara, Pres. Provincial Council of Segovia Pedro Arahuetes, Mayor, City of Segovia Jos Jimnez, Ministry of Culture Mara Jos Salgueiro, Minister of Culture of Castile Leon Manuel Escribano Soto, Director de Caja de Ahorros de Segovia Jos Antonio Lopez, CEO, Iberpistas, S.A Carlos Mara Martnez, Director, Caja de Madrid Ambassador Jos Luis Pardos Fernando Escard Elvira Gonzalez Jos Mara Parreo, Director of the Museum Atilano Soto, Founder President of the Museum VICENTE--Harriet. The Rockefeller University deeply mourns the loss of Harriet Vicente, a cherished member of The Rockefeller University Council. We are fortunate to have known this warm and generous - hearted woman. Harriet embraced the research of scientists working at the frontiers of biomedicine by establishing the Esteban Vicente Postdoctoral Fellowship for talented young investigators conducting research related to mental illness. A tireless ambassador and advocate for Rockefeller, she was also a generous supporter of the University's Women & Science initiative. We celebrate Harriet's keen intellect, her wit, and her great generosity, and compassion for artists in all walks of life. Harriet believed that scientists are creative individuals, and she was attracted by the University's commitment to nurturing scientific creativity and its integration of the arts and humanities with science. In 2003, Harriet Vicente donated to the University a vibrant abstract painting entitled Tremor by her late husband, Esteban Vicente. Given on the 100th anniversary of Esteban Vicente's birth, Tremor will be a permanent reminder to the University community of this unique and remarkable woman, and her intrepid and ever - fascinating journey through life. Harriet, herself, was an artist at friendships. She will be greatly missed by the Rockefeller community. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her family and all who loved her. David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Richard Furlaud, Chairman Emeritus and Council Chair Paul Nurse, President Torsten Wiesel, President Emeritus Marnie Imhoff, Vice President The Rockefeller University

d'HEURLE--Francois M. November 23, 1925--October 8, 2007. Born in Paris; joined IBM in 1958; became emeritus scientist at T.J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown, NY. Honored here and abroad for study of metal silicides. Outspoken peace advocate; active in Committee of Responsibility, FOR, WRL, and WESPAC. Loved trees in all forms, Gregorian chant, Swedish novels, medieval history and art, Lakkalikoori, a good argument. Survived by wife Adma Jeha d'Heurle, sons Amal (Muriel), David (Jan), and Alain (Jenny) and five grandchildren. More at francoisfriends.webhop.net. d'HEURLE--Francois M. Our world is darker without his sparks. We regret he will not see himself in the New York Times. A., B. & E. Walker

MURPHY--James P., 83, on October 8, 2007 of Seaford. WWII Army Veteran, Graduate of Regis High School and Fordham University, Recipient of the Deo et Patriae Award from Regis High School, long-time active Parishioner of St. William the Abbot. Beloved husband of 60 years of Martha, devoted father of James P. Jr, Christine Umstatter (Jack) and Ellen Short (John), also survived by his cherished grandchildren Kate, Maureen, James, and Emma, dear brother of John. Reposing at the Charles G. Schmitt Funeral Home, Inc, 3863 Merrick Road, Seaford (2 traffic lights east of Rte. 135). Mass of Christian burial, Thursday 10am, at St. William the Abbot R.C. Church, interment private. In the late 1950s, when Jane Jacobs joined Greenwich Village activists in fighting Robert Moses’s plans for high-speed car traffic through Washington Square Park, The Village Voice (founded in 1955) played a crusading role in calling successfully for the preservation of public space and, eventually, for the elimination of vehicles from the park. Do blogs today play a similar role in shaping political activism and influencing mainstream media? I moderated a panel discussion on that question on Tuesday night, the second in a series of public programs accompanying the Municipal Art Society’s new exhibition, “Jane Jacobs and the Future of New York.”

Camilo José Vergara’s “The New American Ghetto,” published in 1997, chronicled the desolation and disinvestment of American inner cities that had suffered decades of postwar decline. Garry Kasparov, the former world champion and current presidential nominee of the Other Russia, a small opposition group, gave a one hour speech this morning to thousands of business people at the World Business Forum at Radio City Music Hall in New York City. In his speech, Kasparov, who just published "How Life Imitates Chess" (Bloomsbury USA), said one of the things he had learned from chess is that it was better to be an aggressive decision-maker than one who deliberates too long. "You cannot be afraid to make mistakes," he said. "Are there perfect decisions? No. You must trust your instincts."

I just can't get out of my mind the story of Carol Gotbaum, the 45-year-old Manhattan mother of three who died in a Phoenix airport holding cell on September 28th on her way to alcohol rehab in Tucson. Her funeral was held this past Sunday on the Upper West Side. At the start of it, Rabbi Robert Levine of Congregation Rodeph Sholom said, "The central teaching of both Judaism and Christianity is to love your neighbor as yourself. But at that airport there was no such love offered to our Carol."
