Since the end of TimesSelect, I have been enjoying the ways in which various electronic explorers have been diving into the depths of our paper's history to find interesting content. Jason Kottke is certainly the most prominent blogger doing this. He first led off with a smartly compiled list of gems from the deep archive and followed up with a nice discovery of what might be the first New York Times restaurant review. In a similar vein, Mental Floss has been logging when cultural concepts like Silicon Valley or the Simpsons were first mentioned in the pages of our newspaper. And inspired directly by Kottke, music blog Coolfer has been looking into the more recent archives to chart out the development of modern business models in the music business. Of course, such forays into the past can also dredge up examples of blatant racism and prejudice, but that too is a part of the historical record.

Kevin Smith has been one of the nation's leaders in rushing for much of the season and is just starting to get noticed. Smith, a running back for Central Florida, is averaging 172 yards a game on the ground and his 11 rushing touchdowns are tied with U.T.E.P.'s Marcus Thomas for tops in the country. His 860 yards are second only to Michigan's Mike Hart, who has 976. Smith played his high school football in Miami, but was not recruited by Florida's big-name schools, which is really a testament to the level of football talent in that state.

Marion Jones, the track star who won five medals in the 2000 Olympics, last week pleaded guilty to providing false statements to federal agents and admitted to using performance-enhancing drugs before the Games. She has since relinquished her gold medals and may face jail time. Do these developments tarnish just Jones, or the entire American track and field establishment?

"The last-second field goal is one of the sport's signature moments: tense, terrifying, exhilarating," writes Will Leitch in this week's Play newsletter. "It is the league's inherent drama writ large: three hours of enormous men ramming into each other, with the result of their blood and toil hinging on this one kick." Now, he says, the time-out maneuver, in which coaches call a timeout moments before the kick, "is causing fans to hold back at the exact point they should be cutting loose. And why wouldn't they? Surely the last thing the N.F.L. wants is people not getting excited when they see a game-winning field goal because they aren't sure it counted."

Investigators searching the body of an unidentified man who was hit and killed by a subway train in the Bronx yesterday morning found a piece of paper bearing the name of a woman. When they checked her apartment they found her dead of head injuries, the police said.

Joey Bullen kicked a 29-yard field goal in the second overtime and Navy then held as Pittsburgh inexplicably gambled by going for a winning touchdown on fourth down when a chip-shot field goal would have forced another overtime, and the Midshipmen defeated the Panthers, 48-45, last night in Pittsburgh.Pitt (2-4), losing its fourth in a row despite the freshman LeSean McCoy’s 165 yards rushing and three touchdowns in an almost defense-free game, appeared to be in position to win when Navy (4-2) settled for the field goal and the Panthers got the ball back with a chance to win. But, with Pitt facing fourth-and-goal at the Navy 2-yard line, Coach Dave Wannstedt went for the victory rather than the tie, and the freshman quarterback Pat Bostick overthrew tight end Darrell Strong in the end zone.The Panthers, in desperate need of a victory after losing to Virginia by 30 points and Connecticut by 20 in its last two games, never found a way to slow Navy quarterback Kaipo-Noa Kaheaku-Enhada, who ran for 122 yards and a score and threw for another.

Washington Wizards center Etan Thomas will have open heart surgery today to repair a leak of the aortic valve, a procedure that requires months of recovery time but may not mean the end of his N.B.A. career.Thomas missed the start of training camp Oct. 2 after a routine physical revealed an abnormality in his heart.The 29-year-old Thomas has played only for the Wizards during his six-year career. He started a career-high 32 games last season, averaging 6.1 points and 5.8 rebounds.

Investigators searching the body of an unidentified man who was killed by a subway train at 7:15 a.m. yesterday found a piece of paper on the body with a woman’s name printed on it. Investigators went to the woman’s apartment shortly after 4 p.m. and found her dead of head injuries, the police said. The woman was identified as Mercedes Mesa, 62, of 1050 Anderson Avenue. The police said they were investigating the case as a possible murder-suicide, but emphasized that they had not yet linked the man to the woman or to her death. The man, described as Hispanic and about 55, was found on the tracks of the station at Boston Road and East Tremont Avenue. The police said that his death appeared to be a suicide, and that investigators had sought Ms. Mesa hoping she could help identify him.
President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran was misrepresented by Western news media when he was quoted saying there were no homosexuals in Iran, an aide said Wednesday.
The Rangers dominated the first regular-season meeting with the Islanders on Wednesday but fell short of victory.

A city medical examiner testified yesterday that the injuries suffered by a 4-year-old boy who prosecutors say was fatally beaten by his mother’s live-in companion were most likely caused by a beating inflicted within an hour before the boy died.
The company said it would cut power rates by 5 percent after critics suggested the deal would lead to higher electricity prices to finance the firm’s $24.5 billion in new debt.
Big casino money, not local politics, defines Atlantic City.
The visiting Ottawa Senators remained unbeaten with a 3-1 victory against the winless Atlanta Thrashers.

A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Sept. 26 about television ratings included incorrect ratings data from PBS for Part 1 of the documentary “The War,” by Ken Burns and Lynn Novick that it showed on Sept. 23. Under the measurement standard normally used in the television industry, the program attracted 7.3 million viewers, not 15.5 million, making it smaller than that for most other programs on major networks that night. Also, “The War” was not second in prime time to NBC’S “Sunday Night Football.”.

Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the merger of the American operations of SABMiller and Molson Coors Brewing Company referred incorrectly to the brewing of Leinenkugel’s beer. It is made in Wisconsin; it is not imported.

The Jerusalem Journal article on Monday, about the ways in which Israelis are coping with shmita, a Jewish sabbatical for farming the land that occurs every seven years, misspelled the given name of a theologian who commented on the effect on Israel’s agriculture industry. He is Rabbi Yehudah Mirsky, not Yehuda. Because of an editing error, a picture caption misidentified the location of a man shown holding a scroll of the Torah, which mandates shmita. He was in the southern Israeli town of Kiryat Malahi, not Jerusalem.

The Jerusalem Journal article on Monday, about the ways in which Israelis are coping with shmita, a Jewish sabbatical for farming the land that occurs every seven years, misspelled the given name of a theologian who commented on the effect on Israel’s agriculture industry. He is Rabbi Yehudah Mirsky, not Yehuda. Because of an editing error, a picture caption misidentified the location of a man shown holding a scroll of the Torah, which mandates shmita. He was in the southern Israeli town of Kiryat Malahi, not Jerusalem.

An obituary on Oct. 2 about Al Oerter, a discus thrower who won four consecutive Olympic titles, misidentified the town where he grew up. It is New Hyde Park, N.Y. — not West Islip, N.Y., where he moved after graduating from college.

An article on Oct. 1 about former leaders of the environmental movement in New York who are now working for the Spitzer administration misstated the role played by Pete Grannis, the environmental conservation commissioner, in the passage of important environmental laws while he was in the State Assembly. Although Mr. Grannis was a key supporter of laws like the first bottle bill and the State Environmental Quality Review Act, he did not introduce either bill.

An obituary on Oct. 3 about the actor George Grizzard, who was featured in the original production of “Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf,” misstated the circumstances under which he left the play. His departure was expected; it did not stun his associates. He had already auditioned for the part of Hamlet at the Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis and had agreed to take it when he took the “Virginia Woolf” role, which he left at the end of his contract. He did not leave to audition at the Guthrie.

A report in the Yankees Notebook on Tuesday about Phil Hughes, who became the youngest pitcher to win a postseason game for the club, referred incorrectly to the previous record-holder, Whitey Ford. He gained the distinction by winning Game 4 of the 1950 World Series against the Phillies, not Game 1.

An article in some editions last Thursday about arguments before the United States Supreme Court in a case challenging New York State’s method for selecting judicial nominees referred incorrectly to the outcomes of nominating conventions attended by delegates chosen during party primaries. At least twice since the system was established in 1921 the delegates have chosen judicial candidates who were not favored by the party leadership; they have not always gone along with the leadership’s choices.
The Sky Watch chart on Sunday misidentified a planet. Jupiter — not Saturn —was in the bottom right, between the South and West labels.

The Personal Health column in Science Times on Oct. 2, about a vaccine for shingles, omitted the date and source of a quotation from Dr. Stephen E. Straus, who was an infectious disease specialist at the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases. Dr. Straus’s comment, about the results of a study of the vaccine, was from a National Institutes of Health news release in June 2005, when the study was published; he was not interviewed for the column. (Dr. Straus died in May.).

The Agricultural Bank of China, saddled with $100 billion of bad loans, may move some of its 14,500 rural branches to independent companies to speed up a government bailout and sell shares for the first time. The bank, one of the nation’s largest, was established in 1979 to serve China’s 800 million farmers. The Ministry of Finance and the China Investment Company, an agency set up last month to manage $200 billion of the nation’s foreign exchange reserves, would each own a third of Agricultural Bank, according to a draft of a government proposal obtained by Bloomberg News. Another 20 percent would be sold to foreign investors that have experience with rural lending, and about 5 percent to local corporate investors, according to the document. The remainder would be offered to the public. China has spent about $500 billion bailing out its biggest lenders over the past decade.

J Sainsbury, the British grocery store operator, said second-quarter sales growth slowed, influenced by unusually wet summer weather and strong competition. Sales grew 3.8 percent in the three months ended Saturday, down from 7.6 percent in the period a year earlier. Despite the slowdown, the chief executive, Justin King, above, said the company was ahead of its target to increase sales by £2.5 billion ($5 billion) by March 2008.

Royal Philips Electronics said it sold about $2.2 billion worth of shares in the maker of flat screens, LG.Philips LCD, reducing its stake to 19.9 percent. Philips, which had held a 33 percent stake in the company, said it would book a nontaxable gain of about 500 million euros ($702 million) in the fourth quarter. LG.Philips, which was created as a joint venture of Philips and LG Electronics, is based in Seoul, South Korea.

Murchison Metals bid as much as 986 million Australian dollars ($882 million) in stock for the Midwest Corporation to secure the right to build a port needed for its iron ore mine. The bid values Midwest at 4.70 Australian dollars a share, 34 percent more than its closing price on Tuesday. Murchison and Midwest, both based in Perth, have been competing with each other to build a port on Australia’s west coast to ship ore to Japan and China. Midwest said it was considering the bid.

A British life insurer, Resolution, rejected a takeover approach from a rival, the Pearl Group, that valued it at about £4.5 billion ($9.2 billion). Resolution said Pearl had put forward a possible offer at 660 pence a Resolution share on Tuesday. Resolution announced plans to merge with Friends Provident in July, but a day later, Pearl threatened to make a competing bid.
The reactivation of a long-dormant foghorn on Long Island was followed by a malfunction that caused it to blast every 10 seconds for days.
YONKERS, Oct. 10 — At first there were reports on Wednesday of a car explosion involving some kind of booby trap with one or more law-enforcement officers being injured in a drug arrest gone haywire.
The blanket of China’s air defense radar now almost matches similar networks in developed countries, China’s state news media reported.

In a gesture to the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, Israel will grant residency permits to 3,500 Palestinians living illegally in the occupied West Bank but will not act on another 1,500 Palestinians living in Hamas-run Gaza, Israeli officials said.
A judge who sentenced a man to four months in prison for stealing a Bible from a bookstore first handed him a new Bible.

Roberto Madrazo, last year’s losing presidential candidate who was stripped of his first-place title in the age-55 category of the Berlin Marathon, said in a statement that he had never pretended to have won.

A judge in Kogi State ordered a rerun of the election for governor in the last general elections, in April, ruling in favor of an opposition candidate who argued that the voting was so marred by fraud and violence that the results lacked legitimacy.

A power struggle among the upper echelons of the Russian security services broke into the open this week when the head of the federal drug control service published an open letter in a prominent newspaper.
Danny Williams, the Conservative premier of Newfoundland and Labrador, was re-elected with almost 70 percent of the popular vote.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,808 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Tuesday:.
The walkout appears to have been a way for union leaders and company managers to prove they got the best deal they could at a time of deep troubles.
While clear law exists for the military in war zones, a patchwork of untested laws and practical obstacles all but insulate contractors from accountability.
Many key players in the U.S. attorneys scandal are gone, but Congress has a lot of work to do in uncovering the damage they have done to the justice system.
It does not bode well that America’s leaders can’t even see their way to raising the obviously too low taxes on private equity partners.
The natural elements for a burgeoning rivalry between the Diamondbacks and the Rockies are there, but Arizona is not overwhelmed by enthusiasm for its team.
A House committee voted to condemn the mass killings of Armenians in Turkey in World War I as genocide.
In refusing to consider Khaled el-Masri’s appeal, the Supreme Court has left an innocent person without any remedy for his wrongful imprisonment.
Groups across the country have been raising money in a last-ditch effort to pull Al Gore into the presidential race.
The father and son team who run the Cipriani restaurants in Venice and New York were sentenced Wednesday after their guilty pleas this summer on charges of tax evasion.
The announcement is a blow to a program that had been seen as the most successful in commercial aviation — a perfect blend of technology, marketing and production line innovations.
The authorities said the attacker was disgruntled about having been suspended after a fight earlier this week.
American military officials and Iraqi investigators say the F.B.I. and State Department are refusing to share information with them on their investigation into the Blackwater killings.

Police and education officials fiercely defended school security officers yesterday, a day after a principal was arrested at a high school in the East Village for trying to intervene as officers arrested a student.
Knowing that part of the negotiating process is posturing, Yankees closer Mariano Rivera did his best impersonation of a player who was ruminating about leaving his team.
The identity of the player tied to the evidence is not known.
The police said that their hate crimes unit had mounted a full investigation, including testing the rope for DNA.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Oct. 10 — The severe beating of a Hebrew studies teacher as he walked to synagogue Tuesday evening on a quiet residential street here has shaken this shore town, which in recent years has seen rapid population changes, including a surging Orthodox Jewish community.
A federal judge ordered an indefinite delay on a central measure of the Bush administration’s new strategy.
The Yankees season has come to an end, and the sports-talk radio stations in New England are full of joy and gloating.
The lawsuit includes an allegation that the president of Oral Roberts University, Richard Roberts, illegally mobilized students to campaign for a Republican mayoral candidate.

The former Champ Car star Patrick Carpentier signed with Gillett Evernham Motorsports to drive the No. 10 Dodge in the Nextel Cup series. Carpentier is replacing Scott Riggs, who is leaving to drive for Haas CNC Racing next season. Carpentier, a Quebec native, appears to be a good fit for the Gilletts, who hope he will attract Canadian businesses to Nascar. The team is currently looking for a primary sponsor for the No. 10.

A thoroughbred trainer suspended one year for violating horse medication rules received a temporary stay of his suspension while Kentucky racing officials considered his appeal. The trainer Patrick Biancone received the suspension last week from Kentucky racing stewards after a search of a refrigerator at his Keeneland barn found snake venom, which can be used to numb a horse’s nerves. Biancone said the substance did not belong to him. It was not immediately clear whether Biancone would be allowed to participate in the Breeders’ Cup this month at Monmouth Park.

The body of George Gipp, the Notre Dame player who inspired the rallying cry “Win one for the Gipper,” was exhumed recently for DNA testing in his Upper Peninsula hometown, Traverse City, Mich. The test was sought by the Gipp family and met legal requirements, the Houghton County medical examiner said, although it angered some relatives who live in the area where Gipp was born and raised. The medical examiner’s office declined comment about why the request was made. An ESPN crew taped the exhumation for a coming report, but a spokesman for the network said it played no role in arranging it.

Goalkeeper Hope Solo, whose remarks critical of Coach Greg Ryan got her dismissed from the United States team at the Women’s World Cup, is on the roster for a three-game series with Mexico. The teams play Saturday at the Edward Jones Dome in St. Louis, and Solo and goalie Briana Scurry were listed yesterday on Ryan’s 20-player roster.
The suggestion would have the Marine Corps effectively leave the Iraq war in the hands of the Army while taking on a prominent new role in Afghanistan.

The sprint car star Ricky Stenhouse Jr. signed with Roush Fenway Racing and will move to stock cars next season. Stenhouse, who turns 20 later this month, will run the full ARCA schedule next season. Stenhouse, from Olive Branch, Miss., raced for Tony Stewart Racing this season in the National Sprint Car and National Midget Car Series. He won 2 races and had 14 top-10 finishes in 22 starts.
George Steinbrenner, now 77 and uneasy in public, is depending more than ever on input from his sons, Hank and Hal.
The appeal comes after four days of fierce fighting in North Waziristan that has left scores dead among both the tribes and the Pakistani military.
The lucrative new deal for the music star would rely heavily on her longevity as a live-concert attraction.
Washington has begun to study Japan’s tough system for ensuring the quality and safety of Chinese imports, particularly food.

Two men who federal authorities say gave them inconsistent information in the disappearance of four crew members of a boat at sea last month were charged with first-degree murder. Federal prosecutors said they had enough evidence to charge the men, Kirby L. Archer, 35, and Guillermo A. Zarabozo, 20, who last month chartered a vessel called the Joe Cool. The 47-foot boat, which was supposed to be going to the Bahamas, was found near Cuba the day after Mr. Archer and Mr. Zarabozo chartered it, and the men were later found floating in the boat’s life raft. The crew was not found. The men initially told the authorities that pirates had attacked the group and shot the crew members, Jake Branam, 27; his wife, Kelley Branam, 30; his half-brother Scott Gamble, 30; and Samuel Kairy, 27.

Chicagoans would have to spend 10 cents more on a bottle of water, pay higher property taxes and spend more for liquor under Mayor Richard M. Daley’s proposed budget for next year. Also financing Mr. Daley’s $5.4 billion budget are higher water and sewer fees and more expensive vehicle stickers for people driving large vehicles, $120 a vehicle sticker, up from $90. Mr. Daley announced his budget to aldermen, calling it a last resort to ask taxpayers for more money. His budget closes a $196 million deficit and avoids service cuts and layoffs. Budget hearings will be held, and a city spending plan will require a vote by aldermen.
The Senate Judiciary Committee announced that it would open hearings next week on the nomination of Michael B. Mukasey to be attorney general.

In the third day of deliberations in the trial of a former president of Texas Southern University, Priscilla Slade, a jury of six men and six women told a judge that they were deadlocked 8 to 4. But, the judge, Brock Thomas of District Court in Houston, denied a motion for a mistrial and asked the jury to continue its work in the trial, which began Aug. 24. The jury’s note did not indicate whether jurors were in favor of conviction or acquittal of Dr. Slade, who is accused of spending more than $200,000 on personal items while she served as president of Texas Southern, the state’s largest historically black university.

Nearly 5,000 registered nurses at 15 hospitals in Northern California went on a two-day strike to protest what union officials said were inadequate contract offerings and concerns over staffing deficiencies at sites in the Sutter Health chain. The hospitals, 13 in the Bay Area and two north of Sacramento, have hired replacement workers, in some cases through Monday, which the union said would result in a lockout. Nine hospitals in the Sutter network, some of which have multiple campuses, are negotiating separate contracts. Viki Ardito, a spokeswoman for Alta Bates Summit, one of Sutter’s largest sites, said nurses had been offered a “rich benefit package” with an 18 percent wage increase and free health care options, adding, “It’s really not about us, it’s about broader issues with Sutter.”.
The Supreme Court is likely to take up the issue again soon, with nationwide implications.
The defense secretary said Wednesday that the Army needed to improve its ability to train foreign militaries and prepare for more unconventional conflicts.
Gerhard Ertl’s work in surface chemistry has applications across an array of fields, including the environment.
The S.E.C. has been asked to investigate stock sales by Angelo R. Mozilo, Countrywide’s chief executive, before its shares plummeted amid the deepening mortgage crisis.
The city’s first global advertising campaign is the latest weapon aimed at hitting the mayor’s target of increasing the number of visitors to 50 million a year by 2015.
Certain marketing tactics aimed at students are the latest focus of the continuing inquiry into the student loan industry by the New York attorney general.
Senator John McCain will propose overhauling the nation’s health care system by offering incentives for both patients and doctors.
A tougher policy means that families who are turned down for benefits will be without shelter as they reapply.
Two Congressional panels on Wednesday adopted a measure that would give federal judges greater oversight over electronic surveillance conducted overseas by the National Security Agency.
Joe Torre might have managed his final Yankee game,  but the team is still acting to move persistent newspaper photographers and TV camera people off his lawn and driveway.
The maker of Snapple and Dr Pepper decided to spin off its drinks unit after faltering credit markets made a sale difficult.
The competing measures are aimed at helping homeowners trapped in a vise of unaffordable subprime mortgages and falling home prices.

A lawyer testified in a case about accusations of White House interference in the Justice Department’s corruption case against a former Democratic governor of Alabama, who is serving an 88-month sentence.
The announcement comes at a time of declining gambling revenue as Atlantic City faces increased competition from new slot parlors in Pennsylvania and New York.
The defense lawyer in the murder case of Allan Cameron, who is accused of killing a Brooklyn police officer, attacked the evidence against Mr. Cameron as fraudulent.
Mr. Wallace, an investment banker, played a leading role in several of the largest recent telecommunications mergers.
If the F.D.A. follows the advisory panel’s recommendation, Medtronic may be able to enter the lucrative American market for drug-coated stents by the end of this year.

Charles E. Friedgood, formerly a wealthy heart surgeon from Long Island who almost got away with committing the perfect murder in 1975 but managed to talk himself into prison, could not talk himself out this week.
City officials agreed Wednesday not to enforce an ordinance used to bolster police sweeps of homeless people sleeping on sidewalks until 1,250 units of low-cost housing are built.
The agricultural company posted a wider quarterly loss partly because of weakness in its selective herbicide business and a higher interest expense and tax rate.
Airlines have long sought to meet with the Transportation Department to coordinate schedules to ease flight delays, which reached record levels this summer.

A fifth Municipal Court judge in Jersey City has left office in the midst of a state investigation into ticket fixing in the city, the mayor’s office said yesterday. The judge, Vincent A. Signorile, a former city councilman, informed the court yesterday that he was taking an unpaid leave of absence. A spokeswoman for Mayor Jerramiah T. Healy said the leave was connected to the investigation. One other judge has resigned, three judges have taken leaves, a court worker has resigned and another has been suspended. The state assumed control of the court this month. The mayor appointed replacements for the judges yesterday, and they are expected to be sworn in today.

A Long Island man who worked as a lawyer for a prestigious Manhattan law firm admitted in State Supreme Court yesterday that he was not really a lawyer. The man, Brian Valery, 32, of Massapequa Park, started as a paralegal at the firm, Anderson, Kill & Olick, and was later hired as a lawyer after falsely claiming that he had a law degree and had passed the bar. Mr. Valery pleaded guilty to second-degree grand larceny yesterday, admitting that he stole more than $200,000 by claiming a lawyer’s salary for almost two years. Justice Gregory Carro said he would sentence Mr. Valery to five years’ probation if he repaid at least $150,000 by Jan. 30. The firm fired Mr. Valery and reported him to the state attorney general’s office when it discovered the deceit.

A federal judge ruled yesterday that a defense lawyer must continue to represent the co-defendant of Sharpe James, the former Newark mayor, in a corruption case despite the lawyer’s request to be relieved. Judge William J. Martini of Federal District Court said the lawyer, Gerald Krovatin, knew even before his client, Tamika Riley, above, was indicted in July that she was having trouble paying his fees. Mr. Krovatin maintains that Ms. Riley cannot afford to pay him for the expected three-month trial and the six weeks needed to prepare. Mr. James, 71, is accused of using city-issued credit cards to pay for $58,000 worth of personal trips and expenses and for engineering the sale of nine city-owned properties at a discount rate to Ms. Riley, his companion. Ms. Riley, 38, is charged with fraud.

A man in a wheelchair was critically injured yesterday when he was struck by two cars while trying to cross a street in Harlem, the police said. The man, 44, whose identity was not revealed by the police, was hit about 6 a.m. by a white van traveling west on 125th Street, the police said. The impact threw the man into the eastbound lane, where he was hit by a black Lincoln Town Car. The police said that both drivers left, but that the Town Car driver returned. The injured man was taken to Harlem Hospital Center, the police said.

Mims Hackett Jr., the current Orange mayor and a former Democratic state assemblyman, was indicted yesterday by a federal grand jury on charges of accepting a $5,000 bribe. The indictment was expected, as Mr. Hackett was among 11 current or former public officials arrested by federal agents on Sept. 6. Mr. Hackett, 65, resigned from the Assembly on Sept. 10 but remains the mayor. He faces charges of bribery and attempted extortion. Federal prosecutors have charged Mr. Hackett with accepting $5,000 in an alley outside City Hall from an undercover operative posing as an insurance broker seeking a government contract, according to the indictment. Compiled by John Sullivan.

Subway service was interrupted yesterday for about two hours on much of the No. 7 line, after electrical power to the signals failed shortly after 1:35 p.m., transit officials said. The signal problem originated in the area of the 111th Street station in Queens and quickly spread to most other stations on the line, which runs between Times Square in Manhattan and Main Street in Flushing. All service was halted, but trains were able to reach the nearest station to let off their passengers, said Charles Seaton, a spokesman for New York City Transit. Mr. Seaton said the cause of the power failure was under investigation but did not appear to involve an interruption in the power supply delivered by Consolidated Edison. Some service was resumed between Times Square and Queensboro Plaza a few minutes before 3 p.m. Local service along the full line returned at 3:33 p.m., the agency said.

City officials have arrested 35 building owners, business owners, and employees who failed to answer summonses issued for uncorrected fire code violations, city officials announced yesterday. The City Department of Investigation said the 35 people faced fines ranging from $100 to $3,500 if they were found to have violated the fire code. The violations include nonworking alarms and sprinkler systems, operating an auto repair shop without a permit, and operating an unlicensed cabaret, city officials said.

ALBANY, Oct. 10 — Gov. Eliot Spitzer outlined roughly $850 million of economic development initiatives on Wednesday aimed at revitalizing Buffalo and Niagara Falls, including a plan to redevelop the Buffalo waterfront, which will have a nearly 200,000- square-foot sporting goods store built to resemble an old Erie Canal wharf terminal in the historic inner harbor.
Mayor Robert W. Levy resigned less than 24 hours after ending his unexplained absence with the disclosure of his emergency stay in a rehabilitation clinic.
The Bush administration asserts that the detainees at Guantánamo Bay “enjoy more procedural protections than any other captured enemy combatants in the history of warfare.”
Reports of abuse of troubled young people in privately run boot camps and other residential treatment centers are widespread, according to a federal report released Wednesday.
The tests to verify the bloodlines of would-be immigrants who want to join family members living in France.
The penalty is to settle charges that Sandell Asset Management  engaged in improper short sales in connection with the merger of Hibernia and Capital One Financial.
A federal judge today ordered an indefinite delay on a central measure of the Bush administration’s new strategy to curb illegal immigration.
Allan Houston will return to practice for the Knicks on Friday, but the 36-year-old will not have much time to make the team.
Cincinnati Bengals linebacker Odell Thurman says that the N.F.L.’s decision not to reinstate him because officials believe he is an alcoholic violates the Americans with Disabilities Act.
Several major companies suggested that a slowing economy was taking its toll on corporate profits, sapping investor sentiment.
The Masters will no longer be carried by the USA Network, its home on cable for the tournament’s early rounds since 1982, but will shift to ESPN starting in April.

A new crew bound for the International Space Station, including Malaysia’s first astronaut and the first woman assigned to command the station, blasted off Wednesday aboard a Russian Soyuz spacecraft.
Mr. Kempowski compiled thousands of pages of recollections from eyewitnesses of World War II into a monumental firsthand record of the German wartime experience.
Dr. Saenger set off a dispute over medical ethics by leading a cold-war research study that exposed patients in Cincinnati to intense doses of radiation.
With the return of Brandon Jacobs, the Giants have become the latest surging team to showcase a 1-2 punch of productive running backs.
The 43-year-old quarterback has signed a one-year contract with the Carolina Panthers, the sixth franchise of his career.
The data was a sign that manufacturers were poised to expand production and help avoid an economic slump.
Goldman’s business of packaging home loans into bonds has fallen off dramatically as investor appetite for mortgage-backed securities slowed amid record home foreclosures.
Greater cultivation of crops to produce ethanol could harm water quality and leave some regions of the country with water shortages, a panel of experts is reporting.
The suit asserts that the company breached its duty to shareholders by mishandling product safety procedures responsible for three toy recalls during the summer.
The warehouse retailer’s 5 percent rise in fiscal fourth-quarter earnings was driven by a rebound in sales growth, cost cutting and a tighter returns policy for electronics.
House & Garden is teaming up with NYC & Company, the marketing organization of the city government, to put on Design Happening.
The former chairman and chief executive of the copper producer Phelps Dodge spent four decades at the Phoenix-based company.
Joseph P. Nacchio claimed he had been found guilty of insider trading based on insufficient evidence.
An advisory group of hedge fund executives said that the funds should disclose indirect investments in companies and do a better job of informing clients of risks.
A Supreme Court argument on the consequences of a World Court ruling in favor of a Mexican murderer on death row in Texas turned into an intense and lively seminar.
The Jets quarterback has reached that stage in every veteran quarterback’s N.F.L. life span when a younger, cheaper and stronger-armed replacement begins breathing down his neck.
Further vaccinations are seen as the only remedy for the outbreak, which has raised concerns that it will be a new setback for troubled eradication efforts in Nigeria.
Mr. Griffith, who was known for using dark humor in his scripts, wrote dozens of films in several genres, like science fiction, westerns and horror.
Mr. Owen played on the 1960 team that won the first Olympic gold medal in ice hockey for the United States.

Richard Bangs knows adventure travel. He completed first descents of 35 rivers (meaning he was the first known human to traverse them), and co-founded Mountain Travel Sobek, the oldest adventure travel company in the United States. But over time the satisfaction from the “mindless” hard-core adventures wore thin, he says, especially after finding some locations he had visited before dramatically altered by humans.

On Monday night, 22-year-old Nick Folk of the Dallas Cowboys accomplished one of the most difficult tasks in sport: He made a 53-yard field goal, as time expired, in front of a hostile crowd, on national television, to win an N.F.L. game. It was as exciting as sports get. He ran off the field screaming ... only to learn that the kick did not count, that a timeout had been called before the play, that he had to do it again. His reward for doing this was being forced to do it again. Which, mercifully, he did.

Marion Jones, the track star who won five medals in the 2000 Olympics, last week pleaded guilty to providing false statements to federal agents and admitted to using performance-enhancing drugs before the Games. She has since relinquished her gold medals and may face jail time. Do these developments tarnish just Jones, or the entire American track and field establishment?.

The economy of motion, the relationship between energy use and speed, can determine the small difference between one elite athlete and another, and sometimes the big difference between fast and slow runners, reports Gina Kolata in The Times today. The goal of athletes, of course, would be moving faster while expending the same amount of energy.

Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico ran a series of four humorous advertisements in Iowa, all with the same theme: Mr. Richardson posing as an overqualified job candidate being interviewed by a boorish potential employer.
American courts and publishers must take steps to preserve the unique protections American authors and journalists treasure.
Perhaps we find China’s reincarnation laws so outrageous because they spill the secret of what we have done for so long.
More and more sleep-away camps are seeking to boost revenue by hosting outside groups and by staying open beyond the traditional summer season.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.

Rita Braver, who interviewed Lynne Cheney on the CBS News program “Sunday Morning,” told viewers that her husband, the Washington lawyer Robert B. Barnett, had represented Ms. Cheney in the publishing deal for her new memoir.
The firm of Sanford I. Weill’s son-in-law, Natan Bibliowicz, has been hired as the architect for Carnegie Hall’s $150 million expansion into two studio-filled towers above the hall.
Women who have suffered horribly are creating exquisite, elegant objects that are transforming their lives.

RIESS--Michael. The 92nd Street Y Board and Staff mourns the passing of Michael Riess, beloved father of Board member, Dr. Gail Saltz. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife Dr. Doris Riess, Gail and the entire Riess and Saltz families. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Fredric Mack, President Michael Goldstein, Chairman Sol Adler, Executive Director RIESS--Michael, Naval Analyst, Entrepreneur, 76, of Wilmington, NC, died Monday October 8, 2007. There will be a private service for the immediate family. Michael was born on March 13, 1931 in Berlin, Germany, son of Ilse and Curt Riess. He emigrated on the Europa to the United States in 1936. He attended PS6 in Manhattan followed by Peter Stuyvesant High School before serving as a paratrooper and instructor stationed at Fort Bragg, NC during the Korean War. After the war, he received a Bachelor's Degree in Aeronautical Engineering at New York University and a Master's in Aeronautical Engineering at the University of Maryland. Michael worked for the Navy in Washington, D.C. where he assisted the Secretary of the Navy, Paul Nitze before becoming Chief Scientist for anti-submarine warfare under Admiral Charles Martell. He left the Navy in 1970 for the private sector and became an independent business man in New Jersey, establishing several companies before retiring from Warren, New Jersey to North Carolina. He enjoyed traveling in their single engine Grumman Tiger with his wife, both of whom were instrument qualified pilots. They flew to Mexico, Guatemala, Belize, and across the United States. He is survived by his wife of 47 years, Dr. Doris Riess of Wilmington, his daughters Dr. Gail Saltz and her husband Dr. Leonard Saltz of New York, NY and Holly Hagerman of Newark, DE, and his son Dr. Adam Riess and Adam's wife, Nancy, of Baltimore, MD as well as seven grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Lower Cape Fear Hospice & LifeCare Center, 2222 17th Street, Wilmington, NC 28401.

Tim Copeland, a Vermont furniture maker who has exclusive rights to produce Frank Lloyd Wright's furniture, was reviewing drawings at the Taliesin West archives in Scottsdale, Ariz., last year when he made a surprising discovery. Among the drawings for the 1908 Boynton House in Rochester, N.Y., were studies for a dining chair that curved in two directions, to support the lumbar area and to cradle the shoulders -- a radically different design from the flat-back shape of most of the Prairie-era chairs. To bring Wright's vision to life, Mr. Copeland converted the sketch, above, into a computer image and asked a custom laminating firm to build a mold on which five layers of quarter-sawn oak could be stretched and sealed together. The resulting side chair ($949), right, and armchair ($1,149), introduced this month along with a matching dining table (starting at $4,999), can be ordered now for February delivery. Information: (802) 222-9282 or copelandfurniture.com. JULIE SCELFO

LAURSEN--Steingrim. It is with enormous sadness that The International Council of The Museum of Modern Art notes the death of Steingrim Laursen of Copenhagen on September 27. A loyal and enthusiastic member of the International Council since 1972, he was a Vice President since 1996. Steingrim was Director Emeritus of Denmark's Louisiana Museum, an Officer of the French Legion of Honor, and the organizer of many exhibitions. Steingrim's curiosity, intelligence, and immense good nature brought him to the forefront of the international arts. His many friends from all over the world mourn his absence. Brian Urquhart, Chairman Emeritus Agnes Gund, Chairman Jo Carole Lauder, President Joanne M. Stern, Vice Chairman The International Council of The Museum of Modern Art

An exhibition and sale of sculpture by Yonel Lebovici, the late French artist, opens today at Maison Gerard. Many of Mr. Lebovici's works were inspired by everyday objects, and are both decorative and functional. Although Mr. Lebovici is relatively unknown in the United States, his influence can be seen in the work of Pop artists like Claes Oldenburg: The oversize safety-pin lamp Mr. Lebovici made in 1980 ($150,000) predated Oldenburg's giant safety pin by nearly 20 years. The show also includes the 1969 Satellite Lamp ($42,000), above; the 1988 Thon Bar ($150,000), which resembles a giant tuna; and a pair of doors called Les Yeux ($275,000) with mechanical eyes. Through Nov. 20 at Maison Gerard, 53 East 10th Street (University Place), (212) 674-7611.MARIANNE ROHRLICH

In the late 1700s wealthy merchants in Salem, Mass., flaunted their cosmopolitan taste by commissioning neo-Classical buildings and furniture from Samuel McIntire, a self-taught local architect. McIntire (shown in a circa 1786 portrait above) designed many of the colonnaded houses and public buildings in town, and carved scrollwork and foliage into countless chairs and tables. A number of those pieces, as well as mantels and paneled rooms, will be part of an exhibition of his work opening Saturday at the Peabody Essex Museum in Salem. Dean T. Lahikainen, the museum's curator of American decorative art, calls it ''a mixture of naïve charm, beautiful proportions and very coherent systems of details.'' Through Feb. 24 at the Peabody Essex Museum, Salem, Mass., (866) 745-1876 or pem.org. EVE M. KAHN

PICKETS, THEN A PROPOSAL Six hours after union leaders sent Chrysler's 45,000 workers to the picket lines, the United Automobile Workers and the automaker announced a tentative agreement. The terms are expected to echo the contract that was hammered out by the union and General Motors after a two-day walkout last month.

For fans of midcentury modern furniture who cannot afford the record prices now paid for the work of superstars like Charlotte Perriand and the Ateliers Jean Prouvé, whose 1952 bookshelf sold for $180,000 in June at Christie's, ''The Modern Show,'' opening tomorrow at the 69th Regiment Armory, offers lesser-known designers at much lower prices. The beechwood scooter, below, which becomes a rocker when turned upside down, was made around 1950 by Hans Brockhage and Erwin Andrä; it will be $1,200 at the booth of Sarah Latham-Kearns. The 1930s hand-thrown Japanese ceramic vase, above, is also $1,200, at the Cannondale Antiques booth. Through Sunday at the 69th Regiment Armory, Lexington Avenue at 26th Street. Information: (212) 255-0020. ELAINE LOUIE

The renovation of the Royalton Hotel was done so quickly that many probably didn't even notice it had temporarily closed. In just four months, the firm of Roman and Williams completely transformed a lobby designed by Philippe Starck that some considered iconic (and others dated) into a space that Mari Balestrazzi, the vice president of design for Morgans Hotel Group, says she ''hopes people will think of as a new living room in the city.'' A lobby that once revealed itself immediately from the entrance is now broken down into smaller seating areas, visible first through a massive fireplace with textured iron surround, top right. Colors go from dark to light from the lobby to the restaurant, Brasserie Forty-Four, bottom near right, also designed by Roman and Williams and owned by John McDonald. Redesign of the rooms, bottom far right, however, was perhaps appropriately assigned to Charlotte Macaux Perelman, of Studio CMP, who had worked for Mr. Starck on hotel projects like the Sanderson in London. ''I wanted to keep some of the Philippe gestures, like the bed niche and the fireplace, just making it more sexy and up-to-date,'' Ms. Perelman said. She kept the round bathtubs but surrounded them with mirrored mosaic tiles and a rain-effect shower head. Very sexy indeed. RIMA SUQI

VICENTE--Harriet. The National Women's Division of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University records with profound sorrow the passing of Harriet Vicente, a member of our New York Chapter Executive Board. Harriet was a founding member of the National Women's Division and was dedicated to its mission of support for medical research and education at the College. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to the entire family. National Women's Division Bambi Felberbaum National President Judy R. Rosenberg Chairwoman, Executive Committee VICENTE--Harriet. A devoted friend of Jerusalem whose generous spirit will live on in the projects she helped bring to life -Alison's Park, in memory of her daughter, and the programs for Arab women to help enrich their lives. Alan G. Hassenfeld, Chairmn Ruth Cheshin, Intl. President Board Members & Staff VICENTE--Harriet. For more than 60 years, Harriet G. Vicente was an inspired philanthropist in the cultural arts field. With her husband, the painter Esteban Vicente, she honored Yaddo by establishing an endowed residency for Spanish painters. We mourn her death on October 4 and gratefully acknowledge her friendship and support. Elaina H. Richardson, President Peter C. Gould, Chair The Corporation of Yaddo VICENTE--Harriet. The Rockefeller University deeply mourns the loss of Harriet Vicente, a cherished member of The Rockefeller University Council. We are fortunate to have known this warm and generous - hearted woman. Harriet embraced the research of scientists working at the frontiers of biomedicine by establishing the Esteban Vicente Postdoctoral Fellowship for talented young investigators conducting research related to mental illness. A tireless ambassador and advocate for Rockefeller, she was also a generous supporter of the University's Women & Science initiative. We celebrate Harriet's keen intellect, her wit, and her great generosity, and compassion for artists in all walks of life. Harriet believed that scientists are creative individuals, and she was attracted by the University's commitment to nurturing scientific creativity and its integration of the arts and humanities with science. In 2003, Harriet Vicente donated to the University a vibrant abstract painting entitled Tremor by her late husband, Esteban Vicente. Given on the 100th anniversary of Esteban Vicente's birth, Tremor will be a permanent reminder to the University community of this unique and remarkable woman, and her intrepid and ever - fascinating journey through life. Harriet, herself, was an artist at friendships. She will be greatly missed by the Rockefeller community. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her family and all who loved her. David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman Richard Furlaud, Chairman Emeritus and Council Chair Paul Nurse, President Torsten Wiesel, President Emeritus Marnie Imhoff, Vice President The Rockefeller University

AS the weather cools, rock climbers must trade their shorts in for pants. The trick is to gain protection against colder temperatures without any restriction of motion. Made of stretchy or durable material, this season's crop of climbing pants features articulated knees, crotches reinforced with additional fabric and wide waistbands to better provide mobility for scaling a rock face. Vibrant colors, contrast stitching and slim or cargo silhouettes indicate that the pants are styled to be worn off the wall or rock.

This week there are two obvious big games in L.S.U.-Kentucky and Missouri-Oklahoma, but beyond that lie numerous matchups that are not without their intrigue. South Florida and Central Florida meet in a game that showcases two up-and-coming programs that are each a testament to the incredible depth of talent that comes from the Sunshine State. Arizona State and Cinncinati - two of the surprising teams thus far - put undefeated records on the line against dangerous conference opponents. Also Boston College takes its undefeated record on the road to South Bend against a Notre Dame team that is coming off a victory for the first time this season. As always there's plenty to watch. Enjoy the weekend.

A teenager at the center of a civil rights controversy was back in jail after a judge decided the fight that put him in the national spotlight violated terms of his probation for a previous conviction, his lawyer said. Judge J. P. Mauffrey Jr. of State District Court sentenced the teenager, Mychal Bell, to 18 months in jail on two counts of simple battery and two counts of criminal destruction of property, the lawyer, Powell Lexing said. The charges were filed before the Dec. 4 attack on a classmate, Justin Barker, in which Mr. Bell and five others were charged. Charges of attempted murder against five of them were later reduced.
Pitcher Jeff Francis led the Rockies over the Diamondbacks in Game One of the N.L. Championship Series,  the team’s 18th victory in 19 games and its ninth consecutive win on the road.

Riley Skinner threw a 35-yard touchdown pass to Kenneth Moore in the fourth quarter to lead host Wake Forest past No. 21 Florida State, 24-21, last night.Skinner completed 19 of 27 passes for 215 yards and 2 touchdowns for the Demon Deacons (4-2, 3-1 Atlantic Coast Conference), who rallied in the second half to defeat the Seminoles (4-2, 1-2) in consecutive seasons for the first time in team history.Skinner led the Demon Deacons 82 yards in nine plays, converting three third downs in their winning drive.

An exchange of words with another motorist on a campus road was blown out of proportion by Internet-fueled rumors and news media speculation, Penn State Coach Joe Paterno said Thursday night.

Ryan Newman captured a pole at Lowe’s Motor Speedway in Concord, N.C., for the seventh time when he knocked Jimmie Johnson off the top spot with a speed of 189.394 miles an hour in qualifying for the Bank of America 500. Johnson, who has won 5 of the past 12 races at Lowe’s, will start second after a lap of 188.990 for tomorrow night’s race.

The state agency that owns the former Deutsche Bank building hopes to resume work dismantling it next month, and the delays after a deadly fire should not affect the rebuilding schedule at the World Trade Center site, an agency official said yesterday. Avi Schick, the chairman of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, would not estimate the completion date for dismantling the tower, which now stands at 26 stories. Before the fire, the agency had said that the building, heavily damaged by the collapse of the trade center on Sept. 11, would be removed by the end of the year. Work to dismantle the tower floor by floor — and clean several floors of toxic debris left by the trade center’s collapse — stopped after the Aug. 18 blaze, which killed two firefighters.
