An article yesterday about the Nobel Prize in Chemistry, won by Gerhard Ertl of Germany, referred incorrectly to the way that gas molecules might behave when they hit a surface. The molecules could be adsorbed, meaning they remain on the surface — not “absorbed,” which occurs when molecules enter the interior of a solid.

An article on June 28 about friction between parents and the wealthy founders of a charter school in Brooklyn misspelled the maiden name of the multimillionaire widow of a Time Warner executive who founded a charter school in Manhattan, the Ross Global Academy Charter School. (The error appeared in an article on Aug. 3, 2006, about a shortage of space for new small schools in New York.) She is Courtney Sale Ross, not Sales. The error came to light last week during the editing of an article about the closing of City Hall Academy, which was displaced in 2006 by the Ross school at the Tweed Courthouse.

Because of an editing error, a sports article yesterday about the Giants’ success in rotating the running backs Derrick Ward and Brandon Jacobs referred incorrectly to their performance on Sunday against the Jets. (A picture caption repeated the error in some editions .) Ward and Jacobs led the team to 188 rushing yards; they did not combine for that total. As the article noted, Jacobs gained 100 yards and Ward rushed for 56.

An article in some editions yesterday about arguments before a federal appeals court in which plaintiffs opposed to the Atlantic Yards development project in Brooklyn are seeking to reinstate a lawsuit that was dismissed earlier this year referred incorrectly to the plaintiffs. They include property owners; they are not all leaseholders of homes and businesses.

A picture yesterday with an article about troubles at youth boot camps carried an erroneous caption in some editions. The photograph showed Paul Lewis and Cynthia Harvey, parents of children who died in a residential treatment facility — not Robert Bacon, another such parent.

The Books of The Times review in Weekend on Sept. 21, about “The Nine: Inside the Secret World of the Supreme Court,” by Jeffrey Toobin, misspelled the given name of the brain-damaged woman whose case was used by some Republicans in a way that outraged Justice Sandra Day O’Connor, according to Mr. Toobin. She was Terri Schiavo, not Terry.
A U.S. attack killed 19 insurgents and 15 civilians, including nine children on Thursday -- one of the heaviest civilian death tolls in an American operation in recent months.

Because of an editing error, an article in The Arts on Oct. 4 about fears for the safety of the three Afghan schoolboys starring in the film “The Kite Runner” referred imprecisely to their roles in the film. While there are fears for the safety of all three boys, only two appeared in a culturally inflammatory rape scene. The article also included an erroneous description of United States refugee law. Afghans can apply for refugee status in the United States; they are not excluded as a group from qualifying for such status.

An article yesterday about the Nobel Prize in Chemistry, won by Gerhard Ertl of Germany, referred incorrectly to the way that gas molecules might behave when they hit a surface. The molecules could be adsorbed, meaning they remain on the surface — not “absorbed,” which occurs when molecules enter the interior of a solid.

A picture in some editions yesterday showing Don Mattingly, with an article about deliberations over Manager Joe Torre’s fate with the Yankees, referred incorrectly in some copies to the current post for Mattingly, a leading contender to succeed Torre. He is the team’s bench coach — not its hitting coach, a job held by Kevin Long.

A television review on Saturday about “Life Is Wild,” on the CW network, referred incorrectly to the series on which it is based. While that series, “Wild at Heart,” was shown in the United States on BBC America, it was a Company Pictures production for ITV. It was not a BBC series. A picture caption with the review, using information provided by CW, reversed the identities of the actors shown. D. W. Moffett was on the left, and David Butler was on the right.

The New York State Division of Human Rights awarded a lesbian prison guard $850,000 yesterday after an administrative law judge determined she had been subjected to a “relentless, daily regimen of mental and physical threats” by a co-worker at an upstate prison.

The response from the stands during the Knicks’ first night at Madison Square Garden in six months showed that the public is not yet sure what to make of the team in the wake of a recent sexual harassment trial.
In Dover, N.J., on Thursday, an alderman spent much of the afternoon explaining why he had warned of the hidden dangers lurking in gum balls and other candy dispensed by coin-operated machines.

It will cost fans up to $775 a seat to watch the men’s gold medal hockey game at the 2010 Winter Olympics in Vancouver, British Columbia. Officials organizing the Games announced ticket prices yesterday, saying their goal is to make sure all people can enjoy some events. Still, in-demand events will be pricey.Men’s gold medal hockey tickets start at $350, and tickets for the opening and closing ceremonies will range from $175 to $1,100. Tickets for the opening ceremony at the 2008 Beijing Games range from $26 to $650, but are selling online at several times their face value. For other Vancouver events, 100,000 tickets will be priced at $25.

Guard Chris Smith, the brother of J. R. Smith of the Denver Nuggets, did not enroll at Seton Hall and will not play for the team this fall. Smith’s enrollment was pending a decision by the N.C.A.A. Clearinghouse, the university said. Once cleared, Smith, who averaged 18.8 points at St. Benedict’s Prep in Newark, could play in January.

The defending champion, Paul Casey, and the six-time winner Ernie Els advanced to the second round of the World Match Play Championship at Wentworth in Virginia Water, England. The top-seeded Casey beat Jerry Kelly, 3 and 2,. Els beat Colin Montgomerie, 6 and 5. Ángel Cabrera, the United States Open champion, beat Retief Goosen, 6 and 5.
Mats Sundin set two Toronto records on one play on Thursday and the host Maple Leafs rebounded from an embarrassing loss with an 8-1 victory against the Islanders.

Texas A&M officials admonished Coach Dennis Franchione for his for-pay newsletter. Franchione did not lose his job, but the athletic director, Bill Byrne, said the newsletter — which delivered inside information to boosters for $1,200 a year — would be considered when he evaluates the coach after the season. The university said it would report the results of an internal investigation to the N.C.A.A. because of possible violations.Franchione was also ordered to shut down his Web site, CoachFran.com. A&M reported that the Web site and e-mails generated about $80,000 between 2005 and 2007. The school said Franchione’s net profit was $37,806.32.
Paula Creamer and Angela Park shot five-under 67s to share the first-round lead at the Samsung World Championship in Palm Desert, Calif. Michelle Wie was last in the field of 20 after a 79.

Stefano Baldini of Italy, the 2004 Olympic champion, joined the field for the Nov. 4 New York City Marathon. The race has been won four times by Italian men: in 1984 and 1985 by Orlando Pizzolato, 1986 by Gianni Poli and 1996 by Giacomo Leone. Baldini has run in New York five times, with finishes of third place in 1997 and fifth in 2002. He set the Italian record, 2 hours 7 minutes 22 seconds, last year in London. He won bronze medals at the world championships in 2001 and 2003 and gold medals at the European championships in 1998 and 2006.
It is good news that a federal judge has halted a reckless plan by the Bush administration to use Social Security records for immigration enforcement.

Former Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales has hired a high-powered Washington lawyer to represent him in investigations of mismanagement of the Justice Department. The lawyer, George Terwilliger, was the No. 2 Justice Department official in the early 1990s. Mr. Terwilliger said Mr. Gonzales maintained that he had done nothing wrong or illegal. “It would really be unfair to individuals who are smart enough to get themselves a lawyer to draw some inference that they need a lawyer because they did something wrong,” Mr. Terwilliger said.

The Bush administration reported that the federal budget deficit fell to $162.8 billion in the budget year just ended, the lowest amount of red ink in five years. The administration credited the president’s tax cuts for helping generate record-breaking revenues but warned of an approaching “fiscal train wreck” unless Congress dealt with unsustainable growth in Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid spending. The deficit for the 2007 budget year, which ended Sept. 30, was 34.4 percent lower than the $248.2 billion deficit recorded in 2006. It was $81 billion lower than the administration had projected in February.

The chief justice of the Illinois Supreme Court has agreed to accept a $3 million settlement after winning a libel lawsuit against a suburban Chicago newspaper and its former columnist. Tom Shaw, president and chief executive officer of The Kane County Chronicle, and the columnist, Bill Page, apologized to Chief Justice Robert Thomas. The settlement is the latest chapter in a battle that began in 2003 when Mr. Page wrote a series of columns about Chief Justice Thomas. In the columns, Mr. Page accused the chief justice of softening his position in a disciplinary hearing of a former Kane County state’s attorney. Chief Justice Thomas, a former Chicago Bears kicker, filed a defamation lawsuit. In November, a jury ruled in his favor and ordered the newspaper and the columnist to pay $7 million.
The federal effort to flush out illegal immigrants is having major effects on workers and employers alike.
Loss of access to military installations in Turkey would force the United States to send more military supplies for Iraq through other countries.
Representative Barney Frank is closely tied to the issue of gay rights, but he has recently come under siege from gay rights groups.

Representative Ralph Regula, left, an Ohio Republican who has been in the House for more than 30 years, is expected to announce today that he will retire at the end of his term, other Republicans said. Mr. Regula, 82, is the dean of Ohio’s Congressional delegation and the No. 3 Republican on the Appropriations Committee. He has held his seat since 1973. While his decision to retire has been anticipated, it will magnify the headaches confronting Republicans in their uphill quest to retake control of the House.
The Marine Corps said Thursday that it would investigate the killings of several Afghan civilians by members of a Special Operations platoon in Afghanistan in March.

A judge ordered Fulton County to pay some of the defense costs for a man accused in a 2005 shooting rampage at a downtown Atlanta courthouse. The judge, Hilton Fuller of Superior Court, said the county must pay the legal fees of Henderson Hill, the lead lawyer for the defendant, Brian Nichols, at a rate of $175 an hour from July 1 through the end of the case. The order does not apply to Mr. Hill’s expenses nor to the fees of Mr. Nichols’s other lawyers. Mr. Nichols is charged with escaping from custody at the courthouse, where he was on trial for rape on March 11, 2005, and killing the judge presiding over his trial, a court reporter, a sheriff’s deputy and a federal agent he encountered that night. Jury selection is to resume on Monday.
As delinquencies and foreclosures rise within Countrywide’s loan portfolio, the lender is increasingly finding itself at the center of the mortgage storm.
Only grainy video exists from Barack Obama’s 2002 speech against the Iraq war, so Mr. Obama reread the speech for an advertisement.
In many Shiite neighborhoods in Baghdad, the Mahdi Army is increasingly regarded as a threat.

The Roman Catholic Diocese of Sacramento named a successor for Bishop William K. Weigand, even though the bishop, the spiritual leader to about 500,000 Northern California Catholics has not said when he plans to retire. Pope Benedict XVI appointed Bishop Jaime Soto, above, to the second-highest post in the sprawling diocese, one step below Bishop Weigand. His appointment means there are now 25 Hispanic bishops in the United States, according to the Conference of Catholic Bishops. Bishop Soto, 51, has been an auxiliary bishop in the Orange County Diocese since 2000. In Sacramento, he will serve directly under Bishop Weigand, 70, and will share his pastoral and administrative responsibilities. Bishop Soto will take over when Bishop Weigand retires, which he is required to do by age 75.
An orphan is caught in a dispute between an heiress, Elizabeth Ross Johnson, and Lionel Bissoon, a celebrity weight-loss doctor with whom she was having an affair.
Senator John McCain proposed that reimbursement for the treatment of chronic diseases should be drastically altered.
There is a lot of crossover between the two teams in this year’s American League Championship Series matchup.
Fifty foreign fighters were among 200 militants reported killed in three days of fighting in the tribal areas near the Afghan border, according to the Pakistani military.
At least 2,002 people died during their arrests by state and local law enforcement officers from 2003 through 2005, the Justice Department reported Thursday.
There are compelling reasons for all members of Congress to support expansion of the important State Children’s Health Insurance Program.
Looming over all the other questions about the future of the Yankees is the role of its 77-year-old owner and whether he can still make decisions.
A group of 138 Muslim scholars urged Pope Benedict XVI and other Christian leaders to engage in a deep dialogue for peace between the faiths.
Children’s Place, which runs the Disney Store chain, said its former C.E.O. left “at the request of the board” and described improper conduct involving “securities trades.”
A 19-year-old man who shot at foreigners on a street in Antwerp last year was sentenced to life in prison.
The cash shortage followed a decision by Israeli commercial banks to halt all business transactions with Palestinian bank branches in the Hamas-run Gaza Strip.
Aiming to attract younger audiences, ABC is using its evening news staff to produce a separate and distinct 15-minute daily news program for the Web.

Venezuela’s government has blocked the Spanish pop singer Alejandro Sanz from using Poliedro Stadium in Caracas for a scheduled Nov. 1 concert because he criticized President Hugo Chávez three years ago.
An aspiring crime novelist was arrested after the Mexico City police said they found the dismembered body of a woman in his apartment along with evidence that he had cooked her flesh.
wo worshipers at one of India’s most revered Muslim shrines were killed when a bomb went off.
Florida needs to bring its policies into line with those of 39 other states that automatically restore voting rights to inmates who are released from prison.
The statement was agreed to by all 15 members, including Britain and the United States, which submitted a stronger original version, and China, which submitted a weaker one.
Watching Tuesday’s Republican presidential debate, it felt as if the candidates, or at least the front-runners, were living in an alternate universe.
After finding a second man guilty of manslaughter as a hate crime in the case of a slain gay man, jurors criticized the state’s hate crime law, and said it seemed inappropriate to the case.
The Chinese government has announced that it will relocate an additional three million to four million people to accommodate construction of the Three Gorges Dam.
The voluntary withdrawal, already under way, affects only products labeled for use in infants, not for use in children 2 and older.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,809 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:.
Automakers in India, one of the world’s fastest-growing car markets, are racing to respond to Indians’ desire for small and inexpensive cars, some as cheap as $2,500.
David Ortiz does not look like a computer nerd, but the designated hitter for the Red Sox studies videos on the computer after every at-bat.
With its latest redesign, BusinessWeek is looking for some magic to raise circulation and keep advertisers interested.
CHICAGO, Oct. 11 — At least two groups, one based here and one in California, use the words “operation homefront” in their names, and both say they are devoted to helping military families.
A professor said she remained mystified over who could be responsible for leaving a noose on her office door at Columbia University’s Teachers College.
Electronic Arts said Thursday that it would acquire two software studios from Elevation Partners in a deal worth $860 million.
What is puzzling is how a problem that management recognized came to hurt the brokerage firm so badly.
Victor Navarra has long played a crucial organizing role in the New York City Marathon. This year, his biggest challenge is living long enough to attend the race.
Record export sales along with a shrinking trade deficit suggested a rosier outlook for third-quarter growth, but analysts warned a weakening dollar could drag down domestic demand.
Analysts have begun to question whether Sweden’s financial system, and its regulators, are ready for a larger stage.
The Diamondbacks are a largely faceless team, but closer José Valverde, at 6 feet 4 inches and 254 pounds with a scraggly goatee, is perhaps the most recognizable of the bunch.
The overhaul is part of an effort by its new chief executive, Anthony Hayward, to restore BP’s advantage against its competitors after a spate of safety problems.

Doris Lessing, the novelist whose deeply autobiographical writing has swept across continents and reflects her engagement with the social and political issues of her time, won the 2007 Nobel Prize in Literature.
Military prosecutors said  the detainee threw a hand grenade at a jeep carrying two American servicemen and an Afghan translator in Kabul.
The appointment generated a wave of optimism inside Ford, which is grappling with sharply lower sales and a loss last year of $12.6 billion.
Concerns over national border security, the safety of the nation’s bridges and an economic crisis in Michigan have all prompted debate over a privately owned bridge.
Columbia’s football field will be named after Robert Kraft, who played for the university’s team more than 45 years ago.
The beverage and snack foods maker said favorable foreign currency conversions and acquisitions accounted for more than half of its international growth.
The company, which is trying to force its buyers to complete the deal, said some of its losses stemmed from recent legislation cutting government subsidies to student lenders.
Beazer, which also reported that sales of new homes plunged in the third quarter, said it would have to restate several years of financial statements.

Allan Cameron, 29, left the courtroom in silence after he was convicted of first-degree murder for fatally shooting a police officer during a wild car chase through Flatbush at the close of the Thanksgiving weekend in 2005.
LONDON, Oct. 11 (Reuters) — The Swiss banking giant UBS, where market turmoil this summer led to $3.4 billion of credit losses, pushed out two fixed-income executives yesterday.
Scores of Muslim clerics, theologians and academics issued an open letter Thursday to all Christian leaders saying the two religions need to work more closely together.
Bleak sales from big retailers should be a boon to shoppers: To clear unsold fall merchandise, retailers are expected to offer steep markdowns.
A comprehensive global study of abortion suggests that outlawing the procedure does little to deter women seeking it.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 11 — After a short life of chaos and neglect, the teenager who opened fire on Wednesday against classmates and teachers in a downtown high school seemed to stand on a precipice between improving his life and throwing it all away.

A teenager being tried on charges that he beat his companion’s 4-year-old son to death last year testified yesterday that he had never struck the child, contending instead that the boy’s mother was the one who beat him in the days before he died of internal injuries.

Two years after Minnesota officials forbade drug makers to give doctors more than $50 worth of food or other gifts per year, drug company sales representatives there are having a far harder time marketing to doctors.

ALBANY, Oct. 11 — Gov. Eliot Spitzer plunged back into his political feud with the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, on Thursday, as the governor’s aides suggested that Mr. Bruno could owe income taxes on flights he took on state-owned aircraft.

Mr. Ekins went from racing through the mountain trails and desert rambles of Southern California in the late 1940s to renown as the stuntman double for Steve McQueen in a 65-foot flight over a barbed-wire barrier.
A wounded survivor and relatives of three people killed when employees of Blackwater USA opened fire on Iraqis last month in Baghdad sued the firm in an American court on Thursday.
Two of the Giants wins this season came after they faced big halftime deficits. A bad team entered the locker room. A good one emerged. No one can quite explain it.
The New York State pension fund is drawing scrutiny over claims that investment firms paid friends and relatives of former Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi.
Thursday’s practice produced few answers for the Carolina Panthers as they try to figure out who will start at quarterback Sunday against the Arizona Cardinals.
The withdrawal of South Sudan’s former rebel movement from the power-sharing government is the gravest blow yet to the fragile peace accord signed two years ago.

F.B.I. agents went through file cabinets at the Mount Vernon City Hall yesterday, apparently investigating the city’s trash-hauling contracts, a lawyer for the mayor said. After a few hours, the agents, numbering about half a dozen, left with about eight boxes of papers. They did not comment to reporters, and a call to the F.B.I. was not returned. Herb Hadad, a spokesman for Michael Garcia, the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York, said he could not comment. The search warrant made no accusations, said Ravi Batra, a lawyer for Mayor Ernest Davis. He said it specified boxes, drawers and binders holding documents related to the Department of Public Works and two carting companies.

A handyman who was questioned by the authorities after four bodies were found last year in Egg Harbor Township plans to plead guilty today to an unrelated criminal charge, his lawyer said yesterday. The man, Terry Oleson, stayed briefly at the motel next to which the bodies of four women, identified by the police as prostitutes, were found. Mr. Oleson was questioned and gave a DNA sample to the police, but has never been named as a suspect. His lawyer, James Leonard, said Mr. Oleson had been charged in Salem County with secretly videotaping a naked 15-year-old girl in his home in 2005 and planned to plead guilty to reduced charges in the case today in State Superior Court. Mr. Leonard has said that his client had nothing to do with the Atlantic County killings.

A former Mrs. New Jersey has been charged with writing bad checks for antique furniture, the Essex County prosecutor said yesterday. The suspect, Hedy Di Carlo, 36, of Essex Fells, was charged with writing the checks to buy $70,000 worth of furniture from an antiques store in Sloatsburg, N.Y., in June. Ms. Di Carlo, who won the Mrs. New Jersey pageant in 2005, is scheduled to be arraigned on Thursday.

Crews were working yesterday to clean up 2,300 gallons of oil that leaked into the Delaware River from a tanker at a Citgo operation in Paulsboro, the authorities said. The leak was reported shortly before 11 a.m. Wednesday and contained the same day, according to Nyx Cangemi, a spokesman for the Coast Guard. Crews skimmed oil off the river yesterday and set up booms to keep the spill from traveling up the Woodbury and Mantua Creeks as officials worked to determine the cause of the leak. Mike Hanson, a spokesman for Cardiff Marine Inc., which owns the tanker, said the leak started after the tanker was moored at the Citgo Asphalt refinery.

A payroll executive from Westhampton was arraigned yesterday in Suffolk County Court on a 53-count indictment charging that he used money collected for clients’ taxes for his company’s business expenses, prosecutors said. The executive, Herbert Geller, 59, the former president of Quality Payroll in Bohemia, pleaded not guilty, prosecutors said. Thomas J. Spota, the Suffolk County district attorney, said 92 companies were affected by the scheme. He said some of Quality Payroll’s clients were required to pay the taxes with interest because the payments were not made on time. Quality Payroll stopped operating in June 2006, prosecutors said.
Genentech is moving to restrict the use of its drug Avastin by ophthalmologists, a move that could substantially raise the costs of treating a common eye disease.
The I.R.S. income data help explain why so many Americans report feeling economic distress, despite overall economic growth since the Internet bubble burst in 2000.

Lieutenant Herndon, a navigator-bombardier in the storied Doolittle raid over Japan in World War II, spent more than a year interned in the Soviet Union after his plane made an emergency landing in Russia.
It bothers Jets linebacker Jonathan Vilma to be the captain of a defense that seems to have lost its way.
New England Patriots quarterback Tom Brady’s astonishing accuracy is captivating the N.F.L. the way his dating proclivities intrigue the tabloids.
Jerry Buss said he “would certainly listen” to trade offers for superstar Kobe Bryant.
John Schuerholz stepped aside Thursday after 17 years as general manager of the Atlanta Braves with one regret.
Bryan Berard, who has been through a lot since leaving the Islanders nine years ago, got off to the right start by scoring in his first game back.
A sell-off in technology shares led U.S. markets lower, as concerns arose that the prices of computer-related stocks were outpacing their profit outlook.
The Democratic candidates jostled for attention on the education front, laying out proposals devised to appeal to middle-class voters.

Raising parking meter rates in Manhattan, creating more taxi stands and putting in place a series of other measures could achieve the same level of traffic reduction as Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s congestion pricing plan, according to a report by a group opposed to the mayor’s proposal.
A brazen and meticulously planned robbery of a jewelry store in central Paris last weekend was one of the largest jewelry thefts ever.
Georgina Bloomberg, the daughter of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, is, if anything, groomed to be reticent.
Sandra Ávila Beltrán, accused of playing a key role in building a cocaine trafficking operation in Mexico, has captured her nation’s attention.
A $40 million pleasure craft containing fine art and antiques has moored at Chelsea Piers.
TRENTON, Oct. 11 — A Mercer County jury has convicted a member of a local faction of the Latin Kings street gang in the murder of a female gang member and the attempted slaying of her male companion.
All kinds of broad topics have popped up in the debates — but not issues that speak directly to everyday life in big cities and suburbs.
The boy was arrested Wednesday night after the police received a tip that he was plotting a shooting spree at a high school in a northern suburb of Philadelphia.
Political and legal experts suspect that a brutal two-year battle for the power in the A.N.C. is spreading from within the party to the government itself.
How can marathon participants — runners and organizers both — prepare for unique and dangerous weather conditions?
Gaza’s banks have run out of cash, an economic adviser to Ismail Haniya, the Hamas leader in Gaza, said Thursday.
People.
Donald Samuels, who died Wednesday after being struck in Harlem, was a familiar sight in the neighborhood, though little was known about his past.
Atilla Selek, a young German man with Turkish parents, stands at the center of the investigation in to a suspected terror plot uncovered last month, despite his denials.
The CMJ Music Marathon, the annual showcase of indie bands and mainstream hype, is still full of hopefuls and  industry types in search of the next big thing.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
Two gulf nations ban an American film, Paris Opera names music director, jail for “Lost” star and more culture news.

Michelle Rodriguez, a former cast member of the ABC series “Lost,” was ordered to report to county jail in Los Angeles on Christmas Eve to begin a six-month sentence for not completing community service and alcohol monitoring as part of her probation from a previous drunken-driving incident, The Associated Press reported. Superior Court Judge Daviann L. Mitchell barred her from being granted early release or electronic monitoring. ... The Wesley Snipes tax-evasion trial was postponed yesterday until next year after the actor dismissed his legal team, The Associated Press reported. In Ocala, Fla., United States District Judge William Terrell Hodges called the action a “ploy” but nonetheless ruled that the motion was in the public interest. Prosecutors objected.

The Swiss conductor Philippe Jordan, who turns 33 on Thursday, will become the music director of the Paris National Opera in 2009, Agence France-Presse reported. The appointment of Mr. Jordan, currently a guest conductor at the Berlin Staatsoper, was announced Wednesday. He will become the first permanent conductor of the 174-member orchestra of France’s leading opera company since James Conlon, an American who left in 2004 after nine years. Since then the ensemble has been led by guest conductors.

French archaeologists believe they have found the world’s oldest wall painting, right, an 11,000-year-old red, black and white design dominated by rectangles, adorning a Neolithic settlement in northern Syria, Reuters reported. “It looks like a modernist painting,” said Eric Coqueugniot, leader of the team excavating Djade al-Mughara on the Euphrates River. “Some of those who saw it have likened it to work by Klee. Through carbon dating we established it is from around 9000 B.C.” The six-square-foot painting formed part of an adobe circular wall of a large house with a wooden roof. According to Science magazine, the world’s oldest painting on a constructed wall, found in Turkey, was dated 1,500 years later.

The Persian Gulf nations Kuwait and Bahrain have banned the American film “The Kingdom,” right, starring Jamie Foxx, Jennifer Garner and Chris Cooper in the story of a team of F.B.I. agents dispatched to investigate the 1996 bombing in Saudi Arabia that killed 19 Americans, Agence France-Presse reported. “The screening of the film has been banned in Kuwait for many reasons, chiefly because it is a false depiction of facts,” said a source in the cinema committee of Kuwait’s information ministry. The director of publications at Bahrain’s information ministry, Jamal Daoud, said the film had been banned there “on orders from high up in the ministry.” But theaters in the United Arab Emirates began showing the film this week, and it will be shown in 26 theaters in Qatar, said Abdurrahman Mohsen, director of the Qatari Cinema Company. There are no public movie houses in Saudi Arabia. Peter Berg, director of “The Kingdom,” said last month that while politics and religion figure in the film, its primary purpose is to entertain.

Solid performances from the new shows “Private Practice” and “Pushing Daisies” helped ABC to another first-place finish in the ratings’ key demographic on Wednesday. Although “Private Practice” drew a modest 12.2 million viewers at 9 p.m., the “Grey’s Anatomy” spinoff was the night’s top-rated show among adults 18 to 49, Nielsen estimated. It easily outpaced its time-slot competitors, NBC’s “Bionic Woman” (10.1 million) and CBS’s “Criminal Minds,” which tied for second in that demographic. “Criminal Minds” attracted the night’s largest audience over all (14.5 million), helping CBS surpass ABC in total viewers for the night. CBS struggled at 8, however, as “Kid Nation” (7 million) ranked last in the hour in the 18-to-49 set. “Pushing Daisies” (10.1 million) led the time slot in that demographic, although its ratings fell 16 percent from its premiere a week ago.

“It’s looking good.” Fresh from a journey to North Korea, Zarin Mehta, president of the New York Philharmonic, used those words to assess the chances of a performance there by the orchestra next year, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Mehta, accompanied by an unidentified State Department official and Eric Latzky, the orchestra’s public relations director, went to North Korea last week to meet with officials of the culture ministry and explore sites and other arrangements for a concert in Pyongyang, the capital. “We are making inquiries and exploring, and then we will make a decision in the next few weeks,” Mr. Mehta said. He added that he did not know when such a concert might be held. Word of an invitation to the orchestra came in August.

J. K. Rowling and Warner Brothers are suing a community group in India for erecting a huge replica, right, of the Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry for the biggest Hindu festival in East India, Reuters reported. The film company and Ms. Rowling, creator of the adventures of Harry Potter, a Hogwarts student, are seeking two million rupees (about $50,000) for breach of copyright. “We had no clue that we had to seek permission from the author,” said Santanu Biswas, secretary of the community group that designed and paid for artists to make the pandal, a temporary structure to the goddess Durga. “We do not have any commercial motive behind this.” The four-day festival begins on Wednesday in Kolkata. Lawyers representing Ms. Rowling confirmed that a petition had been filed in Delhi High Court but declined to comment further.

Tony Martin, 95, will appear at Feinstein’s at the Regency on Oct. 21 and 22, reminiscing about Hollywood stars like Fred Astaire, Ginger Rogers and his wife, Cyd Charisse, and performing songs like “Begin the Beguine” and “A Foggy Day.”.
The quiet revelation of the National Theater of Greece’s new production of “Electra” is in the graceful attention the director, Peter Stein, brings to bear on the role of the Greek chorus.
If ever a troupe deserved a do-over for its New York debut, this is it: disastrous sound quality robbed the company of the immediacy and texture of its flamenco on Wednesday.
Ms. Walker’s exquisite, implacable, loose-cannon retrospective at the Whitney Museum of American Art is about race first and last.
The accomplished musicians chose an adventurous program, with recent works by Bright Sheng and David Bruce, and contrasting 20th-century masterpieces by Bartok and Poulenc.
P J Harvey’s concert offered a chance to see how the quietly unsettling new songs fit with some of the thunderously unsettling old ones.
This show is 75 intermissionless minutes of high-spirited all-out Halloween-season fun for audiences age 7 and up and up.
It is still possible to follow some likely freedom routes in Brooklyn, once a hub of the Underground Railroad.
Lorin Maazel undertook peculiar experiments in balance in his interpretation of Tchaikovsky Fifth Symphony at Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday.
The perfect combination of author and actor comes along in “Rats,” one of five quick plays in this bill of very new works.
The indie-pop band unpacked their songs in no-nonsense fashion at the Nokia Theater on Tuesday.
“The Beebo Brinker Chronicles,” based on Ann Bannon’s lesbian novels, aggressively goes after laughs.  But it doesn’t settle for caricature.
The most interesting aspect of “Monk at 90”  was the panoply of approaches toward Thelonious Monk’s music, which abides its own logic and inhabits its own climate.
The art of Bon, the centuries-old indigenous religion of Tibet, is presented in a beautiful exhibition at the Rubin Museum of Art.

This latest revival of “The Ritz” is cute, cuddly and often oddly inert.

AROUND TOWN.
The latest player to express support for Yankees manager Joe Torre did so from enemy territory.
The Gardzienice Theater’s vivid if frustrating “Iphigenia at Aulis” comes at you in a rush.
The show at the Walters Art Museum rewards the kind of close study few exhibitions of famous French paintings afford.
The Altria Group has listed its Park Avenue building, which is also a branch of the Whitney, for sale. Where does that leave the museum?
The work of Carleton E. Watkins, a pioneering photographer who lived from 1829 to 1916, helped persuade President Lincoln that Yosemite needed protection.
Aesthetics versus storytelling: as much as anything, that is the issue that defines the 45th New York Film Festival.
The starvation of a welfare recipient whose benefits were cut has turned attention to a system touted as a model.
A Kurdish lawmaker in Iraq condemned Turkey’s moves toward a military incursion across the border.
With Canada’s next federal election campaign possibly coming as soon as this month, Canada’s Liberals have won a strong majority in the country’s most populous province.
Prime Minister John Howard proposed a referendum to change the country’s Constitution to recognize the role of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders in Australia’s history.
Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said that the force reductions were being made with the full consent of the United States.
Turkey recalled its ambassador and threatened to withdraw its support for the Iraq war in response.
MOVIES.
Two professors of management offer evidence that stock options as they are now structured act as an incentive for corporate bosses to take poor risks, with no serious consequence to themselves.
Indians pitcher C. C. Sabathia, who did not have one of the best games of his life in his first game this postseason, returns to the mound on Friday.
Hillary Clinton accused him of being a plant, but Randall Rolph typifies the conscientious Iowa caucus-goer.
If most of the rest of the world argues that the Ottoman government tried to exterminate its Armenian population, why does Turkey disagree?
Even by the extravagant standards of Bollywood movies, “Bhool Bhulaiya,” a lavish comic epic about psychiatry, mythology and spiritualism, has a lot of plot.

In the course of her very long and peripatetic career, Doris Lessing has done just about everything, from naturalism to psychological realism, from postmodern experimentation to moralistic fable-making, from science fiction to horror stories.

The CMJ Music Marathon offers a thousand bands, playing at more than 50 locations over five days. Trying to choose among the shows is difficult even for the most devoted fans. The pop music critics of The New York Times highlight 10 acts that will perform at this year’s festival.

To the Editor: Re “Locals vs. ‘Aways’,” (Oct. 5): As a full-time resident of East Hampton (going on six years now), I would never presume to call myself a local. Generations of my family lived elsewhere in and around New York City, and my family moved here from somewhere else. Therefore, I just consider myself a “year-rounder,” nothing more nor nothing less. Yet, I must admit that I very much enjoy the peace and quiet that returns to the area after the summer people are gone — just as the locals do. Steven Morris.

J MANDLE PERFORMANCE After Julia Mandle's current project, ''Come and Have a Chicky Meal, Cuz You're Gonna Love This Deal,'' was previewed last year at Montclair State University in New Jersey, one of the performers confessed to its creator that she never thought ''wearing a chicken head would be a life-changing experience.'' Ms. Mandle laughed while recounting the story recently in her Brooklyn studio, but it's clear that she wants to change people with her arresting performance-art pieces -- or at least make them pause and think about the world and how they move through it. She describes ''Chicky Meal'' as a live sculpture, a ''portrait of America going through an identity crisis.'' Part installation and part performance, it explores how Americans' perceptions of themselves line up with the nation's image abroad. Three women, costumed in Ms. Mandle's striking, structured gowns (embroidered with anti-American slogans), interact languidly with a white, star-shaped structure, spreading charcoal stains along the pocked, damaged walls. A fourth woman, the one wearing the giant chicken head, moves more rapidly and plays the role of seductress. (Her dress reads, ''I said I was Canadian while traveling abroad.'') Perhaps she is a metaphor for the lure of American popular culture.

WALLACE--Shane M. , husband of Dana nee McAleer and father of son James, died Tuesday at his home in Greenwich, CT. He was 38. Mr. Wallace succumbed after a valiant fight with brain cancer for more than a year. At the time of his death, Mr. Wallace was the Head of J.P. Morgan Chase's Telecommunications Mer gers & Acquisitions Group. In an era when many investment bankers move from one firm to another, Mr. Wallace spent his entire career at J.P. Morgan. Mr. Wallace was a graduate of Bronxville High School and Dartmouth College. At Dartmouth Mr. Wallace was a member of Psi Upsilon fraternity and writer for The Dartmouth Review newspaper. A lifelong Republican, Mr. Wallace also worked during his undergraduate years as an intern for then Vice President Dan Quayle. Mr. Wallace was an accomplished wing shot, fly fisherman and skier whose passion for the outdoors gave countless hours of joy to him and those who had the privilege of spending time with him in the field, stream and slope. Mr. Wallace is survived by his wife, Dana; son, James; his mother, Sheila Riley of New York City; his father, Ronald and stepmother, Sue of Yellville, Arkansas; and his sister, Amanda and her partner Tamara of New York City. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested that donations be made in his memory to Accelerate Brain Cancer Cure. Donation information is available by either calling 202-419-3140 or accessing the website at www.abc2.org. Funeral services will be held at 2pm on Monday, October 15, at Christ Church Greenwich, 254 East Putnam Avenue, Greenwich, CT.

NEW YORK CLOWN THEATER FESTIVAL Coulrophobics, beware: Clowns are swarming over Williamsburg this month for the second annual New York Clown Theater Festival at the Brick Theater in Brooklyn. The zaniness began last Friday, when more than a hundred clowns and their fans rode the L train from Union Square in Manhattan to Bedford Street in Williamsburg and marched to the Brick for a huge pie fight. This year's festival is bigger than the last, offering several one-night-only cabaret performances, a series of lectures and classes and more than 20 productions by individuals and troupes from around the country, as well as from Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Spain and Britain. On Thursday the Clown Olympics, a new event this year, will pit clowns against one another in events like kiddie pool swimming, slapstick and eccentric dance.

Rose Hall, in the Time Warner Center, Broadway and 60th Street; the Walter Reade Theater, 165 West 65th Street, Lincoln Center; and Avery Fisher Hall, Broadway at 65th Street, Lincoln Center; (212) 721-6500; filmlinc.com. With the exception of ''Persepolis,'' which will close the festival on Sunday night at Avery Fisher, screenings for the films mentioned in today's article will be at Rose Hall: ''Before the Devil Knows You're Dead'' (tonight at 6 and tomorrow at 12:45 p.m.); ''A Girl Cut in Two'' (tonight at 9 and tomorrow night at 6:30); ''Useless'' (tomorrow at 3:45 p.m.); ''Mr. Warmth: The Don Rickles Project'' (tomorrow night at 9:30); ''Calle Santa Fe'' (Sunday at 1 p.m.) and ''Persepolis'' (Sunday night at 8:30).

SHERRIE LEVINE As the Richard Prince exhibition plays at the Guggenheim, spare a thought for Sherrie Levine, another 1980s appropriation artist, who has a survey show at Nyehaus Gallery in Gramercy Park. On view are several examples of her reworking of sculptures, drawings, paintings and photographs as part of a wider questioning of the authenticity of art and its status as a commodity. What we all know now is that she was just making more commodities, cleverly repackaged as critique. But it is still fun and instructive to return to a moment when artists were -- back then, boldly -- taking the works of other artists and reproducing them, sometimes almost exactly, and claiming them as their own. It is extraordinary now to think that there weren't a flood of lawsuits surrounding this process. For example, a 1981 photograph here of a photograph by Walker Evans looks exactly like, well, a photograph by Walker Evans. The same goes for a photograph after Alexander Rodchenko, and replicas of sculpture by Brancusi and Duchamp.

GOLDEN--William T . The Board of Trustees, scientists, and staff of the Marine Biological Laboratory (MBL) in Woods Hole, MA, mourn the passing of our valued colleague and friend William T. Golden, who served the laboratory for nearly 40 years as a corporation member, trustee, and honorary trustee. Throughout his career, Bill invested heavily in the advancement of science, influencing the development of U.S. science policy and the public's understanding of it. A true philanthropist, Bill generously supported the MBL's research and educational programs, and his commitment and enthusiasm for the MBL's Science Journalism Program was contagious. If anyone knew the importance of communicating science, it was Bill. For five decades, he used his skill as a communicator to advise our nation's presidents, to bring science to the government, and to garner public support of the sciences. We are grateful for having had the privilege of working with Bill. He was a wise counselor and visionary who helped to shape our institution for decades and he will be deeply missed. On behalf of the entire MBL community, we extend our heartfelt sympathies to his wife, Catherine, and the entire Golden family. John W. Rowe, M.D., Chairman, Board of Trustees, Gary G. Borisy, Ph.D., Director and CEO

The director of the Central Intelligence Agency, Gen. Michael V. Hayden, has ordered an unusual internal inquiry into the work of the agency's inspector general, whose aggressive investigations of the C.I.A.'s detention and interrogation programs and other matters have created resentment among agency operatives. A small team working for General Hayden is looking into the conduct of the agency's watchdog office, which is led by Inspector General John L. Helgerson. Current and former government officials said the review had caused anxiety and anger in Mr. Helgerson's office and aroused concern on Capitol Hill that it posed a conflict of interest.

FILARMONICA DELLA SCALA Opera houses and their orchestras often have a complicated relationship. In Leipzig and Vienna, the leading orchestras (the Gewandhaus and the Vienna Philharmonic) do double duty in the opera house. In Berlin and at the Metropolitan Opera in New York, the orchestra breaks out of the opera house for an occasional concert or even tour (the Berlin Staatskapelle under Daniel Barenboim, the Met orchestra under James Levine). But in Milan, the Filarmonica della Scala postdates its eponymous opera house, the Teatro alla Scala, by a century or so. The orchestra was not founded until 1982, when Claudio Abbado conducted its first concert, presented as a way to offer the theater's musicians a deeper immersion in the symphonic repertory as a self-governing body.

MORGAN--Graham James , 1917-2007. Graham J. Morgan, 90, the retired Chairman and CEO of the United States Gypsum Company, now the USG Corporation, passed away October 7, 2007. He is survived by his beloved wife, Michele; loving daughter Heather Bilandic Black (Rick); stepdaughter Shelly Marten (Eric); and grandson, Michael Morgan Bilandic. The son of Caradoc Morgan, a Congretional minister, and his wife, Nina Hermania, the daughter of Norwegian settlers, he grew up in small Midwest towns where he learned to appreciate the out-ofdoors and became an expert fisherman, hunter and Eagle Scout. He received B.A. degrees from Carleton College. Morgan's entire business career was spent working for USG, rising to the office of President by age 42. In 1980, he was named one of the three outstanding Chief Executive Officers in the Building Products Industry by Financial World magazine. He was the first recipient of the Dept. of Housing and Urban Development Urban Pioneer Award and in 1981 was inducted into the housing hall of fame. Among the corporate boards he served on were: Baxter International, American Hospital Supply, Illinois Bell, IC Industries and International Harvester. His community involvements included serving on the board of trustees of: Northwestern University, Northwestern Memorial Hospital, the Museum of Science and Industry and the National Park Foundation. A former resident of Chicago, he passed away at his home in Palm Beach Gardens, Florida. Funeral services are private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent in his memory to Mayo Clinic, c/o Dept. of Development, Rochester, MN 55905.

Colt Brennan rallied No. 16 Hawaii from 14 points down in the final four minutes by scoring the tying touchdown on a 2-yard run with 31 seconds left in regulation, then threw an 8-yard scoring pass to Jason Rivers on the first possession of overtime to give the Warriors a 42-35 victory over visiting San Jose State last night. The victory for Hawaii (7-0, 4-0 Western Athletic Conference) was not sealed until Myron Newberry intercepted Adam Tafralis’s pass in the end zone on the first drive of overtime for the Spartans (3-4, 2-1). Brennan completed 44 of his WAC-record 74 passes for 545 yards and 4 touchdowns.

A man accused of killing his estranged wife and two stepchildren fatally shot himself as he drove into a lake after a nearly seven-hour standoff, the police said. When the car was pulled out of Lake Arlington, officers saw that the man, Arthur Jackson, was dead and had a head wound, said Lt. Blake Miller of the Arlington police. Mr. Jackson dropped off his 3-year-old daughter at a church earlier, Lieutenant Miller said, and someone at the church called the police after hearing the man say he had committed a crime at his house. Officers went to the house and found the bodies of the woman; her daughter, 13; and her son, 10.

A soldier from Queens killed in Iraq was mourned in a prayerful ceremony that blended the Buddhist traditions of his Thai ancestors with the symbols of American military service.

Leo Mazzone was fired as the pitching coach of the Baltimore Orioles, less than two weeks after completing his second season with a struggling staff. Mazzone worked wonders with the Atlanta Braves from 1990 through 2005, but could not duplicate that success with the Orioles. Baltimore ranked 29th among 30 teams with a 5.17 earned run average and yielded more walks (696) than any major league club.

Pittsburgh Steelers running back Najeh Davenport was charged with domestic violence, child endangering and unlawful restraint in a custody-related confrontation with the mother of his 5-year-old son. Chief Michael McGrath said Thursday night that Davenport would be given a chance to surrender for a court appearance on the misdemeanors.

At least two families seeking a place to sleep were denied beds at a homeless shelter as the city started enforcing a tougher new policy on emergency sheltering, according to advocates for the homeless and the families themselves.

Garrett Willis shot a 10-under 62 on the TPC Summerlin course for a share of the second-round lead in the Frys.com Open in Las Vegas. D. J. Trahan and the rookie George McNeill matched Willis at 13-under 130. McNeill shot a seven-under 64 on the par-71 TPC The Canyons course and Trahan had a 64 on the same course in an event missing all of the world’s top-20 players.

Dallas Cowboys quarterback Tony Romo’s father has prostate cancer. Ramiro Romo, 50, found out he had cancer days after he and his wife were at Soldier Field in Chicago on Sept. 23, when Tony threw for 329 yards with 2 touchdowns in a 34-10 victory.

The defending champion Lorena Ochoa shot a five-under 67 to take a one-shot lead after the second round of the Samsung World Championship in Palm Desert, Calif. Ochoa’s bogey-free round moved her to nine-under 135 through 36 holes, one shot in front of Paula Creamer, Angela Park and Angela Stanford. Stanford moved into contention with the lowest round of the day, a 66. Creamer and Park, who were tied for the lead after the first day, each shot a 69. Michelle Wie shot her second consecutive 79.

The United States Open champion Ángel Cabrera beat the defending champion Paul Casey, 4 and 3, in the second round of the World Match Play Championship in Virginia Water, England. The six-time champion Ernie Els beat Andres Romero, 6 and 5, and Henrik Stenson and Hunter Mahan also advanced. Stenson, the Accenture Match Play Championship winner in February, beat Anders Hansen, 7 and 6, and Mahan topped Soren Hansen, 6 and 4. Cabrera will play Mahan, and Els will face Stenson in today’s semifinals.

Bernhard Langer shot a 10-under-par 62 to take a four-stroke lead after the first round of the Administaff Small Business Classic in Spring, Tex. Langer, playing his fourth Champions Tour event since turning 50 on Aug. 27, needed only 24 putts to match the best round of the season on the tour. He broke the Augusta Pines Golf Course record of 63 set by Jay Haas last year. Tom Kite pulled three strokes back of Langer with a birdie on the 17th hole, but a bogey on 18 dropped him into a tie for second at 66 with five others.

Justin McBride, as the No. 1 rider in the Built Ford Tough Series, will be eligible tonight to attempt the richest ride in Professional Bull Riders history. McBride, who has already set a record for the season with $467,000 in earnings, could add $150,000 more with a successful ride on the bull Scene of the Crash. Just by attempting to ride Scene of the Crash, McBride will receive $25,000, and if he covers the bull for the required eight seconds, he will add another $125,000, making it the richest ride in P.B.R. history.McBride has never faced the 1,650-pound bull. In 2006 and 2007 regular-season competition, Scene of the Crash has a 100-percent buck-off percentage in 27 attempts. He has only been ridden twice in his career in 51 regular-season tries.

Austin Scott, a suspended Penn State running back, was charged with raping a woman at his campus apartment after meeting her at a bar. Scott was arraigned yesterday on charges of rape, sexual assault and two counts of aggravated indecent assault, all felonies, in connection with the Oct. 5 encounter.
Rangers center Scott Gomez scored his first goal since joining the team in the off-season as a free agent and ended the Rangers’ futility on the power play.

Because of an editing error, an Associated Press report in the Sports Briefing column on Thursday about the exhumation for DNA testing of the body of George Gipp — the Notre Dame player who inspired the rallying cry “Win one for the Gipper” — misidentified his hometown. It is the village of Laurium, on Michigan’s Upper Peninsula — not Traverse City.

A front-page article on Thursday about a House committee’s approval of a resolution defining mass killings in Armenia as genocide misidentified the committee. It is the Foreign Affairs Committee, not the Foreign Relations Committee.

An article on Thursday about a lawsuit by three former professors charging financial, political and personal irregularities by Richard Roberts, president of Oral Roberts University, included an erroneous spelling from legal documents for the surname of an aide of the Oral Roberts Ministries whose computer document was cited in the legal action. She is Stephanie Cantees, not Cantese.

The Books of The Times review on Wednesday, about “My Grandfather’s Son,” a memoir by Justice Clarence Thomas, referred imprecisely to his actions regarding his first marriage. While he did eventually end it, he did not also abandon his son.
Corrections: For the Record

A picture caption in some editions yesterday with an article about the stellar performance of quarterback Tom Brady, who was shown removing his helmet, misstated the number of touchdown passes he has thrown this season for the New England Patriots. As the article noted, it is 16 — not 15.

An article in Business Day on Thursday about delays in initial deliveries of the Boeing Company’s 787 Dreamliner jet misstated the name of the company headed by Scott Carson, who commented on what the delay might cost Boeing in penalties. It is Boeing Commercial Airplanes, not Boeing Commercial Aviation.

A picture caption yesterday about David Ortiz, with an article about his use of technology to improve his hitting for the Boston Red Sox, misstated his on-base percentage this season. As the article noted, it was .445 — not .455.

Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a federal study of deaths related to arrests misstated the percentage of arrests in which a person died. There was a death in about one in 20,000 of the arrests studied — or about five thousandths of a percent, not fewer than one ten-thousandth of 1 percent.

A dance entry in the Listings pages of Weekend yesterday, about a program on Monday in which Carolyn Brown will discuss her career with the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, misidentified the location and gave an incorrect telephone number and Web site for more information. The program is at the Bessie Schonberg Dance Theater at Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers, not at Dance Theater Workshop in Chelsea. The telephone number is (914) 395-2412 and the Web site is slc.edu/events.

An article yesterday about a young German man with Turkish parents who is being investigated in a suspected terrorist plot in Germany described incorrectly the roots of the Islamic Jihad Union, which operates a training camp in Pakistan for militants that German and American intelligence agents say the man attended. It is a splinter group of an Uzbek terrorist organization, not of a Tajik group.
Allan Houston reappeared on the Knicks practice court Friday morning like a man out of time in just about every respect.

A judge declared a mistrial in the case of a former Texas Southern University president after a jury said it could not decide whether she had misspent university money to lavishly decorate her homes. The jury deliberated for four days in the trial of the former president, Priscilla Slade, left, before telling Judge Brock Thomas of State District Court in a note that “to continue deliberating would be of no benefit.” The jurors had said in three previous notes that they were deadlocked. Ms. Slade was president of Texas Southern, the state’s largest historically black university, for more than six years. She could have been sentenced to life in prison if convicted.

The Russian Soyuz craft bearing the first woman to command the International Space Station, Peggy A. Whitson, left, docked with the station. The capsule ferried Dr. Whitson; Col. Yuri I. Malenchenko, a Russian flight engineer; and Sheikh Muszaphar Shukor, Malaysia’s first astronaut. This is Ms. Whitson’s second six-month stay on the station; she served as a science officer aboard the orbiting laboratory in 2002. The change of command will occur Oct. 19, and she will greet the crew of the shuttle Discovery, which is expected to launch Oct. 23. The Discovery will also be commanded by a woman, Col. Pamela A. Melroy, retired from the Air Force, and will carry a new module to the station.

A lawyer for one of O. J. Simpson’s co-defendants in an armed robbery case said his client would plead guilty Monday to a reduced charge and testify against Mr. Simpson and four others. The co-defendant, Charles Cashmore, left, is accused of being one of five men who joined Mr. Simpson in a confrontation in a Las Vegas hotel room with two sports memorabilia dealers. Mr. Cashmore will testify that two of the other men who entered the room were armed, said his lawyer, Edward Miley.

A seven-hour standoff with a man accused of killing his estranged wife and two stepchildren, and then dropping off his 3-year-old daughter at a church, ended when he led Fort Worth police on a brief chase before driving into a lake. There was no immediate word on the man’s condition. Someone at the church, in Arlington, called the police after hearing the man say he had committed a crime at his house, said Lt. Dan Draper of the Fort Worth police. Officers then went to the house and found the bodies of the woman; her daughter, 13; and her son, 10, who had all been shot to death, Lieutenant Draper said.

A judge approved a plea deal allowing a couple to avoid jail time for tying up their pregnant daughter and taking her out of state in hopes of persuading her to have an abortion. The daughter, Katelyn Kampf, 20, spoke out against the plea agreement in a tense hearing at which she and her parents avoided eye contact. The parents, Nicholas and Lola Kampf, pleaded guilty to misdemeanor assault and disorderly conduct charges. The district attorney dropped felony kidnapping charges, and the assault case may be dropped if the parents undergo counseling.
Philadelphia forward Jesse Boulerice was suspended 25 games for cross-checking Vancouver’s Ryan Kesler across the face, the second Flyer in three weeks to receive a ban of at least 20 games.
With contract negotiations between producers and stagehands at a standstill, the union representing almost all of the stagehands on Broadway scheduled a strike vote for Oct. 21.

Vladimir Kuznetsov, a former Russian diplomat who once led the United Nations budget oversight committee was sentenced to 51 months in prison by a Federal District Court judge in New York for money laundering.
Serbia offered a reward of 1 million euros, or $1.4 million, for information leading to the arrest of Ratko Mladic, the Bosnian Serb general who directed the Srebrenica massacre in 1995.

A 1959 Mercedes-Benz that belonged to Padre Pio, the 20th-century monk said to have had stigmata and supernatural powers and who was elevated to sainthood in 2002, will be auctioned in Padua on Oct. 27.
Two nurses were responsible for “serious mistakes” in which two baby girls were swapped at birth 10 months ago and ended up in the wrong families, and they will be fired, a hospital in Trebic said.
Mayor Marcelo Ebrard sent more than 1,000 police officers in riot gear into the historic center to keep street vendors from setting up stands and blocking sidewalks.
The government said it would ban the sale of hallucinogenic mushrooms, tightening the country’s famed liberal drug policies after the suicide of an intoxicated teenage girl.
The Vatican has published secret documents about the trial of the Knights Templar, including a parchment, showing that Pope Clement V initially absolved the medieval order of heresy.
Audiences of mostly black women crowded theaters throughout New York City to see “Tyler Perry’s Why Did I Get Married?” on the day of its nationwide release.
Senators worry that an unusual inquiry into the work of the Central Intelligence Agency’s inspector general could undermine his role as independent watchdog.
Fresh accounts of a shooting in Baghdad last month cast further doubt on guards’ statements that they were responding to insurgents.
Galvanizing the Homeland Security Department with effective leadership should be high on the national agenda for the presidential candidates.
The sole trustee system of New York’s pension fund is good for the politicians who control it, but it is terrible for the workers whose pensions are at stake.
Despite growing scrutiny of the quality and safety of Chinese goods, China’s exports are up 27 percent so far this year.
George Mitchell’s final report on his investigation into the use of illegal performance-enhancing drugs in baseball may include the names of players linked to banned substances.
Executive pay practices may have helped drive strong corporate performance, but what about the moral element?
Bernard B. Kerik, the disgraced former police commissioner in New York City, is trying to avoid being indicted for tax fraud and a range of other crimes, including bribery.
While Google’s stock climbs ever higher, threats to its dominance of the industry are mounting as well.
New-media campaigns are finding that many caucusgoers in Iowa are happily encased in an old-media bubble.
Al Gore may be remarkably well-equipped to lead the nation, but it’s George W. who is president.
Leo Mazzone was fired as pitching coach of the Baltimore Orioles yesterday, less than two weeks after completing his second season.
Pfizer’s most recent compensation report, the basis for an attempt to revamp the format of such reports, is now under S.E.C. review for inadequate disclosure.
Barack Obama accused Hillary Rodham Clinton of being disingenuous about her record on Iran and Iraq, while she said he was muddying her views.
Texas Tech’s Michael Crabtree is having the best freshman season of any receiver in college football history. And yet he almost chose the hardwood over the gridiron.
The recently unveiled design for a bridge to replace the span of highway that collapsed in August has been met with a lukewarm response.
The Virgin Group said Friday that it planned to bid with a consortium for Northern Rock, the troubled British bank.
Five developers submitted separate billion-dollar offers for the right to transform the West Side railyards into a small city of residential and commercial skyscrapers.
A jury on Friday acquitted seven guards and a nurse who had been charged with aggravated manslaughter in the death of a 14-year-old boy at a boot camp in the Florida Panhandle.
Lt. Gen. Ricardo S. Sanchez is the most senior war commander of a string of retired officers who have harshly criticized the conduct of the Iraq war.
The Justice Department appears to have taken a renewed interest in the case against Universal Express, a delivery company that has been the target of a civil suit by the S.E.C. since 2004.
Vladimir Putin could do good for Russia if he told the Iranians that they must halt nuclear enrichment and accept diplomatic payoffs if they do.
In her inaugural speech, Drew Gilpin Faust offered a spirited defense of American higher education against demands that it quantify what it is teaching.
President Hu Jintao was denied a decisive consolidation of power in the new Communist Party leadership.
Mr. Chinmoy used strenuous exercise and art to spread his message of world harmony and inner peace.
While many other basketball-first institutions have dropped football, Georgetown is moving ahead with its biggest ambitions for the game since World War II.
The state is making thousands of fifth- and sixth-graders retake a part of its standardized writing test because a newspaper article revealed the topics of two questions.
Melvyn I. Weiss, known for filing class-action investor lawsuits and representing Holocaust victims, made appeared in a Los Angeles courtroom Friday for bail proceedings.
Mark Hurd, Hewlett-Packard’s chairman and C.E.O., says that focusing on strategy and staff were key to helping the company recover from last year’s spying scandal.
Al Gore and the United Nations panel of scientists have shown how much citizens with courage can do to raise awareness about the danger of global warming.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, underwent surgery on Friday morning to remove a blockage in his left carotid artery, aides said.
Republicans in New York and New Jersey are feeling intense pressure to vote to override President Bush’s veto of a bill expanding a popular health insurance program for children.
The Colorado Rockies have won 18 out of their last 19 games going into Game 2 of the National League Championship Series.
The I.R.S. is examining the use of arcane but powerful investment entities known as real estate mortgage investment conduits to see if participants are reaping illegal tax benefits.
Rudolph W. Giuliani seems to be having second thoughts about interrupting a speech to the National Rifle Association to take a call from his wife, Judith.
BEA Systems, an Oracle rival in the market for corporate software known as middleware, is being pressured to sell by its largest shareholder, the investor Carl C. Icahn.
An energy shortage in Brazil, Argentina and Chile is generating tensions between neighbors and emerging as one of the biggest brakes to growth and integration.
The official purpose of the president’s trip to Florida was to talk to business leaders about free trade, but he also quickly raised $1 million from the Republican faithful.
During Ramadan, Hamza Abdullah of the Denver Broncos ate a hearty meal before dawn and then did not touch food or drink again until sunset — no matter how difficult practice turned out to be.
Michael Lombardi, the N.Y.C. Transit senior vice president who played a key role in wrenching the subway system out of its 1970s abyss, will retire next month.
Paul Tudor Jones II, one of Wall Street’s most fabled financial speculators, predicted the 1987 market crash but today is keeping quiet about the market.
Alan G. Hevesi claims that he did not know that his political adviser was receiving fees from firms that were doing business with the state pension fund while he supervised it.
California authorities searched six locations as part of an investigation into the sudden death of Anna Nicole Smith last February.
Consumers and producers alike spent more than expected last month, the government said Friday in two reports, offering investors a mixed economic outlook.
John A. Catsimatidis, the supermarket mogul, has switched his party affiliation from Democrat to Republican in anticipation of a New York mayoral bid in 2009.
Finding out what’s in cosmetics, the troubles facing municipal Wi-Fi systems, and more.
Sixty years after the first families moved into Levittown, N.Y., a historian looking to preserve one of the original homes is having trouble finding one that hasn’t been altered.
One of the nation’s oldest and largest biotechnology companies said it has had expressions of interest, and its shares skyrocketed.
Yale is 4-0 entering Saturday’s home game against Lehigh, and junior Mike McLeod has been almost unstoppable, amassing 719 yards and 13 touchdowns.
Prosecutors say that the police officer who abandoned a homeless Guatemalan man in a remote spot in Mount Kisco also delivered the blow that ultimately proved fatal.
Margaret Carson was widely regarded as the leading lady of classical music publicists in New York, who shepherded a generation of singers through the Metropolitan Opera.
The Yankees have said they will not negotiate with slugger Alex Rodriguez if he opts out of his contract and becomes a free agent.
An Indian court yesterday threw out a copyright infringement suit by J. K. Rowling, author of the Harry Potter books.
New York’s Department of Labor has found that the parent company of the American Idols Live Tour ’07 violated child labor laws.
A professor of genetics at the University of Pittsburgh who was facing a federal charge of illegally sending bacteria to an artist in Buffalo pleaded guilty.

Cate Blanchett, the Oscar-winning actress who next year will become artistic director of the Sydney Theater Company in Australia, will have the support of the designer Giorgio Armani in that new role.
Theater couture, a guilty plea in bacterial art case, Bond cast in concrete and more culture news.
For the third consecutive Thursday, CBS’s “CSI” outdrew ABC’s “Grey’s Anatomy.”
The British actor Roger Moore, who played James Bond, now has a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame in front of an address that includes the numbers 007.
Amy Winehouse, the British singer whose recent cancellations sparked concern over her health,will perform at the 2007 mtvU Woodie Awards in New York next month.
New York Philharmonic officials were returning yesterday from an exploratory trip to North Korea with glowing reports of concert possibilities in the capital.
The mother of a 14-year-old boy accused of planning an armed attack on a suburban Philadelphia high school was arrested Friday on charges that she had given him three firearms.
A man who had been imprisoned for the rapes of at least five women moved to Southbury, Conn., on Friday, amid a sea of television cameras and a crowd of disgruntled neighbors.
Driving, off-kilter, powerful rhythms, heavy on the percussion, were the common thread in a rather odd concert by the Juilliard Orchestra, led by Anne Manson, on Thursday night.
In a performance on Thursday night by Jeanette Stoner and Dancers at the choreographer’s loft in TriBeCa, there was no text, little drama and not much dance of substance.
A former relay teammate of Marion Jones acknowledged she might have to pay for Jones’s mistakes, perhaps even by giving back her gold medal.
From the nuanced, organic and cohesive interpretation of this chamber ensemble,  it was clear that these are musicians with a history together.
A decades-old system for paying residuals ignites a new fight.
With two world championships decided, the Venice Cup and the Senior Bowl, and one to go, the Bermuda Bowl, the United States has won two gold medals and one bronze here.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,813 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:.
The New York Public Library’s “Graphic Modernism From the Baltic to the Balkans, 1910-1935” gives a nationalist spin to a continentwide phenomenon.
A divided federal appeals court has ruled that a human rights lawsuit filed against corporations that did business in South Africa under apartheid should be revived.
Alfred Russell was a New York School painter who abandoned abstraction for a classicizing, Surrealistic figurative style.
Gen. Soe Win was nicknamed “the butcher of Dipeyin” for his role in overseeing a bloody attack on Daw Aung San Suu Kyi and her followers in 2003.
In retrospect the piece, presented by Yummy Dance on Thursday night at the Danspace Project, was filled with intriguing promise.
Mr. Robbins made his mark not only by expanding Cox fourfold but also by giving customer service high priority in an industry where it had not always been valued.
Six people have been arrested since June and accused of submitting fake degrees in applications for jobs with the New York Fire Department, the authorities said.
“Kazuo Ohno 101: 3-Week Butoh Parade,” a birthday party for one of the founders of the Japanese dance form Butoh is something for even jaded New York audiences to cheer.
After a summer of bad news, home builders are now cheap enough for some investment advisers to recommend buying.
Touch screens bought after 2000 have now been deemed failures and must be replaced with optical-scan machines.
G.E.’s revenues jumped 12 percent from last year in the third quarter on robust orders for aircraft engines, power generators and other pieces of heavy equipment.

Proximity is the cost, and virtue, of a civil and democratic society. We run the risk that some lunatic or self-promoter will violate the public trust of an open space because we value that space as a democratic ideal.
With the timber industry in decline, some new investors are snapping up open spaces to be private playgrounds.

Frieze, Britain’s largest contemporary art fair, opened on Wednesday for the usual coterie of serious buyers and collectors.
The least-pressured way for a singer to make a debut at the Metropolitan Opera is to start small with a minor role, get the jitters out, then take on bigger assignments.

Kiri Te Kanawa’s principal asset as a musical artist is lovability, and those who came to hear this New Zealand soprano sing at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night made no secret of their ardor.
A nuclear agreement with the United States has stirred opposition from Communists in the Congress Party-led coalition government.
The German government won a crucial vote in Parliament Friday to keep its troops in Afghanistan for another year.
The Nobel Peace Prize committee made a powerful statement today that the consequences of increasing carbon emissions could be as dangerous as the ravages of war.
Modernity has swept over and changed some of rituals of Id al-Fitr, but it hasn’t altered the holiday’s core.
