A ceremony was held yesterday in Arlington National Cemetery for 12 soldiers killed on Jan. 20 when their helicopter was shot down in Iraq. Army Honor Guard members held 12 flags at the ceremony in which some unidentifiable remains of the soldiers were buried.

ROSENZWEIG--Roy, The staff and board members of The American Social History Project (CUNY) mourn the passing of our cherished collaborator, advisor, and friend. A distinguished historian, visionary educator, lifelong radical, and supportive comrade, Roy counseled us in times of need and was our indispensable partner, board member, and co-author for more than a quarter-century. From our ''Who Built America?'' books, documentaries, and CDROMs through our many Web collaborations, Roy was our intellectual anchor and our inspirational and kind taskmaster. He has left his indelible mark on the field of history, democratic education, digital scholarship -and in our hearts. We send our deepest sympathy to Roy's wife Deborah, his family, and to his many colleagues in the History Department and Center for History and New Media at George Mason University.

GOLDTHORPE--Dwight, age 87, of Palm Beach, FL passed away September 24, 2007. Dwight graduated from Mercersburg Academy, Amherst College and the Harvard Business School. He served in the United States Navy from 1942 to 1946 and finished his service as a Lieutenant. Dwight was a member of the Bath & Tennis Club and the Everglades Club and was a champion tennis player at both clubs. He is survived by many friends. He has been laid to rest in Hempstead, New York. For more information, please contact Stuart Haft at 561-659-1770. Services entrusted to: Dorsey E. Earl Smith Memory Gardens Funeral Home, 3041 Kirk Road, Lake Worth, FL 33461.

TARASENKO--Victor, sud denly on October 11, 2007. Cherished son of Antonina and the late Anatoli, devoted husband of Elaine (nee Rahner), loving brother of Christopher, beloved brother of Anatoli, Tamara, Leon and his twin Valentin. Greatest uncle ever to Tatjana Dolan. Reposing at Village Chapels 6767 Eliott Ave., Middle Village, NY Friday 2-4pm and 79pm and Saturday 2-4pm. Final disposition will be private.
As the holy month of Ramadan ended for some, amusements were set up in celebration at a temporary park in the Iraqi capital.

ORLIAN--Alvin E., Herb's cherished friend for 54 wonderful years, and a very special friend to me. A kind, compassionate man who enjoyed life and its many rewards. A man of great integrity. I will miss him dearly. To Bobbi, his loving and caring wife, I extend my deepest sympathy and support. I wish for you to be comforted by the many happy memories we share. May they bring you and your family peace at this very difficult time. Best friends together again. Love, Linda Gallen ORLIAN--Alvin E., of Shaddock Lane in Boca Raton, Florida died peacefully on October 12, 2007 in his home at 11:00am. He is survived by his wife, Barbara Orlian and his four daughters: Joan Hillman, Amy Orlian, Robin Chaplin and Stephanie Lessing and his five grandchildren: Jared Hillman, Chelsea Milkman, Kim Lessing, Zackary Milkman and Jesse Lessing. Alvin battled lung cancer for the past year and fought stoically until the end. He remained optimistic and retained his sense of humor until his final days. His wife and family will remember him as a deeply devoted, loving and courageous man who valued his family and friends above all else. His intelligence, honesty, strength and depth of character will forever remain in our hearts. Alvin graduated in 1943 from the West Point Military Academy. He served in World War II as a major in the United States Army and was one of the founders of the Jewish Chapel at West Point and served on the board of the Rockleigh Jewish Home. Donations would be warmly received by any of the charities dear to his heart including: The West Point Jewish Chapel. The Jewish Home at Rockleigh, the Anti-Defamation League, the United Jewish Federation and the American Cancer Society. The funeral will be held at the Beth Israel Memorial Chapel at Jog Road and Woolbright on Sunday, October 14 at 1:00pm. ORLIAN--Alvin E. For more than 25 years of working with Alvin Orlian, I came to know him as a friend and as a man who cared genuinely for others. I know his wife and children feel his loss deeply, as do I. Howard M. Krams ORLIAN--Alvin E., a good and gracious man, a valued friend and client. Our condolences to his wife, Barbara and to all of his family. He will be missed. The partners & staff of H.J. Behrman & Co., LLP

WOLF--William, Lt. Col. USAF Ret., died on October 9, 2007 at age 85. He is survived by his loving family, his wife Phyllis, to whom he was married for 62 years, son Lari, daughter Louise, son-in-law Bob, and grandchildren Kyle, Taylor, and Corinne. Bill flew combat in WWII and served in the Korean War. He was the President of Major Chevrolet. The world will never be the same without this wonderful man.

ROBBINS--James O. 65, of Hobe Sound, Florida and Westport, Massachusetts died October 10th, 2007 at his home in Westport. Robbins served as President and Chief Executive Officer of Cox Communications from 1985 through 2005. In 2006, he was elected to the board of Cox Enterprises Inc. In addition, he served on the board of Bessemer Securities, LLC, Humana, Inc. and STI Classic Funds, Inc. He was President of the Board of Trustees of the St. Paul's School in Concord, New Hampshire and previously he served as Chairman of the Board of The Westminster Schools in Atlanta and as Chairman of the Board of the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation International. He was recognized with multiple awards including the Vanguard Award for distinguished leadership in 1996, and he was inducted into the Cable Hall of Fame in 2006. A man of tremendous honor and passion, perhaps what Jim should be most remembered for is his constant commitment to people and his integrity in all of life. A graduate of St. Paul's School, Class of 1960, and the University of Pennsylvania, Class of 1965, he also held an MBA from Harvard University. He served in the Navy and completed two tours in Vietnam. An avid golfer, he was a member of the US Seniors and loved playing with his family and friends. A devoted husband and father, what he loved most in his life was time and travel with his family. He is survived by his wife of 37 years, Deborah Hale Clark and three daughters, Jane Brooks Robbins, Payson Robbins Murray and her husband Grant Thompson Murray, Hilary Robbins Thomas and her husband Randell Croft Thomas, Jr, a brother Elwood Brooks Robbins, a sister Barbara Robbins Anderson, two stepbrothers Thomas Curtis Schwartzburg and John Anderton Schwartzburg, and several nieces and nephews. There will be memorial services held at 3pm on October 20th at Trinity Church, Copley Square, Boston, MA. and at 11am on October 27th at All Saints Episcopal Church, 634 W. Peachtree Road, Atlanta, GA. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation, 400 Perimeter Center Terrace, Suite 750, Atlanta, GA 30346 (404-420-5990) or The Melanoma Research Foundation, 170 Township Line Road, Building B, Hillsborough, NJ 08844. Interment private. Services in the care of Waring-Sullivan Home of Memorial Tribute, Fall River, MA. www.waring-sullivan.com

''Whether you rush for the exits or laugh until your lungs ache will depend both on your appreciation for sight gags, eyebrow gymnastics, sustained slapstick and vulgar malapropisms, and on whether you can stomach the shock of smashed frat boys, apparently sober rodeo attendees and one exceedingly creepy gun store clerk, all taking the toxic bait offered to them by their grinning interlocutor,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. 6:30 P.M. (Discovery Kids) THE FUTURE IS WILD What will the world be like in a few hundred million years? This new animated series imagines it: birds that shoot acid when they feel threatened, fish that emit enough electricity to jump-start a car and enormous whales that rely on vomiting as their main defense mechanism. And three 21st-century children -- Ethan, Emily and Luis -- are there to witness the changes. Wormholes and a time machine (what else?) make the travel possible. According to the people at Discovery Kids, this show is based on actual science.

RICHENTHAL--Arthur. October 11, 2007. Beloved husband of the late Vivian. Adoring father of Donald, David and Susan. Cherished grandfather of Daniel, Matthew, Kate, and Julliette. Loving companion of Joan Easton. Service Sunday October 14, 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Vivian Richenthal Pulmonary Institute at Mount Sinai Hospital . RICHENTHAL--Arthur. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of The Mount Sinai Medical Center mourn the passing of Arthur Richenthal, an outstanding philanthropist and dedicated member of The Mount Sinai Boards of Trustees. Mr. Richenthal's commitment to patient care at Mount Sinai was extraordinary, and included the creation of the Vivian Richenthal Institute for Pulmonary and Critical Care Medicine and support for many other health and scientific programs. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his sons, Donald and David, his daughter, Susan, his companion, Joan Easton, and the entire family. Peter W. May, Chairman of the Boards of Trustees, Kenneth L. Davis, M.D., President and CEO, The Mount Sinai Medical Center RICHENTHAL--Arthur. The Gaisman Division of Pulmonary, Critical Care and Sleep Medicine of the Mount Sinai Medical Center and the Vivian Richenthal Research Institute deeply mourn the death of our extraordinary friend and advisor, Arthur Richenthal. His strong support and wisdom has enabled us to make major contributions in the battle against disabling Lung Disease. Victims of lung cancer, fibrosing lung diseases and the World Trade Center catastrophe have benefited from his commitment to research and patient care. He was a valuable, proud New York City treasure who had a rare blend of intelligence, incisiveness, wisdom, warmth, and humility. Our deepest sympathy to his children and grandchildren. Our staff, patients and all New York join them in grieving the loss of this pillar of our families. Michael C. Iannuzzi, M.D. Alvin S. Teirstein, M.D.

GIVEN--The Reverend Davis. On October 10, 2007, The Reverend Davis Given died peacefully at the age of 87 with his family at his side. The son of the late Dorothy and William Barns Given, Jr., he is survived by his sister Dorothy Given Kee of Dallas, Texas, his niece Dorothy Davis Kee of Herndon, Virginia, nephew William Given Kee of Charleston, South Carolina, and nephew John and his wife Louise Kee of Dallas, Texas, great-nieces Hilary Davis Kee, Elizabeth Given Kee, Sarah Wright Kee, and great-nephew John Rutherford Kee. A graduate of St. Paul's School in Concord, New Hampshire and Yale University 1942. He served in WWII with the Eighth Air Force in England. He graduated from General Theological Seminary in New York City. Father Given was head of the Navajo Good Shepherd Mission at Fort Defiance, Arizona, assistant priest at Trinity Church in New York City and Chaplian at Morningside House and Amsterdam House. In retirement, he was a priest at St. Luke in the Fields. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, October 16 at 4pm at St. Luke in the Fields Episcopal Church, 487 Hudson St., New York, NY 10014. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Music or Outreach Programs at St. Luke's.

According to the New York Post of Oct. 7, Maloney, unhappy with the performance of his dry cleaner, began plastering his neighborhood with flyers proclaiming that the offending establishment "sucks and is overpriced." Now he is being sued for defamation, and he has responded to the suit by declaring that what he did is "clearly protected speech."

After a day of work or touring in Rome (which can feel like work!) you need a bit of rest and relaxation. So how great to report that a Turkish Bath -- or hammam -- has opened its doors in Rome's historic center. Now before you protest that a Turkish bath in Rome doesn't feel place-appropriate, guess again: Turkish hammams are the descendents of the traditional Imperial Roman baths -- more Roman than anything that exists in modern day Italy.

Novel? Epic poem? Historical chronicle? "War and Peace" is all of that and, as they say, more. This is the third time I've read it. The first was incollege for one of those loony world-lit survey courses: two weeks for "Don Quixote," another two for "Bleak House," etc. I missed so much of the novel; I remember skimming the war parts to get to the peace parts. The second time was right after 9/11, and the book just seemed like reportage: the generalized anxiety, the fragility, the terrifying ease with which the world can change. This time, (maybe it's my post-Reading-Like-a-Writer phase) I've been trying to figure out how Tolstoy does what he does, and what I can't get over is the almost reckless wildness of his ambition, the sheer nervy bravado of his technical competence. Anyone who's ever tried to write fiction knows how hard it is to introduce characters, one or two at a time. Even Dickens makes sure you get a character fixed in your mind before he moves on to the next one. But Tolstoy essentially starts the book, or at least the second chapter, by plunking you down in a room crowded with major and minor characters, all talking at once, then the action moves to another room filled with completely different characters, then another household, then the home of a dying man, a house in the country, then a battle. Deal with it. And the amazing thing is that the reader can keep it all sorted out  the identities, the familial relations, the histories and hopes and fears of a huge cast. Reading it feels a little like looking at a Velásquez and trying to figure out how he puts a few dots of white paint at the end of his brush, and bingo! a string of pearls just wills itself into being.
